productDescription: Discover the difference that freshly ground beans make to your coffee, with the Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill! The elegant brushed stainless steel Cuisinart burr mill boasts 18 levels to grind your coffee beans, from ultra-fine to extra-coarse. With an automatic stop, your beans are guaranteed to be consistently ground to the right grade, maximizing the oils, aromas, and flavors for a better cup of coffee. Grind enough coffee to make 4-18 cups, and store any remaining grounds in the chamber.
- Burr grinding provides uniform grind and optimum flavor
- Elegant stainless steel styling with convenient cord storage
- 18-position grind selector - from ultra-fine to extra-coarse
- 4 to 18-cup slide dial and removable 8 oz. bean hopper
- Removable grind chamber holds enough ground coffee for 32 cups
- Separate one-touch power bar, heavy-duty motor and scoop/cleaning Brush
- Electric timer automatically shuts off unit when grind cycle is complete

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't Last, Costly and Difficult to Replace or Repair Under Warranty
reviews.reviewText: The motor stopped working after 8 months of light use. It has an 18 month warranty, but the customer is responsible for all shipping and handling. It has been difficult to reach the company with the number they provided to request warranty repair or replacement. I will update this review and let you know if my experience improves. The product worked well until it died.

They say if it isn't broke, don't fix it. Well, in this case, it was broke, but it lasted eight years! So, we had to replace it and why not go with the same unit when we had such great success using it to grind our daily coffee?! This is a very nice burr mill that we have gained much use from over the years and now we replace it with a brand new unit that is exactly like the other one and hoping we get another 8-10 years out of it.

Why do we like it?
* It has a nice look with the majority being shiny stainless steel housing.
* The hopper on the top holds a half pound of beans.
* You have a choice of 6 settings for every type of grind you choose.
* It does great on coarse grind for our French Press coffee, very uniform.
* You hit the button and it stops when it is done grinding.
* Once you figure out what grind you like, how much you want and what setting you prefer it is a simple process and then you just have to decide what kind of bean you want in there. It does the rest.
* It is fairly easy to clean up, doesn't take up too much space and best of all it works great and does it all quite fast.

If either of us had anything negative to say about it, we'd have to say it is loud, but then if you aren't hand grinding, what isn't loud when it comes to grinding coffee via electricity?

We're happy with the product or we wouldn't have purchased a second one of the same exact type eight years after the first one. Plus, it must be others feel the same because eight years later the company is still making the same model! Hope if you get one you like it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works, but produces a fine powder in every grind setting.
reviews.reviewText:
I wanted to get a burr grinder to make cold brew coffee. I needed coarse grounds. This grinder produces the coarse grounds well, but it also seems to pulverize some coffee into a fine powder no matter what the coarseness is set to. This isn't great because now my cold brew ends up with a lot of sediment in it, and I've actually been filtering the final product through a paper filter as well just to get all the extra fine grounds out of the brew.
I think the possible reason for the pulverization is the high speed the grinder spins at. I might take it apart to see if there is something I can do to slow it down.
I had to edit down to 2 stars. Just started another brew and paid close attention to the grinds. It blew me away by how much fine powder was in the bin. Going to order a hand powered grinder to have something to compare this to. As-is I don't find this acceptable.

Edit 8/12/17: Added a photo of the grind on the most coarse setting. You can see the nice grinding on the right, and the fine powder that is always present. Grinder would probably be fine for drip coffee, or another paper filter method.

reviews.reviewTitle: Also recommend the "Coffee Grinder Cleaning Brush
reviews.reviewText: I have turned into a coffee snob over the past decade or so, and had NO IDEA that a burr grinder would make such a humungo diff in the flavor of my Morning Addiction. OMG. How did I ever live without this??! Also recommend the "Coffee Grinder Cleaning Brush, Heavy Wood Handle & Natural Bristles Wood Dusting Espresso brush Accessories for Bean Grain Coffee Tool Barista Home Kitchen" to help get every bit of the grounds out of the plastic chamber. Cross-reference the brush review, it's awesome too and it helps with the static tendencies of the coffee. You can only do so much by tapping the chamber and it WILL piss you off to have so much coffee stuck in there, so go ahead and order the brush now.......you'll understand when you grind the coffee. You're welcome.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent mill grinder for the money. May require regular tear-down cleaning if you want it to last more than about a year.
reviews.reviewText:
Products like this are tough to review because it's all about getting what you pay for. You can't give a Ford Escort one star because it doesn't ride like a Cadillac. :)

In this case, we have one of the lowest price mill grinders you can get. My prior coffee grinding has been with blade grinders. I had been shaking them gently while grinding just to get better uniformity. I've been through 3 blade grinders in 3 years due to broken blades, or warn out lid switches, etc.

This time I decided to try a mill grinder and found this one. I wasn't ready to spend $150+ to grind my coffee (as much as I love my coffee a certain way). After using this product a few times, here are my observations:

NEATNESS. It is true that it is messier than using the blade grinders I used before. It is a bit dusty. However, I have been able to minimize this issue after grinding using the following steps: (a) leaning the grinder forward and tapping the back, (b) gently pulling out the filled grind bin, (c) covering the opening with my hand (leaving the lid on), tilting the bin at an angle, and tapping again on the counter to make a nice pile for pouring, then (d) removing the lid and pouring directly into the coffee grind basket of the coffee pot, lightly tapping the bin. Even doing this, it's a little dusty, but not horrible.

GRIND UNIFORMITY. Grind uniformity isn't amazing, but it's way better than a blade grinder.

CONTROLS. The number-of-cups switch, which is really just a way of setting the automatic grinding time, is way off. At least the way I like my coffee (which is about a tablespoon of whole beans per 6oz coffee pot cup). For me, I have to take the number of tablespoons of beans I'm using, multiply by 3, and that's the approximate timer setting. So for 6 "cups" that's max setting on the timer of 18. For more cups, I have to run it twice. I think there's much room for inexpensive improvement for the product in this area. The timer should be much more generous. Also, to turn it off manually, you have to slide the switch to the off position. It would be more convenient if pressing the START button was really a START/STOP, but not a huge deal...

MAINTENANCE. I could imagine that if I ground a variety of flavored coffees in this machine, it would be a bit of a hassle to clean it between each change-over. It does leave some grind and chunks behind. But for me, I'm pretty much consistent in the type of coffee I use, so no biggy for me. I do clean it out anyone once in awhile. The nice thing about the unit is that the removable pieces are dishwasher safe.

MORE MAINTENANCE: There are several negative reviews that have said that their Cuisinart DBM-8 just stopped working after some time. Mine did exactly that after approximately 2-1/2 years of use. I decided to take the unit apart and found that, over the course of 2-1/2 years of grinding coffee a couple of times per day, there were a lot grounds into the cavity of the grinder workings compartment (see[...]). This comes from "blow back" of grounds when grinding beans back through the exit shute of the grinder. A little bit blows back on each grind, and how much probably depends upon how finely you grind your coffee. (We grind ours at about 30% of way around the indicator, from the finest position). In the 2-1/2 years, the unit accumulated at least 8-12 dry ounces of coffee grounds. It resulted in the slider switch being insulated and never allowing the unit to turn on. After cleaning out all the grounds and using a Q-tip to gently wipe the slider switch with 91% isopropyl, the unit works fine again.

My recommendation is, if you are mechanically inclined, take the unit apart every 6 months or so and clean out all the coffee grounds. That would include both the bottom cavity and the top cavity (they are accessed separately). The bottom cavity is accessible by pulling off the replaceable rubber feet and removing 4 screws. To get to the top cavity, you need to remove 4 screws that you can see recessed deep in the bottom cavity (you'll need a long stem, small or medium Phillips head screwdriver). There's another screw near the top where the grounds container goes. So that's 5 screws to get to the top cavity. You'll need to take out 4 more screws to remove the slider and push-button circuit card so you can clean it up before re-attaching it.

A possible design improvement for the unit would be a better seal or some kind of gasket around the small, square connection between the grinder and the grounds bin.

Bought the first one in November 2017 to replace the one we had for 10 years that finally kicked the bucket. That one lasted until March. Got a replacement on 3/22/18- it died on 5/10/18. Contacted the seller - who told me that I had to mail this unit back at my expense so that they could verify why it died - this cost me $20.52. They even asked me what kind of beans I had putting in the grinder. Apparently, Starbucks beans are too greasy for it and cause it to clog. Does it say that anyway in the instructions? Not that I could find. I am VERY unhappy about having to pay to return a faulty product the second time. The first time- I had to cut the cord and pay $10. I now have $30.52 into a replacement grinder. When this is resolved, IF they resolve it - I will NEVER buy another Cuisinart Grinder again. They are seriously lacking in their customer service!

reviews.reviewTitle: I dearly wish I had saved the box so I could return this beast.
reviews.reviewText:
I wanted to love this coffee grinder. I have used it for three weeks, but I'm finally giving up. I liked that it had a reservoir for beans, but that turned out to be the only positive feature. My issues were:

-The noise. It is hard to describe how loud the sound is. The only thing I can compare it to is when I enter the workshop while my husband is cutting wood on the saw and I can't even shout to him; I just have to wait until he's done. It's that level of volume, and it has some of the saw sound's high-pitched quality that is the LAST thing you are prepared to hear in the morning before you have had coffee.

-The time. It takes a weirdly long time to grind the beans. Maybe that's just a burr grinder for you, but coupled with the unacceptably loud sound, it's a horribly long wait.

-The mess. Somehow this grinder creates a wild amount of static. I have no idea why, but it means that the grinds don't pour cleanly into your pot for brewing. They flutter, they fan, they stick to the outside of the grinder and to the outside of the pot. And they stick INSIDE the grinder so you have to get in there with the brush end of your bean scooper and try to free all the stuff that's stuck to the side.

-The grind. I have mine set all the way to espresso-size fine, and I still see large hunks of beans. Perhaps a fine grind is just my personal preference, but I don't see how big chunks of unground beans are going to make a cup of coffee for anybody.

A large proportion of product reviews, whether positive or negative, are subjective declarations of personal tastes that are either met or not. Likes and preferences are debatable. What is not debatable is the fact that the grinder that I purchased failed to operate 10 weeks after I first started using it. Dead, nothing, zero.

I had been grinding a measured amount of beans sufficient for one mug-full of coffee daily. I consistently cleaned the grind chamber after each use and thoroughly cleaned the bean hopper, burr grinding plates and the grind release area once weekly.

This product, The Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill, has long been criticized for:
-Noisy during operation: Short of taking a reading with a decibel meter, I found it to be unacceptably loud. But that is my opinion.
-The grind size is inconsistent on all settings: Not that much of a problem for me but again, subjective on my part.
-The grinding times are not dependable: Even when set for the longest grinding time, the burr mill would routinely stop before completely grinding the 35g of beans that I had pre-measured. Since I never relied on this feature to begin with, that this function routinely failed to operate correctly was an annoyance but not an important feature for me.

The mediocre performance of this machine gave me little user satisfaction but I was at least able to make a decent cup of coffee with the fresh grounds that it so ineptly produced. Despite this machine's considerable number of flaws, I would not have reviewed this product had it at least continued to work. I would have lived with the sub-entry-level-grinder deficiencies that plague this machine which at this price point are not unreasonable to expect.

That the Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill utterly failed after such a short period of light usage and regular care and that so many others reported having had a similar experience, are the facts that I cannot overlook. These are facts that I believe to be worthy of your consideration before making this purchase my friends.

reviews.reviewTitle: disappointed with Cusinart - is it on the decline?
reviews.reviewText:
Update: the replacement grinder I got from Cuisinart died today. I checked and cleaned the grinding chamber. I made sure the grinder wheel inside the chamber moves freely and it still doesn't run at all. Out it goes in the trash can and no more Cuisinart coffee grinder. I'm glad I got a spare non Cuisinart coffee grinder ready for use. Cusinart = Crapinart

Purchased it last December and it just died. No motor activity... checked blades to find them move freely.. no jams. I had old one that worked for years and was disappointed to find new one not lasting long. I have another one in another home that also died. So disappointed. I noticed same complaints from others concerning same issue. I will call Cuisinart tomorrow.

Update: I called Cuisinart... the rep was nice and said it is under warranty. They will ship a new one to me. I was told I have to pay $10 to ship the old back! I protested and said I will use other shipper which is cheaper than UPS. The fee is waived but I have to bring it to a shipper to ship it back. Buyer beware!!! You have to pay to ship broken or defective product under warranty back to Cuisinart! I have other Cuisinart appliances.... I think I will not buy another Cuisinart appliances again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fantastic for the price point, perfect espresso grind, even for only one shot at a time.
reviews.reviewText:
Well this is a treat! I got this and a cheap blade grinder to compare both them and how they stack up against my burr hand grinder for espresso grind. I don't care of the other grinds, so this comparison is only on how it works for them. In a nut shell, the grounds for this were EXACTLY the same as the hard earned grounds from the hand crank burr grinder. Perfect for an espresso. In case you were wondering, the cheap blade grinder, no espresso setting came out exactly as course as the brew pre-ground grounds you buy from the store.

I included some pictures with measurements of this machine, and a comparison of the results. On the upper left are the cheap blade grinder grounds, lower left pre-ground bag grounds, and on the upper right this machine and lower right the hand crank burr.

Also, I only did two scoops (scoop included) which is enough for one shot of espresso. I just put it on the espresso setting at the lowest 4 cups. No problems with the very small amount. The catch cup has a lid, so be careful when you take it off to pour the grounds out (use a corner, not a flat side) straight into the deal to pack for espresso. There is static, so some grounds do stick in the bucket, but actually less than in the cheap blade grinder. This is easy to rinse out.

I don't know of course how long this will last, like any modern appliance it is mostly plastic. But it looks like it's fairly well made and treated well shouldn't have a problem. Until this breaks (and I'll update if it does soon) I would HIGHLY recommend this as a great grinder for the price point. If this review helped you, please click below and let others know!

I've been using this for a few months now and the #1 problem is that while leaving the settings alone and never touching them it will grind different amount of coffee each day. Sometimes it's 4 TBSP of coffee and other time it fills the entire container. If I want to use it at all I have to keep the coffee bean container empty and just put the amount of beans I want to grind in it each time.

This is a piece of junk and I cannot recommend it.

It taints all things Cuisinart for me. Conair has made the band cheap so I'll be avoiding it in the future and buying other brands.

After two months my Cuisinart grinder may on the road to coffee perdition. This morning with no beans in the grinder the unit got a mind of its own and started grinding nothing but air. The grinder was set for six cups on a medium-coarse setting. Fortunately. someone was home to hear the beast roar! Now I leave the Cuisinart unplugged until I'm ready to use it. To its credit the grinder does an excellent job of grinding beans but I'm leery of leaving it connected to power since it may start up at any time.i
*************
I returned my Cuisinart grinder for warranty repairs to Cuisinart. They don’t even acknowledge that they received the grinder like it just disappeared in thin air. It cost $30 to UPS it to New Jersey. That’s customer service...NOT!! I’ve replaced the Cuisinart with a Segura burr grinder. So far it’s quieter and faster than my previous purchase.

I originally rated this a 3 after a few day’s of use but after a month of 2-3 grinds a day, my #1 con below has become a major annoyance. I don’t touch the slider to change the length of the grind and it never grinds the same amount of coffee twice in a row.

I bought this to replace a Baratza grinder that I've had for many years. It served me very well but finally had an electrical issue and for the cost to repair it, I was able to get this grinder. My model of Baratza doesn't seem to be made anymore, but it looks exactly like the Encore that you can buy on Amazon for $139. I certainly didn't pay that kind of money for it way back when. I really liked the Baratza except for two things. It was very messy (grounds got everywhere in the vicinity of where it lived) and the knob fell off with almost every use. So how about this one?

Pros
Clean. Yay! the design of the grind chamber with a lid on it and a small opening to where the grounds come out of the grinder means the grounds stay in the chamber. Thank you designers – that’s a massive improvement.

Cons
It’s been impossible to set the time (number of cups) for the grind with the little slider consistently. I make a big pot of coffee first thing in the morning and then single cups in a smaller pot a couple of times later in the day. I could never get the same amount ground for the two pot sizes as I set it back and forth. I never had this problem with the Baratza. I’ve finally just decided to leave it at one spot and run two cycles for the first pot and then a single cycle for the singles. My big pot is bigger than two times the single serving pot, so I either have to go light on the big pot or heavy on the singles. I do the latter (cuz I really like it strong first thing in the morning) but that means I’m using more coffee than I really need for the later singles. I suppose I could grind more than I need and just measure out the right amount for each pot, but hey – fresh ground coffee, isn’t that the point?

I like my coffee strong. I use a French press and a lot of coffee per pot. So a coarse setting and a setting of about 8 cups for my big pot. That fills the chamber almost half full. The slider goes up to 18 cups. If you set it to that, you’d overfill the chamber and I’m not sure how the grinder would deal with that. On the Baratza, the maximum turn of the knob only filled the chamber about two-thirds. The importance of this is if you need to grind up a bunch of coffee for a vacation trip (I don't take my grinder with me). It seems like Cuisinart could have designed that slider to be a lot more robust and easy to set over a range of grind times that aligned better with the chamber.

The grind chamber is not the best shape for pouring. So even though it’s now clean around my grinder for the first time in forever, I tend to spill some of the grounds when I pour them into the pot. The shape of the Baratza grind chamber was better in that regard.

My last con is a weird design thing. The hopper for the beans is round at the bottom but angling outward to square at the top (the Baratza hopper is round bottom to top). You rotate the whole hopper to set the coarseness of the grind. With the grind I use, that means that the grinder looks off-kilter. If you’re OCD about symmetry, this would drive you crazy. You’d probably have to rotate it to align symmetrically after each grind and then move it back to your coarseness setting for each grind. I’m not OCD about symmetry, but it does look kinda weird sitting on the counter – like there’s something amiss.

On balance this grinder seems to be okay. Hopefully it will give me the many years of multiple-times-a-day service that the Baratza did.

July 2019 update: gave up the ghost (electrically) today, so it lasted less than 2 years.

After only 2 months of usage , this machine broke :(
We are not heavy user, only used it no more than 3 times a day ...

*update* we have contacted Cuisinart for warranty, and they require user to pay for shipping both ways in order for them to ship us a replacement. Shipping cost to the return center comes out to be around $12, and there is no option to purchase a prepaid label from Cuisinart at a lower rate. Furthermore, we were also instructed to include a $10 check/money order to cover for the return shipping. Altogether we will be spending an additional $22 just to receive a replacement for a defective product that we only worked for 2 months. Terrible Customer experience, I will not recommend this product to anyone. It looks like we will just have to take it as a loss on our side, I hope my experience can serve as a warning for Customers that are considering your purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very poor - Inconsistent grind and clumsy design
reviews.reviewText: The product only worked twice, then churned out broken bits of black plastic, then stopped working entirely. The grind was inconsistent the only two times it worked at all, a common problem with Cuisinart grinders. I think the Burr aspect that allows you to select the kind of grind is gimmick-y and clumsy. It's possible the unit we received was just defective, but the product seems cheap and I do not feel I can recommend it. We ended up getting the Epica Coffee Grinder instead and it's great: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01I20TMGC/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_43

reviews.reviewTitle: Well worth the extra money compared to a bladed chopper. Multiple settings so you can adjust it to the grind you like best.
reviews.reviewText:
This is an excellent burr grinder. I tried it on a few grind-size settings and it produced a mostly uniform grind in all cases. Yes, there were a few bigger pieces that got through somehow (see the picture) on the finest setting and some small stuff that got out (probably just got jammed between the wheels and another coffee bean) for the larger, french-press setting, but all-in-all, 95% or better of what came out was exactly the size set on the wheel. You're not going to get that from a bladed chopper...and if you're grinding beans for anything other than a drip coffee maker, having that consistency really matters in the cup.

Yes...it's loud...but it's not that much louder than a bladed chopper, and to get a good, uniform grind, it's well worth it.

I like that there are so many grind-size settings. Some machines can be very finicky about the grind size...just a bit too small or a bit too large and you get something less than it could be giving you. With this burr grinder, you can literally dial in the exact grind size that makes the perfect cup of coffee...the one that tastes best to you.

Sure, you can spend $15 less and get a bladed chopper, and I used one for years...until I got a burr grinder for a Christmas present one year. That one finally wore out (I work from home, so I use the grinder A LOT!) and there was no way I was going to get anything but a burr grinder again.
Go ahead and spend the money...get this grinder. You'll thank yourself within days once you have that perfect setting dialed in and are getting the best-tasting coffee you've ever made.

reviews.reviewTitle: I will tell you a story to illustrate how good this thing is...
reviews.reviewText: This is an awesome grinder. I will tell you a story to illustrate how good this thing is. Back in 2010 I drove down to Mexico, to Nayarit, close to to the ocean. There I opened a small coffee shop to supplement my savings while I lived there, and for the adventure of doing so. Now I had an older, single group, commercial espresso machine that I bought (very) used, and a (very) small budget. As such I did not want to buy a commercial grinder. I bought this very same model from a brick and mortar store for $50 and took it, fingers crossed. It worked flawlessly, making beautiful ground espresso, and in much greater volume than you will at home. I had seating for 20, and didn't close until after midnight on weekends (packed until closing with young people drinking coffee and having a good time). I did this for 5 months. I did well enough to have money to buy tacos after expenses. When I left to return to the U.S. I sold off my equipment. I have a smaller, non commercial, espresso machine these days, and I make a lot less coffee at home. When I seen this on Amazon, I did not hesitate to buy it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excels at: grinding to a halt, unsightly bookend.
reviews.reviewText:
Did you ever stop to wonder what manufacturers did with their discontinued products of yesteryear?
For example, what did people do with warehouses of "He-Man Master of the Universe" toys from decades ago?

I think I have found the answer. I think that they are melted into new parts, bound with rubber bands, and placed inside the Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill. Go ahead, left your DBM-8 to your ear, turn it a little bit, don't you hear those plastic bits falling around inside of it?

I bought one of these, but, because they are such poorly made devices, I am now on my third (technically, though I never actually laid hands on the second).

The first one broke after a few grinds. It ground, then ground to a halt, never again to grind.
Hot tip! Get your replacement through Amazon, who will do it for free, and not Cuisinart, who will charge you $10.

The replacement DBM-8 was shipped to me, but never arrived, some snafu of UPS sent it back to Amazon, sight unseen. So Amazon shipped me a third. Kudos to Amazon for excellent support here.

I waited to place this review. I wanted to see if the first broken unit was the exception, not the rule. The new one arrived around January 2019. It lasted until today, Sep 26, 2019, where it ground to a halt after some tens of grinds. RIP DBM-8.

The thing is, I generally perceive Cuisinart as a quality brand. Food choppers of all forms mostly. But this experience shows me that they will slap their name on the worst quality of manufacturing garbage to take your $36 and leave you wanting.

Do not buy this machine. Think twice about buying anything from Cuisinart ever again. Clearly the brand quality is not what it used to be.

I will now go order some much more expensive grinder made by whose brand is not Cuisinart, not because I want to pay more, but because I want one that works and has more mechanical staying power than an egg shell.

You have been warned.

This is my second grinder by Cusinart. My first one died after nearly 8 years of faithful service. I could have taken it apart and perhaps fixed it, however, at the price I paid for the replacement, it really wasn't necessary.
I really like the idea of being able to grind a pound of coffee, place it in a sealed container, and keep it in a cool, dry place. While waiting for my new grinder to be delivered, which was exceptionally fast, I bought one of those Mr. Coffee grinders that was a waste of my money. Just imagine having to grind your coffee every day just for that one or two cups, end up with expresso grounds (and unground beans) in your coffee maker, when you really needed a grind for a drip machine....
This grinder is exceptional in service, has several levels of grind possibilities, takes 1/2 lb of beans at a time, and only takes a few minutes to fill up a container of ground coffee ready to go- wake up to the smell of delicious coffee and not have to fuss with the grinding noise of a cheap machine that doesn't give you what you want.
Buy it Now- by the way, no one paid me to write this review. So far, nine years of total satisfaction!

reviews.reviewTitle: Versatile Grinder for Those Who Really Dig Coffee and Its Process(es)
reviews.reviewText:
No assembly required, other than to unwrap everything. I’d advise a wash of the hopper and the coffee collection box, just to be sure. This will mean getting the hopper off the base…I had to refer to the manual for that. So, it was clean and ready to go in about ten minutes.

It’s fully intuitive, if you know anything about coffee. It’s easy to tell where the beans go on, where they come out, how to fine-tune your grind and how much you want, and to turn it on. The instructions are great on all of this, and then some, but it’s easy to set up and get right into production. And it’s not huge, and looks good on the countertop.

It’s loud, that’s for sure. There is no subtlety in the way this thing works—you’re not going to surprise anyone in the morning with freshly ground coffee.

You get a wide range of settings for grind, from very fine to coarse. The fine is not quite powder, but it is mighty fine, so make sure your filter/mesh accommodates before you go too fine with your grind.

Best keep the lid on, so that when you get to the last few beans you don’t get them hopping up and out of the hopper…which happens. The grinder does work when the hopper lid is off. That means there is no safety mechanism; if it’s plugged in, it’s ready to grind. There is a small plastic dome over the grinding area, but there is plenty of room for fingers or utensils to get in there, so be careful.

Have no fear that you’ll overfill the grind collection box. With the hopper full to the brim and the 18-cup selection made, you’re still only going to get less than half of the beans ground, and that will fill only about half of the box. With a completely full hopper you will have to go to the max-cup setting at least three times to get it all ground up.

The ground coffee box is nice and compact, and is suitable to put right into the fridge or the freezer, as there is a small gasket on the top which keeps the lid nicely in place. But the small rectangular opening that lets the ground coffee in does not seal in any way.

The coffee box is not really optimally shaped for pouring the ground coffee out. Your best bet is to go with a spoon or a scoop. A design improvement would be a pouring spout/beak on the box so that you could gently pour the ground coffee right into your coffeemaker.

Documentation: You get a quick reference guide, in English and Spanish. This suffices to get things moving right away, and in the cleaning section it’ll tell you how to remove the hopper. You get a clever registration brochure, where you can take and text in a photo, which will allow them to immediately capture your phone for future marketing purposes. Or you can email your photo…which gives them your email address. Or you can register online.

The “instruction book” is a multi-fold pamphlet. The text is very clear, as are the diagrams and their annotations. There is a customer service phone number, and a physical address for mailing. The flip side is in Spanish.

For assistance, there is a help URL and a text number to ask for help. No phone number.

Price: At approximately $38, this is a big jump up from your standard little canister grinder at $10 or even less. This is a nice one to have on the counter, and is a good investment for folks drinking a lot of coffee, especially for folks who like different kinds of grinds and/or are making coffee in different ways. I think that this price is fair for the product.

Bottom Line: If you’re really into coffee and you want some variation on the grind that comes out, this is a good item to invest in.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cuisinart has deplorable customer service ... Times 2
reviews.reviewText:
Update: Original product bought in February of this year, replaced in late April. It's now August, and the replacement has stopped working. After 30 min on hold with Cuisinart, I gave up. What a terrific waste of time and money.

I bought this grinder to replace a much loved, but too old burr grinder (and to keep some peace in my marriage). The product stopped working less than 2 months after I received it. I contacted cuisinart through their "contact form," but after a week I hadn't heard back and I really needed to solve this problem. I then called cusinart twice. The first conversation I had was with someone who kept repeating that my grinder only had an 8 month warranty and I was outside of that window, and that I should return it to Amazon because they sold me a bad product. The second call I had to convice cuisinart that it wasn't Amazon's fault the grinder didn't work, and they reluctantly agreed that they would ship me out a new product if I returned the old product's cut cord at my own expense. After contacting Amazon, who, in turn contacted cusinart with me on the line. Cuisinart told us that I had to pay for shipping for the outgoing replacement unit AND the shipping to return the cut cord of the bad unit.

For Amazon's part, my customer service Rep Narumi, who listened to my third conversation with Cuisinart, was very understanding and made me feel better about the situation. But to some up, I won't be replacing anything with a cusinart unit ever again.

Also, if anyone has a recommendation for a good burr grinder, I'm all ears. :)

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinding for drip machines as well as French Press works fine, as both the medium and coarse settings seem ...
reviews.reviewText:
Overall decent quality grinder for the price. I purchased one after a family member let me borrow theirs for a few days. Grinding for drip machines as well as French Press works fine, as both the medium and coarse settings seem consistant. Would give it a four stars, except for the fact that the grinder grinds a small portion of my coffee beans very VERY fine every time no matter the grind setting.

There are some downsides to this grinder depending on the intended coffee method. For drip or French Press, works great. If grinding for Espresso or Turkish style coffee, I would not recommend. The grinder is on the loud side, so if you don't want to wake up your house mates in the morning you may want to skip this grinder. As for me, I have preground espresso roast that I buy from the store and all of the people I live with are out of the house by the time I grind my coffee. From what research I have done on BURR style grinders, there really is no other option in the price range of the Cuisinart DBM-8 that will solve the problems mentioned above. For the espresso purist or some one concerned about noise of the machine I would recommend spending more for a higher quality grinder. For the casual coffee user like my self this has suited most of my coffee needs.

This is a replacement for the exact same item that I've had for over 8 years. That one replaced another exactly like this that had been a Christmas gift six or seven before that. There is one review on Amazon that explains how to clean the grinder out, but I decided it was worth the money to just buy a new one. For years I used the Saeco Aroma Semiautomatic Espresso Maker (two over a period of more than twenty years). When my second Saeco Aroma died this past winter, I had to switch because they'd discontinued that model. I ended up with the DeLonghi Dedica (lots of adjustments from the Saeco to the DeLonghi, some good, some not so good, but that's another review). Anyhow, this inexpensive Cuisinart grinder model has worked as well for me as the $300 conical burr grinders that friends have, so I decided - why mess with a good thing? Hence, my third one. It's a workhorse, as I make anywhere from five to twelve espressos per day. (I only grind enough for one - two cups at a time so that it's fresh.)

reviews.reviewTitle: Bad timer mechanism design -- wears out quickly.
reviews.reviewText:
I just had an acquaintance who also owns this exact model discuss a problem with it, today. Turns out, their timer stops the grinding process early and they wanted to know how to fix it. (Parts are NOT available for DIY repairs.) I had to let them know that we also have the same problem with ours, using it once a day. That problem cropped up after only six months of use. My acquaintance also has only owned theirs for a similar time before the problem showed up.

The unit has a very poorly imagined design for the timer mechanism and the wear is quite evident. Having opened the unit, I can easily see how this problem almost must occur given some use. It's practically designed to fail. It's that bad.

The fix is to just "push the button" again and make it grind some more. But the design flaws would keep me from ever considering the purchase of a replacement or recommending it to anyone else. Especially now that there are two units within my immediate group of folks I know personally who have experienced the same problem and now that I've seen what is going on, inside. It's a design that should have been caught and changed, and wasn't.

Find something else.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great price on a good grinder!
reviews.reviewText: I LOVE this grinder and I have went through quite a few. It is quick (and isn't that what you need in the morning?) and it is so much quieter than my last one! The container is easy to remove and to replace, it doesn't get hung up and spill coffee dust everywhere. Well, it couldn't anyway because there is so little coffee dust! Another reviewer stated that it has too much coffee dust, I think he must of gotten a bad unit! This is the cleanest running coffee grinder that I have ever had! I highly recommend this grinder. I am just an average girl who like her beans ground, I am NOT a coffee aficionado or expert in the study of grinders and I was NOT compensated for my opinion

I would give this product negative five stars. Worst product ever. Complete piece of crap.
So I bought this item several months back. I had 5 bags of pre-ground coffee I had to use before I would use this item. I was excited about grinding my own beans and having fresh coffee from different companies that I could try out that I couldn’t buy in the store already ground. I started buying different companies beans in anticipation. Several were not cheap. In all, I have spent about $250 total on the “exotic” beans. I wanted to be ready when I was out of my pre-ground.
It broke on my very first use approximately two thirds through the hopper. No lie. If you buy this, you’re crazy. I’m so disgusted I’ll never buy a Cuisinart product for the rest of my life.

Update 8/11/19,
Stopped working after just under 2 years. Liked it when it was working. Can not recommend any more.

Ok so I purchased this grinder to replace a very cheap and small blade grinder (the motor burned out) This Burr grinder is fantastic! I grinds the beans to a perfect and uniform consistency! People complain that it is loud. People have to remember that it is grinding coffee beans and that just makes a loud noise! its not wrapped in sound proofing material (LOL) I use a medium grind (drip machine) so I set mine in the middle and compared to my old cheap blade grinder this one is just so superior, perfect uniform ground coffee. Love the large hopper for the beans. Just hope it lasts longer than a year (old cheap blade grinder didn't) This is a perfect addition to my Ninja Coffee Bar!! Oh it can be a little messy if your not careful taking the ground coffee chamber out and taking the lid off the chamber but I'm not going to take a star off for that I consider that user error. I got it down to a science now.

reviews.reviewTitle: A good looking basic unit- nice grind but loud.
reviews.reviewText:
This is our second of these burr mills. The first one we had lasted for 5 years, so no complaints replacing it at this price (I think about $40?).

I still really like the size of the bean reservior and it looks good on our counter. The unit loses one star because it's so loud- I wrap it in a towel in the mornings when grinding the beans so it doesn't wake up my kids upstairs!

Also note; the slide bar that dictates how many beans are ground is not very useful, at least based on the cup numbering system provided. I find that two "Clicks" on the bar (which says 4-6 cups coffee) works well for 8 cups of coffee, but again I suspect this is entirely dependent on the strength of your beans, the quality of your coffee maker, and personal preference on how strong your coffee actually is. So just know that you will need to play with the measurements until you get what feels right.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not built with espresso in mind.
reviews.reviewText: The storage is definitely not air tight, it is reasonably sealed up, but far from air tight. It does not produce a very consistent grind, there is quite a variation from one grain of ground coffee to the next. It will not grind consistently or finely enough to satisfy my cappuccino machine, and no it isn’t the cappuccino machine. The cappuccino machine is a commercial grade illy, and it has recently been tuned up. Some of the grinds come out as dust, and others as large flakes when it is set on it’s finest setting, this leads to considerable trouble getting the grinds to pack appropriately and therefore issues with extraction. I have an electric blde grinder of the same brand and it produces a more consistent grind than this machine. Stay away from this machine if you have intentions on making espresso to the Certified Italian Espresso standards.

reviews.reviewTitle: Hard to find fault with a best seller, but
reviews.reviewText:
OK, I got this to replace my second Mr Coffee burr grinder, basically the same machine. On Both the Mr Coffees, the timer failed. Still, by counting seconds they did the job.Grind quality was about the same. The catch is that, in order to get my desired cup of joe, I'm back to counting seconds.
In the interest of disclosure, I design industrial controls for a living. So, I understand what inside and could certainly fix it. And I may as a convenience.
Here's the issue. Like at least 90% of the target audience, I brew a pot of coffee at a time, or at least a small quantity to cover the folks with a french press ( I have one ) or say an aeropress (I don't have one yet ). The timer has settings which I understand are merely a guide, I get that, as there are too many variables to nail down. But for my case, the time i need is let's say 17 seconds. I have a choice of about 12 or about 22. in other words, much too weak or much too strong. In accommodating those few _home_users_ who brew 32 cups and the folks who want to grind a few pot's worth at a time, the majority get far less chance to conveniently get the desired result. So, it's easy to complain, but I'll propose a solution which wouldn't cost much. Simply cut the range in half. Easy to do with the analog timer. This way you serve the majority, ( I could dial in 18 seconds, reasonably close) and the quantity brewers could simply hit the button a couple times. That would also give the motor a break. Big upside, little downside. I haven't opened the unit yet, but I may, just to have what I bought the unit for, an automatic grind in the morning. The rest of the things people complain about aren't easy to address and for the most part are just the nature of the beast. And custom silicon to count more precisely (line frequency counter) would be another way. But I think a component change is the way to go.

This was a repeat purchase for us. Our first grinder, purchased from a brick-and-mortar store, lasted 12 years in daily use. That's great value for the money, as far as I am concerned. We're hoping to get at least the same performance from this one.

The grinder can be adjusted easily for various grinds from very coarse to very fine. The top-loading hopper is large enough to hold enough beans that you won't be having to fill it too often. it's easy enough to clean the top hopper and the container for the ground coffee. Noise level is what I'd expect for this sort of appliance.

Two changes would improve it: First, it would be even easier to clean if the top hopper was in two parts. Removing it for cleaning requires unscrewing it from the base, which loses your grind setting. So separating the top hopper into two parts, one of which was only the hopper itself, would make cleaning easier and slightly more convenient. The second is that the container for the ground coffee might be hard to remove and replace for people with grip impairment. Adding some ridges to the sides of the molded plastic container would make that easier.

reviews.reviewTitle: You had one job to do!
reviews.reviewText:
After using this Cuisinart Coffee Grinder it's clear that it's just not bad but the work of an evil genius. So bad in fact, the only rational explanation was that the creator's ex-wife ran off with a Starbucks barista and since then, he's had it out for coffee drinkers everywhere.

Coffee grinders have one job to do -- grind coffee at a measured amount with an evenly ground particle size. Inexplicably, this coffee grinder does neither. The gravity fed design of this coffee grinder makes it impossible to pour in a pre-measured amount of coffee and assume you'll have all of it ground on the other end because it requires the pressure of other beans to push the ones you want ground to go through the grinder. Instead, whole coffee beans pop out like a popcorn maker if you forget to put the lid on it.

As far as the grind, this product grinds beans as evenly as a heavy set man just jumping up and down on beans on the kitchen floor. I can attest because i am such a man and my stomping grind was more even than the grind produced by this machine. My wife would say I'm a lot more expensive but YMMV.

Worst of all is the static electricity that this device produces such that once the beans are ground, when you open the resulting container, an exploding haze of coffee particles engulf your kitchen making a mess. There is nothing a middle aged man, groggy from a night's sleep, enjoys more than cleaning an entire kitchen, especially before his morning cup of joe. This product leaves a kitchen looking like it was rampaged by a family of black bears, hellbent on dispersing coffee particles around the kitchen in pursuit of wild salmon.

I did give it one star for the public performance art aspect of this product. Historians will look back at this product and wonder how a society that discovered nuclear fission and the secrets of DNA made such a disastrous product. If you are a tea drinker with a grudge, I suggest you send one as a gift

reviews.reviewTitle: Differnt style of "burr" than I've seen, but does the job.
reviews.reviewText:
This is my first burr grinder, so I don't have anything to compare to besides what I've read. This grinder produces a fine dust along with even the most coarse grind setting, but I suppose that probably happens with other grinders as well. The timer is kind of pointless, unless you guess perfectly how long the machine needs to grind the amount of beans you put the in the hopper. It's on the loud side, but I'd assume that most grinders are pretty noisy anyway. As other reviews brought up, there is an issue of static cling with the grinds (mostly the fine, powdery stuff) sticking to the canister; but it's really not that big of a deal. Overall, I think I'm going to be happy with this grinder. We'll probably see what else is out there when it comes time to replace though.
Also, this grinder doesn't employ the same type of burr that you'd see in a hand grinder. Rather, it's 2 toothed plates which crush/grind the bean between them. Obviously this is still considered a "burr" style though.

reviews.reviewTitle: I then broke down and bought this grinder after doing some research for the best sort of grinder for pour-over or French press styles ...
reviews.reviewText: I had never owned or operated a coffee grinder before as I would buy my beans already ground or use a K-Cup. But ever since moving to the Pacific Northwest, though, I have gotten in to freshly roasted whole bean coffees from the many local roasteries (as there are many here). They usually grind the beans for you depending on what you plan on doing with the coffee. However, I did a mail order purchase from a local vendor, and did not realize it was whole bean when ordering. When it arrived, I immediately realized my mistake to my dismay. I then broke down and bought this grinder after doing some research for the best sort of grinder for pour-over or French press styles of coffee. As this is a burr mill grinder, this was shown to be the best sort per my readings. As the price was right, I ordered the grinder. It arrived the next day, and I had it up, running, and grinding away in less than 10 minutes! Very easy to use, and I made some excellent pour-over coffee with my single-sourced, rain forest certified Guatemalan coffee! I then found out later on from a co-worker that she has this same model but was over 10 years old. It finally broke, and they had JUST ordered the exact same coffee grinder. So this little fact about the potential longevity made me more at ease with my purchase as well. If you need a really great coffee bean grinder for pour-over or French press styles of coffee, then this is the one!

Updated Review: "Honeymoon is Over" (March 2016) - I've used this for a year now and haven't encountered any mechanical issues with the grinder. To get around the matter of scattering grounds I mentioned in my original review; I remove the coffee filter basket and perform this task over the sink. Still messy, but at least the stray grounds are falling into the sink and not into the water reservoir of my coffee pot.

My only complaint is the reason for subtracting one star and I've uploaded some photos here to illustrate. On the bottom of the reservoir that catches the coffee grounds is a lip, you might even call it a "base", that extends beyond the reservoir on all sides except its back side. Perhaps it doesn't go across the back side because that would make it too difficult to place into the grinder? Anyway, as you can hopefully see in my photos, the bottom back of mine has chipped off on both sides. This design leaves this reservoir at it weakest on the two most vulnerable contact points where it needs to be strongest. The grinder still works properly but I worry about the longevity of this plastic reservoir component based on the "wear and tear" damage I've observed after one year in service. I will update this review again if the condition worsens.

Original Review Title: "Still on Honeymoon"

Update - March 2016 - I've used this for a year now and haven't encountered any mechanical issues. It is still working just as designed and I'm satisfied. To get around the matter of scattering grounds I remove the coffee filter basket and perform this task over the sink. Still messy, but at least the stray grounds are falling into the sink and not into the water reservoir of my coffee pot.

Original Review:

I purchased this in March of 2015 and paid $49.95. It has been used daily for just over a month at the time of this review and if I should encounter durability issues in the future I will update my review. There is a lot to like about this grinder and as of this writing I'm happy with the purchase. I only have one dislike to report so far and that's the design of the grind chamber. I find it difficult to replace back into the grinder and I don't think the square shape is conducive to emptying grounds directly into a coffee filter basket without creating a bit of a mess. Hopefully in time it will get easier. But that aside, I'm happy overall with this purchase and hope that will be the case long after the honeymoon is over.

I have used this grinder a total of two times and it already does not work. I was excited about the price reduction and did not pay attention to the negative reviews because there were a lot of positive reviews as well. Anyone out there have any tips as to the best way to clean the grinder? I’m hopeful that that may be all it needs but what a pain! I use a aero press, so the fine grind is the best choice but it may be the worst for clogging the grinder. The two cups of coffee I made were the best EVER! Two very expensive cups :/

This grinder works fine, but it's not great. It's larger than I expected having ordered it on line. It grinds relatively quickly, the grind seems mostly consistent. My "complaints" are that it is messy, because the ground coffee grounds stick to the sides of the receptacle by static electricity, and collect in the corners, so they don't pour out neatly and you get fine grounds scattered in the top of the coffee maker and your counter. There is a separate lid for the receptacle that must be on it for the grinder to work, not a big issue, but more fussy that my old Saeco grinder was. Those issues aside, it is a decent functional grinder for a decent price, which is what I was looking for.

This is intended to be a scathing review.

This is a terrible coffee grinder. It is just so bad. I've had other, cheaper coffee grinders that lasted far longer than this model from Cuisinart.

After a little more than a year, my device that I purchased here on Amazon no longer works correctly. I will mash the button over and over before it suddenly starts grinding the beans for two seconds before dying. Other days, the grinder just won't turn on at all, no matter how many times I mash the button and plug it into the outlet over and over again.

In addition, the removal of the tray is a messy business and will always get coffee bean dust on whatever surface one is working on. The settings for "fine/coarse" are also inexact and simply inaccurate.

I'm never buying a Cuisinart product again.

reviews.reviewTitle: 16 years of life and I'm back for another!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this exact model AT LEAST 16 years ago and used it daily (graduating college to having kids, I needed my coffee let me tell you). This is the best of the best because it's all automatic. You select how fine or coarse you'd like your grounds, select your cup size, press a button, and you're done. And by the way, if you're buying ground coffee, you're missing out on truly great, fresh ground coffee! I loved this thing, but at last, it stopped working one fateful morning as I told my 8 year old she should be making me coffee now and started showing her how. What luck...

I knew I wanted this same one again and found it for the best price here. It's exactly the same, probably because it was perfect to begin with and didn't need any updates. Our new one works just as well as our old one did after all those years so I'm confident I'll use this one at least another decade and a half too. Good grief, I could have grandkids by then!

reviews.reviewTitle: This is the best, most reliable whole bean coffee grinder I have ...
reviews.reviewText: This is the best, most reliable whole bean coffee grinder I have ever used. The variable volume, as little as one cup, the most I have done is ten cups worth of grounds, coupled with the range of settings from finest to very coarse make it a product without parallel. It is easy to use and looks great in my kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: We like it, and here's why:
reviews.reviewText: Well, yes, we do keep purchasing this grinder every year or so, even though it doesn't hold up forever. But it's an under $50 grinder that gets used between 365-500 times a year! Ultimately, the grounds get junked up inside the internal mechanisms. Yep, it can be disassembled & cleaned out, but in our experience that only helps temporarily. We can actually taste a difference in the ground coffee once the machine is congested. Haven't had any other issues with it though. It grinds the beans according to the setting, the grounds cup is easy to snap in & out, hopper is easy to clean, looks nice, and doesn't take up much counter space. The reviews for more expensive grinders don't seem to be much different, so we're going to stick with this one!

reviews.reviewTitle: It's ok: the measuring, mess, and lack of airtightness are issues that keep me from recommending.
reviews.reviewText:
The good price for a burr grinder convinced me to purchase. That, and that it was a Cuisinart. The flavor of the ground coffee is great, but this is not Cuisinart's best product, and I own quite a few. The mess, measuring, and lack of airtight containers are my biggest complaints. Overall, an ok (but not fantastic) grinder. I don't think saving a little money on this grinder was worth the extra hassle. If I was to buy another burr grinder I'd choose one that kept the beans in an airtight container and eliminated the mess and measuring issues. For more details about these issues keep reading.

Measuring:
It's not easy to get the exact amount of beans ground. I alternate between using a french press, and using a drip machine, and depending on how many cups you'll be making, it requires experimentation to get the correct amount. Often there is a bit leftover in the collection container, which I use the next day, but many coffee connoisseurs would be horrified by that. I don't know if it really matters, because the area that holds the beans doesn't have a great seal anyhow. For that reason, I try to leave as many beans as possible in a separate airtight container, and I wait to pour the beans into this grinder until right before grinding. That requires guessing the amount of beans.

Mess:
Every time I grind beans, I have a mess to clean up on the counter, and the collection container also gets little blocks of finely ground coffee stuck on the top and sides. This isn't so bad when I'm making a finer grind to use in a drip machine, because I can scrape it into the container and use it for brewing, but when I'm grinding a coarse grind for the french press, those finely ground blocks stuck to the side of the collection container get thrown out. Over time that adds up to a lot of coffee being wasted.

The grinder itself also gets this finely ground coffee stuck in the hole that connects to the collection container, so once in a while that needs to be cleaned out, or the grinder will stop working.

Lastly, I wish the coarse setting went a little bit bigger. It works for a french press, but it's not as coarse as other grinders I've tried.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good but doesn't allow for precise measurement of beans
reviews.reviewText: There's a switch on the front that you set to the number of cups and it grinds the beans just fine. However, I don't know who figured out how much was enough for, say, 6 cups, but it grinds a certain volume and shuts off. You'll have to figure out how much ground coffee you want for your pot of coffee depending on the beans and personal preferences. It's very useful, but not as simple as you might imagine. I find myself grinding beans for coffee and it's frequently not enough ground coffee for my desired strength. Aside from that, it's very handy. If you're using flavored beans you'll have to clean it after each use to avoid contamination. It's easy to drop when you're emptying the beans back into a bag from the hopper and machine. It's best to measure your beans carefully and grind until they're all gone, rather than rely on what the manufacturer deems to be the right amoung for your brew.

We have owned and used this Burr Mill EVERY DAY of the past 8 YEARS 2 MONTHS, and it is STILL WORKING! We have replaced the plastic container the grounds feed down into once (3 years ago) and other than that this Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill has been the BEST COFFEE GRINDER we have ever owned in our 45 years of married bliss and fresh ground gourmet coffee drinking :-) I am buying a replacement unit today. Time to put our old trusted unit to the side for some much deserved R&R. I will keep it as an emergency back up "just in case", but am confident the new unit will perform just as well as our former one. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!

Does a good job initially but soon clogs up and not easy to clean. First just the output into the bin clogs which seems easy enough to clean but... in the meantime hopper spout is slowly getting more narrow until the beans don't fall into the grinder without shaking. Took a while to discover this (since everything is black). Thoroughly cleaned the hopper soaking in hot soapy water after scraping off the coffee I could see. Took the body of the grinder into the garage and used the air compressor with a needle attachment and blew everything out of there (after scraping what I could get to first). Back to a good grind with no more shaking but poor design since it is almost impossible to completely clean!!!

The main selling point of burr grinders is consistency. I either use a pour over (paperless) or a french press to brew my coffee so I was looking for something to do a nice coarse grind. I've been using an electric blade grinder for quite a while and, even though I have figured out some tricks to get somewhat even grounds, thought it was time to upgrade to something that would produce more grounds and be less hassle. This product was not that! I found that, while this was able to grind more beans at a time, the grounds were not very consistent and even on the coarsest setting produced a medium grind at best. My biggest issue is the mess. No matter what setting you have it on it produces super fine particles that go all through the grounds and the machine. This is totally not going to work with my brewing methods and also makes cleaning the machine a total pain. After running just 6oz of beans through this thing it took at least 5min with a pastry brush to get it anywhere near clean. Totally NOT less hassle than my blade grinder. Just have to say, I'm very thankful for Amazon Prime and their free no hassle return policy which allows me to send this right back to them for a full refund. I'll stick to my blade grinder and keep looking for something better...

reviews.reviewTitle: Works for a while, but LOUUUUUDDDDD!!!!!
reviews.reviewText:
This item is so NOISSSSSY!!!!! Problem is that sometimes you want to grind coffee in the morning when people are asleep. BUT, you cannot with this Cuisinart because it will wake the entire household. Seriously, we have a train that runs near the house and this coffee maker is way more disruptive to our mornings.
That said, when it works, it works fine. However, it only worked for 6.5 months before it made another sound (not loud, but like it was struggling with something), and stopped grinding. I shook and shook and unplugged and emptied the beans and adjusted settings, etc., but nothing worked. It was dead after 6.5 months.
The kicker is that I bought a square trade warranty. So, I called Amazon, and they passed the buck to Square Trade. Then Square Trade passed the buck to Cuisinart. Now I cannot get ahold of Cuisinart. So nobody is taking responsibility for the coffee grinder or the warranty or anything else. This entire return experience was completely absurd.

We have been using this grinder for drip coffee and after about two months are very happy . We had a Capresso machine before this (our second Capresso) and it failed after about two years, just like the first one so we opted for two separate pieces of equipment this time: a grinder and a brewer. The Cuisinart machine uses a disk grinder and sounds different than a conical grinder. but so what? I care about the coffee and it tastes great. When the grinding completes, I remove the boxlike container holding the ground coffee and tap it on the counter. This causes the ground coffee to drop to the bottom of the container and limits any losses or spills. I think a fifth star will have to wait for at least two years.

reviews.reviewTitle: A good coffee grinder. Not for me
reviews.reviewText:
Definitely one of the best coffee grinder for the buck. It does the work perfectly. You can select how fine or coarse you like your ground coffee, from a ~20 clicks dial on the base of the beans reservoir. I like my coffee very fine for the macchinetta so I set it all the way to the left (CW).
It makes a "normal" grinder noise. I admit the noise is loud but since you are not going to grind 2 tons of coffee every morning, you can live with it.
The real issue is the collecting box. The box is made of the most electrostatic plastic you will encounter in your life. The kind of plastic that Elon Musk is looking after for his electrical vehicles. The moment you open the top lid to collect the ground material, half of the coffee powder gets attracted by your utensils around and you'll spend the next 15 minutes cleaning microscopic dark dust. After 2-3 annoying trials that produced sheaves of ground coffee everywhere, I decided to put a towel on the kitchen marble and only then open the lid. Still the towel needs to be shaken, but less cleaning work overall.
So yes, I will buy one for my mother in law's anniversary. For myself, I will look for something more professional

reviews.reviewTitle: Works fine so far, but cup size is off.
reviews.reviewText:
This mill was worth the price I paid for it.. I was using my nutri-bullet to grind my coffee, but felt I wanted more control over the grind size. When I ran the nutribullet too long, the coffee was too fine for my coffee maker and this led to overflow problems. I also wanted less mess and found that transferring coffee from the nutribullet to the filter and to a container was a bit messy.

I was hoping that by having a cup size and grind size option, I could just grind what I needed, dump it into the filter and have less mess since I would not also need to transfer extra grinds to a jar. (I supposed I could have figured out exactly how many ounces of beans I prefer to grind per cup and never need to transfer grounds to a jar). Every time I have to move grinds from one container (the nutribullet container, to filter or to jar to store grinds) it was just making a mess.

I can truly say this is much messier than the nutribullet. The container that hold the grinds is a box with a lid. Ground bean dust is everywhere. It is much messier than I expected. However, the reason I am keeping this is now I have more control over how fine I grind my beans.

The cup size selection doesn't work for me. I must use much more coffee than expected per cup because I need to set mine to 12 cups just to grind enough for 8 cups of coffee. If I use the 8 cup setting, it is entirely too weak and pale when brewed.

I will keep this product and try to figure out how to reduce the mess.

I’ve had mine for over 2 years now and loved it-till I read all the negative reviews just now—- kidding,, I take reviews with a grain of salt.

I’ve used mine virtually every day for 2 years and 2 months. I’ve even taken it on road trips I like it and my French press coffee so much.

Only reason I looked it up was I am going to order another to keep in my new motorhome so I don’t have to move it back and forth. I was surprised at the % of low ratings. It’s far better then the last one o had— not sure the brand. Looking on amazon, I saw burr grinders for up to $250+. That’s a bit crazy in my opinion. I saw the capresso brand— which I hated paying $250 for an automated overly complex deal that constantly required tinkering with.

I’d never use starbux coffee, to me, the stuff is pretentious swill. I like Burke Brands, Subtle Earth Organics, medium dark Honduran. Been drinking it for several years on the subscribe and save deal. Also, larvazza has a couple that I like.

Yeah, it can be a bit messy, yes it’s loud, too bad, I like it

As others have described, this grinder inevitably produces a lot of ultra-fine dust in addition to your chosen grounds. And as Anakin Skywalker says, it's irritating and it gets everywhere. This renders it useless for grinding beans for cold brew or French press, which require a coarse grind. With a commercial grinder, there's very little dust, and most of that is heavy enough to settle to the bottom of the container. On the coarsest setting, the Cuisinart produced dust that's so light and fine that it stays suspended after 24 hours and then passes straight through two layers of filter paper without leaving residue.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good not Great Coffee Bean Grinder
reviews.reviewText: I've used this product several times since receiving it in the past month. I read reviews where they mention that the grinds are still a bit coarse even on the FINE setting. This is true. It's especially coarse on medium, too. Today, I used the 'almost' FINE setting and there were some coarse bits but not enough to detract from the mission of getting great, fresh coffee!! My single gripe with the unit is that it is LOUD. Other than that, it's performing as expected and I recommend it, especially at the price. It seems to be well made and sturdy and it's easy to clean and looks good on the countertop.

Hey all! I just bought this two weeks ago and have used it almost every-day to grind my coffee beans on medium grind for my morning coffee. Also when I first got it I used it to grind coarse and set the grounds in my air tight container for when I want to French Press. So far it is amazing! Easy to use, pretty fast, and the clean up is easy. Just don't do what I did and forget to put the lid on the plastic container that catches the grounds... It shoots the grounds everywhere. I'll probably do a video update soon when I get a chance.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... had 3 of these grinders and they do a great job of grinding coffee
reviews.reviewText:
I've had 3 of these grinders and they do a great job of grinding coffee. I am actually purchasing my 4th Cuisinart grinder today because I really like the way it grinds coffee, the convenient large coffee bean hopper on top that holds plenty of beans, and lastly the large reservoir for holding the ground coffee. Some of the other coffee grinders I have used have very small grind capacity and you have to grind a couple times to fix a large pot of coffee. I use a French Press, Ninja-Coffee Bar System, and a De'Longhi EC155 15 BAR Pump Espresso and Cappuccino Maker
for fixing coffee and this grinder does a great job of grinding the coarse grind for my French Press, a little finer grind for my Ninja-Coffee system and extremely fine for my Espresso maker.

The ONLY reason I did not give this grinder 5 stars is because they don't last very long before wearing out. I fix coffee daily and I only get about 2 years out of one of these grinders. Because of the great job they do grinding coffee and their reasonable price I always come back to this grinder. As previously stated, if these grinders lasted longer it would have been a 5 star review. Do yourself a favor and purchase on of these grinders, you won't be sorry!

reviews.reviewTitle: Makes some fines, but they're easy to pull out of regular grind
reviews.reviewText:
It's pretty noisy, but it is a grinder, so what else would we expect? It grinds evenly. I use it to grind coffee. It grinds a plain bean very well. When I grind flavored beans, the fines are sticky, and start to clog the grinder. But I can take a toothpick and loosen them out of the chute where the coffee comes out, and this is where most of the problem is. When I'm done grinding the flavored beans, I can take apart the grinder easily, and loosen up any other clumps of fines easily enough. I have to use a tool to do it, but I can reach everywhere I need to.
This does hold most of a pre-roast pound of coffee (maybe 5/6 a pound post roast?)
When it grinds coffee, even plain beans, it does produce fines. These collect and stick near the top of the collection container, and and they can be pulled out easily enough before dumping out the normal ground beans.
The first grinder I had like this seemed to have one setting. I'm not 100% sure I had the funnel on far enough, because the second grinder I got is just fine, and adjusts to different coarseness well.
I said "second grinder". Yes, my first grinder shelled out. You have to baby those flavored bean grinds more than I was, or you will burn out your grinder. Only grind one set, then clean, and so on. Flavored beans are much harder on the machine.
The collection container works well, fits together easily, inserts easily.

reviews.reviewTitle: Well made, not good for french press
reviews.reviewText:
I have an inexpensive blade grinder which does a perfect job of grinding coffee for my drip coffee maker. I bought this exclusively to coarse grind coffee for a french press. Unfortunately it doesn’t do a very good job of it. On the coarsest setting it produces a huge amount of tiny particles along with the desired coarse ones. The result is a lot of sludge in the bottom of a cup of coffee from the french press. I found as a workaround, that I could put the grounds in a glass jar and shake it causing the larger bits to rise to the top. Then the coffee could be scooped out and used in the french press, while the smaller particles that had settled could be saved and used in a drip machine. Certainly not an ideal solution.

A second issue is the plastic cup which receives the grounds. The grinding produces a large amount of static electricity causing the powdery pieces to stick all over the cup, inside and out. I found it virtually impossible to pour the grounds into anything smaller than a large funnel without making a big mess. After emptying the cup, so much powder remained stuck to it that it had to be washed after every use.

Like most Cusiinart products, the build quality is excellent and it would be a great value if one finds the grind quality acceptable. For french press use I did not and chose to return it. I’ve ordered an Oxo unit that reportedly produces far less powder and has a stainless steel cup, but does cost nearly three times as much.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good quality burr grinder at a good price (so far)
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this unit to replace a similar Braun grinder that gave up after about 8 years. After a month of use, I am pleased with its performance. The size of the grind is uniform (which is what you want in a burr grinder), and the amount it grinds at a given cup number setting is pretty consistent

This grinder is noisy, but a little quieter than my old Braun. It's also a little better in terms of the general coffee grinding mess that ends up on the kitchen counter. Most of this happens while transferring the grinds into the coffee maker, and it's just part of using a grinder.

It took some trial-and-error to figure out my grind size and cup number settings, but not much. To make 7 cups as measured by my Cuisinart drip coffee maker, I have settled on medium grind and 10 cups for a full-bodied brew. This grinder is BIG but has a quality look on the counter. It holds a lot of beans and is very easy to refill.

Coffee grinds tend to stick inside the catch container on the side that is hit by the ejecting grinds, but this was no surprise. Cuisinart provides a tiny brush for this purpose, but I'm shopping for a better one. If this unit lasts a few years, I'll be very happy.

I purchased this from another vender on Amazon, this a review of the grinder and Cuisinart.

1. Bad Grind - While the grinder allows for adjustment of the size of grind, there is always an inordinate amount of fine coffee powder on the sides of the collector. This grinder is a mixer of a grind plate and blades.

2. Poor quality - When your grinder malfunctions, which mine did just shortly after the return window ended for Amazon. Cuisinart has a "limited warranty" which means that they may cover their product, but you will have to pay for it.

3. Bad Customer Service - If you have unfortunate need to call their Customer Service Center, you may wait 20 minutes to finally talk to someone. And then you will PAY to have a new unit sent to you and you will PAY again to send the broken unit to them. or you will PAY double the cost of the unit. I ended up paying 50% of what I could have purchased a new one online.

I will never buy a Cuisinart again.

Works as described and anticipated. I have only used it on medium grind (for my drip-filter coffee maker), so cannot speak to either fine (for espresso) or coarse (for French press) settings. But there seems to be a wide range of settings available. The length of automated grind time is determined by the slide setting for "number of cups", and each user will have to determine what setting produces the amount of ground coffee desired; another way of saying this is that the indicated size of the "cups" may or may not be commensurate with the individual user's idea of cup size and may require a larger or smaller slide setting for a given number of cups of coffee for desired strength and for a particular bean source. Even though it is a disc-burr and not a cone-burr machine, the coffee grinds appear to be sufficiently uniform and better than a blade grinder machine. I like that both the bean reservoir and grinds reservoir are dishwasher-safe. My sense is that for my fairly ordinary purposes, I could have spent 2-3 times as much for a coffee grinder and not been any happier.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's not a bad machine, but.....
reviews.reviewText:
