This grinder is okay. I do like it, but you really have to do a little trial and error on the grinds. Some adjustments for the grind size just don't make a difference. Even though it has multiple settings, it seems that every 3 or 4 notches is really where you notice the difference.

Also, not all the beans are ground that are put in the holder. I believe this relies heavily on weight/gravity in order to grind the beans. So once you have a small amount of beans in the grinder left, they just jump around while trying to grind. This is problematic if you decide to grind a different bean later as you'll have to remove the unground beans from the container unless you want them blended with your new grind.

It's not a bad investment if you grind for a variety of coffee makers, but if you use a standard coffee maker, there may be better grinding solutions for you.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... Adjustable coarseness - Comes with a cleaning brush - Good value for the price Cons - Inconsistent grind - ...
reviews.reviewText:
Pros
- It will defiantly grind your coffee
- Adjustable coarseness
- Comes with a cleaning brush
- Good value for the price

Cons
- Inconsistent grind
- Flat burr (not conical burr)
- Makes a little mess, even when the catch bin is fully seated grounds till get out. It's not bad, but I do have to wipe up afterwards.
- High RPM (Noisy and contributes to the grind inconsistency)
- Medium quality construction.

Do you want a consistent grind and a conical burr? Or something to grind your coffee for your pour overs? Keep looking this isn't it.
However, for your coffee drinker who wants to make cold brew, drip coffee, or throw this in your refillable K-cup. Stop right here, this is what you are looking for. It do great for you.

I wish I had gone with a true burr grinder. This one grinds alright, but is very noisy and very messy when you empty the bin. It has to be cleaned each grind or you can't get the bin back in to place. This is the first time I have been slightly disappointed with a Quisinart product....

Adding to the review. I am finding this grinder to do a good job grinding, but is truly the messiest grinder I can imagine. The bin is impossible to empty without coffee going everywhere (unless you use a bucket to catch the grounds). It seems the build up of static electricity has something to do with it. I suggest a redesign on this, what should be a great grinder, to make it less messy. I have been putting a newspaper under the grinder and my coffee holder to keep the grounds from travelling around the kitchen. Not a deal breaker, but just something to consider when shopping for a good grinder.

This product replaces a small coffee bean grinder that eventually met its match in trying to keep up with my coffee consumption. It gave a good fight though. That said, I could not be more happy with this product within the price point. It is stylish enough that I gladly keep it out and it does the job. I appreciate that it holds beans in the top and has an auto function that allows you to select the amount of beans that are needed and it goes to work.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wow. My coffee is so much better!
reviews.reviewText: I have only experienced a blade grinder until purchasing this unit, so I don't have anything else to compare it to. Wow, I am amazed at how much better my coffee tastes! I always read about the tasting notes but with the blade grinder it just tasted like coffee. With the burr grinder I actually taste some of the flavor described. I understand the more you spend on a burr grinder the better it is, but I an very pleased with this little inexpensive model. Maybe one day I will break down and spend $200 on a better unit, but until then I'm excited to try different beans in this unit!

reviews.reviewTitle: Search elsewhere for a better grinder
reviews.reviewText: I liked this grinder at first but after 6 weeks it stopped working. I contacted Cuisinart and they suggested grinding sugar, salt and rice. None of these tricks worked. They are willing to replace it but I would prefer a refund and buy a better quality grinder. The grind also came out a little flakey and I tried different beans but always the same weird flakiness. I guess you get what you pay for.

reviews.reviewTitle: Two have died in 8 months of normal use. - Edit: Now three
reviews.reviewText:
Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill, Stainless Steel
Ordered on August 10, 2018
♱ Died early February 2019

Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill, Stainless Steel
Ordered on February 22, 2019
Never Delivered
Order replace on February 25, 2019
Received February 27, 2019

♱ Died April 19, 2019

♱ Died May 12, 2019
This one died as well... Cuisinart products have gone way down hill in quality. I will always look for a different manufacturer for and product sold by Cuisinart in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds the beans pretty well--but very noisy
reviews.reviewText: I've owned an exact model of this coffee grinder for 15 years. The only reason I bought a new one was that the three safety buttons that contact the base of the bean hopper got to where they would only allow the grinder to activate if the grind setting was on the highest (fine) setting. But this current batch is not as good as the 15 year old model. The motor vibrates a lot and it is very loud. I either leave the room or wrap a bath towel around it. The metal finish is brushed steel instead of chrome. I may just swap out the defective safety contacts and put them on my old grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: TWO of these have burned out in SIX months!
reviews.reviewText: We grind coffee maybe twice a week, unplug it after each use, never change the settings, and simply turn it on. This morning, just like our last identical model six months ago, the grinder started up, made a strange noise, then stopped (with an electrical burning smell.) We've had no other appliance in the house burn out. Not going to pay for return shipping for another grinder that will last maybe last six months. Will not buy this model or brand again.

reviews.reviewTitle: I replaced simply because I couldn't find anything with a better mechanism (e
reviews.reviewText: This is my second unit. The first one suffered from stress cracks and fractures of the plastic housing surrounding the burr mechanism. Result? The interior fills up with ground coffee! The timer mechanism and other circuitry are somewhat fragile, so when you take the unit apart to clean it, you run a risk of disabling the machine. I replaced simply because I couldn't find anything with a better mechanism (e.g., nothing but blade grinders) short of very expensive units. It's a shame small appliance manufactures build in failure. Ratings: 5 for utility, 1 for longevity. It's loud as heck too because it runs at high speed.

For over 2 decades I've used blade grinders. This is the first burr grinder I've owned. I chose the Cuisinart DBM-8 because of the excellent reviews it's received, and the relatively inexpensive price for such a highly respected grinder. It's less expensive than the last blade grinder I bought.
The difference between my old blade grinders compared to the DBM-8 was apparent as soon as I unboxed it -- the size, although one of the smaller appliances on my counter, is still larger than any blade grinders, a large hopper, a setting for grind as well as a setting for number of cups, and a separate, detachable container for the grounds.
The differences didn't stop at size and number of key components, but the grounds were outright, considerably much more uniform than any blade grinders I've had. That's probably the reason why most people are on this page in the first place.
There is one slightly negative feature about the DBM-8, though: it's LOUD! There's no way to ignore the fact that it's one ear-shattering machine... as loud as any very loud, hand-held power tools I have. Except when using those, I wear some type of ear protection. Any semblance of a tranquil, peaceful morning will be destroyed with extreme prejudice as soon as you plug the DBM-8 in and press start.

We bought our original Cuisinart Burr Mill 8 years ago in a store that sells refurbished items. We used it every other day until it finally wore out. (I'm not altogether sure that it wasn't my operator error at fault!)

Thank goodness for Amazon! We didn't even want to attempt another brand or model. This one worked well and we wanted the exact same thing. Of course we knew where to find it.

Since this one was brand, spanking new it came with an instruction booklet. Holy Moley: the top hopper can twist off in order to clean it and the internal parts of the grinder! What?? Cue rockets exploding and confetti. Here's where I knocked off one star, and kinda hate to do it because I love the performance on this thing. I put the top hopper in the dishwasher to clean it and a little water collected between the clear plastic top and the base underneath that screws into the machine. I set it upside down on an Arm & Hammer moisture remover container, put a bag over it and in a few days it was all dried out. Now I just hand wash it. Lesson learned.

reviews.reviewTitle: Big, Loud, and A Lot of Coffee Powder
reviews.reviewText:
Prior to me ordering this Cuisinart grinder, I ground my coffee with a manual burr grinder (Camano Coffee Mill). I had total control over the grind from coarse to fine. The Cuisinart is different; While a burr grinder, it's a cross between a frappe blender and a leaf blower. A pulsed blade grinder will provide somewhat of a consistent grind. This Cuisinart grinder however, is loud, and makes a fine, or at best almost-medium grind with a lot of powder. And attempting to set beyond a preset coarse grind prevents the unit from turning on.

To the Cuisinart engineers who designed this, slow down the motor by a factor of 50, and have the ground coffee fall into a container below - you don't need to forcefully blow coffee out the front into a canister. Until then, I'm back to using the manual Camano grinder.

Sometimes I forget to grind my coffee beans in the public coffee grinder at where I purchase my coffee. For those emergencies I've relied on a small Hamilton blade grinder, but I've never gotten the results I wanted.

However, the Cuisinart is exactly what I have been missing! A world of difference. I can now get the same results as the commercial Bunn grinder at my coffee store.

The Cuisinart conveniently holds a half pound of coffee beans in its hopper, ready to grind as much coffee as needed. The ground beans are automatically forced into a small rectangular plastic container. You simply pull out the container, take its lid off, and scoop out the amount of ground coffee needed. So easy and convenient.

I recommend this coffee grinder.

Love the burr grinder. This is the second one purchased. Only thing I wish is that there were not any plastic parts that break. The first one we had the top bean holder cracked in the housing so I looked for a replacement, they do sell them but cost as much as purchasing a new grinder so I opted to purchase a new grinder. The ground coffee sticks in the container but does clean out easily. I would purchase again if needed just because I love how you can control how large or small you want to grind the beans.

It's cheap because it's cheap. Look at the one star reviews. There are hundreds with the same complaint. That the grinder just stopped working one day. Mine failed 5 months after I bought it (with infrequent use). Cuisinart and Amazon know this is a defective product yet they still insist on selling it. The Amazon return window has closed and Cuisinart has refused to refund my purchase price, but immediately offered a replacement which I refused. They then offered a Cuisinart credit which I also refused because I WILL NEVER BUY ANOTHER CUISINART PRODUCT. Reporting them and Amazon to consumer affairs.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very nice with a couple of cons
reviews.reviewText: I think this is wonderful if you’re needing different settings on a grinder. It makes grinding quick and simple. I feel like it does grind to much for the setting I put it on sometimes. Probably my biggest problem with this is the static electricity that happens when it’s done grinding. It makes the grinds cling to the sides of the container and if your not careful it explode out of it when you open it. My solution is to cover the back opening with my hand and tap the container against the counter a few times to knock the grinds down into the container. Works like a charm. Also the coarse setting works perfect for cold brew!!! I haven’t tried the fine setting. Overall I love this and it’s a massive upgrade from those 1 pot grinders.

reviews.reviewTitle: Really good grinder-good coffee, but noisy
reviews.reviewText: I really like this grinder. My coffee has been excellent since I started using it, grind is even and very easy to adjust. Overall I like the top hopper and the cup quantity selector. If you choose 8 cups it grind that amount of beans. I’ve been happy with that but some people might like more manual control of the bean quantities. The top bean hopper lends itself to making more grinding noise- it’s a good alarm clock for the rest of the House! Also you should understand that the hopper makes you pour in one blend- so if you want to use this for a decaf pot and it’s got regular in it, you have to pour out the beans in the hopper to put in the decaf beans. So, this may be a limit for you. But it’s a really good grinder and I’d buy it again, hoping it’s more durable than the Bellemain I had, it grinds more consistently for sure, better than my Krups too.

reviews.reviewTitle: Might be OK for drip machine
reviews.reviewText: If you have a drip machine this grinder will probably work just fine for you. The grind is too darn fine and inconsistent for my french press and that is at the max setting for coarse grind. It has the same static cling issue that the Cuisinart CBM-18N has, except the grind container opening is much bigger on this model and makes a bigger mess. We buy a specialty coffee that is a bit on the oily side and it will clog this grinder up once a week. This machine has a slide switch, which basically tells the grinder how long to run. There is no fine control for it. It either runs too long or not long enough. The longer we have this machine the more we hate it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Why are the grounds all over my kitchen?!
reviews.reviewText:
This burr grinder has lasted almost a year so far with grinding away bags upon bags of coffee weekly. She’s loud, boisterous and chews those beans up with vigor! Beware of the fact you can put the collection bin in without the lid and activate the grinder resulting in an early morning catastrophe where you’re trying to stop grounds from blanketing you and your entire kitchen. The collection bin does not make an airtight seal and also no matter how hard you try the unit will be covered in fine particulate coffee matter which you should remove frequently for best operation. I’ve yet to break mine down and clean out the inside compartment but you better believe I’ll have to before the year 2020.

Don’t use this if you’re trying to not wake the dog, the baby, or the wife cause the whole house will know you’ve revved up the stump grinder for action.

Do use this if you want an affordable grinder to obtain freshly ground beans from a fine powder to small granules. It’s settings allow for grinds compatible with just about any coffee brewing device I’m aware of.

I use it to prepare coffee for my French press and my cold brew carafe. It also works for pour overs, and could definitely be used for espresso, percolators and drip. I’m sure you could even set it up for those fancy aero presses too.

Happy grinding coffee addicts.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... 5 years ago (September 2010) and it still functions wonderfully. I'm amazed at how well this has stood ...
reviews.reviewText: I bought this over 5 years ago (September 2010) and it still functions wonderfully. I'm amazed at how well this has stood up to my almost daily grounding routine! I mostly use a drip maker so for the most part it's set on medium grind. However I just started using a French press for when when I'm camping & it produces perfect course ground as well. Yes there are some particles that get ground to dust & stick to the side of the container.... but it's NO thing. There isn't that much & I just poke it off the side into the rest of the grind with a spoon. BTW - the sticking is caused by the oil in the coffee beans. I highly recommend this to anybody, except those self proclaimed "Coffee Snobs"....

This is the BEST Burr Grinder!!! It has so many different grinds from Espresso to course. We have used other brands and they just do't have the control that this one does. Our old Cuisinart Burr Grinder died and I found another brand on line--thought I was getting the same thing just another brand. Well that new one wasnt even close. The coffee was always ground tooooo fine and made the coffee bitter. We tried everything. We were afraid we would never find another grinder again. But when I went online there it was and at a cheaper price than I had paid originally. Ordered it immediately. And now we have the strength and brew we love. I have now tried it on Flat basket, cone basket, french press, and the coffee always comes out wonderful. Thank you Cuisinart Supreme Grinder!!

This is my second one. I believe my first one was about 10 years old. I use it everyday. The first one finally gave out..not sure why. Usually when it quits working it needs a good cleaning with the brush that comes with it. Ive done this several times with perfect results..runs like its brand new after cleaning. Didn't work this last time so I bought another one. For a small appliance, the amount of use it gets and the fact that it was 10 years old, I didn't feel cheated. I like to perk coffee sometimes so being able to adjust the grind is a feature you don't find in many coffee grinders.

I have the Cuisinart DCC-1200 Brew Central 12 Cup Programmable Coffeemaker. I bought this grinder to go along with it. As this is my first coffee grinder, I really don't know how grinders are supposed to be. This one seems to work well. The auto shut off feature combined with the adjustment of the 18-position grind selector; 4- to 18-cup slide dial is great.
The only issue I have is.....IT MAKES A MESS. It seems the holding container design is wrong. The grindings are placed in the container through a whole in the back and when removing the holding container, the grinding dust goes everywhere! When removing the lid of the container, grinding dust goes everywhere.
Like I said, this is my first grinder so I don't know if this mess is a "common" thing with grinders. It seems there could have been a better design for the holding container. Overall it a nice little grinder.

I have used my DBM-8 for 5 or more years and ordered the same grinder today when the original one quit working. In my opinion, 5+ years of daily use is a very good track record so I have ordered another one just like it. We also have one of these that we keep in our motorhome.

We use Ruta Maya Organic dark roast and the beans are fairly oily. We do take the grinder apart and clean it every so often to keep it running well, but that is pretty easy to do. We also bought a second receptacle (the part that the ground coffee goes into) because over time, the lower edge of the original one became chipped but it never actually broke. Lesson: don’t bang it on the counter to loosen the grinds!

Before discarding the “dead” one, we removed the burrs and hopper in case we need replacement parts in the future but if the new one gives as good service as the first one, I doubt we will ever use the spare parts.

I was really happy with this when bought this 7 months ago (from this review). However, the grinds shoot out very clumsily from the hop and they end up all over the table and under the chamber eventually (not ever sure how that happens!). The static from the plastic is really annoying to deal with and it decided to stop working today. I cleaned it out, and there was not a lot stuck under the burr or beside it. Now the only way it works is if I hold down the "start" button. I suspect there is a loose part inside as the start button is somewhat loose to begin with. I don't have time for this in the morning, and I doubt you do either. It doesn't help that I used this for my espresso machine (I thought it made a pretty decent texture). I am not sure how air tight this machine is, but it makes really fine particles, even if you don't want it to.

It's pretty loud, but that's to be suspected... About cleaning, as I said it shoots perpendicular into the chamber and the static that's created pushes the particles into the air.

I have had good consistent grind results with this machine. It is not very difficult to clean either. The only downsides to this machine is that it is a little loud, and the cup measurements. The cup dial may grind far less than you need if you like strong coffee. For example, I typically use approximately 2 tablespoons or about 10g of coffee per cup, and I usually make about 4 cups. If I were to set the grinder on the 4 cup setting, it may grind about 13 to 17g of coffee. So you have to know about how much each setting will grind, or just weigh out your amount of coffee, and just dump in that amount and grind it all, which is what I do. Minor inconveniences that I overlook for this great lower priced burr grinder!

The difference between fine-ground and coarse is almost no difference at all! I had to give this to a local charity, since I have no use for a coffee grinder that can't really grind beans coarse enough for a french press. I ended up buying a "Handground Precision Coffee Grinder: Manual Ceramic Burr Mill - White", which does the job for me. This electric unit is well-built; I just wish it didn't have a plastic receptacle for the ground coffee. Plastic always retains a static charge, that makes them hard to clean unless you dunk it in water (just the receptacle, NOT the whole unit!)

reviews.reviewTitle: Use only with adequate ear protection
reviews.reviewText: Well. It does grind coffee. So far. aka, the first and only time I tried it. BUT, it's really REALLY LOUD and at a totally obnoxious frequency. Nerve rattling offensive ntm first thing in the morning. My non-noise sensitive canine friends immediately RAN for any cover they might happen to find. When they could not secure adequate protection they just stared, giving the 'hairy eyeball' with curled lips and tucked tails wondering why I had chosen to torture them for absolutely no reason. Plus, the exit container is SO damn wide that you'll need a cake pan to empty it into with making a mess. And the cord is about 16" long, so plan accordingly. Even if its built to last a lifetime (dubious at best) I can see this thing surviving my collection of hammers for very long - perhaps not even tomorrow.

We have had our cuisinart coffee bean grinder for just over four years. On this lovely, autumn, rainy Pacific Northwest morning, the only thing that got me out of bed was the thought of my ritual slow morning coffee routine.

So, having my coffee grinder slowly grind to a stop without producing any ground coffee was like waking up to a cold bucket of water thrown in my face.

I did what little diagnostics I could, thumping the thing around, checking to make sure it was plugged in, making sure the hopper was shoved in as far as it could go with top tightly in place. Nothing. Not a whimper.

Disgusted, I threw the she-devil into the trash and stomped on over here to check out replacement coffee grinders. Of course, my mind was mostly on how I was going to get through the day without my pleasant morning of coffee, classical music, and the news. Yes. I am “that” kind of nerd. And tea just doesn’t cut it. Tea and pop music is for unwinding in the afternoon. Angry rap is for house cleaning, in case you needed to know. (The more swear words the better.)

But back to Amazon and coffee grinders. As always, I read reviews. People love this product or hate it. I loved mine until I hated it, so I was willing to give it a second look.

Ah ha! Lightbulb moment. One of the reviewers said the product required a periodic breakdown cleaning. I have no idea how to do that, so I proceeded. I pulled the beast out of my trash, turned it upside down and whacked it on the counter a couple times. Coffee began to snow, slowly and stubbornly, but enough to make a nice drift on my counter top.

I turned it on its side and noticed the little square the coffee comes out of was almost completely choked with fine grain powder. I used a steak knife and cleared that all out. I then used the steak knife to clean between the grinders, which was actually very easy.

All in all, I rescued about a quarter cup of trapped, finely ground coffee. Skeptical, I plugged the delicious beast back in, filled it with beans, installed the hopper and, guess what? Coffee in hand, music softly playing, fireplace glowing, rain pattering against my windows.

Today is a good day after all.

The promotional videos didn't show how much of a mess this thing makes. I love it aside from the powder mess it creates. We use the medium grind value, and the grind that falls to the bottom of the container is great. I absolutely love the convenience of a fresh grind, exactly the amount we want every time. But, then there is a caked buildup of fine powder against the top edge of the container.

When you open the container to pour the grounds into wherever you're putting them (french press in our case) the powder inevitably falls out. It also falls off the top of the lid. Leading to super fine coffee grounds (powder) on the counter every time. Oh well, the convenience is worth the paper towel sweep up every morning.

reviews.reviewTitle: Always makes a lot of dust, also very loud!
reviews.reviewText: Got this 4 years ago for work, and was just back looking for another, and noticed I hadn't reviewed it. Ha. Well, it's not good. The whole point of a burr grinder is to create an even grind - a narrow particle size distribution around the particle size you choose. This thing does not do that. No matter how you set it, the size distribution of the grind is very broad, and includes a substantial fraction of powder, which makes for very nasty dirty-tasting coffee, and makes cleaning the collecting chamber, where the dust gets stuck in the corners, very difficult. It's also ridiculously loud. All grinders are loud, but this seems at least twice as loud as the old Capresso I have at home. Don't buy it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder. Noisy and messy - can’t be beat.
reviews.reviewText: Awesome grinder, especially for the price. A bit noisy, but you can’t do much about that. It does get messy, so it’s best to lay a paper towel around when scooping out your fresh grounds. I think a good change would be to use a different material for the grounds container. Yes, it’s nice that it’s clear plastic so you can see the grounds, but that material produces static which makes getting the grounds out cleanly a little difficult. Also, the straight edges at the back of the container need to be rethought. I tend to use the brush to sweep everything onto my coffee filter and these edges add to the mess. All in all, excellent grinder and it can’t be beat.

I've got a couple of these. One has been grinding coffee beans for morning espresso for over a decade. The second, more recently purchased and essentially indistinguishable from the old one, is used for grinding small, oily, seeds and nuts (think flaxseed). They both work a treat, are easy to clean (on the infrequent occasion that happens), and are stupidly cheap compared to quite a few other products I've seen that cost more and often don't work as well (lookin' at you, fancy coffee grinders).

I have had perhaps four or five occasions over the years where I thought for sure the old one was done for, and each time it turned out to be nothing that could not be cured by simply cleaning out any detritus that had built up near the grinder, in the output spout, or between the base of the machine and the catchment container.

Used it this morning, another day, another triple tall breve, and hoo-rah.

reviews.reviewTitle: We’ve used this product over a year.
reviews.reviewText: I like to wait and do reviews after I’ve used the product, this coffee grinder we’ve had over a year. We loved it so much I purchased a couple more. Yes, it is a bit loud, but then considering it is a grinder it will have some noise. We go through a lb of coffee a week, and this grinder has grinded beans for every pot over the past year. It has held up very well to all the use and love the ease and convenience of having the beans loaded in the hopper ready to go. I love that you can select the type of grounds. I also grind up coffee to use in spices and marinades. After over a year of constant use, for the price point, I have no complaints.

I love Cuisinart products, but this coffee bean grinder has been a BIG disappointment. It stops grinding when the ground coffee container is about 1/3 full. I have had to shake it as it is grinding and often have to empty out the remaining coffee beans and put them back in. It's a nightmare and I would not recommend this product. What a disappointment! It's totally worthless and a huge waste of money! 😩

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after a week, it's more than a bit of a mess to use
reviews.reviewText:
The first 16 cup pot I ground it spit out more coffee than the filter could hold. Subsequent grinds were far more in line with what I expected and the flavor was actually excellent using a bean we'd used day in and day out for years (earning it the 2nd star). The grind does make a difference. Then on our 7th or 8th pot when I went to pull the grinds out and the top was full but nothing was in the grind cup. I dumped the grinds, made sure nothing looked jammed, and tried again but it wouldn't turn on. I went to the old grinder, made the pot, and figured I'd try again the next morning. Next morning same thing, turned on, heard grinding noises but no grinds. Packed it up and shipped it back.

Decided not to get a replacement because for as good as the coffee was it was a mess to get it from the container into the filter. With my 12 year old Braun grinder it dumps right in with the excess coming out with a simple tap on the lid. With this? I'm cleaning counter tops and still can't get everything out of the inside. It shows using a brush and yes, that helps, but now the brush is full of grinds and, well, it's not THAT much better flavor.

This is my second DBM-8 grinder. The first one lasted several years and overall, worked surprisingly well, using it daily, medium grind/12 cup setting. Recently it was starting to grind poorly and inconsistently, then finally stopped working unless I pushed down on the hopper. I took it apart and determined was a bad winding on the motor. That allowed me to look at the burrs. I was a bit disappointed to see that they were extremely worn, meaning they are not hardened. Also, the adjustment threads are plastic and were cracked. Definitely time to replace this grinder. I decided to purchase the same one since it does offer descent performance for the relatively low $45. I'll just replace it again in 4-5 years, saving my Rancilio Rocky grinder for grinding espresso alone.

I like the fact that this has many, many choices for grinding coffee … from very small & fine to coarse! I drink "regular grind" coffee & my husband drinks the heavy duty coarse grind! We are both extremely happy with the size & choices of grinding. The problem is I put the holder for the ground coffee in our dishwasher. It came out cloudy, very white. I haven't been able to clean off the residue (?) off of it so it doesn't look the best … BUT, the grinder works like a dream!! The residue on the "holder" does not affect the quality of the different types of ground coffee that we both love!!!!

I purchased this as a replacement for a Black & Decker burr grinder that was about 4 years old. Since I only drink dripulator coffee I reasoned that any burr grinder, even the cheapest would be A. Better than a blade and B. sufficient for dripulator coffee. The Black & Decker required that the coffee be measured into the unit, and that the button be depressed during the entire operation.

I decided to buy the Cuisinart grinder because the price seemed competitive and also because my Cuisinart coffee maker continues to perform well and is now 3 years, 8 months old. The moment I opened the new Cuisinart I saw that it was much more of a machine than what I had been using. I always drink the same amount of coffee every day, and the ability to push “start” and forget it is so much better than going through the entire procedure of measuring in the beans every morning and holding the button while it’s grinding.

The grind itself, while not perfect in the way a 200.00 grinder would be, has far greater consistency than what I’ve been used to, and the taste during the last four days has been smoother than anything ever obtained, even once, with the other grinder. I am extremely pleased.

reviews.reviewTitle: Effectively produces coffee grounds and decibels
reviews.reviewText:
I got this grinder to replace my $10 toastmaster coffee grinder. That was a reliable grinder but it didn’t grind the coffee evenly, and every once in a while, you need to make upgrades in your life.

The Cuisinart DBM-8 grinds the coffee well. But it is really loud. I plug my ears with my right shoulder and hand while starting the machine with my free hand. Then I run out of the room and hide under the bed with the dogs until the onslaught of noise has subsided.

Last thing the product designers overlooked was the process of getting the coffee from the grind container into your filter basket. This process is messy, I’m wiping up grounds after every batch.

For the money, it’s fine. Thing thing was cheap and it arrived in one day. Coffee tastes great. Might consider buying ear protection in tandem with this product.

reviews.reviewTitle: a bit noisy - great at first - dying a slow death
reviews.reviewText:
this replaced our OXO grinder -- that stopped working (and tossed, just after return period of course).

I really like that it stores beans - that you can see. and has nice clear ground coffee holder. easy to use -- it is a bit noisy -- but OK.

UPDATE 07/19: Well -- the motor is going. On it's way out. I've taken it apart best you can. It only grinds now if I put pressure on the top, pushing it down, then it grinds. So this lasted about 6 month....has been doing this past few weeks. Time to look for another grinder. We grind coffee every or every other day -- that should not over work a coffee grinder! 3 stars is now generous (great while it worked).

reviews.reviewTitle: It is not the huge commercial version seen in Sams or Costco.
reviews.reviewText:
This works very well as it will produce a good coarse grind which is perfect when
I make my cold brewed coffee extract. Ideal for this purpose. There is an adjustment
slide on the top that needs to be slid from left to right for the machine to even turn
on. Even when it is far to the right and I am thinking that it is a time of sorts, the
machine shuts down with about 1/3 to 1/2 of the coffee grind receptacle filled. just
push the go button again and it starts right up. Not good to over fill the receptacle
so pay some attention. I would definitely buy it again. Note: it is a bit (lot) noisy, but
hey it is a grinder and better than having to run to the store to grind a new bag of
coffee beans that you bought and forgot to grind.

The $700.00 model seen at Costco is probably better, but about $640.00 more
expensive and takes up considerably more counter space. :0)

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't burn the beans like a blade grinder
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is great. Set the grind size and the amount of cups fill the bean cup and press the start button. That's it and you're good to go for a great cup of coffee (as long as you have good coffee). I didn't realize how badly my old blade grinder was burning the beans. The only bad thing I noticed is that the grinds tend to stick electrostatically to the grind cup (maybe because of our super dry air this time of year). Been a few weeks and this still works great, but I have taken the bean cone off and cleaned down by the mill wheel as preventive maintenance. I also rock the grinder forwards and back before I grind so that the beans don't bridge in the cone.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quit after 3 years of moderate use
reviews.reviewText: I had higher hopes for this machine, and wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt, but I've gone through two of these in five years. We grind once a day plus a bit more around the holidays when preparing home roasts for gifts, cleaning it 1-2x a month. Both times it went out, the motor just seemed to die a slow death. Pulled the whole thing apart, cleaned it, tried different outlets, different beans, and no dice. Bought one several years ago for my parents and it did the same thing - they use theirs significantly less than we do. If you consider yourself a "moderate +" user, meaning you grind a *bit* more than the average household, I'd recommend looking at a different product. I'm researching other brands and asking for something else for Christmas.

We purchased this to avoid the community grinder at the front of the warehouse club when purchasing bags of unground coffee. Unfortunately, we have not been overly impressed with this grinder. The grinding is slow and the capacity of the collection bin is small, so grinding a full bag takes quite a while. Also, the unit is loud although a good amount of noise is not totally unexpected. I would have considered a brewer that grinds at the time of brewing, however we typically use a programmed brew time while still sleeping so that's not an option. This grinder also seems like it will be difficult to keep clean as dust and ground coffee end up everywhere.

Even when set to its coarsest setting, rather than grinding consistently, this burr grinder produces a huge amount of fine powdery chaff or coffee dust. The chaff then gets everywhere, sticks to everything with static cling, and can't be settled by any amount of tapping or shaking the container. The grind container is so large that it's impossible even to open it and move the grounds into the coffee pot without getting the fine, blowy, staticky powder absolutely all over the place. If you don't want a kitchen covered in fine coffee dust, look elsewhere.

I used to dread having to grind beans. It was take out the grinder, take the beans out of the refrigerator, spend who knows how long grinding enough to fill a mason jar, put everything away, clean up where I spilled grounds, and then make coffee. Now I just pour a 1/2 pound of beans into the hopper, select the grind and amount of beans I want ground, and turn it on. Done. Love it. Don't believe what it says about how many beans to grind for say 10 cups. It grinds far too many. But I will grind what it says is 15 cups worth and have enough tor three days.

Purchased for my husband for father's day. It's been awhile since I have seen him so excited. I also impressed him, as a non-coffee drinker, that it has a burr grinder and ability to easily select ground sizes. That super important to purist coffee drinkers like the one I am married to. We previously had this one Mr. Coffee 12 Cup Electric Coffee Grinder with Multi Settings, IDS77-RB and it did the job but it was loud as hell, a pain in the butt to clean, and used only blades to grind leaving inconsistent coffee bean chunks behind. If you are looking between the two and really care about your coffee, go for this one because you will probably end up with one anyways.

This is the third one of these we had over a span of 17 years. It is made well, offers a dial option to choose from coarse to fine grind and the container for the beans on top keeps them fresh. We use it every day. It can easily be cleaned with a brush but also advise occasionally cleaning out the shoot from the coffee to the receptacle. Depending on the oil in your beans, it can accumulate. The noise is very loud when its grinding but then again, its a grinder and only for a few seconds. Cuisinart is a great brand and I would highly recommend.

Its a nice brew grinder for the price. The only con I have is that it just does not grind the right amount of coffee for me. One setting is too little coffee, the next is way too much coffee. Suppose I have the Goldie Locks syndrome and expect for this grinder to get it just right. I suppose since the ONLY smarts it has in in the timing of the grinds it would be pretty impossible to get it just right. So far it has worked well for the reasonable price I paid for it. We shall see if it lasts long enough for me to get my money’s worth out of it. For the price paid, I am happy with it, however, it is a bit noisy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poorly designed and underpowered. Call Cuisinart directly for customer service.
reviews.reviewText:
This is a cheap coffee mill. Mine failed (burned out motor) after 9 weeks of standard intermittent (1x ever few weeks) usage.
If it runs then it is an OK product.
However:
1. It's noisy, really loud,
2, It's slow.
3. It is underpowered. (Motor got bogged down before burning out)
4. A bit difficult to deal with ground coffee dust.
5. Customer support only offered to replace it. I wanted a full refund. It took an hour of phone time to reach someone at CONAIR, the company that markets this. The customer service company listed on Amazon (1-800-726-0190) is subcontracted to Conair and cannot issue a refund, just a replacement for a $4 shipping charge. So I asked for ConAir's phone number and spoke with someone there who would issue a refund. Their number is 609 426 1300.

If you buy it, good luck.
Dr. Jazzbass

reviews.reviewTitle: Great investment if ur a coffee snob
reviews.reviewText: To be honest when I was buying it I didn't realize all the features on it. So if ur not fussy about ur coffee then this may not be the one for you. It has a couple of settings ... fine.. medium and course depending on how you plan to brew your coffee. You simply fill the top part with beans and click on roughly how many cups you want to grind for and voila it does the rest for you. I love it !!

reviews.reviewTitle: End up with fine dust from coarse grind
reviews.reviewText: Bought this for coarse grinding for cold brew coffee. While you do get some coarse grounds, you also get plenty of fine dust, and the coarse grounds are consistent in size. I have also had a hard time using this and not making a mess, between the large size of the output bin, the hole where the grinder shoots the grounds into the bin, and the fine dust stuck near the top, I just can't manage to not make a mess. I haven't used it much, less than ten times, and will probably replace it, so I can't report on the reliability/durability issues this grinder seems to have.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Drip Grind. Poor Espresso Grind
reviews.reviewText: I should have read the reviews more closely. Got this for Christmas. Won't grind fine enough. Set to fine, the output won't generate any measurable pressure in my Breville espresso machine. Does fine for drip, but still set quite fine. It must generate large, fractional beans set to course. I'm going to have to hang onto my spice mill to make espresso grind. Static is an issue, too. Coffee adheres to the walls of the output container and ends up all over the place if you don't open the lid carefully. A couple of gentle raps on the counter help before opening helps. Disappointing. If you have and espresso machine, pass on this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: especially if all you want is coffee for an auto-drip but like having the illusion of choice that you could get ...
reviews.reviewText: Decent grinder, especially if all you want is coffee for an auto-drip but like having the illusion of choice that you could get any other grind out of this machine. Using the coarsest setting produces a grind that is slightly too fine for my French press and the finest setting produces coffee that is too coarse for my espresso machine. I've gone back to using my old Mr. Coffee grinder for my grinding needs. If all you use is an auto-drip, or a pour-over, then this grinder should work well for you. If you use a French press or an espresso machine, steer clear of this grinder.

Purchased on 8/17/16 used daily without problems. Died today 9/3/17. Having purchased Cuisinart previously with a bad outcome..lasted <year I was wary of purchasing another but the stellar reviews swayed me. Wish I had listened to myself instead of the far revels. Last Cuisinart product for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after 6 months, difficult to use
reviews.reviewText:
Bought this to replace a much-beloved Capresso grinder because I figured a grinder is a grinder, right? Wrong. I'm going back to the Capresso grinder. This thing was a waste of money--noisy, difficult to use, and poorly designed. I'm giving it 2 stars because it has lots of grind options and can make many different amounts of coffee, but if not for that, one star.

The canister that holds grounds is poorly designed and needs you to be exactly level and straight with the grinder for it to seat correctly. This sounds like a minor thing, but when you need to use the device at least once a day, it becomes a daily annoyance. The canister is, like, one of four moving parts the human using the device really needs to work well (the other being the grinder, the button to start the grinder, and the switch that changes the grind coarseness), and man, it's super annoying to have to slam the stupid canister into place three or four times every single time just to get it to sit properly.

The morning, the grinder broke when I removed the canister before it was done grinding. I tried changing the ground coarseness, switching the device on and off, and unplugging it, but it didn't want to start back up. Honestly, I was grateful. Capresso, here I come.

This is one of those products that just keeps on keepin' on. I first purchased one ten years ago, and after grinding coffee 365 days a year for that entire time, it finally gave it up. Was so pleased to find that the design hasn't changed a bit. Good for Cuisinart to recognize when they've got something good and sticking to it. To all appearances it's the same product it was 10 years ago. Looking forward to another decade of fresh-ground coffee!

I studied reviews over and over and purchased another grinder, that turned out to be a cheap rip off. Thanks Amazon for changing what used to be a good review service. Now when you read a review you don't know if it is the same product you are trying to purchase. But this Cusinart is wonderful. I get an even, consistent grind. It appears to be of good quality and I think it will last. I wish there was a way to clean out the burrs, but this isn't a big deal, I just make sure I grind every bean when I do each grind. Very happy with this.

reviews.reviewTitle: Nothing like the smell of fresh ground coffee
reviews.reviewText: I do not know if it tastes better fresh ground, but the grinding process itself smells wonderful. Not that most any grinder would not do so, but I have always bought coffee already ground, and this mill is the first I have used. It is fast, fairly consistent, and not messy. It is quite loud, but fast enough that the noise is brief. It grinds consistent in that it does not produce larger grinds than the setting, though it does produce a fair amount of much smaller dust, so you still need a fine filter even if using course ground settings, though the majority will be course. I like it. Looks nice on the counter as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked great, grinded fine, till it died after 7 months of use.
reviews.reviewText: Worked great with no issues for 7 months, then it stopped working. Bought this in January 2019 and worked until today. Bought this on the premise that this would be a good grinder because my parents had a older unit that worked for years with no issues, however, it seems product quality has gone down over the years using cheap manufacturing and parts. It would grind with a pretty good consistency, but there would be chunks of fine powder, which is okay for me since I would use it for espresso. Used it almost everyday up to the point that I would hit the start button and nothing would happen. Cleaned it regularly and checked the parts and they would spin freely. Seen some other pictures of this where they would disassemble the unit and there would be coffee inside, however, that should be noted to the company as a defect and we the consumer shouldn't have to clean it out and shouldn't have to pay expense when it's under warranty for a defect. Thus, I won't be buying another one as I've seen some paying upto close of the price of a new one just for shipping and handling as Cuisinart requires you to do so even under warranty. I wouldn't recommend this grinder unless you are going to use it very sparingly or only upto maybe 8 months to a year.

reviews.reviewTitle: Best grinder & I have tried many!
reviews.reviewText: I cant even remember when I purchased this but I know it was several years ago and it is a great automatic grinder in every way. I had tried so many grinders of all makes and prices that I had given up hope, until this one. It became sluggish a few weeks ago with the coffee beans not wanting to drop down into the blades and so I removed the few parts that I could and cleaned it thoroughly. A job well worth doing, as now it works like new. Last year I purchased another one exactly the same to have as a reserve, but so far, fingers crossed, I have not needed it and it does get a lot of use, almost every day. For the price I think this is an excellent machine and would highly recommend.

at $40 this definitely is a no brainer. Being a burr grinder it's way more accurate than any blade grinder and if you only plan on doing pour overs or drip coffee this is definitely good for that. if you want to make espresso you will definitely need a more expensive grinder. Everything feels pretty sturdy but there's a lot of plastic which is expected at this price. it looks pretty good so no complaints there. with all that being said there is definitely some things that i don't like about it. first of all by far the worst part of this grinder is how loud it is. its insanely loud, and not only that but it's a fairly unpleasant sound. I'm also not a huge fan of the timer, i wish you could just press a button to turn it on then press it again to turn it off. overall if you're only making pour over or drip coffee and can get over the noise it's a pretty good grinder, especially for this price.

I really enjoy this coffee grinder. Its a bit noisy and sort of messey evertime we scoop out coffee but it really does an excellent job at grinding coffee to fine dust. I prefer dust rather than chunks or bigger pieces of ground coffee. This product grinds coffee both coarse or fine. I get more flavor out of finely ground coffee rather than coarse a d thats what I like. Big roast flavored coffee. This machine helps provide that. With the exception of a couple issues, this machine does a great job. Nothings perfect after all. The price point is a fair deal for what you get.

reviews.reviewTitle: ADVERTISING ERROR. BURR MILL DBM8-AMZ IS NOT A NEWER MODEL!
reviews.reviewText:
Cuisinart advised me on 7/15/2018 that burr mill Models DBM-8AMZ and DBM-8 are identical. "AMZ" is just an abbreviation for Amazon. It does NOT designate a new model
and there are absolutely no changes in the grinder's design.

Aside from that, this very good-looking, durable burr mill delivers a lot of bang for the buck. Its Fine settings will deliver espresso grinds for use in pressurized filter systems. It works perfectly with my DeLonghi EC155M. However, it will not grind finely enough for use in non-pressurized filters.

If you're a fan of oily, dark coffee beans, be sure to keep this grinder clean to avoid problems. It comes with a small, stiff brush.

Works like a charm once you figure out how the buttons work. We recently switched to one of the combo coffee makers that you can use the Keurig pods in and also make a full pot of coffee. We had an older coffee maker that had the grinder built in. I had always heard the burr grinders were better so tried this one out. I do think the grounds come out much better that the other style of grinder. It is kind of hard to get the plastic container to slide into place. I have to monkey with it every time I use it. You would think this brand for this price that would be a synch.

reviews.reviewTitle: so it would make a finer grind for my espresso machine and wanted to make ...
reviews.reviewText: This is my second Cuisinart grinder and I basically purchased it for parts. I altered my other one, so it would make a finer grind for my espresso machine and wanted to make sure to have spare parts if anything should happen to my first one. Oh yeah, and I am using the grind chamber, as I chipped the old one (it alone would have cost me almost half of a whole new grinder!). With the alteration it makes a perfect in-expensive alternative to way more expensive grinders needed to make fine espresso grind.

I'm learning as I go, about espresso, coffee, and what makes a good cup of it. I never realized there was so much science behind it, lol. I've always used a metal blade grinder for making my espresso in my cheap Mr. Coffee espresso maker, and I was consistently getting very bitter cups of espresso. That's when the researching began. After reading that what type of bean grinder you use makes a huge difference, I decided to buy what I could afford. To be honest I was very skeptical at first, and even held off on buying a burr grinder. I should have never of delayed. Even with a cheaper burr grinder, the difference in taste is more than drastic. I think my taste buds had gotten used to burnt and bitter espresso. In all honesty, I was not getting the results I wanted from my Mr. Coffee espresso machine, so I bought a coffee maker, and got rid of the 'espresso' machine. My coffee was coming out extremely sour at first, but I turned the dial on the burr grinder to a finer grind, still on medium, but a notch more to the left, and I was able to get a really good cup of coffee. I hope to one day be able to afford a real espresso machine, but until then, I can live with coffee, and with this burr grinder. I encourage anyone debating to buy a burr grinder to do so, there is a huge difference in taste. This device is also very easy to use, and to clean. There's a good YouTube video out there on how to clean it as well. You do need to take it apart from time to time, and brush out the dust with a toothbrush, or some sort of brush. You can also run rice through it, grind it like you would the beans so the rice catches the coffee bean oil and cleans it out. I heard if you don't clean it out from time to time your machine can stop running, due to it being clogged with coffee bean dust.

My husband and I refer to the bell signifying our coffee's dripped and ready as "Call of the Wild," which should cue you into how important it is for us to get it right without going crazy and spending a million bucks.

That said, we hoped to get a more satisfying cup of joe with stout full-bodied flavor with Cuisinart's burr mill. But it has been a big disappointment.

First, it was very difficult trying to get the two adjustments for an optimal grind to work together, having to fiddle repeatedly with the 18 different grind size choices at the same time as picking the number of cups we wanted ground fresh. (It's geared to grind exactly how much you've selected by pressing "start" without having to hold the bar down.) Too fine grounds make for a bitter cup and too large ones don't deliver the flavor. Only now do we appreciate how well our coffee company has perfected this process, which explains why the coffee we usually buy is STILL better preground than the same brand/type beans we've been trying to grind ourselves fresh with this grinder.

That's because even when you think you've got your grind setting right, it's impossible to fine-tune the number of cup measures if you're not making a pot for a crowd because the choices are limited to 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18. It's like Cuisinart figured everybody wanting a mug or two of great coffee have defected to the "la-la" pod makers, which is just the opposite direction of where coffee connoisseurs ever head. If you want to make a single large mug, the "4" setting grinds too much (we would have wanted a "3"). For two mugs, we would have wanted a "5," but that's not an available choice either. In any case, you are left grinding more beans than you want and either making more coffee than you planned (big waste of money!) or going back to remeasuring and making a mess. And it's a mess because the grounds do not pour out well from the small rectangular bin whether you try to tap them out from the opening in the back or take off the clumsily-fitting top lid. The grounds all just want to dump out in a big lump, but because the bin's plastic and there's no shoot or spout, and grounds static-cling to its sides, too. The bin is also difficult to slide back into the mill, taking multiple jiggling tries--like a bad door key.

The only pluses are that you can store beans in the top hopper, having to fill it only every couple of days, and that the grinding noise is less than expected, letting you use the machine even before your partner's up as long as you have at least one closed door between the two of you. BIGGEST DISADVANTAGE: the results will cause enumerable fights between frustrated couples!!!

It's too bad Cuisinart didn't do its homework because it could have made this a sensational product for little more investment. It needs to 1) increase the setting choices for amount of coffee ground cup by cup starting at 2 so that those not making a full pot--most people--can use it (i.e., 2, 3, 4, 5, 6...) and 2) redesign the cheap bin with a usable pour spout or shoot in glass, not plastic. I would have willingly paid $5-10 for these features...and been happy.

I got this grinder to go with my semi automatic Delonghi Espresso machine. I'm new to home espresso making, and just wanted a simple burr grinder so I can practice pulling shots. I was nervous to get this because of the mixed reviews, but so far I haven't had any issues. The grind is consistent all the way through, and I typically use it close to the finest setting.
I havent seen any leakage or major static. So far, so good! It was a wonderful purchase for my needs, and affordable too. Most people think I paid much more than I did for this grinder!

I bought this to replace my old worn out Krups burr grinder, which still works, but whines terribly when it thinks the hopper is empty. This new Cuisinart grinder is really nice! Much larger than I expected, but the top holds a whole half pound of beans! It is loud, but not any more so than previous grinders I've owned. The only think I don't like is the lower container, which has a flat -lift off lid just like my old Krups one did. I would really like a solid lid that you could snap on & off without worrying about dropping it. Static is still a problem, but I didn't want to spend double the dollars to get a grinder with a glass grounds container. All in all, this burr grinder works well, and is a nice looking appliance to have out on the counter top.

reviews.reviewTitle: and it grinds great, up until you get to the last ounce ...
reviews.reviewText:
bought this grinder as it was a cheaper option than other grinders, and now I understand why those others are so expensive.

purchased for use with my Chemex, and needing something that could adjust the grind, but also did not want to break the bank doing it. upon first use, and every use since, I've noticed that you cannot get the last few beans to grind properly.

I usually grind about 40 ounces of coffee beans to make 2 cups of coffee at a time, and it grinds great, up until you get to the last ounce of coffee beans. the grinder kicks around the beans, and instead of grinding it, it either creates shards, or doesn't grind the beans at all, so you're left with a few whole beans in the hopper that you then have to remove (by "pouring" them out of the unit), otherwise you'll be grinding old beans the next time around. I've tried using my friend's bodum conical grinder, and this one grinds all the beans with precision, all the way down to the last bean - however I didn't want to buy that one, because over time, the coating on the unit gets sticky on the outside.

this one will do for now, as I don't want to waste money on buying another b/c this one still works - but I am planning on purchasing something else afterward. not going to get this one again.

If you are looking for a grinder that provides good quality grinds, this is not the unit for you. All grinds I have performed contain grind sizes from very fine powder up to what is to be expected from grind level setting. Definitely way below quality obtained from a brand like Baratza and other quality machines. For a quick grind for the novice who is only looking for the freshness of just ground beans, this may be an ok product, otherwise look elsewhere. Cuisinart has produced some poor products and this is definitely one of them. Spend twice as much and purchase a real grinder.

Have had a number of burr grinders & most all of them have failed with only moderate use-not this one. had one of these a couple of years ago & it too failed, but this updated version meets the demands of everyday use. Large capacity bean hopper, complete versatility in the grind & graduated capacity's for the cup size. Some points that bare mentioning: the discharge outlet from the grinder to the container gets gummed-up when you grind high-oil beans such as French Roast & will need to be dug out to continue smooth operation; also, the finished grind container is still made of a plastic that takes to static charge & the ground coffee will stick to the sides/lid where you don't want it to-not tragic, just aggravating.

Perfect. Until I tried using for the third time! Would NOT start. Called Cuisinart for technical support. They had no ideas and said to send it back through Amazon. I HAD NO COFFEE TO BREW ONE MORNING. Fortunately a dear friend promptly brought me some before I had a complete breakdown. Very disappointed. It’s a perfect grinder- IF it worked!!

reviews.reviewTitle: They seem to really like it and I know they use it often
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this as a gift! It has worked well for my brother and sister-in-law so far! They seem to really like it and I know they use it often. My whole family loves coffee! In fact, I'm considering going to make more coffee now just thinking about it!

Coffee grinding is an important part of the process of crafting a great cup o' joe. This coffee grinder can meet a high standard due its functionality, durability, and dependability. It will grind coffee properly because it is a burr grinder! Consider investing in this machine if you have high standards for the process of making coffee!

reviews.reviewTitle: but still a good idea. The problem is that it is not ...
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is fairly well designed. It is messy when emptying out the grounds, but still a good idea. The problem is that it is not reliable and breaks too soon. I have had 2 of these. The first one broke and I returned it. To receive a replacement you must send the broken one back and pay Cuisinart an addition $25. After a few months, the second one broke and the same return policy applies even if the grinder is not that old and it is a replacement itself. So, Cuisinart, I my opinion, has not been very consumer friendly and I will be purchasing another brand.

reviews.reviewTitle: Useless for espresso on Breville machines
reviews.reviewText:
This unit will not grind coffee fine enough for use on Breville espresso machines (and perhaps others) even when modified as far as it can be. The chute for the grinds is constantly clogging up and it is very difficult to clean. The grinding process in combination with the type of plastic the hopper and the rest of the unit is made of generates huge amounts of static that make removing coffee from the hopper a very messy affair. I tried grounding the hopper to reduce the static with very minimal positive results. I

If all you want to do is produce large grind coffee for a percolator this might be ok. I waited too long to test and missed the return window so it's going to Goodwill for a second chance.

5/6/2019 - Changed from 1 to 2 stars since it can be used by others not interested in grinding for expresso.

reviews.reviewTitle: Did a jet just land in my house?
reviews.reviewText:
If you are deaf, this would be a decent grinder for you!

This coffee grinder is so loud I cannot use it if I have guests over for fear of waking them up. Fortunately my bedroom is on the other side of the house so it doesn't disturb my spouse. This would not be ideal if you live in an apartment. You would wake the neighbors.

An additional quirk. I have to set the cup amount to 18 for it to grind 12 cups. That took some trial and error.

A pet peeve. The grinds stick to one corner of the catch container and you have to tap the plastic container on the counter when done grinding to get them to fall off the side. This usually creates additional clean up.

A friend at work who has the same grinder confirmed all the above as issues he has with it. He has convinced me to get a different grinder as his morning have become more pleasant since he bought a different quieter brand. He was literally wrapping his up with two towels to muffle the noise.

I love coffee! Just not all the noise.

reviews.reviewTitle: It was wonderful for a month and a half
reviews.reviewText: It was wonderful for a month and a half. Then magically stopped working. We have to shake it to get the coffee to grind. After reading other 1 stars I see this is a consistent problem with the people leaving poor reviews. All I wanted was an easy way to grind coffee. We drink really strong coffee and with our other grinder we had to hold down a bottom until it was ground, and then empty and do it again. I loved the thought that I could push a button and the grinder would do the rest...but no...I have to shake it to get it to grind. Of course the Amazon window to return expired 8 days ago. Buyer beware: it's not that amazing. Take it from legit coffee drinker.

reviews.reviewTitle: Pure junk and I would give it zero stars if ...
reviews.reviewText: Pure junk and I would give it zero stars if that was an option. I bought this grinder as a step up from my blade grinder that was worn out and taped together with tape but still worked. I had this item for two weeks and it completely quit working. I had not even ground one hopper of coffee in the machine. Emailed customer service st Cuisinart and after a week of back and forth emails was told I could return the product to them under warranty but had to pay shipping both ways. They also said I could return it from where it as purchased although it clearly stares on the product packing not to return a defective product to the store. The only bright side to this is that Amazon is stellar and it’s free for me to return it to them. Cuisinart, your customer service and products are horrendous. You’ve lost me as a customer forever.

So I have been using the grinder now for about 3 weeks and I'm disappointed:
- grinds by amount of cups instead of grinding to the fill limit of the bin, therefore having to push start several times. I had thought that you had a choice of filling bin.
- loud
- extremely hard to clean, brush included does not work for me
- the small whole where the ground coffee falls into the bind is extremely hard since you cannot submerge the unit. I had to use a small bottle brush to get in there to clean.

Nice looking little machine. Compact and well constructed but poorly designed. Very inconsistent grind. For every couple of ounces of coarse ground for a press, I get a tablespoon of finely ground powder. The static in the canister makes it impossible to not spread coffee grounds over a 4 square foot area of the counter every time I take the lid off and try to pour the grounds into our French press. I thought I'd give it a while to get used to it, but that's not happening. Save your money or invest in a conical grinder.

I really like the abundance of settings on this grinder. Anytime I would make coffee at home, the grounds would be too fine and leave sediment at the bottom of my cup. This took care of the issue, plus I can grind bigger pieces and use them for cold brew! It's fairy loud, but it's a grinder.. I expected it.

My biggest annoyance is the static caused by the heat + plastic combo. Every time I pull the container away from the base I have coffee grounds all over my countertop and hands. Minor detail, but worth noting.

As a grinder, it works fine, but the design of the place where the grinds fall is terrible. First, it's made of plastic, which means static sticks the grinds to the sides and top. Second, the large, rectangular design means that it's next to impossible to dump the grinds into a coffee filter without them scattering everywhere. It looks good, but I recommend you get something else with a smaller, glass receptacle instead.

Looked around for a burr grinder for light household duty. We enjoy our french press coffee, but ar not coffee fanatics, and used the blade-type before it broke. I also didn't want to pay an arm and a leg for a grinder. Although this grinder is bigger than our small blade grinder, it still fits under the counter and its footprint doesn't take up too much real estate. I feel the setting make the course grind too course, even for french press, so we moved it to a medium setting. I like the reservoir both for beans and grounds. You can make up to 18 cups of ground coffee should you need! We've been happy with the purchase.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good entry level grinder, look elsewhere for cleanliness and noise
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is a good replacement for a cheap blade grinder but don't expect much more than that. While it's a nice looking appliance the grinding performance leaves quite a bit to be desired. Biggest issue is that regardless of what grind setting you are using 5-10% of the grinds are just super fine powder, makes it a pain to have to clean out this dust. There's a lot of static in the bin too so grinds are always left in the bin and needs to be cleaned more often than necessary. Irritatingly noisy too, more of a high pitched whirring sound like a blade grinder and not as quiet as a true conical burr.

A good buy for a decent drip coffee but for pour overs or espresso or any other more precise coffee's you should look elsewhere.

This my second Cuisinart DBM-8 Suprime grinder...the first one (exact same make and model) lasted about 10 years and the burrs seem to be getting dull, but still works pretty good. I wanted to replace the burrs but there are no replacement parts available. It was a great grinder and bought a new one as a replacement. It has been only 14 months and the old one grinds better!!! Very disappointed...there is another “highly rated” hand grinder for about half as much I will try.

A good upgrade from blade grinders. We used a Magic Bullet for years, until the tabs broke on the cup we were using. Decided to upgrade to a burr grinder. The grind is more consistent than the blades were, and we don't get a "burnt" flavor like we were getting from the blade grinder. We still get some extra fine coffee mixed in with the medium grind we select, but it's ok. Be sure to clean the plates about once a month or more depending on use. We started to develop a metallic taste after about 6 weeks. We disassembled the grinder and cleaned it well with a bristle brush. A youtube video also recommended running some rice through it to clean out any grounds.

The rice worked, and now the coffee tastes great again.

Like many other reviewers have a reported, my grinder too stopped working one morning. I took it apart to see if it was full of grounds like some of the pics I've seen on here, but nope! Nothing in there. Tried to run it after putting it back together, it made some noise like the grinder was going, but no coffee came out. Then it just petered out and won't start up again. Bummer. It was a pretty okay grinder while it worked, but not worth it for 6 months of light use.

This is my first grinder so I’ve nothing to compare it to but I’m satisfied with my purchase. For a novice it’s easy to operate and clean. It’d be nice if it were a bit quieter but it’s a grinder after all and it’s not nearly as loud as my food processor attempting (& failing) to grind coffee beans. I was concerned that I’d need to measure the amount of beans necessary for ‘x’ amount of cups but the machine does that automatically. Just pour in the beans, set the texture then select cups of coffee desired and press start. Easy peasy!

I previously had this grinder when it came out brand new several years ago, but somehow the top portion broken off mysteriously. I couldn't figure it out, but realized that one of my sons was home at the time and I was in another room of the house when he asked me how much I paid for the grinder. Obviously I put two and two together, he accidentally knocked it off the counter onto the floor. I was so happy to find it here on Amazon so I could grind my own beans again. I like the different settings since I like my coffee strong and I can make it weaker for company by just adjusting the grind.

It’s a reasonably good grinder for different grinds. Used mainly for press brewed & pour over coffee it gets the job done. I really wish it was better insulated for noise but you can’t argue the price compared to other grinders. This is my 2nd unit which replaced my 1st which died after about 4-5 years of almost daily use so you can’t go wrong with this grinder unless you have higher expectations.

If you don't like a messy kitchen, don't get this. Not sure if this is a 'feature' of all burr grinders, but the static build up with this grinder makes using it a messy proposition. Once ground, the coffee sticks to the lid and the removable grind box. Once you open the box coffee goes everywhere! It will leave your counters and shelves covered with coffee. I've even resorted to opening it over the sink to cut down of the mess a little. After two months I can't take it anymore and will be replacing this with blade grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Didn't last too long - motor died
reviews.reviewText: I bought this in April of 2018; it's now September 2019. Long story short.. Its dead! Motor completely gave out. I know this isn't the most expensive grinder, but I'd expect a little more useful life. I liked it for the variability in grinding coarseness preferences, amounts and the timer. We didn't use this unit for what I call heavy use. We used it: 5-6 days/week to grind enough coffee to brew 7ish cups of coffee to have on the way to work. I'd expect A unit like this to last a little longer. personally I'd expect it to last 4-5 years at that usage rate. I don't think I'll be replacing it with this make and model.

reviews.reviewTitle: ANY burr grinder was better than the blade grinder
reviews.reviewText: I'm liking the coffee ground this way. I was using a small Krupps and kept reading that I needed a burr grinder... ANY burr grinder was better than the blade grinder. This one is not a conical burr, but it does still grind better than the blade grinders... much more control over the size of the grind. I can see that a pricey conical grinder is in my future someday, but this one is doing just fine for now. Pros: controllable grind size and "automatic" runs until it quits without having to hold the button down. Cons: takes a bit of trial and error to get the grind right, but once you get the amount of beans, # of cups and grind set you're golden... the other problem is that it is messier than expected. That can be dealt with by being more careful when opening and brushing out the grind receptacle.

reviews.reviewTitle: you might need to shake it...
reviews.reviewText: I originally bought this to use with an espresso machine. it made great, espresso grind. last year I switched to a French Press, which uses a coarse grind. again, it makes great FP grind. However, once and a while, it stops working, much to my consternation (a day without coffee? perish the though). I found, by chance, that if I turned it upside down, it loosened the beans inside, and would work once again! so don't despair if this happens to you; just remember my trick. I don't remember when I bought it, but it's held up perfectly.

Ordered in April 2010, still going strong. I don't know what average life is for an appliance like this but it's been grinding my coffee daily for 7+ years now. The hopper holds about a half pound of coffee and you can adjust your grind size by simply twisting the top ring. There should be a grind size for everyone from espresso fine to very coarse for french press.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working after a few months
reviews.reviewText:
I originally purchased one in May 2010 and was super happy with it. The grinder lasted exactly 8 years which is very respectful! When the unit burnt out (would turn on after pressing the button many times and then eventually wouldn't turn on again) I decided to get the exact same one, hoping it would last for years to come.

However, the new unit was purchased in May 2018 and we're now in October and the unit just burnt out again. The same exact issue as the 8-year-old grinder, but this one lasted only a few months. So very disappointed, as I was hoping the quality would have gotten better instead of worse.

This grinder is like that kid at school who is average at everything and exceptional at nothing. Think of your slacker coworker who is somewhat competent but you can never trust with big responsibilities. That’s this grinder. I’ve had it for two years and it does the job but it’s not great. Even at the fully coarse setting, it still produces some fine grind. The cup setting is completely wrong. You can put just 2 tbsps of beans and set it to 4 cup grind and it still won’t grind all of it. But it works decently well. I’ll keep using this until it breaks. Also, it’s loud.

I bought this coffee grinder and though it was EXTREMELY noisy, it ground coffee ok. Then, out of the blue, the machine stopped working. No warning, it just stopped.
I ordered another one and bought the extended warranty so I don't get screwed again. It arrived today, but was delivered in a personal vehicle by a driver who was completely indifferent to the product. I have a gated drive way with a basket attached to the fence to place deliveries in. I happened to be looking out my office window when the driver arrived. Rather that logically placing the item in the basket, he carelessly dropped it over the fence. He did not lean over the fence to reduce the dropping distance, he dropped it from shoulder height. So if it doesn't work, I'll be sending it back.
