I am very particular about my coffee. I remember when Green Mountain Coffee Roasters was a start up when I was living in Vermont. They turned me on the the fine points about making coffee. You can get fresh roasted beans, grind them yourself, and brew them in the best coffee makers and still not get the quality that you get from a good coffee shop. The beans can be the same, the coffee maker can be the same, the only difference is your grinder. Based on that, I can say that for the money, this is a great grinder. The only better grinders cost hundreds more.
A burr grinder spins the beans while cutting without smashing them. The cheap rotary grinders heat the beans and produces a lot of dust. This one produces very little dust, and more uniform ground coffee.

This is the second Cuisinart burr grinder. They have lasted less than 11 and 5 months respectively both instances. Both units simply stop grinding even though they were both maintained. My advice is to seek another grinder. This is a total waste of money. Oh yes, calling Cuisinart for assistance. I think that a 45 minute is well beyond any reasonable thought. My total disgust should be noted. First, you should note that this is very unreliable. SECOND, you may be dead before Cuisinart responds.

Burr grinder works great but it makes a mess. Coffee grounds get everywhere on our counter after using. Static electricity like others have said. Consistent ground uniformity however there is always very fine ground coffee that gets mixed in after grinding. I always have to pick it out of grounds that did grind consistently. It is kindle annoying that I have to even do that, but for the most part the grind consistency is good and will surely be a step up from a blade grinder.

Negatives: • grind-hopper is a plastic that generates & retains a STATIC-charge!, making ground-coffee & chaff to STICK & CLING to the plastic hopper! •. Grind has vastly irratic gradual sizes within each grind! Irratic grind sizes (CONCISTENCY!) is NOT a CONCERN for the average coffee drinker.!!!. However, it is CRUCIAL for someone making Espressos!, where CONSISTENCY is CRUCIAL in CONTROLLING PRESSURE & EXTRACTION times.!!!.

ie, this grinder is adequately SUFFICIENT & a DEPENDABLE choice for a drip-coffee-maker.!!!., But definitely NOT sufficient for the REQUIREMENTS of a Espresso maker.!!!.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cuisinart Burr Grinder, provides good product but is VERY noisy
reviews.reviewText: We bought this coffee grinder to replace a Capresso Burr Grinder that kept stalling in the middle of grinding. The beans in the Capresso would get stuck and in order to get them moving down the hopper we had to tap or shake the grinder. From what I have read this is a common problem with the Capresso over time. After reading many reviews on different models of coffee grinders I settled on this one for the price and look. It does a nice job grinding the beans and I like the settings for different levels of courseness or fineness. HOWEVER, it is very loud, much louder than the Capresso. Many other reviewers reported this same experience and it's the one downside of this grinder. Luckily, we live in a large enough house where the bedroom is far from the kitchen but you cannot even talk over the grinder it is so loud. Just like the Capresso, this receptacle for the coffee grounds gets static which causes a mess with the grounds. I have found that if I spray the container with cooking spray and wipe it down with a paper towel it helps minimize the static.

reviews.reviewTitle: Probably not the best grinder, but it does an adequate job and is definitely a very good value
reviews.reviewText:
A good all-around coffee grinder. I grind for both drip as well as French press, and it does an acceptable job with both. The uniformity of the end product is excellent (except for the powdery by-product which I will get to later).This is the second Cuisinart grinder I have owned. The first was basically an older generation of the same model, and it lasted more than 12 years. This newer model is not "quiet" by any means, but it is noticeably quieter than the older model, and its ability to grind coffee at the coarse setting (for French press) is considerably better. In my opinion, the feature which allows you to set a number of cups to grind is useless. I never use it, as I prefer to measure by coffee scoop rather than trust the grinder to do it, and I doubt that it could be very accurate or repeatable given that I am sure the setting is based on time and not volume--in other words, setting it to "12 cups" will simply cause the grinder to grind for a longer time before auto-stopping than setting it to "4 cups."

The major drawback of this grinder is that, no matter how coarse the grind setting, it always produces a certain amount of fine powder in the final product. When grinding enough coffee for a full pot (10-12 cups) this powder collects just beneath one corner of the container holding the ground coffee and is at least one to two teaspoons. If you do not carefully try to capture and discard this powder, it will mix in with the coffee you have just ground. In the case of drip/filtered coffee it's not the end of the world, but it is awful for French press coffee since it winds up as unpleasant murky grit in the final product, and a layer of sludge at the bottom of your cup.

I'm by no means a coffee snob or anything so here it goes. If your looking to grind fresh beans for coffee all types of coffee EXCEPT espresso then this is for you. I brink coffee and espresso I was hoping this machine would break me away from my small spice grinder but no luck. On the fine setting it gets close. The fine setting is good for using my K cup. I opened up a Starbucks K cup and compared the grind. .35-.40 grams is needed to be used in a my K cup.

This machine does make it easier to grind down farther for espresso versus using whole beans in a small spice grinder but for the price you really can't complain this machine saves me a lot of time grinding for espresso.

All in all a very good buy. Would be 5 stars if the grind was smaller but again for the price you really can't complain.

Well update... Tried to grind some beans this morning and it died. It lasted 2.5 months and its dead, I do not drink coffee everyday but still its dead and I can not return it... Maybe time to shop costco at least when their for sale items fail they will allow a return or refund !!! 2.5 months !! come on Cuisinart and Amazon PRIME !!!!!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Fresh brewed coffee from supremely ground beans - nothing better!
reviews.reviewText:
Words cannot describe how wonderful it is to pour the beans in, select the grind and number of cups, and then just push a button to get perfectly ground coffee that I just pour into the filter. You have to play around with the number of cups - if you're making four cups, but want coffee strong enough to melt your teeth, you need to grind more beans by selecting a greater number of cups.
I prefer french roast and bold flavor coffee. If I'm making a 10-cup pot, selecting 10 cups on the dial at medium grind, gives me a perfect pot. So far, this grinder has been bullet proof. No problems. It comes with a scoop/brush combo. It comes apart for cleaning but so far, I haven't needed to.
My daughter purchased this grinder and the Cuisinart Cuisinart CHW-12R 12-Cup Programmable Coffeemaker Plus Hot Water System for my birthday. It's now my special evening ritual to grind the beans and get the coffee ready to auto-brew in the morning. Waking up to the smell of freshly brewed coffee - there are no words to describe the happiness that brings.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not all grains come out the same size, but great price for what you get.
reviews.reviewText:
l'd be lying if i said i didn't like this grinder, consider the price.

the only thing and the ONE major CON that people need to be aware of before buying this grinder is that not all the grain come out the same size. they actually vary greatly in sizes. even at the lowest/finest grain setting, half of the grind come out very fine, while the other half come out fairly large.

IF you're very picky about your espresso gear and a snob, this is NOT the grinder for you. But for someone like me, a casual drinker, this is perfect. i don't mind the various grain sizes. it's my first dedicated grinder, i get more kick out of the whole process than the size of the grain. plus, this thing is just drop dead gorgeous to look at. you get a dedicated mill, and a pot to store your beans, which is exactly what i was looking for.

For the current price, and knowing the major shortcomings, i am completely OK and happy with the unit. If you're buying this unit and expecting professional grade grain sizes, you're fooling yourself.

I generally don't buy Cuisinart products as they are too spendy, in my opinion. This purchase only serves to re-enforce that opinion. After the second week regular jamming of the grinder occurred. This meant I had to empty the coffee ground already as well as the still whole beans from the device, take the coffee holders off and then unclog the device. This happens nearly every time I use it. Now all other aspects of the device seem to be ok however, when grinding one pound of very normal coffee beans causes the thing to jam, one has to wonder.

In my opinion this device is not any better than an comparably priced Mr. Coffee or Hamilton Beach product and those sometimes are the subject of sale prices.

reviews.reviewTitle: Broke after 2 months, static, inconsistent grind.
reviews.reviewText: Worked fine for 2 months then stopped working entirely. It just makes a really loud noise and doesn't grind anything now. The hopper and catcher are also staticky and grinds stick to the catcher, which means you never get them all out and have to clean it constantly. The grinder also produces really small grinds that stick to the top of the catcher regardless of what grind size you choose. Since I use a french press and chemex, this is not ideal at all. I would suggest saving up and buying a better grinder. It's not worth wasting the $40. I submitted for support from Amazon and the manufacturer and did not receive a response from either.

I purchased this online and didn't really pay attention to the size, but it is larger than it looks. Takes up a good deal of counter real estate. Also, it is incredibly loud--be prepared to wake up the whole house. Every coffee grinder makes noise, but this one is like using a power tool. The most irritating thing is that when it grinds the coffee, it gives it a static charge to the finer grounds which then stick the walls of the receptacle and fly around when you try to scoop them out. Always makes a mess when using. I would not buy this again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing Burr Mill for Coffee Beans
reviews.reviewText: I use this grinder for my coarse ground coffee beans to use in a french press. It's spot on with its cup measurements and it allows you to put in nearly a full pound of coffee beans in the reservoir. The coarse setting is still a little too fine for my press, but I think that's just my press' mesh screen. For the price, it's very good quality and consistency and the separate grind reservoir makes it easy to clean.

Not impressed with this machine. It is an extremely high-speed burr grinder that essentially turns itself into a bladed grinder that generates ultra-fine powdery coffee grinds that result significant debris and sludge in your coffee cup if using a French press. I have it set to the 3rd coarsest setting and still see coffee grinds the consistency of confectionary sugar. The ultra fine particles, coupled with having to remove the cover of the grind capture container result in coffee dust ending up all over the kitchen counter. I purchased this specifically due to the burr grinder and the purported consistent grind size that yields a better cup of coffee but this unit is no better than a cheap blade grinder. I do not recommend this unit!!!

I purchased the Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill which wasn't what I expected. Of course the Breville Espresso machine which I also bought has a grinder built in & hopefully will sufficiently grind the beans for espresso to my liking. On the Cuisinart I have to select the finest grind (meant for espresso) just for pour over coffee. It is also way too noisy. This is an example of what you pay for. If you aren't that specific about the details, it's definitely satisfactory.

I don't usually write reviews but sometimes it just needs to be stated clearly when a product does not meet your expectations. Don't get me wrong this grinder will grind coffee so I gave 3 stars but there are several areas it's lacking.

1. This thing makes a huge mess. There is no easy way to take the ground coffee and put it in anything without it making a huge mess. There's a weird lid that you need to take off to get the coffee out and it goes everywhere when you do.

2. It just doesn't seem to work very efficiently. Compared with my old grinder and some that my friends have it just seems to spin its wheels while it's trying to grind. I bought it so I could make large amounts for cold brew but grinding a couple cups seems to take 10 minutes. Maybe I'm off on this but it just seems odd.

I hate not giving cuisinart a good review cause I like all their other products but this was par at best and really probably closer to a 2-star product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great burr grinder for low price
reviews.reviewText: I've been grinding my own coffee for decades and noticed a flavor improvement in when I bought the Cuisinart burr grinder about eight months ago. It lets you select your grind, so you don't over-grind. It's convenient—don't have to hold your finger on the grind button, like my previous grinders. The ground coffee sits in a big easy-access receptacle, so I don't have to scoop around the grinder blades to retrieve it. A bit of grounds spillage is inevitable but can be minimized if one taps the receptacle lid before removing it. I purchased two of these for gifts and just bought myself a second one for my office.

I had an earlier version of this grider that lasted fifteen years - until it was dropped.
Sure, it was 10 decibels louder than a jet engine, and messy to empty - it worked every day, and it was a good value. When it was broken, we bought another.
This one lasted 4 months, and Cusinart expects me to spend over 50% of the price of the thing to return it? Nah, I'll spend more on a decent grinder and pick another brand.

I am extremely happy with it, especially for the price. It was on sale at Amazon for less than $50 and I'm glad I got it. Sure, I would have liked to have purchased a conical burr grinder with an infinitely variable timer that's a little easier to clean, but I would have to pay 3-5 times as much. This Cuisinart DBM-8 makes consistent grounds with very little dust ("fines," as the snobs would say), takes up very little cabinet space, is easy to use and I'm making what is, to my taste, really good, strong-but-not-sour coffee. I will say it's a bit on the loud side, but not obnoxiously so. If you're looking to upgrade from a blade grinder, this is a really good option.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great with my Cuisinart Espresso Machine!
reviews.reviewText:
I have been using this grinder since early January and am 100% satisfied with it. I have a Cuisinart Espresso Machine and I set the grinder on the finest grind, every cup comes out perfect. Love having my beans freshly ground and not contaminated by the grocery store grinder. The grind is
perfect and it just plain works. I grind just enough for the current use so that I have a fresh grind on every cup.

Have not had any issues with it clogging and I just brush out the left behind grinds with the supplied brush/scoop combo.

I highly recommend this product and I am not being paid to say it.

Bought and used for about 8 months before it broke. Durability issues aside (not sure if others have had this issue), in the 8 months I used it daily, it was "OK". Fresh ground does taste better. I was hoping this would produce a more consistent grind, more easily, with less mess. In the end 1 out of 3 ain't bad. Or good. See below. In the end, I'm going back to my blade grinder instead of going through the hassle of replacing this one.

Pros: Easy to use with the exception of the mess issues noted below. Consistent grind, though I mostly used a medium grind.

Cons: Loud. Messy; when you grind, the unit builds up static electricity which causes a small amount of the grounds to "jump" out of the grind container when you open it. You will spend some time cleaning up every day you use this. It's not small; unless you have some big cupboards and want to haul it out every time you use it, this will live on your counter.

I kind of laughed when I read other reviews that commented on how loud this grinder is since it is a grinder but it really is louder than I thought it would be. I actually grind my beans at night before going to bed now because I feel like it will wake everyone in the house up if I wait til morning.

I like that you can just pick the number of cups and it measures beans for you. I did not notice much difference between the coarseness of the grind even when changing the setting but it is okay for us because we are just making drop coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: inconsistent grind, not fine enough for espresso
reviews.reviewText: been using this for a few months and its time to rethink. On its finest setting, The grind is inconsistent, and one in 4 or 5 times is it grinding fine enough to pull a decent espresso shot... the other times, might as well be making drip coffee. Might be fine enough for drip/French press coffee, but if you want good espresso, this is not the grinder for you... Its also the loudest grinder ive come across.

Nice all-around grinder. Not many fines in coarse settings, and does okay on the espresso / Turkish end of things. Well made for the price, I'm actually more than thrilled with how this has worked (currently traveling, have many much more expensive grinders at home).

If you want something to help enjoy your press or moka pot with, get this grinder. If you make a ton of espresso using expensive machines, well, you can use this too, but you probably want to step up your grinder game by about $200 more if that's the case (it's a nice grinder, not a miracle for under $50).

No hesitation recommending this to anyone that just needs good all-around grinder for their press / pot / percolator / stovetop espresso maker / etc.

I use this at my business, I own a small pizza shop and only make a pot a day so it’s not getting heavy duty wear and tear, I love the push button ease of this, you set it on how many cups you’re making and it automatically stops, makes everything easy. So far it’s been wonderful! I owned this years ago and loved it, but it didn’t last so i’m Hoping that they made improvements over the years. So far so good!

reviews.reviewTitle: Glad I got this great grinder!
reviews.reviewText:
I have been using my grinder for coarse/medium-coarse grounds for a French press. Before this I used a blade grinder which I would pulse several times to get the coarse grind I needed but it was inconsistent. This grinder has taken the guess work out of the equation and given a much more consistent grind. I have noticed an increase in flavor and a pleasant aroma each time I’ve used grounds from this grinder.

At first I was hoping to only grind what I needed but I ground too much the very first time. Even so, the resulting coffee was still better than when using my blade grinder.

It takes a little bit of tweaking to know the right settings for a specific brewing method. It tends to grind a little finer than I think, so I usually lean a little more to the coarser side and have been getting good results.

There are several drawbacks to this budget friendly burr coffee grinder: 1) Its insanely loud. I thought all the other reviewers were overreacting until I heard it for myself. I feel like I need earplugs to use it. 2) You have limited control over how much coffee is ground. You select how many cups you want to brew for and hope that you get more or less what you want. I am using this for pour over brewing, so I need more precise control. Putting only the amount of beans you want to grind into the canister doesn't work because the beans end up hopping around inside the canister and do not get ground. 3) I get about a tsp of finely ground coffee near the mouth opening of the grounds container, even though my setting is medium/coarse. I just scoop it out and toss it, but not sure why this is occurring. All in all, for the price - its okay.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does a great job of grinding coffee beans on the coarse setting
reviews.reviewText: Does a great job of grinding coffee beans on the coarse setting. We use this for cold brew. There are a couple of issues however. Although the canister that catches the ground coffee is not a bad size, I wish it were even bigger--especially since when you fill the top part, the bottom part cannot catch all of that. So it stops several times and has to be emptied. Which leads to the next problem--the ground coffee sticks to the sides and top of the plastic catcher. So, for me, and the amount of coffee I grind at once, it's kind of messy.
This is a solid 3/5 star item. This is my third burr grinder. They usually last a year or so. They start to clog up with grinds on the inside. It is also very messy while grinding.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder at a great price
reviews.reviewText:
As a budding coffee enthusiast, I looked long and hard at the grinders here and different information regarding blade versus burr grinders. Apparently, burr grinders produce less heat (preserves the taste) and make more consistent grinds than a blade grinder and so the former is preferable to the latter. With that, I also found that the blade grinders weren't that much cheaper than a burr grinder like this one so I opted for this product.

I must say that I am VERY pleased with my purchase. Like others have said, if you are expecting this thing to never make any powder, or to make perfectly super finely ground coffee, you're hoping too much for it. For my purposes, I don't want my coffee ground that finely anyway---I drink coffee from a french press, so it's supposed to be more coarsely ground. I really like how you can set how much coffee you want, hit the Start button, and it will stop on its own. From what I understand, for the blade grinders you have to sit around and push the button until you get the consistency you want.

Yes, this guy makes noise---but would you think that something that is pulverizing coffee beans into smaller grains is going to be a silent affair? I actually am amused by the noise it makes and enjoy watching the beans falling down and coffee being shot into the grind chamber. Besides, unless you're constantly grinding coffee, the noise lasts for at most about a minute, less if you don't grind that much at a time (I only set it between about the "8-12 cup" range on the machine)

Strangely, I don't have that much of an issue with static with the plastic grind chamber, which is a complaint I've read more frequently here in the reviews. Yet, I live in an area that has very dry air, hence I would think it would be a bigger problem. When I take the grind chamber out, I just give it a couple light taps (to get the grinds to settle a bit), pull it out, and dump the coffee into its personal airtight container. I then just flick the powdery leftover from the chamber body and lid into the sink and wash them. I'm not sure what's going on with other owners in having the "static cling" problem.

I think this grinder is a perfect start-up machine for anyone getting into grinding their own coffee. If you're using it to make coffee for a french press, through a drip coffee maker (in other words, nothing that needs super consistent, super fine grinds), I think this will do it for you. If a buyer does not have unrealistic expectations of what this machine can do, I think he or she will be very satisfied with the purchase.

UPDATE: January 2011

I just wanted to throw out there that this guy is still trucking along just fine. And I still don't have a static problem either, even though I live in the desert, and it's dry as all get-out here. Unless you're a true coffee connoisseur / coffee snob, this grinder will definitely be more than enough for most everyday needs. I actually stop and watch the beans go down and listen to them get ground up....so the noise issue that people complain about isn't an issue for me. Combine this guy with a french press and you've got absolutely divine coffee.

UPDATE: March 2012

This is *still* chugging along great! So I'm not sure what may have happened with anyone who suffered a durability issue; might have been just the individual product. Still producing great grinds for great coffee =) Noisy enough to scare my cats but a non-issue for the 30 seconds or so it's working at a time for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Received March 11th - it stopped working April 16th - return deadline April 13th!
reviews.reviewText: I initially liked this item very much. Ground the exact amount needed for brewing and at the coarse level I wanted. BUT - after using it maybe once a day since March 12th - day after receiving it till April 16th - it just quit working. Apparently my return date expired April 13. Also, had been on vacation from April 2 through the 15th so it didn't get used during that time. Now what? Can't return? Paid for a defective item that I can't return or exchange? DONM"T BUY THIS PRODUCT! Fortunately I kept my 20 year old coffee grinder that just never gives up.

We've been using this for several months and I can't tell you how much I hate it. It grinds on a timer, so you can't just hold down a button until you get enough coffee. It's extremely loud and sounds like someone cutting a cinder block in half with a chainsaw. I get up an hour before everyone else, when the house is all nice and quiet, but if I want to enjoy coffee I have to endure about thirty seconds of a machine shop murder soundtrack at 120 decibels and risk waking everyone else in the house up. And on top of that, it doesn't grind the coffee evenly. Half of it is dust. It's messy and the powedery coffee sticks to the sides of the canister so you have to use a spoon to get it all. I can't believe I paid money for this.

Loudest bean grinder ever. Pulls double-duty, grinding beans to your chosen preference and will help wake your husband in the morning. Unfortunately, it will also wake your children. Shut their bedroom door and turn the volume up on the sound machine before grinding those beans. Love that it will grind a larger volume than those cheap small blade grinders. A little costly, but so far it seems to be holding up and doing well...and I live on coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: Durable, well priced grinder delivers consistent, even grind for great aroma, flavor and extraction
reviews.reviewText: Bought to replace dead Cuisinart blade grinder which lasted 8 plus years as a backup. Former GM of Kona coffee distributor..so a bit of a coffee addict/snob no longer able to use company grinders. This burr grinder delivers and is priced well for its capabilities. Takes a little usage to learn how to optimize and it is a bit noisy. But it delivers good quality, consistent output whether using a drip or French press or other brewing approach. It can get hot if used extensively like grinding a whole 24 oz bag all at once...and can shut down to cool. But after 5 minutes it was fine. So far so good.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product at a great price!
reviews.reviewText: For what I paid, I wasn't expecting such a quality product. Set up is very simple, the coffee is ground to a uniform consistency and the automation lets me start grinding beans and do something else while I wait for it to finish. Only a couple small downsides: 1) Seems like static (or something) makes coffee grounds stick to the side and lid of the bin... and then fall off when you remove the lid, so I always seem to end up with a little spilled coffee grounds on my counter, no matter how careful I am. 2) It's pretty noisy. Not much chance of grinding beans in the AM for a surprise cup of coffee for your sleeping loved ones!

I like this product because of the adjustable grind AND the automatic feature. I think the coffee is ground better and I actually can taste the difference compared to my old braun grinder where I kept pushing down on the lid until I guessed about when to stop. I like to make french press as well as drip and the grinds for those should be different. The only drawback as I can tell is if you don't use a brush to remove the grind from the container, you end up with bits of coffee all over. In the old grinder, I just tapped the grind into the brewing basket. I think I can get used to that for better tasting coffee.

We are on our second Cuisinart coffee grinder. We love that we can grind enough coffee for a twelve cup pot. I also like that I can adjust the grind from fine to course. We make both drip and French press coffee.
Our first grinder lasted 3 years and then needed replacing. Unfortunately the container that holds the grounds completely broke last week. I had saved the one from our old machine so thought we had been saved. Not so, I went to use the ground coffee this morning and noticed a piece of plastic in the coffee grounds. Ordered a replacement container since our grinder is less than a year old. It will take about 8 days to get here! I’m not a happy camper. Had I purchased a new grinder, it would have arrived tomorrow. By the way, the lid is not included with the replacement.

Simple to set up and operate. Relatively low mess; the grounds container is easy to clean. Regardless of grind setting, it always leaves an amount of very fine powder in the grind. This clumps up at the front of the container and can be scooped out - which is necessary if you happen to be making cold press and filtering it with a #4 cone (I didn't realize this the first time I used the grinder and that batch took hours to filter when it usually takes about 20 minutes). Fine for the price, but I'll consider upgrading to something more consistent in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: great grind, huge mess! stopped working entirely
reviews.reviewText:
I love the way it grinds the coffee. I like my coffee finely ground. So in terms of taste and grinding performance, it's great.
But it makes such a huge mess every time i use it! The finely ground coffee seems to create static electricity, so when I uncover the box with the coffee after it is ground, coffee flies everywhere. I have tried everything i can think of to avoid this and cannot find a suitable solution. Because of the big mess, I've started grinding my coffee weekly rather than daily--which somewhat defeats the purpose of having a home grinder.

My other minor complaint is that there does not appear to be any convenient way to empty the hopper on top. For instance, let's say i fill it with caffeinated coffee and grind it, and there's some leftover on the top. Then i want to grind decaf. i have to tip over the machine and turn it upside down to get the caffeinated beans out so i can grind the decaf.

bottom line--i find the coffee great for use, evenly ground, etc. The mess this makes is a nuisance.

This is an addendum: The grinder stopped working completely on its 10th use or so. I wrote the manufacturer and they sent me another--but I'm afraid to use it! Lots of reports online about the thing clogging up with coffee and then stopping entirely. I cleaned and cleaned it but could not get it to start again. Completely dead. buyer beware.

Given it's relatively low cost (by comparison), I really hoped I'd like this unit but I think I will end up trying to sell it. First, it has 18 grind settings but the difference from one setting to the next is basically imperceptible so there's a lot of trial and error. It could easily be pared down to 1/2 that many settings, maybe even a 1/3. That's more a comment than a complaint however. The biggest con of this unit is the plastic hopper (wish I had taken other reviewers comments more seriously) and the static cling. It is a royal PITA. Good coffee beans are not cheap and the waste and the mess from this hopper is unacceptable. You can't pour the ground coffee from the hopper directly into a filter basket as it makes a mess. I have to put it into a another (glass) container and even that makes a mess. Sorry Cuisinart, Reduce the number of settings, use a glass receptacle, and you'll have a really good product rather than an OK one.

I liked the grinder. It had multiple settings, ground well and had limited static when grinding.

But it died two weeks after the one year anniversary of my purchasing it. I took it apart and it wasn't dirty at all. Internally it was sparkling clean. No mechanical problems at all. It simply committed electronic suicide. So unless you feel one year is an acceptable service life (I have a Scala burr grinder that's around 25 years old and still working) I'd stay away from this one and look at an alternative brand.

reviews.reviewTitle: The loudness wouldn't be too bad if it wasn't such a high frequency but as ...
reviews.reviewText:
It's okay. I bought this after getting tired of manually grinding beans with a hand held conical burr grinder. I heard that the disc burr grinders were less consistent than the conical burr grinders but I figured it would get the job done. It does work, but the grind consistency is definitely sub-par. I usually grind only enough for a single serving of coffee and there is substantially more dust and small particles than the $27 handheld conical burr grinder. I haven't done a side by side test but the consistency seems to be barely a cut above a blade grinder. The other issue is that this grinder is fairly loud. The loudness wouldn't be too bad if it wasn't such a high frequency but as it is, it is not very pleasant to turn on.

Overall, for the $39 I paid it is a decent product and decent value. It looks nice, has a large capacity hopper, and is much faster than a hand held grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is not the burr grinder you are looking for.
reviews.reviewText: I waited a few months prior to reviewing this product. This product is not worth your money. If I could send it back, I would. First, this is not a true burr grinder. It is a burr plus blade. It provides inconsistent grinds. It is also incredibly difficult to clean, and generates a large mess. It’s is too loud to use as a daily grinder, and well, any time grinder. I essentially have to do all my beans at once to avoid the frequent assault to my ears. This grinderdoes not grind small amounts well. Once the hopper is 1/4 full or less the beans do not stay in the grinding area because of the blade. It takes a substantial amount of time to grind them. I would either pick another more expensive burr grinder, or just settle for a blade grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works great but makes a mess.
reviews.reviewText: This grinder works great, so far. The bin keeps the beans fresh, and the burr grinder really releases the flavor of the beans. And I love being able to tap the grind button while I go about getting the other items ready to make coffee. The only draw back is that it makes a solid mess. And the little brush included makes things worse. I'd love to hear some pointers about how not to get coffee grounds all over the place. I use a cone filter, and have started sitting it the sink to hold it upright. Then I rinse the rest of the mess down the drain. I haven't seen a better design at this price point, so I'd likely buy this again.

reviews.reviewTitle: I love the size and how it looks sitting on my ...
reviews.reviewText: I love the size and how it looks sitting on my kitchen counter although my husband comments every time I use it that it’s the noisiest grinder he’s ever heard. We do like our coffee strong so our beans tend to be more oily than most which meant I needed to clean this grinder often or the port where the grinds are distributed into the holding unit would often clog. I owned two of these grinders as my first one bought in Feb. 2016 lasted merely a month, I was sent another one at no charge but yesterday a little over a year later also just quit working. I’m disappointed for the money this grinder hasn’t lasted longer especially with the special care I was giving into it. Onto shopping for a more durable coffee grinder for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quality declined on second unit. Not recommended.
reviews.reviewText: I'm on my second one and it's totally shot after 6 months use. The first one I had lasted only a few months until the circuit board went bad. I removed the board and put in a toggle switch for manual use. Got around 6 years of service out of it. Retired it due to plastic cracking in stress areas. Not too bad. But I should have saved the motor...Bought another here - refurbished. Box and unit looked new. No signs of use. 2 months, dead - same deal with the circuit board. Put in a toggle switch as before. Now the motor is shot. Lasted 6 months total. Never again.

This is a very cost effective alternative to a conical burr grinder. This works great! You get a beautiful uniform grind. I love the settings for amount to grind so you get a consistent pot of coffee every time. I use the setting a couple clicks finer than medium for my drip coffee maker. The only couple cons are that it is very loud and you have to occasional clean the port where it spits out the grounds as it can get clogged up. Also it can be messy trying to dump the grounds from the grinder into the coffee pot.

reviews.reviewTitle: not made to grind espresso fine beans per stated
reviews.reviewText: looking for very fine burr grinder for Cuban and espresso coffee... I did read the instruction booklet.. shopped around and thought this was great. I already have the old fashion coffee grinders which are now for spices (2) and coffee this Cuisinart supreme grinder ifs just for regular coffee...DEFINITELY not for espresso or Cuban.. even set on "fine" it doesn't grind fine enough....Great for brewed coffee , but then I already had a grinder for that or my french press or my drip.. Doesn't anyone make a fine grind coffee grinder????

reviews.reviewTitle: NOPE! FIND ANOTHER GRINDER - Lasted 2.5 months
reviews.reviewText:
Unit did its job at first but always sounded as if it were cheaply made. 2-1/2 months later, the motor starts performing slower and eventually refused to even grind the beans while the grinder ran very sluggish. Now, it does not even power on. Not even gonna waste my time with tech support, I'm sure they won't offer any replacement after this amount of time from purchase. Personally, go find another grinder.
Grinder looks sharp and like a good quality but didn't come close from this experience. I knew I should've returned it early before it actually gave up working. The JUNK that is made today!

reviews.reviewTitle: Many settings from course to fine. very loud
reviews.reviewText: meh. grinds well. Many settings from course to fine. very loud. One big issue I have is that the receptacle where the grounds end up is plastic (as is the whole unit) and there is a ton of static electricity that gets generated and when you pull the receptacle out to pour the grounds into your coffee maker the grounds fly all over because of the static. We have to grind at night, pull the receptacle out and set it on the granite overnight so the static electricity dissipates in the morning. Weird. Probably will be getting a new one, but not this brand.

Product is not built to last - I was not using this machine daily, maybe only three times a week. During those uses, I would grind at one of the most coarse settings, and would grind between 12 and 18 cups (18 being the max). Warranty is 18 months, and mine broke the week after the 18 months passed. The machine will not run at all now.
Reading the instruction book, Cuisinart asks that you send them $40 for shipping and handling in case of any repairs, which is costlier than the product itself.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not good even for low price.
reviews.reviewText:
Pros: Easy to clean, easy to use.

Cons: inconsistent grinds, settings don't change grind enough, can't grind fine enough for espresso, doesn't grind consistently enough for French press, lots of static cling in the grounds chamber.

I picked this grinder up when it was on sale for $35. I should've known what I was getting at that price for a burr grinder. First of all this is a disk burr grinder NOT a conical burr grinder, if you really care about your coffee a conical burr grinder will give you a much better grind. But back to this grinder, there are different courseness settings but they don't actually change the grind all that much. This grinder also doesn't grind fine enough for espresso, and the course setting is not consistent enough for French press, you will have lots of fine grinds in your coffee that don't get pressed out. This grinder will work fine for people who use autodrip machines with paper filters, there will be some fine grounds that will make it through reusable filters. The plastic grounds chamber is not the best either, the grounds really like to stick to it's surfaces and you will need to wash it out and dry it after every use. This unit is easy to use, and easy to clean. It includes a cheap cleaning brush. The bean storage is not airtight, but at this price I didn't expect that. I would not recommend this grinder to others.

reviews.reviewTitle: could be improved to keep the ground coffee from spilling all over
reviews.reviewText: bought this after I purchased a manual grinder which took way too long to get enough ground coffee for one cup. This one grinds very well; however, it is very noisy so grind at night if you don't want to wake up everyone everyone asleep in the morning. Another quirk or should I say problem with this grinder, is getting the ground coffee out of the plastic container after grinding. The hole is so small and the lid does not stay on =ing a mess of ground coffee all over your counter (and sometimes your floor). Cuiinart needs to have it's designers/engineers create a collection container that is less likely to dump your freshly ground coffee all over your kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the job but has problems
reviews.reviewText:
Like a lot of users say, this was my first burr grinder, so I bought the cheapest available. It is definitely better than the old blade grinder I used, much more uniform grind and same grind every day. That being said, there are problems, some of which are also posted by other users.

Problem No. 1 is that mine quit working in mid-grind after about 3 months. The company service department was very helpful, immediately sent me a new one on condition I would pay shipping for the new one and send the old one back. Then the same thing happened to the second one after three more months. Same exchange. I am now $50 more or less into shipping costs for the exchanges, more than I paid to start with. But the service is quick, at least.

Problem No. 2 is that the three grinders were very different. I fill it every time using 64 grams of coffee for an 8-cup pot. The first grinder took about 60 sec. to grind that much, and was barely coarse enough for my Bonavita filter brewer even when I set the grinder to the coarsest setting. The second grinder had a better texture of grind but it took a ridiculously long time to grind one pot's worth of coffee--up to 2 1/2 minutes sometimes, very annoying considering how noisy the thing is. The third grinder is by far the best. I get the grind I want on the fourth from coarsest setting, and it zips through a 64 gram pot's worth of beans in 30 seconds.

I am wondering, is there bad quality control, or are these things made in more than one factory, or what?

I have read on line that sometimes the stopping problem isn't the motor going out but some switches that can be cleaned or bypassed. I think next time this third machine of mine stops working, I will take it apart and see if I can fix it rather than spend another $25 on postage and maybe get another one that doesn't grind as well as this one I have now.

As user after user has said, you get what you pay for.

From my experience these grinders last about five years of every day use which I think is pretty good. Definitely not the best coffee grinder you can buy but one of the cheapest burr grinders. To get a better one you would probably have to spend another hundred dollars. Also if you like to make espresso I would spend the bucks on a better one, But for a drip machine or a French press these are perfectly adequate. They do produce a fair amount of dust especially with finer grinds and old beans.

reviews.reviewTitle: Overall pleased with function but has a couple of flaws.
reviews.reviewText:
Positive features: consistent grind size, easy to use, great for freshly ground coffee
Negative features: VERY loud (but I expected it to be loud), and because it has a. plastic collection bin, it causes an incredible amount of static so grounds stuck to the sides and lid which is frustrating and messy.
Overall I’m pleased with this grinder as a beginner. I may upgrade to a more expensive option with a glass or stainless steel collection bin at some point but I’m perfectly pleased to use this one now.

For a burr grinder this one is extremely nice and very quiet compared to our last one. The last one sounded like it was ready to blow up at any time and it was from a much more expensive company. Like you'd have to brace yourself before pressing the start button if people were sleeping in the house. Lets just say this one I can't always tell when coffee is ready, and that's not a bad thing. Works exactly like it should and exactly as advertised.

reviews.reviewTitle: on the 3rd grinder in a year; look for something else!
reviews.reviewText: The first grinder worked for 6 months then suddenly wouldn’t grind or do anything at all. The second one worked for 2 weeks then had the same problem, stopped grinding. I’m getting a new one under warranty but I don’t expect it to last very long.

so i bought this because i have been turned on to the amazing world of cold brew coffee and fresh course ground coffee beans tast better than pre-ground. this allows me to gring my coffee just hte way i like... but dont plan on holding a conversation while you are grinding. yes its noisy when its operating but not too sure what to compare it to as this is also my first grinder. been using it for over a year and have had no complaints.

I've had this unit since Mid-September 2014 and so far it has performed adequately. And herein lies my 4 star rating: it is an adequate grinder but not superb. My gripe being that at it's finest setting it still doesn't grind small and evenly enough to yield great results when paired with my espresso machine. I'm not sure if the grind will improve with usage . . . hoping it will. Construction is solid, hopper capacity is fine, slider control feels a bit flimsy but I've basically left it in the same position since the first time I used it. Operation is fairly clean but static is not your friend here as the ground coffee sticks to the walls of the receptacle and the lid. Just empty the contents from the receptacle over the sink to avoid too much cleanup. I'm sure this grinder will work fine for other coffee preparation applications but definitely not the best match for an espresso machine.

This was a replacement: For years I hated how loud the old one was... Like a lawn mower in your kitchen at 5am. I used this once for the first time and I swear it's like theres a jet taking off in my fkn kitchen. So much noise. SO MUCH. Returning it for that reason alone. Why can't they make these things quieter? I think I just woke up my neighbors :l

reviews.reviewTitle: This is a "back up grinder" for us.
reviews.reviewText: Haven't even opened this one yet, but it is an exact replacement for the one we have, which is starting to act funny. We have had one of these for about 4 years and we grind coffee beans every day. Every once in awhile it gets sorta plugged up and I have to take it apart (easy) and clear out a build up of packed grounds, but this only happens about 4 times a year and takes maybe 10 minutes. However, the current one, (our 1st original one) is having trouble starting up when the hopper is full. I assume this is a sign that the electric motor is beginning to weaken, If I play with it enough it will finally get going and grind 12 more cups of beans, and then might work great for several days and the have that problem again. So I purchased one as a back up so that when the original completely croaks, we will have a replacement on hand.

reviews.reviewTitle: SOOOOO much better than a hand grinder. Read the measurements.
reviews.reviewText:
Updated review may 2017; my beloved grinder died today. Just totally quit on me with no warning. One month past 18 month warranty~~~ hmmm.

Will do more research, but if I buy another, I'll definitely purchase extended warranty.

Bought after trying a hand cranked burr grinder. It was hardly any more money than that one anyway. Also, the manual grinder did not have a calibration for grind size either -- my real deal-breaker, since I use for both drip and cold drip. Sure love the ease of use! Kind of noisy. I was surprised however, how fine the coffee gets chopped. I have to use almost the coarsest setting for drip coffee, and the coarsest for cold drip. Someday I will try espresso, and I have no doubt it will grind finely enough.

Use it every two days or so, and it matches nicely with my Cuisinart coffee maker. It is big! Read the measurements before you buy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not last its own warranty period!!
reviews.reviewText: I bought this Coffee Grinder in 3/29/2016 & used carefully according to instruction for less than 20 times, for no apparent reasons it just stopped working on 07/19/18, it just went dead. Very disappointed and will advise anyone not to buy this product, because it's not durable that it couldn't even last its own 18 months warranty period!! Now I have to go through the trouble of contact the manufacturer to have them honor their warranty which I have never experienced until now.

reviews.reviewTitle: I am completely satisfied with this disk burr grinder
reviews.reviewText: I spent many hours researching coffee grinders before I bought this one. I did not want a combination coffee maker/grinder. I wanted them separate because you're not going to get a burr grinder in a moderately priced coffee maker and I'm not going to spend a fortune for a coffee maker, grinder included or not. I would rather have a conical burr grinder but you're not going to find one for this price. I am completely satisfied with this disk burr grinder. I love coffee, but I don't require the finest ground, best tasting coffee in the world.

Great product, I just ground enough coffee to make 9 cups There was no mess or dust scattered around the grinder like my previous grinder. (Bodum) It ground the coffee perfectly to the right grit. It was no louder than any other grinder I have used. It seems pretty easy to clean. I'm happy with it the Only negative thing I can think of is I wish the cord was a bit longer. I would recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent Burr Grinder with a Very Few Minor Issues
reviews.reviewText: Excellent burr grinder for 1/4 the price of the high end machines. Many different grind settings and all do a great, consistent job. Only downside is that the grind hopper/container is plastic, which the ground coffee sticks to - it should have been glass!. Love the various settings for grind consistency and cup sizes, makes grinding just the right amount very easy. Do buy a brush for the hopper though - the included brush is very small and very stiff and doesn't work all that well, but for the price and features of this burr grinder, it can't be beat. Looking forward to a long ownership and usage of this essential piece of coffee equipment.

This product has nice features with the quantity control, as well as varied settings for coarse to thin grinds. So, I was very excited to find something like this at this price point. But that's where my excitement ended.

The product is unusually noisy, relative to other grinders that I've owned. It took about 20 minutes to grind 1.35 pounds of espresso beans, which is unacceptably long. Then the motor overheated and would not function. I had to wait another hour for the unit to cool in order to complete the remaining 0.15 pound.

While the product attempts to encapsulate the grind - ultimately it does not do a good job and the grind was everywhere and required a fair amount of clean-up to the unit and the surrounding area

reviews.reviewTitle: Loud, coffee grind container is hard to use and makes a mess!!
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is exceptionally loud even by coffee grinder standards. Additionally, the square coffee grind container is hard to use. I like the feature set and the semi-automatic grinding .. but the container and noise suck! It's impossible to use without making a mess and over time it just becomes messier. I wish I had picked another grinder. It does grind well .. but that's it.

As other reviewers have noted, this grinder produces a fair amount of extremely fine, espresso level grounds with each grind - even when using the most course option. This results in wasted coffee at best, to overextracted and difficult to manage brews at worst.
If you're using a standard drip coffee pot, this isn't a huge deal. If you're using a pourover or aeropress, this is a dealbreaker.
I wish I could return this and get something more consistent, but I'm outside my return window.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good Grinder for the price point
reviews.reviewText: I Have had this grinder for about a year, and here is how I use it. First off, I primarily use my grinder on its finest setting as I use a Melitta cup top coffee hopper with #2 cone filters. Their cheap and make a good cup of coffee. Yes there is always dust that statically clings to the collection hopper due to the acrylic material. I simply fill my cone over the sink and wash the "dust" down the sink. Do I lose some coffee? sure I do. But it is a very small amount. Cleaning the chute is a breeze using a toothpick before I grind. I find that I have to do this about once a week. I just tilt the machine back slightly, clean the chute and slide the hopper back into place (while I still have it tilted back) to catch the residue and it makes no mess. I also find that no matter which setting I have it on, there is a certain amount of dust. On the occasions that I use it to make a pot of drip when we are having guests over; I set it on a medium grind and it does the trick perfectly. The coarser the grind, the lesser dust the machine makes. Again, you must consider the price point of this machine. I have yet to have any bogging problems that I have read about in some of the other reviews and I have never removed the bean hopper to clean it? All in all, I think this machine is hard to beat for the price point.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good, but too fast and furious!
reviews.reviewText: Works as advertised, but the motor should run much more slowly. It takes several cycles to get all the beans processed because they're constantly being thrown back up into the hopper. Grind is pretty consistent, definitely good enough for my needs, very good for a non-conical burr mill.

reviews.reviewTitle: The Grind is easily adjustable and produces great coffee. 5 *'s if they can find a way to cut the noise in half.
reviews.reviewText:
Dear God this think is LOUD! Sounds like a vacuum cleaner choking on Legos. Forget about holding a conversation while this thing is running.
The Grind is easily adjustable and produces great coffee. 5 *'s if they can cut the noise in half.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for the price, but not a consistent enough grind for French Presses
reviews.reviewText:
Pros:
- Considering the price, it's much better than using in-store grinders (hint: don't).
- Based on what I've heard from some friends/colleagues about their grinders & how much they had to pay for similar performance, it's a good deal.
- Quite a few grind adjustment settings.

Cons:
- The big one: just too much fine powder in the course grind. By the time I finish the last cup of coffee, there's so much sludge left that it feels like I'm drinking turkish coffee (exaggeration, but it's bad). I've heard that, even with the best manufacturers, you're not getting a great grinder for less than $100. This proves it. Maybe it's better for pour-overs or drip makers.
- There aren't enough 'cup' settings. I end up with not enough grounds, or too many.

Summary:
- If you want to enter the world of grinding your own coffee, it's a good start if you only have $50. It's definitely good enough for me for now. But I'll definitely upgrade when I get an opportunity.

We LOVE all things Cuisinart, and have found their products to be such high quality. However, this is the second time we purchased this burr grinder - the old one stopped working and we assumed we just needed a new one. Almost immediately, this one malfunctioned. My husband takes it apart and cleans it almost daily, and it does not grind the beans. Upon conducting further research, we learned that burr grinders with plastic are generally just not effective, and have since ordered a model that is completely metal from another company. This product is not made well and is frustrating on a daily basis -- put your money toward an inexpensive grinder or a higher quality metal option.

I've only had this for about a month but am very pleased. I like being able to store coffee beans in the top portion. The lid fits well so the beans don't seem to lose flavor. Once the number of cups and grind consistency is set, pressing one button to start grinding is a big plus for me. It is not quiet but not any louder than the Braun I used for years. Cleaning is easy; it comes with a scoop/brush but I bought a cleaning brush which is a bit larger.

I love this grinder! It is actually the 2nd one I have purchased. Very easy to set/adjust your grind texture and you can set the amount that it grinds each time with the little slider so you get a consistent grind every day.
Why 4 instead of 5:
1. The lower edges of the grind cup chip off - but it doesn't affect the function at all
2. Since it is plastic, the interior of the grind cup essentially has been sandblasted by the grinds shooting out - doesn't interfere with function (but the grinds do gather up on those areas)
3. A little difficult to clean - you NEED to unscrew the hopper at least once a month and clean inside where the burrs are, but the interior area is hard to get to to really clean it well, I didn't realize my this needed to be done on my first one and it ended up breaking because of this after 2 years - but I bought another one because I loved it so much (and have given them as gifts).

Update: 2017 - Still have the same grinder 7 years later and it's working like a champ! I clean it about once a month, more if the coffee is very is oily. But no issues!

This is the most disappointing purchase ever. Coffee grounds all over the counter when I finally got it to grind! It shut on and off over and over ran a few seconds than stopped. I don't even want to continue this review it makes me angry all over again. Coffee everywhere!

reviews.reviewTitle: Use it daily, worth my hard earned money.
reviews.reviewText: For the money this is a great buy. Only two complaints are the static electricity build up causes caking, and it doesn't grind as consistently as others (even on the coarse setting there is a fine powder). My guess is the motor spins too fast for a even grind. I roast my own so I use this grinder for everything from an Aero Press to a French press and the lesser drip coffee maker as well. A must more consistent grind than any of the blade grinders I've used.

Despite the clean, convenient look it has, it makes a BIG mess every time you grind coffee beans. Coffee grounds get stuck on the lid, and they falls off whenever you open the bin, which messes up your tabletop. You have to clean the bin with the stupid brush they provide EVERY TIME before you can use the grounds. This is not worth $35.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great once you figure out the directions.
reviews.reviewText: I do like this grinder although I had to have a friend figure out how to make it work. The directions aren't that good. And, be sure the vessel clicks in place after pouring in the beans or coffee will fly all over the kitchen. Once you start it, it won't stop until the beans are completely ground, otherwise, pull the plug if it's not on tight. However, once I got used to it, I love it because I can grind coffee for the regular coffee maker and my french press. If I didn't want a grinder which could grind course coffee as well, I would have stuck with the old fashioned one grind one.

Having ground my own whole beans for 4 decades - with many different grinders - this grinder's 'preset the number of cups to grind' - has proven to be its best feature. It is nice to no longer have to either measure the amount of beans to be ground - or to have to measure the amount being removed - just so simplifies the whole process.

I purchased this coffee grinder when my 8 year old Cuisinart, grind and brew, coffee maker finally bit the dust. I replaced the coffee maker with another Cuisinart that does not have the grinder built in. I've been using this grinder every morning for about two weeks. Although it is quite loud in it's operation the grinder works well. The grinder has a number of settings from fine to coarse. I would recommend the use of a pastry brush to help remove some of the fine residue from the lower hopper.

I didn’t realize until I was doing the review it’s suppose to have airtight storage for the beans.. well it doesn’t. But we go through so much coffee, it’s not a big deal. So far haven’t had to clean mine, but it does make a bit of a mess when pulling the coffee compartment off. And it’s noisy, but doesn’t wake my kids in the morning noisy.. if ya know what I mean. Over all good grinder, looks nice in the counter, I’d buy it again If I needed to.

Ordered from Amazon. Ready to grind right after 90 day warranty from Amazon, so had to use Cuisenart warranty. Grinder didn’t work straight out of box. Cuisenart makes us pay $4 to ship new unit that hopefully works, and then have to cut cord and mail back to them so they have proof. Should have gone to brick and mortar store. Seems more stuff arriving broken. Feels wrong that Cuisenart charging us for their broken product. I think it will cost them more than $4 in the long run, as I’ll remember my experience.

I will admit that I did not want to spend big bucks on a burr grinder so I was looking for a cheaper option. This is the one. I love this grinder. It provides a great and consistent grind. I usually do pour over coffees and this does great for the more fine grind. Some other reviews have pointed out that more coarse grinds for a French press brew don't come out well. I have not had a problem at all. So far every setting has worked well!

The only reason I am giving it 4 stars is it can be a bit messy to pour the fresh grind out of the 'catching bin.' I tend to use pretty fresh and oily beans so the grinder beans tend to stick to the side of the catching bin. When I tap the bin, fine coffee grind goes everywhere. That might a a little bit picky, but I thought it was worth to let you all know of.

Overall, love this grinder! Super happy I have it and helps make the coffee brewing process better for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Gettin' nothin' but static from Channel Z
reviews.reviewText:
Nice grinder, doesn't quite grind as fine as the big commercial ones like they have at Starbucks but you can still get a fairly fine espresso grind on the finest setting. Of course, as any electrical engineer will tell you, if you spin a metal blade at high speed through a dielectric material like, say, coffee, you're going to end up storing a huge amount of static electric charge. Then if you store that statically charged material in a non-conducting container, say, the plastic bin on the Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill, when you open said container, you'll get a flurry of tiny, statically-charged coffee particles flying everywhere and sticking to everything.

Possibly if you live in a climate that's humid year-round and/or don't set the grinder to the finest setting, your kitchen won't be covered in clingy brown dust every time you make coffee. And possibly if the designers had made the bin out of metal instead of plastic, it would have reduced the static build-up (inside joke for electrical engineers: I need to ground my coffee).

So other than the mess it's awesome. Makes great espresso, just takes longer to clean up.

I've had this same brand of coffee mill for 10 years, but didn't read the booklet. I didn't know the hopper could be unscrewed to enable cleaning. For years the coffee dust built up and finally clogged everything to the point of my having to replace the mill. The cleaning procedure only takes a minute or two so I expect this new mill may last me for at least 20 years.

This Burr grinder is wonderful. just keep coffee in the hopper and you are ready to enjoy some really great coffee. It grinds the proper amount for your coffee maker from 2 -12 cups. in addition it can be adjusted to the fineness of the coffee to espresso to larger grind. What this does is make the coffee stronger to weaker so you can choose your taste and strength. Only negative is the static generated during grinding and dispensing the coffee some sticks to the walls of the receiver. However they provide you with a small brush and measuring spoon. I have had several grinders over the years this is the best I have ever had.

reviews.reviewTitle: Ground coffee spills out when pouring into french press, mocha pot, or espresso machine
reviews.reviewText: Grinds the coffee fine, but the part where you pour it out is just a clunky square shape. It's hard to pour it into the method of preparation (french press, mocha pot, espresso machine, etc.) without spilling like 5% of it, which is annoying. If it had a shape more like a pitcher that would funnel the ground beans into the receptacle without spillage, that would make it 5 stars. And yes, I know it comes with a scooper and brush thing, which can be used for some of the ground beans,but if you want to get it all out you'll still need to turn it upside down and make a mess. Maybe with a drip coffee filter it's fine, but why have a nice grinder for a basic drip coffee anyway? Much cheaper, smaller options exist if that's all you want.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent product. Less than ideal return process.
reviews.reviewText:
Got this grinder as a Christmas present in 2016. Worked really well for the first four months (thus, the two stars), but today, it stopped working. Grinding slowed, then stopped. Opened the lid and smelled melted plastic.

So I called the CuisineArt customer service line. They warranty their products for 18 months--that's good, and they'll ship a new unit out right away, but the unfortunate customer will be liable for a $10.00 shipping and return shipping fee for a replacement. Also, the return box does won't have the return address on it (the rep had to give me that address). AND, if that wasn't enough, I was also given a 15 character "service number" to write on the outside of the box as well as on a piece of paper that was to be inserted inside the box, along with my check for $10.00. I guess I've been spoiled by Amazon's very friendly return process. CuisineArt's return process is very customer unfriendly and I get to pay $10.00 for the privilege? Nope. I'll look for another grinder from another company, and I'll keep this experience in mind when I shop for other CuisineArt products knowing this may be my misfortune again if another product dies under warranty. Thankfully, other options are available.

My coffee mill looks just like the DBM-8 but has a model number of CCM-16PC1 with the same title 'Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill'. For around $40 you cannot beat this coffee mill. I have not seen any failures mentioned in other reviews after months of daily use.

The grind size quality is good. you get 80% of what you want and 20% is a little smaller or larger. This coffee mill is perfect for drip coffee makers. There will be some static cling and some powered coffee to clean up periodically.

The lunatic fringe coffee people may be happier with a coffee mill that is a true burr coffee mill. This model has two rotating plates that does the coffee grinding. A true burr mill coffee grinder has two conical serrated metal rollers that grinds the coffee. These coffee mills can cost several hundred dollars but do turn out a more consistent uniform grind for the purists.

For the money, this coffee mill gets the job done for me. I previously used a krups $15 blade type coffee/spice mill.
Even on the coarsest setting this grinder was visually and physically too fine for my Linkyo French press coffee maker. A lot of sediment came thru the double stainless steel filters.

First off, it took me quite some time to discover some information about this product:

- That $90 list price is, of course, a fiction. If you go to [...], you'll find that it is offered for only about $10 more than on Amazon. Although manufacturers almost always sell to consumers at their list price, so as not to undercut their retail partners, in this case [...] actually is a retail outlet licensed to use the company's name.

- Models CCM-16PCI and DBM-8 are actually the exact same item. Manufacturers often make different "models" for specific retailers in order to make price comparisons difficult. According to Cuisinart (the manufacturer), the serial number on my CCM-16-PCI shows that it was made for Sam's Club.

Now, as to the product itself, I've been testing it with French-roast Jamaican Blue Mountain (an odd combination that I was given as a gift):

- I would buy it again, because there doesn't seem to be a better choice in this price range. The Burr Mill Adjustable/Pre-Programmed Coffee Grinder is cheaper, but it got horrible reviews.

- It works quickly.

- Insofar as it is noisy, because the unit works quickly I don't find it a problem. I am not, however, the earliest riser in the family; so there is not really anyone to disturb. It is quieter than my previous burr grinder.

- I wish the timer had a two-cup setting.

- Nowhere does Cuisinart give their definition of a "cup". A standard measuring cup is 8oz. Until a few years ago, most automatic coffee makers defined a cup as 6oz. When the standard capacity of an automatic coffee maker was changed from 10 cups to 12 cups, the size of a cup magically became 5oz. (Do the math, and learn something about marketing.) When I make my coffee, I start with 16oz. of water; so the four-cup setting isn't too far off. I like strong coffee.

- I found that the "medium" setting was perhaps a bit fine for use with my filter-and-cone brewing, but I'm still playing with it. I can't blame Cuisinart for that, as brewing techniques and preferences differ.

- At two notches coarser than medium, a couple of large bean chunks made it through. How, I don't know.

- I'll second all of the complaints about static electricity. The square corners on the receptacle make it difficult to get all of the coffee out without making a mess. My old Braun (no longer made) had rounded corners, so you could get closer with the scoop.

- Because of the static electricity, wiping or brushing the receptacle is messy. It's a good thing coffee grounds aren't sticky.

- The exit shoot on the grinder can't be brushed out with the receptacle in place, so anything that gets brushed out of there has no place to go except all over. Fortunately, I don't think much if anything accumulates in there.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked great for about a year
reviews.reviewText: I bought one of these about two years ago. After owning it for a year, it stopped working consistently. So I contacted Cuisinart and they replaced it for a small shipping fee. Ok, so far so good. Yesterday after less than a year, the replacement unit also died -- has that electrical 'short circuit' smell so obviously the little motor overheated and died. Frankly this is junk and landfill bait. If you want a 1 year device, buy this, otherwise look elsewhere.

This is our second. We love it. Old one lasted about 7 years until the teeth finally wore down. The one we bought this time made a louder noise. My wife called customer service and after hearing it, the tech agreed it didn't sound right. We had to pay 4.00 to get a replacement. They sent us a shipping label to return the old one, but no pre-pay. When we asked why, customer service said it was our responsibility to return it. So, we still have the first one too.

This works fine. It was my first burr grinder, and it's nice that it measures the amount for you and has multiple grind settings. The coffee tastes better than it did with a regular grinder. I decided to spend a little on this Cuisinart instead of what seemed like a lot on the KitchenAid. And I've had this for all of a couple of months. But I'm ordering the good one now. Don't waste your time and money and hearing. First, it's a complete mess, grinds everywhere because of the design and plastic cup. But the worst, worst thing: it's the loudest thing I've ever heard. It's just so loud. I didn't use my decibel meter but if I had, it would definitely be an osha violation. Like, it's so fricking loud. The cat runs and hides. It's louder than my husband's power tools and louder than any rock concert. And it's the first thing you hear in the morning. And so, you know, there it is. That's my review.

This grinder is pretty good. It is loud, and squeals a bit, but not as bad as everyone says. It doesn't deafen me at all.

I got this grinder to grind grains to make my own flour and it has delighted me thus far. I have been able to make my own brown rice flour and yellow pea flour. It grids as finely as a grainy wheat flour, and that is fine enough for me. It doesn't grind it to an aerosol powder, but is great for cookies or breads.

For coffee, this would do a fantastic expresso grind, but will barely do it. It will not be the finest expresso, but it will get the job done. For a cone type filter, or regular drip coffee, this grinder would be a delight. It is very nice and is a bit of a luxury item for coffee grinding.

For my purpose of grinding my own grains for flour, it does really well and allows me to make healthy foods cheaply. This is far less expensive than an electric grain mill, and I don't have to worry about blades breaking off or dulling over time, since it is a burr grinder.

As far as value for the money, this is a steal of a deal. It is so nice, and about the cost of a good little blade grinder.

I'm happy with this item. Hopefully it will last me a long time. I plan to use it a lot before the warranty expires to make sure.

Works great even fine ground for espresso etc. Still a little static and container and bottom of grinder has to be cleaned and or brushed out regularly. The one thing I dislike the most is that it is loud. Good price and does the job! Better than a blase grinder. Not as good as a vertical (conical) ceramic grinder. I would probably buy this again. Will see how long this one lasts.
no issues to date and works as intended. Just not that it is VERY loud.

reviews.reviewTitle: The selector is a nice feature with plenty of different coarse types
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to try a burr grinder. It holds a lot of beans; but doesn't clear all of them. To do 12 cups worth, I have to put it on 18 cups, and even then, have to start and stop it to turn all the beans into grounds. The selector is a nice feature with plenty of different coarse types. It's messier than a grinder type - as some other reviewers state "dusty". I don't know how Cuisinart would get around that, though - it's almost like there's static electricity when grinding. It's easy to dump the grounds into the coffeemaker, as long as they are not packed into the clear bin. The coffee it makes is much better than a regular grinder.

I've just had this for about a month and so far, so good. The grind is perfect whether I'm making French press or using my Moka pot. (lots of resources online from people about which settings to use for different brewing styles) The most frequent negative comment I read was about it breaking down early, which hasn't happened to mine. I'll update in a few months.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked well until it... didn't work!
reviews.reviewText:
I have used several mills and grinders, being a coffee aficionado. This one was actually pretty good for a fine grind. As others mentioned, it will not give a highly uniform grind. But I found it quite adequate. It was not used heavily, but I enjoy batch grinding for storing the grounds in a mason jar. It is quite noisy, as are most in this price point. Be sure to empty the plastic receptacle in the sink. Static makes the grounds go all over.

Now after a year of fine service, it suddenly sounded like it was climbing a steep grade - slowing.. slowing.. I thought of reaching for the extinguisher but thought maybe a coffee glob was in its feed throat. Nope; smells, then a very quiet grinder. I could not see its spirit leaving, but know that indeed - it was quite dead. May I use the common phrase now that most of these wonderful appliances are made outside the country: they really do not make things the way they used to!

Arrived very quickly with Prime next day. Packaged well. Sturdy little grinder. I read the instructions and then tried it out. Works really good.
Hopper Lid fits snug. Output container fits well. No issues taking it out or putting it back in. Noise level is right on par with other grinders I have used. Its about as perfect as you can get for the price.
For the average coffee drinker this is all you need. Why spend 5 times this amount?

reviews.reviewTitle: Good quality materials and good grind bit messy
reviews.reviewText: I love the capacity and it does a nice even grind. Con is that when grinding a lot (say 10 ounces for a cold brew batch) the grounds tend to spill out of the container as you remove it (not from static, which is a different issue unrelated to the specific product). This occurs even if you do not exceed the amount you're supposed to grind . So what ends up happening is a mess.

The grinder works with a lot of effort on my part. Unfortunately, I used a coffee bean that was coated with some sort of flavoring that caused the coffee beans to be somewhat sticky. Stickiness is not good for this grinder. The coffee tended to back up and plug in the exit to the receiving bin. The grinder tried to force the plug out, compacting the plug and making the problem worse. The grinder then apparently overheated and stopped. The beans also would not go through the opening into the grinder and would leave the grinder running with no coffee beans to grind.
