I purchased this grinder for my husband who likes fresh ground, specialty coffee. We have been using a blade grinder for many years and I figured that it was time for another one or a different type. I had heard that burr grinders were very good and this one came up in my email from Amazon because I had bought a Bunn Coffeemaker a few years ago. I priced other burr grinders and they were very expensive so I ordered this one for a start. We really like the fact that we just push a button and grinding is done quickly. We have found that, even though we like strong coffee, we can turn it to a medium setting and still get the same flavor.
Our only complaint is similar to a few of the reviews I had read earlier - that the grounds stick to the plastic container because of static electricity. Otherwise we are very happy with our purchase!

After fewer than six months of daily use, this grinder began to grind less and less coffee for each setting of the timer. It now requires four cycles of the 12-cup position to grind enough beans for an 8-cup carafe. One reviewer has suggested rigorous cleaning, but even that is of no avail. It goes for replacement (along with my $4) tomorrow, but I expect the same results. Instead,the writer who recommends a simple untimed blade grinder may be on the right track.
This unit was replaced under warranty by the factory at minimal return shipping cost. The replacement has been in daily use for several months and appears to be entirely satisfactory. Perhaps the key to my current pleasure is daily cleaning of the "exit window" which feeds the ground coffee into the collector. Build-up there can accumulate thick and fast and interfere with operation.

I had only used the little one serving, non-burr type and this Cuisnart is like a luxury to me. I like to grind coffee beans and use a french press. You need to have course ground coffee for best results with the french press and couldn't get that with the small, cheap grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Defective device and poor customer service
reviews.reviewText: I was initially very happy with this product. Quick and produced delicious coffee. Almost immediately, however, my husband and I noticed that the process was pretty messy. The coffee grinds stick to the container into which it grinds. Getting the ground coffee into the filter is no small feat. But, we tolerated that until the machine stopped working properly. It would get stuck and whir annoyingly, even though there were plenty of beans to grind. We would shake it gently or tap it to jar it into action. That worked for a while. Now, just 6 months after buying it, it has pretty much stopped working. I waited on hold with Cuisinart for 15 mins to find out that while the device is still under warranty, I have to pay $10 for them to ship me a replacement and then I have to pay to ship my defective device to them! That's about 1/2 of what I paid for the machine in the first place!

It is better than the ones with blades, If you like strong coffee, and want to get all the flavor, this is for you, if you are looking for a grinder that will allow you to get coarse grind without turning some of your coffee beans in to dust, and don't mind paying big bucks keep looking, I am going to try a manual grinder,

Very disappointed in the machine. I purchased it in December and on June 16th it quit working. Appliance man says motor burnt out.

REALLY? There is 2 in my household and we use it once per week!
The actual ground coffee from this is perfect. However, it does make a mess, at noted in other reviews. Keep it clean and it works just fine, this is probably the best option for under $100.

reviews.reviewTitle: 8 Years Old and Still Working Great!
reviews.reviewText: I bought my first Cuisinart DBM-8 Burr Grinder 8 years ago and have used it most everyday (except when on vacation) at least 2 times a day. Just bought my second one to have as a spare. After 8 years anything can wear out. I highly recommend this grinder. You can't go wrong with this purchase.
A little small, but works great
Very happy with this product.
Love the product!........worth the money and it was delivered as promised!
Loud, messy... not great experience...
This is a great product if you care about your grind.
Great little burr grinder.
Great machine. We have used it for over two years without any issues. Several grind options and cleans up well.
Fue devuelto por no funcionar

reviews.reviewTitle: Metal shavings in my coffee! DO NOT BUY!!
reviews.reviewText:
Received this as a gift for Christmas 2015 and it is broken already.
It suddenly started making a terrible, loud, grinding noise and when I took out my coffee, it was full of tiny metal shavings!!!
This piece of crap could have killed me! And it hasn't even been a year! I'm just lucky I looked at my coffee before making it, if I had been particularly tired that morning what would have happened???
For the record I have NEVER ground anything in it other than coffee. Occasionally I buy coffee with hazelnut pieces in it but if hazelnuts could ruin this thing, IT'S STILL A PIECE OF CRAP.
Not to mention the container your coffee grinds in to sucks. It's impossible not to get grounds everywhere, when you pull it out of the machine they go flying everywhere. Some grinds even fly out while it's grinding.

Overall, IT SUCKS! I'm very dissatisfied! DO NOT BUY!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for Drip or French Press NOT FOR Expresso
reviews.reviewText: The grinder works well but does not grind fine enough for expresso. The grinder's quantity setting and bean hopper work well. The unit is easy to use. The lid on the coffee grind collector is covered by coffee grinds during grinding and they typically fall off (onto the counter) when removing the lid. Ok overall, but not great.

I have had this grinder for about 6 weeks. The grind is consistent and uniform. The one touch switch to process a pre-selected number of cups of ground coffee seems to work well. I feel it is an attractive design at an attractive price. What's not to like?

reviews.reviewTitle: Nice machine. A bit of a pain to clean

Love it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well. It is a very noisy grinder.

It's the greatest coffee bean grinder I've ever had
I will be requesting another soon

It's easy to find the right grind setting, still small enough for a kitchen counter, and simple operating design. I heartily recommend this product.
This item has worked great and I use it everyday. Thanks!
Works excellent

Now it only works occasionally and more often than not it either doesn't work at all or we can hear the motor but it doesn't grind the beans. We are very disappointed and I'm sending it back to Cuisinart.

I am open to any and all suggestions about how to deal with static. My wife suggested wiping down with dryer sheets but I don't want to drink Bounce.
Excellent unit. Also grinds nuts.

B Chicoine

Why go to the coffee house, when we can grind our own...and we do. Why go anywhere when instead we can grind coffee. Sometime for a change of pace, we grind our neighbor's coffee or even total strangers. Yes, you get some strange look from people when you offer to grind their coffee but when they see the extraordinary result ,well, it worth getting the finger every other time.

this compact and easy to use product provides a full range of grinds. it requires no more than a brushing between uses.

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible Grinder. Stopped working after 2 months of purchase.
reviews.reviewText: This burr grinder stopped working after 2 months. After this period, the grinder now only produces uneven very coarse grind when I select the fine setting. See the picture below for results. For an expensive unit like this, this is unacceptable. Don't waste your time purchasing, as you will just be disappointed. Even after cleaning every aspect of the grinder, this product works terribly. I called customer support and their policy is that you pay to ship in the product for return before they send you a new one. If you have that kind of time in your life, then take a chance. For me, it costs me more to return this product than to purchase a new one from another brand. Terrible experience with their customer service team whom only wanted to get me off the phone.
We returned the first one because the off/on switch didn't work. Second one seems to be doing okay.
Lasted three months. Cuisinart charges you to ship the broken equipment back and to ship you a new one. Absurd.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good product - not satisfied with Amazon's customer service.
reviews.reviewText: After using this product daily for about 10 months, it started making more noise than usual (it isn't a quiet grinder, so we grind the coffee the night before) - we found pieces of metal in with the coffee where the screws holding the plates had broken off. We purchased the product from Amazon, it was supplied by Connect Buy, but we had to contact Cuisinart to get the warranty coverage. I was disappointed that Amazon didn't take care of it directly. We have to pay postage to return the unit to Cuisinart to get the replacement. I'll definitely pay more attention to these details next time I purchase an appliance from Amazon.

We really love this machine. It is so nice and very convenient. Our company really likes it also. Nothing better than fresh ground coffee! We are glad we picked this one as the burr mill is the best. Our neighbor is the person that suggested this one as they also have it and we had coffee with them and remarked how great their coffee tasted.

reviews.reviewTitle: I used this daily for 3 months and 1 day ...

love it

This product delivers a consistent quantity and grind. I am a coffee snob and I definitely believe burr mills are the way to go.

This was a great grinder. The cup measurements made it easy to determine water ratio and the different settings for fine/course grounds were great for our different brew methods. I would be giving it a 5, but unfortunately it stopped working after a couple months.

This mill replaced on that I have had for 15+ years. I can only hope it lasts half that long. We use it everyday to grinding enough coffee for 12-16 cups a day. This mill grinds very consistently and isn't as messy as the old one.
I would buy again.

Yes

The grinder is a little noisy but works OK. Our issue with this transaction is that the vendor uses UPS to ship to Canada. They quoted $28 to ship a $38 bean grinder, I could live with that, as in Canada the grinder sold for about $80. But it didn't quite work out that way; first off, UPS couldn't find our house (in an older Ottawa neighbourhood) and then had the gall to charge us a $22 "brokerage" fee. So, in the end, UPS charged us $50 to ship a small, $38 grinder. If you do buy anything from Amazon.com, ensure the vendor uses United States Postal Service, they don't charge "brokerage" like greedy ol' UPS.

Dealing with the static is much easier than dealing with a grinder that overheats and stops working all together.

reviews.reviewTitle: Used it for the first time. I added a ...

Used it for the first time. I added a cup of beans at the middle setting for drip coffee. After 30 seconds, it started to miss a few grinds, (no grinding sound). I then tapped the hopper to get the beans un-jammed. Had to to this several times until the unit stopped grinding. I then removed the hopper and poked my finger up to remove the jammed beans. I accidentally touched the grinder (ring), it was HOT!

I'm gonna give it another try, this time w/ half a cup of beans and more coarse grind setting to see what happens.

reviews.reviewTitle: If you want a burr grinder, read this first - this is not the unit for you.
reviews.reviewText: Let me open by saying, I have a lot of experience with high end, conical burr grinders and blade grinders of all sorts, from commercial and european models to the smaller and hinkier consumer models, so I am no novice when it comes to coffee or grinding. While this seems like a nice (thoughtfully designed, good looking) grinder, it has many faults. I am really disappointed. I looked forward to having a burr grinder for the consistent grinds they offer, but this one falls short on too many counts for me to keep using it. Now I've thrown the cost, three times higher than the blade grinder I replaced, of this unit away, along with the unit. First, it's loud, compared to it's much smaller relative, the Cuisinart blade grinder, and loud for a long time, as it goes through the full cycle. Don't try to converse with company and make coffee at the same time. Second, beans frequently get stuck in the hopper so the grinder has nothing to grind for a moment. Since the amount of coffee is determined by a length of time, this throws off the coffee measurement in the grinds cup. Sometimes, beans get stuck early in the cycle, leaving you with little or no coffee in the chamber. I find myself jarring and hitting the unit like a mad man, to try and get the beans to fall into the grinding cone. A bi-product of the plastic chambered burr grinding process, this unit also charges the grinds with static electricity as they accumulate in the plastic chamber. So, when you tap the chamber out into the brewing basket of your coffee maker, these charged grounds fly everywhere, making a mess. If you are using this unit for an espresso machine, the grind cup is too awkwardly shaped to easily scoop the grinds out of, cleanly. Finally, Burr grinders are supposed to have a very even grind, well, in this case, no grounds are too big, which is great, but much of the grind is powder, which makes for muddy last sips. Overall, I cannot recommend this grinder to anyone, for any reason.
Fast well designed coffee grinder. Easy to use

Giant disappointment. Advertised as a burr grinder; couldn't be further from it. It's a DISK mill. This shouldn't even be allowed to put burr in the description. Even on the most coarse setting it still turns coffee to powder. Save your money and spend an extra $100 on a true burr grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a good option for espresso grinding.
reviews.reviewText: After reading several reviews from customers who purchased this product I was convienced and made my purchase. This is a good grinder for people who are grinding for coffee in either a drip or french press. It will give a good grind. I purchased this grinder to grind espresso for my $399 Breville espresso machine. Even on the finest setting available it will not grind fine enough to work on a good espresso machine. For those of you looking for a grinder to grind good espresso for you machine this is not it. After I ground some espresso at the finest setting I could feel it was still to course, but I put it to the test with my espresso machine. I pulled a 2 ounce shoot in about 8 seconds, this is way to fast and left me with a stong cup of brown water. So I did give it 3 stars because it is well built and has many settings.... just not for espresso!!!

It can provide a perfect grind for any coffeemaker and any quantity from two cups to 12 cups at your preferred strength. This is our second, the first served us well for three years of daily (often twice-daily) use.

Wow. What garbage. Got one pound of coffee through before it stopped working. The grinder has completely seized. Since I was outside of Amazon's return policy I tore it open and found the rod that attaches the grinder to the motor has bent. After doing its job one time. Pathetic.

Solid

But Noisy

I'm assuming it might have something to do with the friction of the burr grinder heating the beans and changing its properties, but the coffee tasted awful. The machine is insanely loud as well. Lastly, I didn't think the course setting was course enough to use in my aero press.

You have to shake the grinder to dislodge them while the grinder grinds on with no beans in the grinder. Anyhow a moot point as the thing stopped working completely this morning after three months of light use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Last grinder was of poor quality

Both times the motor died.

reviews.reviewTitle: This + a good french press coffee maker will make you into a ...

I've used it four days, experimenting with different degrees of coarseness. The result is there is always a lot of powder mixed in with grounds. It looks like I will have to dig around and see if I still have a percolator, because using this grinder, drip coffee of all grind consistencies is almost as weak as water and a terrible waste of some fine and costly coffee beans. Although I probably will just accept that I'm a coffee rube and go back to the blade grinder.

Cannot fault the equipment as it does what it was advertised to do; perhaps should be used in a setting where copious amounts of freshly-ground whole roasted coffee beans are produced. Like an upscale coffee canteen in a hoity-toity commercial office somewhere.

It turns out that the machine is just a little-much for the home breakfast coffee preparation in the morning using a one-cup French press!

It may work well for coffee but it is awful for grinding spices. We decided to just stick with our ninja set which did a better job processing and finely chopping the spices.

reviews.reviewTitle: elctric is 220v or 110v it is most inportent to now !!!
reviews.reviewText:
Fortunately the product arrived quickly. But when we came to use it we saw that
it was impossible to operate the grinder.
Electric 110v is not suitable in my country.
Electric 110v is not suitable in my country.
the grinder not work
Sadly this is not a full review. This is just a simple statement that the product I received was DOA(Dead on Arrival). I have since returned it, and will not be order this on again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Used coffee grinder, and I bought a new one!
reviews.reviewText: The item was used, and I ordered a new grinder. It had grounds in the container.
I never had a coffee grinder before so i don't know if it is missing something but it barely grinds the coffee and will be returning it, completely dissatisfied!
junk. doesn't last.
works very good
Grinds dem beans like nobody's bigness.

reviews.reviewTitle: Too loud? Really? On what planet?
reviews.reviewText: Before I ordered this, I read the reviews. I love reading reviews because they usually remind me just how uninformed and weird people are. This GRINDER is not too loud. Heck, it is one of the quietest I've ever had. Bean grinders are loud. They have to be. So, ignore all of the noise complaints. They come from people who've never left their homes, and never read a book. This thing is great. It grinds consistently and makes a great cup of joe. Since that is its job, I give it high marks. And, for the record, I do not expect it to last a long time. A year tops. It is an inexpensive grinder, and to expect any more than a year from it is insane. It's built to be used, and then thrown away. If you want anything more, you have to spend a lot more money, unless you are one of those people who is entitled and special in their own brains.
Works fine but, Noise this grinder makes as it finishes the grinding process is worse than a dentist drill ringing in your ear.
It work ok but I dropped it as soon as I opened the package and it broke.
Lasted about 20 seconds! It completely died on me before I could even grind a package of coffee beans. Unreal! Returning this junk!

This item was purchased for a family member as a gift and I purchased it as new. When my daughter went to use it she found it was used. There were coffee grounds in it and there was no owners manual or registry card. When I contacted the shipper they advised that they had no idea how I recieved a used item but that I could return it at my expense and that it must be returned within 30 days of purchase, which had already passed. Very unsatisfactory experience.
I love this Juicer. I use it every day to get orange juice and lime juice. It works and looks great!

nice things! but I didn't use yet.
but. just on a table is enrgh. good looking!

reviews.reviewTitle: The unit itself I like, but the fact that it cost 65
reviews.reviewText: The unit itself I like, but the fact that it cost 65.00 from you, is troubling when now thru others (including Cuisinart) its 45.00!! Partially my bad not waiting for a reasonable price like I'd seen prior to buying from you.

reviews.reviewTitle: May be useful for coffee but useless as a spice grinder
reviews.reviewText: Didn't last an hour. May be useful for coffee but useless as a spice grinder.
dont buy it i was told u

Love this grinder. We are able to control the volume and coarseness of the grind (probably true of any burr grinder). We believe this (burr) grinder is superior to any blade grinder. Haven't figured out how to keep from making a bit of a mess when removing the container (where the ground beans are dumped) but that's probably true of any burr grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... ordered a new one but mine came used and dirty. Disgusting
reviews.reviewText: I ordered a new one but mine came used and dirty. Disgusting.

reviews.reviewTitle: Reviewers here are stupid if they think this is a quality grinder
reviews.reviewText:
First of all, it makes a very high speed whine which suggest it's not EVEN A BURR GRINDER but a blade one. Secondly, this unit is not capable of even espresso grind, much less turkish. It's capable of the smallest drip grind on the lowest setting.

I'm very upset because a lot of users think this grinder is good. I mean really you guys think Osama bin Laded did 9/11 and not Bush+Saudis, you ignore all evidence and facts for a decade and a half and now you bumble about your pathetic lives making reviews on amazon that don't match reality whatsoever.

The facts being this: this is a very convenient 'upgrade' from an 8 dollar blade grinder, but otherwise: NO IT IS NOT A QUALITY GRINDER and NO, IT WILL NOT SERVE YOUR PURPOSES FOR ESPRESSO.

Finally, I tapped the container on the counter and a bit of plastic broke off the base. This took me literally 10 seconds to break this made in china garbage.

I've been using this product for several weeks now. Here are my thoughts on it:

Noise:
-It is very loud. I always make sure there is ground coffee a day before. I'm afraid if I were to use it in the morning, it would wake everyone up. I would compare it to using a blender.

Grinding Options:
-I read other reviews before purchasing and I knew what I was getting. The different grind settings is wonderful. However as other reviewers have said, it doesn't produce coffee grounds that are consistent (refer to photos). There is definitely fine powder coffee that comes from it even on the "course" setting.
-The option to decide how many cups of coffee works great. I can choose different options from 4 cups to 18 cups worth of coffee grounds.
-Also having the ability to hold extra coffee on top is another reason why I choose this one over others.

Messy:
-The grinder leaves a slight mess after pulling the coffee grounds container out (refer to photos).

So why 4 stars? Because the product cost $50, it works and I'm far from a coffee connoisseur. If you want a grinder that grinds more consistently or is quieter, then I recommend you go and spend more then $50.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great little grinder. True burr grinder
reviews.reviewText:
It's a nice, easy to use unit. Does a great job of going from very fine, to very coarse, and many settings in between. Experimenting with different settings for each type of coffee takes a bit of time, but it's worth the effort and fun anyway. For the $$$ absolutely worth it.

Not too bad to clean. But not something needed every day. The oil from the beans makes the grounds stick a bit to the sides, but that is to be expected, and it's not such a big deal. Finding how to remove the top hopper also takes a bit, but it's easy. Just rotate COUNTER clockwise (in the direction from fine to coarse) and keep rotating past "coarse". Keep spinning the hopper in the same direction, and it eventually comes off and lifts out. Assembly is just the opposite. Usually don't even worry about it when changing beans. Really cleaning it out might take more time and some extra effort.

Noisy? Not really bad. Hey, it's a grinder. If it were silent I'd be shocked.

For the money, overall, I'm impressed. Would buy it again or as a gift.

reviews.reviewTitle: I already own one of these and really like it, so I'm buying one a thank you ...
reviews.reviewText:
I already own one of these and really like it, so I'm buying one a thank you gift for coffee lover friends who invited us to stay at their home during Hurricane Irma. I like just being able to hit the bar to start the grinding, because I've pre-set the amount I want ground and the degree of coarseness. Once that bar is pressed, you can walk away and let the grinder do its job. Then when it's finished, you just slide the little plastic container forward, lift its lid and pour the grounds into your coffee maker. Shazam, you're done.

Now, sliding the emptied container back into the mill can be a bit tricky at first, (my husband still doesn't get it), but once you get the knack - - no problem.

reviews.reviewTitle: I've had this for a year now
reviews.reviewText:
and what can I say, it's a coffee grinder. I like that the hopper holds 1/2 lb of beans as I use it with my Toddy maker to brew cold coffee concentrate. I'm not sure how it works as far as grinding beans any finer than the 3 coarsest settings because that's all I have ever used, however I do find that while grinding a half# of beans it does give you quite a bit of fine grind along with mostly coarse ground beans. I have been told though that that is the nature of the beast with a flat disc grinder. On the plus side though, I don't have to worry about it too much if I am using the Toddy maker because their thick material filter catches over 99.98 % of the fine ground beans. Using it for another cold brew system with the metal filters results in a lot of coffee dust in your brew however, and you will need to strain it through a paper filter if you want clean coffee.

The cup timer is a nice addition, although I usually only use it on 18 cup setting. For me, running the whole hopper takes 2 full 18 cup settings + a bit. Just remember to use the included brush to clean the dust out of the hole where the grind comes into the removable container.

Oh and I get lots of static after grinding coffee, perhaps because I like very dark roasts. The trick to that is to wet your fingers under the faucet and spritz a wee bit of water on the beans before you grind and it really cuts down in a big way the amount of static, so you don't end up with lots of grinds all over the counter.

I've had mine for about 6 months now. I use it to grind for a drip machine, and it grinds for about 16 cups every day. The motor seems to take it all in stride, and it's never sounded like it was under undue stress, so I'm puzzled by all the reviews reporting bad motors. I suspect, at least some of them, are really interlock problems. There are at least two of them: one is under the cup that collects the ground coffee. The other is under the hopper. If the cup or the hopper aren't properly seated, the motor is prevented from operating. This is a safety feature.

The flavor of coffee ground in a burr mill barely resembles that of beans chopped up in a grinder with spinning blades. The spinning blades keep hitting the coffee over and over, heating it up. If you watch, you will see the coffee turn a lighter shade of brown as it dries out. A burr mill spits the ground beans into a cup as soon as it's finished with them, and the grounds are the same shade as the beans were. The difference in flavor is tremendous, so recommending a burr mill, such as the cuisinart, is a no-brainer.

Update Jan 09, 2007: We've been grinding for about 16 cups per day for about a year now. Still going.

Update July 27, 2009: 3.5 years of faithful service, but I have to admit that I'm starting to get paranoid. This thing has done a lot of work, and something has got to be on the verge of going out. I'm addicted to my morning coffee (I drink it ALL morning), and I'd be in a bad way if I couldn't partake of my favorite bean. I'm considering buying another one as a back-up.

Update Feb. 5, 2011: 5 years, and still grinding.

I bought this on a whim, admittedly an uneducated one and let me try to keep you from making the same mistake.

This, no matter what setting, will give you microscopic, powder-like grinds mixed in to your coffee. Impossible to clean, as you cannot take apart the machine to a point where you are able to clean the burrs. The brush is for cleaning the removable hopper out, you can't really get into clean the burrs with the dinky little brush it gives you. This, has metal burs that make an awful sound as they pulverize the coffee rather than grind it.

Spend an extra 50-60 bucks and get yourself a conical burr, ceramic coffee grinder that is capable of fine control of its gears and you can take apart to clean. Coffee oils go -rancid- Cusinart.

I expected more from you.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good value, lasts forever, probably insufficient for espresso or pourover
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is absurdly durable. Mine has been used several times a week for ten years and never had a problem. It's a very good value and a good first choice for anyone wanting to experiment with a step up from a basic grinder. There are definitely some issues with this thing, but you will need to upgrade to a much more expensive grinder (at least $100, maybe $250 if you're picky) to resolve them. So if you're not ready to make that plunge, this is a great model in its price range. Just know it's best suited to making big ol' pots of coffee and nothing fancier.

The main difference between this and a higher end unit is the inconsistency in the grind. About 90% of the output is exactly what you want, and the rest is a fine powder that builds up on the grind container, clogs your coffee filler, and eventually manifests itself as sludge in the bottom of your mug. It's not the end of the world but it's noticable.

You should also know that this thing is LOUD. I know all grinders make noise but this one really takes the cake.

We purchased this on the strength of a friend's recommendation. Unfortunately, we did not get the same experience as them. We ended up returning it, and will look elsewhere for a replacement. Here are the reasons for the return:

* The safety switch for the catch container was flaky. We kept having to re-seat the container multiple times before the device would turn on.
* The hopper rotates way too easily, so it takes little effort to accidentally change your grind quality.
* The grind consistency was questionable. It certainly didn't allow things through that were too big, but we were also getting a lot more "dust" than expected. This had a significant negative impact on our pour-over filters, as they were clogging much faster than normal.
* The device seemed to have a problem with static electricity. The aforementioned dust would stick to the walls of the container. Any attempt to open the container always resulted in a puff of coffee grounds that settled on all the nearby surfaces.
* It's loud. I realize these kind of grinders are going to be loud, but this was a bit too much.

reviews.reviewTitle: Fairly good grinder for a fairly good price.
reviews.reviewText: I have used this for about 12 years without any problems. It is easy to adjust the grind (just rotate the whole hopper at the top). The grind is not super even, but much better than the crappy blade grinder I had before. There is a sliding switch to adjust the amount of coffee being ground (I am pretty sure it is just a timer), but the numbers wore off and it is hard to tell how many "cups" I am grinding so I set it up for about 4 cups using trial and error. If I need 8 cups, then I just hit the start grind button twice. Mine tends to grind on the fine side, so for drip coffee, I usually set mine on the most coarse setting (out of about 14 positions or so). I don't know why people say you can't use it for espresso (not fine enough) - mine will make talcum powder grounds on the first 4 settings. The collector cup in front can be a little difficult to pull out as it is held in by detents to the machine and it is smooth rounded plastic on the sides - it would be nice to have a little texture on the sides to help pull the cup away from the machine. When the hopper is almost empty, the last 2 or 3 beans tend to just bounce around off of the burrs - not a big deal. For the money, I think it is a good grinder. I would like more consistent and coarser grounds, but it looks like I will need to spend about 4x as much.

I bought this grinder a couple of months ago because I was grinding my coffee in one of those spice grinders which made it either too fine or too coarse. Then I read some reviews on this Cuisinart (after buying it...dumb), and I almost returned it. Most of the reviews said that it was not good for espresso machines, the motor would burn out, etc., but thought I'd take a chance and give it a try. I love it! I only make espresso for myself and the beans are ground perfectly, but when company comes and I want to make a large pot in my ICoffee machine (in which the beans need to be ground at a perfect medium level) it also does the trick. It works well with my coffee press too. I am a coffee freak as you probably already have noticed, and I love my coffee rich and strong. People who burn out this machine probably do not clean it. About once a week, especially if you use dark oily coffee beans, you need to brush out the grinding components with a small slightly stiff brush. Buy a couple of different angle small brushes for this, and make sure you clean the grinders. Don't be lazy. Maintenance is the key to keeping to keeping any appliance working properly. Cuisinart rocks with this product! It's reasonably priced and does the trick.

reviews.reviewTitle: Labour intensive, needs lots of cleaning...
reviews.reviewText:
Extremely Labour intensive especially re. Cleaning, mainly due to bean oil adhering to the fine grounds... Or vice versa...
No biggy, just unscrew the top n clean everything out including the rectangular discharge port.
I've have mine several years n after a while it just stopped grinding.
So I unscrewed the 3 Philips head screws n took off the top burr disc n simply Applied several layers of self adhesive foil to pack out the disc, ( disclaimer - reader does so at own risk, im just reporting what I did, the screws are in place n they facilitate such mods...).
Now works great again, ready for the next clean ... LOL...
Still a reasonable buy for under $40....

I've had this for years and it finally broke (it just plain wore out!). But the ONE thing that I really hated about
this product was the incredible static electricity that was generated and held by the plastic bin where the grinds went.
Open that lid and the coffee would fly out and stick to everything. All over the counter, my shirt, the grinds would go all over the place.
For that reason, I'm shopping for a grinder that doesn't do this. I'll pay more (i'm sure of that) but I can't deal with that static at all. it's a mess every morning.
I have no beef with this products reliability, after all, it lasted a long time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Keurig/coffee house quality is a push button away :)
reviews.reviewText:
We just got this but many have testified to the reliability of this model. We actually got the Refurbished model which is $31 bucks. I used to have a little blade grinder because the cost of a burr grinder was prohibitive, or so I thought. The blade grinder was a pain so then, I started buying coffee already ground. Then we got progressively cheaper coffee and never really noticed the error of our ways.

Then we would go visit to people that had a Keurig and wow, this coffee is good. Thing is, a Keurig is expensive and the coffee pods are ridiculous in cost and an environmental pain. So we thought it over and we thought why not some decent bean coffee and keep our old Bunn 10 cup? So that's what we did but we're back to the blade grinder.

So for 1/3rd the cost of a Keurig, we got ourselves this grinder. We use medium roast store brand from Costco. This, my friends, is some of the best coffee I have ever had and I know it's the preparation that's making the difference.

For the bunn, one wants to use 1.6oz of coffee. I set the grinder to medium grind, 10 cups, and it was spot on the 1.6oz we needed, very first time, so the calibration is right for us.

So I write all of this to tell you if you are considering a Keurig, don't. Just get yourself a decent coffee pot (I recommend a Bunn 10 cup) and this grinder. You'll be happy you did.

reviews.reviewTitle: A loud, uncontrollable, messy, difficult to clean coffee powder making machine
reviews.reviewText:
See the dial near the top of the machine that appears to control the degree of the coffee grind? Forget that. Even on the coarsest setting, this machine generates an inconsistent mixture of a few coarse particles and plenty of finely ground powder. If you prefer French press coffee, it is impossible to get a suitable grind from this machine. The grinding surfaces are simply a couple of narrow rings that are parallel to one another with small teeth on each -- no conical burr grinding in this unit.

Want to grind all of the beans that you put into the hopper? Forget that too. The last few beans will ricochet around the inside of the machine indefinitely while the machine gets louder and louder. The motor will likely burn out before those last beans are ground into a fine powder. The built in timer will cut things short long before all the beans are ground even on its longest setting, probably to save the motor.

Want to keep your counter clean when transferring the finely ground powder from the clear bin? Forget that too. First, you have to remove the lid which sends the powder flying, so working over a sink or a trash can is must for the transfer. Trying to remove the statically charged fine powder from the main bin is even messier. Have lots of paper towels handy.

Want to thoroughly clean the unit? Forget that too. There are plenty of seams and grooves in the case to catch those impossible to remove fine coffee grains. Sure, the hopper and top grinding surface can be removed and run through the dishwasher, which is great. The same is not true of the lower grinding surface, and what lies beneath. I can see this area getting caked up with fine powder in very little time.

Please do yourself a favor and look elsewhere to meet your coffee grinding needs.
It sucks

reviews.reviewTitle: "Expected life of 1.5 years" says customer service
reviews.reviewText: Total piece of junk. I was grinding my coffee, and it started to make a funny noise. Then it started to smell funny. The motor burnt out. Granted, I should have been cleaning it more often. But still. Called customer service. Their response "it's out of warranty. We can offer you a 20% discount on a new one. The life expectancy on these models is 1.5 years, yours is older than that, so it's a miracle it lasted as long as it did". I'd rather buy a more expensive grinder one time (e.g., the baratza) than have to buy a $35 multiple times over the course of 10 years. So now this one is trash. What a waste.

This grinder is great for the number of settings it provides, however the quality does not live up to the Cuisinart standard. We picked this up about 9 years ago and it finally died when I went to grind beans yesterday morning. The whole top assembly just came off and when I looked, it had cracked. I have to admit, it has been a workhorse when it does work. There were two times in the past few years when we heard weird grinding sounds, and after dumping out the beans, we found tiny screws that had fallen out of the grinder's inside mechanisms. The grinder clogs if you grind too much without cleaning the chute out and the grinds have a tendency to fall out. Lastly, it is extremely loud so if you have to prep for the morning, do so when you know it won't disturb other people in the household. For the most part, it has been fine using it the past 9 years and I am happy to upgrade to a better burr grinder.

I have owned this grinder for over 10 years. I use it almost daily for drip and mostly for French press. I use a medium coarse setting.
This is a burr grinder with a large hopper, a push button to turn on, an easy wheel dial to select your grind, and a slid button to turn the unit off. Did I mention it was a Burr grinder?
A Burr grinder with these features at this price point? How can you complain?
I read complaints that it doesn’t do something as well as a machine costing double or triple?
I read one very helpful review that tells you in detail, how to disassemble the machine to clean out the blowback bean dust, something by the way, all machines have. What a novel thought that you need to clean the machine! I have to admit, that I have never cleaned mine but I am going to do that after reading that review. I may have gotten away with never cleaning my machine because of the grind size which can cause more or less blowback dust. I would expect much more blowback with a fine grind than with a course grind. If you have never cleaned your machine, how can you call it junk when it stops working? Cuisenart has always been a quality company. Go spend 3 to 10 Times the cost of this grinder on an expensive one and you will find the same things happen on all of them. Exception is, a more expensive one might have a combined on/off button so you won’t have to worry about which button is for “on” and which button is for “off”.

This grinder is the best you can get at this price point. You should by it.

reviews.reviewTitle: All The Comments from the Negative Reviews are True
reviews.reviewText:
I was given this item as a gift. However, the attached picture will validate that I speak for this model. I've watched a week to write this but my feelings since Day 1 have not changed.

For ~$38, you should not expect miracles but the device should still fulfill its general intended purpose satisfactorily, plus meet its manufacturer's claims.

Does it grind coffee? Yes

But the consistency of the grind is a wide spectrum. In its almost "Fine"est grind setting, you get tiny particles that make their way through an espresso shot filter (I.e. turkish grind!) to coarse, drip coffee chunks. See the attached zoomed in picture. This drawback substantially decreases the flavor and texture of most coffees you'll make since (1) variable grind will make it impossible for you to get the right flavor profiles and (2) you'll always get a weird, distinct sandy texture/taste from the particles that make it through your coffee filter. Unpleasant even with the finest beans. And, it makes the centerpiece grind dial pointless.

Does it deposit the coffee grounds into a container? Yes

But all those coffee particles I mentioned as being omnipresent are also VERY charged from the metal grinder (drawback from not using a ceramic grinder). The moment you open the container, or even detach it from the grinder, the coffee particles go flying everywhere in the kitchen (no matter how carefully you open the dispenser). Every use of this grinder creates a giant mess unlike I've experienced with any other device. The coffee particles will get on you, on your counter, on the grinder, and probably your floor.

With the negatives that I've highlighted (of which there are others that you can read about in the reviews), I can certainly understand why this machine does not have a long lifespan with its design.

The price of ~$38 is hard to ignore but it's a purchase you'll bemoan every time you use the device. I would not recommend this to anyone, not even for the office drip coffee club.

I trusted the brand name to buy this, but it is worth paying more for a grinder that works. I need a coarse grind for my French press. This machine grinds a mess of fine powder and coarse granules. The thing is REALLY loud. The feeder often fails so I have to shake it to make it grind. The cup that receives the grind is often quite sticky and hard to put in the device. On further research, I understand that there are at least 2 kinds of burr grinder, flat and conical. This is a flat grinder which means it heats the beans as it grinds, to the detriment of flavor. All in all, such a waste of money I am replacing it even though it works perfectly well, something I am normally too cheap to consider.

reviews.reviewTitle: I think that I have never hated an appliance as much as this grinder
reviews.reviewText: I think that I have never hated an appliance as much as this grinder. Every time I use I battle with it, I have to literally bang it on the counter in order for the beans drop down into the Burr. My husband has the same problem. I absolutely hate the thing. No matter how much we have both tried to get the beans to drop down to grind, it is a battle every time. I have had enough of this and will throw it out as soon as we order a new grinder. There! I feel better already.

I gave it two stars because it is a burr grinder as advertised and mine has worked every time I turn it on, so I gave points for selling me a product that at least works.

The inconsistent grind: As far as I can tell the burrs are way too small for a clean consistent grind. And the high pitched loudness of the motor indicated that those burrs are rotating way too fast, also contributing to the inconsistent grind. This is a step up from a dual or single blade herb/coffee grinder but only in the most technical sense.
I have seen a lot of reviews stating that their grinder quit working after a short time, spit out chunks of plastic...etc. I didn't experience any of these issues. I spent about $50 on this. Trust me to spend the extra $30-$40 and get something 4 stars or above. This is not a grinder for coffee enthusiasts.

As of this post, my cuisinart coffee mill is still running strong after 12 years of 2 pots-a-day duty cycle. We favor dark roasts that made us need to clean it outdoors with compressed air blasts about once a year, sometimes less.
IT STILL WORKS LIKE NEW. (I thought they stopped making appliances that last forever in the 1970s)
A little loud, a little dusty and cup guage is for reference till you get your pot recipe right, but even the clear plastic grind holder has held up and we smack it down on the granite counters every time to loosen the stuck on coffee.
So 12 years ago I"d have given 4 stars but 5 stars for being so well-constructed.

reviews.reviewTitle: Inconsistent grind, very noisy. Look for a better one.
reviews.reviewText:
Note: I bought this elsewhere to use a promotion, but wanted to leave a review on Amazon since this is where I usually buy stuff like this. (So you won't see a "verified purchase" tag on this review.

Here are my observations, which will confirm some comments made by other reviewers:
Pro:
1. Grinds coffee beans, with adjustable grind.
2. Easy to use, easy to take apart for cleaning.

Con:
1. Grind is quite inconsistent, you always get a lot of dust.
2. It's extremely noisy, much more than I'd expected. (I have a more powerful and much better coffee mill, which isn't half as noisy.)
3. The grinder disks are quite small, and don't look robust enough to last a long time.
4. This is rather hard to clean. See pictures, after grinding just one bag of beans, there's a lot of accumulated dust and grit.

So overall, this really isn't worth the money, you'd be better off spending a bit more and getting a better product. The one I have is the Kitchen Aid KCG0702CU, still going strong after several years of regular use. But it's more than $200.

reviews.reviewTitle: Noisy way to make fine powder at any grind setting
reviews.reviewText: When set to coarse grind you get some coarse chunks, but always with as much very fine powder as chunks, so this is no good for a French press. It is very loud, and for most beans I've tried leaves a flay-away chaff that gets all over the work area. The plastic is very holds a lot of static charge so it is challenging to get the ground coffee into a coffee maker. In a standard coffee maker it works well enough and it is nice not to have to weigh or count scoops, and tastes as good as any other type of grinder. As far as being so much better, sorry, I don't buy the hype.

Purchased on sale at reasonable price but would rather use my hand crank Khaw-fee grinder! Main issue it has is the high speed of the grinder that powders the coffee and heats it up as well because of the speed. Not good for brewing coffee. Also, it only has a 1/2" x1" or so exit out of grinder into the holding bin. Used once and can see it clogging after a fee uses if not blown out. Too much maintenance for me. Using the same exact coffee beans in the hand grinder, comes out completely non-powdered ,consistent and COOL.
If you don't mind making a mess of your counter every time you grind beans, this is the one for you. Time to spend more and get a slower speed grinder. Just like they say, get what you pay for.

Purchased this to replace a chopper type grinder and it does indeed make for a more flavorful cup of coffee. Beyond this, I mostly have complaints. The unit could really benefit from a redesign.

Starting at the top: to adjust the grind setting the entire bean hopper must be turned. I was very surprised to learn this. Rather than the dial at the base of the hopper simply turning freely, the entire hopper needlessly must turn. So unless you like your grind at the perfect center "medium" the grinder sits on the counter with a turned, off-center hopper on top that detracts from the look. A stand alone dial would have been better.

Also, with my old chopper I was accustomed to simply adding the beans I wanted to grind at that time, but that is harder to do with this one since you don't grind according to bean volume but rather according to number of cups you want to brew. It is not easy to add exactly the right amount. If less beans are added than what matches to the selected number of cups to brew, the grinder will finish with the beans and grind air for the remainder of the cycle, which is probably not good for it. The only other solution is to fill the bean hopper and permit your beans to sit in the non-airtight bin.

With respect to this "cups" measurement, most standard full size carafes are marked as having a 12 cup capacity, but this grinder is not on that same page. If you set the grinder for 12 cups it will damn near grind the whole hopper full of beans. After a few days of experimenting I settled on 5 cups to sufficiently provide for the 12 cup carafe.

Moving on to the control which regulates the number of cups to make, this slider control has very fine detents which demark the number of cups to make. Sliding this right or left through the detents determines the volume of beans it will grind. But the detents are very fine and feeling/hearing each so you know where you are on the scale is not easy. Also, the scale is graduated with very small numbers and only about every 4th number is actually provided while the in between stops are denoted with just a line. The slider action is sloppy and clicking through the detents is mushy with lots of play. It is easy to stop on the wrong number of cups. A dial with crisp click-stop action would have been much preferred.

The collection cup which catches the ground beans does not pour well, making a mess each time it is emptied. Somehow it also generates a large amount of static which causes the grindings to cling inside the cup and fly off in various directions when the lid is removed. You will definitely need a coffee brush with this grinder. The grinding itself is quite loud and is an unpleasant noise. If you are grinding the night before, make sure no one is sleeping already. Finally, the unit is fully clothed in plastic which does not help the look or feel.

Yes, it does the job, but lots of missed opportunities in the design.

We've had ours for at least 4 years now and use it daily and it's stood the test of time. I have an upkeep tip buried in paragraph three.

The couple times we thought it failed it ended up being just fine. One of those times was because the "Start" button started requiring a bit more firm of a push than before. No big deal.

The most recent "Okay, now it's dead" scare was one where we heard it running but no grinding was happening. I messed with it for a bit and discovered that I could unscrew and remove the hopper and get near the burr workings. I did so only to find that things were very clogged up with old bean finings. Five minutes of scraping in there with a chop stick and we were back in business. I'd recommend anyone add this as a regular thing to do to keep it running well.

Happy grinding

reviews.reviewTitle: Bought around 2003, still using it today
reviews.reviewText:
Many years ago, around 15 to be approximate, my coffee grinder died and I bought one of these to replace it. It gets used 350+ days a year. I often grind several loads before the day is done. It still works, almost as well as the day it was new.

It's not the fastest, not the quietest, not the most consistent, it's not really BEST at anything. You have to spend well north of $100 to get one of those. But it works fine for drip, French Press and reusable K-cup grinds. For the first 10 years it worked well enough for the home espresso machine, but eventually it couldn't grind fine or consistent enough to make a decent espresso. But hey, that's after 10 years of more than daily use. Well over 3,500 loads of ground coffee.

I received this coffee grinder as a gift this Christmas. It was in my wish list so it was easy to see which one I wanted. I loved that it was so easy to set whatever grind you want from fine to coarse and that you can fill it and walk away as it does its job. It beats holding down a button on my old blade grinder. My grinder arrived with a shattered reservoir even though the box was not damaged. I called Cuisinart and a new one came in a week. In the meantime my husband put a duct tape patch on the hole and it worked. There is a fine powder of grounds no matter what coarseness is chosen and one review said that it's actually not a burr grinder and that is why you get the static and powdered grinds. My beef with this grinder is that it lasted a total of 4 months before it crapped out. I won't be buying another like it.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is a BIFL coffee grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is a BIFL (buy it for life item). I've had mine for over a decade now and it still works perfectly. I use it daily or get very cranky.
The grinder easily delivers fine or coarse ground coffee. Also, the setting for # of cups is perfect in my opinion. Set it to 8 cups for instance and pour 8 cups of water into the coffee maker = a perfect cup of coffee to my liking. The motor in this thing is a beast. It's noisy. There's a con I guess. This and my drip coffee maker make a -good- cup of coffee. When I'm in the mood for a -great- cup of coffee... nothing beats my conical pour over coffee dripper and my hand grinder. Coffee tastes like a 7/10 from the drip coffee maker but a 10/10 from the pour-over method. What does that have to do with this grinder review? Nothing. When I'm in my usual morning rush to get out the door this is the go-to coffee grinder for me.

I purchased this grinder. Knowing the brand is a good quality name and having their products in my home for years, I had confidence in my purchase. Grinding only a pound of coffee a week, the grinder became dull way too early. A burr should be able, in my opinion, to grind hundreds of pounds before becoming dull. Having the grinder over a year, customer support was not helpful. I wasn't trying to get something for free, I wanted to get a new burr wheel and was willing to buy it. I was told there was no support for the product or parts available.

Here is a perfectly good product able to continue service with a bit of maintenance, left as a paperweight because of no support/parts or serviceable resources. The housing and motor are impeccable. The mechanics of this product, can go for years and years. Left for dead because of lack of a replaceable burr wheel. I bought a different brand with a replace-able burr wheel and am quite happy with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: A reliable, if noisy, entry level "value" grinder!
reviews.reviewText: Have now owned this for about three years with nearly 3 times a week usage for grinding espresso primarily. (This is an important point because espresso needs to be very fine!) First I have been quite happy with this very inexpensive machine. Yes it is loud. Is that really an issue? You use it for about 3 minutes if that so I don't consider the noise an issue. It has worked basically flawlessly over many years of use and I am a picky person both about my coffee and my reviews. I would like it to grind more finely and since my burrs are showing their wear, I am looking for a new one. This is a super bargain and value and I paid about twice what it sells for now and am still quite happy with it.

I can't remember if I bought this grinder on Amazon, or elsewhere. I've had it for more than 5 years. This grinder does a great job, until it doesn't. I was grinding beans the other day, and it just quit grinding. The motor was still running, but the grinder wasn't. I'll have to say, I'm not really sad about this.

For the years we've owned this grinder, it has always been the messiest grinder I've ever used! No matter what I do, there are coffee grounds all over the countertop when I attempt to transfer the ground coffee to a storage container or a coffee/espresso maker. The design is horrible! I only kept it for so long because my husband refused to let me get rid of it. The cup the ground coffee is deposited in after the beans are ground is awful. The hole in the back lets the ground coffee escape once it's removed from the grinder; the lid of the cup is not secured so, if you aren't careful, it falls off when you remove it, and the coffee grounds stuck on the lid spill everywhere. I hated this grinder, and I'm GLAD it died! Now I can get another one that, hopefully, is much better designed!

reviews.reviewTitle: I love my Cuisinart food processor and coffee maker... I hate this!
reviews.reviewText: Looks great, idea is great and ease of use is definitely a must. However we are in our second one and I can tell it’s about to go out. They only last 3 months and then boom dead. They sent us a new one for free after our first went out but we had to send the old broken one back first.. it cost $18 to ship it back and it took almost a full month until our new one came. At $43 new iys not worth paying nearly half the price to ship it back. Once this one goes out we are spending more money on the OXO. Don’t waste your time on this...

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for Mr. Coffee and french press (COFFEE SNOBS AVOID)
reviews.reviewText:
Update 7/20/2019:
Grinder stopped working today :( Only had it for a few months, so I'm a little disappointed. Going to try to have it replaced under warranty. Will probably just sell it and buy the Baratza grinder.

GENERAL CONCLUSION:
Just want a fresh cup of coffee when you stumble into the kitchen? Buy this. Want a refined brew that allows you to taste the subtle nuances and citrus notes of your carefully chosen, locally roasted beans? Don't buy this.

Detailed Conclusion:
The average consumer who brews from a french press or an auto drip machine and doesn't really have refined coffee palate (no offense) will find this grinder suited to their needs just fine. I typically enjoy pour overs from my local specialty coffee shops, and bought this to start playing around on my own without dropping a fortune since I'm lazy and usually go out for a cup.

I currently only own a french press and a drip maker, so I have never gone finer on this machine than a medium grind. The first thing I've noticed, is that while 100 times better than a blade grinder, it is still not as consistent a grind as I expected from a burr grinder. I would probably recommend using something like a Kruve sifter (which if you're that serious about coffee, why buy this to begin with) to filter out the inconsistent pieces. I have been wanting to buy a Kalita Wave, but due to the inconsistent grinds, I will probably buy a smaller manual grinder for that for now, but with my french press it tastes just fine.

I will also note that if you are filling the hopper with only the exact amount of beans you are wanting to brew, it tends to throw the last few beans around since it doesn't have any weight to push it into the burrs. I realize this may be the main culprit of my inconsistent grinds. I like to store my beans in an airtight container, not the hopper, so this is another downside for those who carefully measure the weight of their beans for an individual brew. Again, this is better suited to someone who is doing a large batch of drip coffee. Would probably be really good for an office break room.

It is a VERY loud machine, so if you are a parent or have a roommate, I would hesitate to buy this product. I work night shift, so everyone is awake by the time I use it (much to the unspoken gratefulness of my apartment neighbors).

Overall, this is a very consumer-grade grinder, if the price didn't already tell you that. Keurig, Mr. Coffee and French Pressers will enjoy this grinder due to its "get the job done" attitude and reliability at an affordable price. This is not the grinder for coffee snobs. Anything less than $100 will simply not be as refined as we need it to be. Eventually I will be upgrading to the Baratza Encore ($139 best price online).

This grinds well for drip coffee. The timer function is nice as it lets you select how many cups you want.

Dislikes:

Big time static buildup in finished product. This can be an issue on burr grinders. This has that problem. Expect stray grounds on the counter and grind hopper. Keeping the grind hopper super clean helps some but doesn’t solve the problem.

Clogs frequently. The output chute is tiny and the ground coffee sticks and eventually closes over. Relatively easy to clean, but you need to empty the bean hopper first. You’ll need to pour them out into a separate container before you remove the hopper as it stays open after it is separated from the motor base. Expect coffee grounds and some beans to get away and make a secondary mess.

Not durable. Ours just up and quit.

Loud.

It’s good for the price and as an entry to burr grinding, which is a step up even for drip coffee. Just expect to need a new grinder in the near term future.

I ended up with the OXO as a replacement. So far I’m pretty happy with it.

reviews.reviewTitle: I found I can't change my attitude - I still don't like it. I will ask for a different model ...
reviews.reviewText:
After several years, I found I can't change my attitude - I still don't like it. I will ask for a different model for a Christmas gift.

The collector bin is plastic and the brush has synthetic fibers, so the grind electrostatically sticks to the bin. When you try to push off the grind with the brush, some inevitably scatters (I mean *flies*) from the bin, repelled by the charge. It is always creating a minor mess. I learned my lesson and I always put the bin in the sink before I dislodge the grinds off the sides into a single corner of the bin. Then I try to dump the grinds into a filter, but the powder always manages to escape in small amounts. This, IMO, is an example of a product that company executives should have been forced to use (under watchful eyes at the office) for a few months before signing off on the final product. The bin did NOT have to be designed from such a mess-making material.

I've only had this product since Christmas, and so far I have to say that I love the product. I like the ability to just fill the hopper, select the dial size and press a button. Yes its loud, but it does a great job. I can definitely tell the difference in having a burr mill vs the grinder that I previously used. My ONLY gripe is how messy it can get. I haven't figured out why yet, but this new toy has made my coffee making process a little more messier than I remember. Also, the static cling to the grounds catcher IS REAL. There will definitely be some grounds clinging to the container. Anyone find a solution to this? Other than that, if you're somewhat daily coffee drinker and like automation/toys, GET IT. You'll enjoy it.

Do not buy! I’m on my 2nd replacement unit and each time I have to send a $4 check and a power cord. I can’t believe a brand of any kind is ok with awful quality and even worse customer service. Each email takes a week to receive a response and the customer service phone line will leave you on hold for hours! Save yourself the frustration and buy something different!

reviews.reviewTitle: It's awful and I hate it. Each of the first 2 versions just ...
reviews.reviewText:
Working on my third DBM-8 unit. Thought maybe third time might be a charm, but... nope. It's awful and I hate it.
Each of the first 2 versions just completely crapped out after about 6 weeks of use - wouldn't turn on at all. Exchanged each one at the store for a different unit of the same, thinking, "Cuisinart's a reputable produc, right? Must be an anomaly..."
Not so much.
While this third unit has "operated" each time I've called upon it (maybe the longevity has increased because I've called upon it, like, twice (??) - opting instead for the trusty cheapo Krups most of the time) it still does a bunk job...
Regardless of the grind coarseness I choose, about 33-50% of my beans always end up powdered into oblivion, and it makes one helluva mess.
Next time I go to the home goods store, I'm walking in with THIS, walking out with...cash? bath towels? a frying pan? anything else but THIS.

I like this coffee grinder. It's sturdy and well made. I like having the beans in the hopper so you don't have to fill it up each time you grind the beams. You press the button, patiently wait and bingo you've got your ground coffee! We grind the beans rather fine, so you have to be careful when your pouring them into the filter of the coffee maker as grounds can go everywhere- kinda like a square peg in a round hole! I'd prefer the canister to be round. All in all, though, it's a fine piece of equipment, and we are happy with this purchase.

Have this for a few years. It is still working but I have to play with the buttons for it to grind. I select fine and it comes out in big chunks, but it is fine. The problem is the cleaning. There is left a lot of coffee powder in the machine. I have to clean it out with a long tweezer pliers and a brush. Takes time. The powder gets on everything. I would make a lot of coffee grind for 2 weeks then clean it out. I have an airtight container and coffee stays fresh. It works after a few starts. It will start then shut down. I know soon I will have to trash it. I bought a kitchen aid pro in 2011 and it was expensive but it works great and cleaning is so easy. Cuisinart has good products but this burr grinder needs improvements. Now that I have a better burr grinder I can say I will never buy another cheap model. It just isn't made to last.

reviews.reviewTitle: Wonderful grinder, RIP. Welcome, new duplicate!
reviews.reviewText:
Received this as one of the best wedding presents we were given. We were not the most responsible of owners, as this was the first of its kind we had ever used, so cleaning wasn't as regular as it should've been. Even with that, this little guy had a good long run! I am sad to report that after 8 years of pretty heavy use (especially after we started drinking french press daily), our Cuisinart is no more. More precisely, the hopper snapped off the stem that fits into the grinding chamber - apologies if I'm not using the right grinder anatomy. And lamenting was heard throughout the land (or at least, the house)!

However, I'm pleasantly surprised at how affordable it is to replace with a replica. "Let joy be unconfined! Let there be dancing in the streets, drinking in the saloons, and necking in the parlor!" (Sorry, one of my fave Groucho quotes, and best opportunity to use it, as yet...)

This was our backup grinder that we pulled out when our Krups GVX2 broke. I have never hated any kitchen appliance more than I hate the Cuisinart DBM-8. We use it to grind single serving amounts (24 grams of coffee at a time) and not once has it ground all the beans. They fly out of the little hole where they're supposed to be getting ground and if you run it a few times, it's more likely to overheat than grind all the coffee. Thus, I now add a few extra beans as a sacrifice to this stupid machine. Once the grinding is "done" there are grinds everywhere surrounding it. They somehow fly out of the cracks between the plastic pieces. Annoying. And when you take the plastic box holding the ground coffee out to use, watch out or the static electricity will send half the amount of coffee flying all over the counter. We had static in our Krups grinder and thought it was a pain, but it was truly nothing compared to the Cuisinart. Only buy this if you don't care about cleaning up coffee every time you use it. And frankly, if you still want to buy this, hit me up and I'll send it to you for four bucks.

Did not buy here, have had this grinder before learning how to "Amazon" 10 years ago. Love it, it does require minor periodic clean out of grinding chamber and exit chute, especially when doing the finest grind for expresso. The slide for volume timer quit working a while ago so I have to keep my finger on the button until done. Now that we use a Keurig daily, the grinder, Krupp's expresso, French Press, Melita pour over don't get used as much except for weekend special coffee. I do not have a coffee problem, I have a problem without coffee. Drink On Coffee Friends!! DB

I purchased this mainly for use with a French press with the possibility of using it for an espresso machine in the future. After doing some research on Reddit I found a lot of people getting great results from this product so I figured I'd give it a shot. I returned it after a few weeks since I couldn't get a solid grind out of it, the grind was wildly inconsistent and the residue left in the bottom of the cup was more than my partner could handle.

This is the first coffee grinder over $10 that I've owned and I was severely disappointed. Prior to returning it I tried out the Capresso Infinity and it outperforms this grinder in just about every aspect. Unfortunately there aren't any decent coffee grinders in the sub $100 range so if you want a decent grind you'll either have to shell out $90 - 100 on the Capresso Infinity or the Bodom Bistro, if you want an automatic grinder, or go with a manual grinder if you've got the time, you'll have a far better brew.

After experimenting with multiple grind settings I gave up and sent the machine back and will be purchasing a Bodom Bistro.

I use this grinder daily, and mine is about eight years old. My ex and I used a bank of these in our small wine store where we also sold coffee, and I got one of them in the split. I have used it for espresso at home on occasion, but it will NOT give you a true, powdery espresso grind, and it seems to me that anyone who is a real espresso connoisseur/coffee snob will know that you need the proper equipment for espresso (I didn't get the espresso maker in the split, unfortunately). This grinder is fairly loud when in operation, and the only grinder I've used that isn't godawfully loud is the one attached to a $5K espresso machine, but this one is certainly not as loud as the mini grinder I use for spices. I'm pretty particular about appliances and tools, and this one does the job it is supposed to, and does it well. I use the grinder set to the finest setting, and it gives a consistent, fine-sand grind that makes a good cup of coffee every time. I've used this on a variety of organic beans, from hard, light roast morning blend beans all the way to the darkest and greasiest beans, and I get the same results every time, with one variation; the Jeremiah's Pick Blue Mountain Blend seems to grind even more finely than other beans (and it makes my favorite cup, too). When I remember to do it about once or twice a year, I throw professional grinder cleaner tablets through the grinder to un-grease and un-gunk it, and I think this may be why my machine is still going strong (knock wood). ***A warning: an employee did manage to burn out one of these grinders at the store by running four or five (or more?) hoppers of beans through the machine without allowing it to cool off in between. (To this day, I cannot fathom why that was even deemed necessary.) IMO, that is unreasonable use, especially for an appliance rated for home use.*** Overall, I recommend this grinder for the home coffee brewer, especially at Amazon prices. I've seen it priced at an even hundred, and that is ridiculous, considering other outlets don't offer the same level of customer service.

reviews.reviewTitle: Despite some bad reviews it's an excellent grinder.
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned a Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill for over three years and it's worked like a champ the entire time.
We make at least four pots of coffee a day. It's set at grind setting nine and grinds for twelve cups.
I've read some of the negative reviews on this product and I believe that this item, like many products, is a victim of poor design complaints when in fact it actually suffers from "Owner neglect".
The stories of the grinder giving up the ghost after six months to a year of use can likely be explained as owners who never take the time and effort to clean the grinding mechanism of the accumulated fine powder that is the inevitable result of grinding brittle, roasted, coffee beans.
Any device with moving parts must be regularly cleaned and maintained in order for it to perform as it was designed.
Taking a few minutes a month to clean the device will insure that residue doesn't collect in the moving parts and cause the device to fail.
I know that this can happen because my Daughter neglected to clean hers for over six months and the accumulated fine coffee dust worked it's way into the mechanism and froze it up tighter than the hinges on the Exit gates of Hell.
I'm not saying that some customers aren't getting faulty grinders.
But I'm guessing that a good number of the complaints would disappear if the grinder is cleaned regularly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Terrible. Save your money for a real burr grinder.
reviews.reviewText: This is not a real burr grinder, despite what the sales literature says. The reason you buy whole beans and grind them at home is for freshness and to control the grind size, but this grinder makes the coffee grounds come out in a multitude of different sizes - you get everything from 1-2mm slices, to a very fine dust. At least two teaspoons of your coffee will be turned into the finest dust you've ever seen and the static electricity generated from the grinding process along with the plastic bin will drive you mad. Why does it matter? First, you're wasting coffee. Secondly, if your grounds are all different sizes, the smaller grounds will overextract while the larger chunks will underextract. If you're going through the trouble of buying whole beans and grinding at home, you probably want the best tasting cup of coffee you can get. This grinder will not do that. You can see from the photos other people have posted that the grind comes out very uneven. Don't waste your money like I did. Buy the lowest end model Baratza and you won't be sorry.

First off, this isn't a top-of-the-line grinder. This is an upgrade from the more-common (and cheap) blade grinder that you're probably still using. And in comparison to that, it's a great upgrade. The grinds come out even, and the coarseness selector works well. I like to have a coarser grind for my pour-over, single-cup brews (less caffeine transfer == a more smooth cup of coffee), and a more fine-grain grind for drip (because I need all the caffeine I can get when I get up at 5am for my job).

The "cup" selector for the amount of grinds, however, is a little squirrely. I'm not sure if it is time based or what, but it seems pretty arbitrary as to how much coffee it will grind depending on the coarseness selected. This doesn't really bother me much, as I usually use a scale to weigh the grinds before brewing anyway (at least for single cups--for full pots, it's just the more the merrier).

The one place that this mill falls short is, as others have stated, in the ultra-fine grinding. Don't get this if you're looking for a grinder for espresso. I'm not much of an espresso aficionado, but I do have an AeroPress espresso maker that I like for americanos once in a while, and for that I still have to use the blade grinder (and yes, I know that supposedly "burns the beans" but go ahead and bite me, hipster). Not a dealbreaker, but good to know in advance.

So there you have it. It's good for brewed coffee, good for pour-over coffee, and lousy for espresso coffee. Make your purchase decision accordingly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good value, decent grind, but not built to last
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this grinder about four years ago. It is inexpensive for a burr grinder, and it produces a much more uniform grind than the blade grinders. I like the fact that I can set the quantity and let the machine grind the beans while I fill the coffee maker with water and filter.

There are some issues, however:

First, the grinder produces a fair amount of dust, particularly at fine grind settings. I bought this grinder in part to get rid of the "mud" at the bottom of my french press brew, but it still produces enough dust to leave a fair amount of "mud." In addition, the dust accumulates at the opening to the grind chamber, and will ultimately block it completely. You have to clean out that opening with a small knife every couple weeks or so.

Second, the safety interlocks on the grinder can be finicky. Coffee gets into crevices around the back and bottom of the grind chamber, preventing it from seating by a fraction of an inch, and the interlock prevents the grinder from working. I almost threw a perfectly good machine away, thinking it was broken, and it just needed a meticulous cleaning.

Finally, and most importantly, the grinder is not designed or built to last. The design puts a lot of stress on the feed tube of the bean chamber. After six months of use, my grinder developed spiral cracks on this tube; I was able to glue the cracks, and the grinder worked for another three years or so, but then the grinder plate on the bottom of the bean chamber became so worn that the screws came off, and the unit failed. I bought another bean chamber, but after I used it once, the grinder plate attached to the motor sheared off.

It took Cuisinart two weeks to inform me that they will not sell the grinder plate attached to the motor separately. When that piece breaks or wears out, the whole grinder has to be thrown away.

People have said that this machine breaks down, BUT like any other appliance, it needs maintenance and you have to use it correctly. About once or twice a month, depending on how much coffee I grind daily, I unscrew the top and wash it out, then brush away built up coffee grinds in the motor and the area that shoots out the ground coffee with a small stiff brush.
