A stiff artist paint brush works great. People also have said that it doesn't grind coffee fine enough. I use strong espresso and french roast beans for my espresso machine and the grinds are as fine as they can be. It'll grind beans any way your coffee maker calls for, from very coarse to very fine. I love this machine. Best buy for the money!

I bought this grinder in 2007 and it finally just died on me yesterday. For the almost 8 years of faithful service, I'm giving it 5 stars. Some of the reviews I've read on here are accurate. For example, the container for the coffee grinder is made of plastic so you definitely get static every time you use the grinder. You have to tap the container lightly to get some of the fine grinds to settle down before opening the lid.

Which brings me to my next point that the grinds can be a little inconsistent. We mostly grind coffee for our french press, but after each grind, we'll get about 1/2-1 teaspoon of fine coffee powder. This is the stuff that works its way into our french pressed coffee only to end up at the bottom of our cup. It's also the stuff that clogged up our machine.

Which brings me to my next point, my machine finally died on me probably because I didn't clean it out, ever. I didn't know this until it died on me and I tried to open it up. Lesson: remove the hopper once in a while to clean out the burrs and clean the opening that feeds the ground coffee into the grind container. The fine coffee grind can build up and clog up the machine.

Something I like about this machine is that there is a "stop" button so you can stop the grinding process quickly at any point. On some other machines, I've read you have to twist the hopper which can mess up the machine.

Overall, for your average, everyday coffee drinker who loves fresh ground coffee, this machine is perfect for the price point and performance. I would buy it again except my husband wants an even fancier coffee grinder now.

This thing sounds and performs more like a blade grinder. The grind size isn't very consistent. Grounds fall off of the lid as soon as you remove it. The last few beans in the hopper keep jumping up away from being ground, make sure you have the lid on. I step away from it as soon as I start grinding as it hurts my ears a little bit. I'm not impressed, but my pevious grinder that I like better cost almost $100.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works better than bladed grinders for drip coffee but not acceptable for espresso
reviews.reviewText:
This is likely a good coffee grinder for folks using a drip coffee maker. As a flat burr grinder it will produce more accurate and consistent grind vs bladed grinders. However, it is not acceptable for grinding espresso and will not produce fine-enough output for that.

I tried using the DBM-8 on its finest grind setting and the output from my low-end Delonghi EC-155 espresso machine was watery with very little crema. I switched to a hario slim hand grinder using the 2nd from finest setting and the espresso was much richer and had significant crema.

So... To grind good quality espresso you'll either spend 3-5x the price of this grinder or you'll have to use a ceramic conical hand grinder.

This machine grinds coffee well enough. Most grains will be the size you want, but, no matter the grind you choose, you'll get a significant amount of espresso-esque powder. Also, along those same lines, the reservoir is plastic and very static-y - all of that powder sticks to the machine and makes a mess all over your counter. I guess, for the price, it's up to you if you're interested. I'm going to replace it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the job, but is absurdly loud
reviews.reviewText:
I've owned this grinder for more than a year and use it a few times a week. From a durability standpoint, it doesn't show any signs of slowing down, and it performs adequately grinding the beans. At any level of coarseness, the machine produces a consistent grind, though it's not easy to fine-tune to the exact level of desired coarseness. As one would expect, it does not perform as well as more expensive models such as a top of the line Breville -- but at this price point you can't really complain.

My chief complaint is that this grinder is absurdly loud -- to the point that I am seeking a replacement. Not sure if others have had noticed this as well? It seems to be getting louder with age, as well.

Summary: If you can deal with the extremely loud noise during operation, it's durable enough and does an adequate job grinding the beans to make it a value buy.

I'm on my 2nd DBM-8. The first one lasted at least 10 yrs. The 2nd stopped working after about 5 years, but I found the problem and fixed it (motor hummed but no coffee came out). Hopefully, this will help someone else. Oily coffee beans had clogged up the discharge chute. To repair: 1) Unplug, 2) Pour the beans out into a plastic bag, 3) Remove the coffee catcher, 4) Remove the bean holder on top by unscrewing, 5) Work over the sink and clean the 1/2" sq opening that feeds into the coffee catcher, 6) Clean the ground coffee catcher around the bottom burl grinder, being careful not to damage the 3 scraper blades that force the coffee to the discharge shoot, and 7) Reassemble. It should only take a few minutes. Hope this helps!

reviews.reviewTitle: DO NOT buy Cuisinart products, especially this one
reviews.reviewText: I had a DBM-8 Cuisnart Grinder for about 3 years. It stopped working. I did some research, and settled on the same one, I figured getting 3 years out of it was okay given the cheaper price. I saw several reviews stating that it was a piece of junk and not to buy it, that it lasted only a couple of months and their warranty service stinks. Well, the new one is less than two months old and it stopped working. I called their service department. I was told to cut the cord off, ship the cord back, and then submit another $10.00 for return shipping. WHAT? I have to ship the cord which will cost money and then I have to pay to have a unit shipped to me? Not happening. Going elsewhere. Don't buy these products, you're taking a shot in the dark if you get a good one or a bad one and given their horrible return policy, it's worth going elsewhere and getting something with some real quality. This customer will never buy another Cuisinart product.

We bought this because:

1 - We love coffee
2 - We have one of those Cuisinart coffee makers that grinds the beans for you just before brewing
3 - We HATE cleaning the grind chamber before EVERY SINGLE GRIND. Not just tapping it out, I mean soap, water, drying, etc. It is the LAST THING WE WANT TO DO with bleary eyes in the morning
4 - We thought we'd love how the coffee maker grinds it up for you seconds before it brews (AND WE DO) we just HATE THE MESS

So, we bought this machine yesterday. We may be a little prejudiced because of our intense hate (yep, strong word, HATE, but it fits) of cleaning out the grind chamber in the coffee maker, but this grinder works great. Simple to use, semi-quiet (the coffee maker we have sounds like an air raid siren or tornado alarm, and we are NOT kidding one bit. It freaks out our guests when they spend the night and we set it up to go off in the morning!), somewhat even grind (there is some dust, to be expected at this price point) and quick enough. Run down of some of my observations from playing with it this morning:

Pros
- Can't beat the price for a burr grinder. The grind is far superior to a blade grinder. Save your blade grinder for spices and get this grinder.
- Easy to use. Dial the grind setting, slide the switch to the number of cups you want to make and hit 'Start'.
- EXCELLENT flavor extraction. We used about 30% less coffee to get the same flavor and strength. We couldn't believe it. I had to dump the first batch (we like our coffee strong) because it was too strong using the same amount of coffee grounds by volume.
- Overall good product.

Cons
- Static electricity is an issue but not a deal breaker for me. Give the chamber a quick tap on the sink bottom and most of the dust is gone. There is some residue but it would compromise less than 1/2 of 1% of the volume of the next grind if you total the weight in nangrams... I am semi-anal but if this bothers you, it really shouldn't.
- Kinda tough to get 100% clean between grinds, but if you are looking at this machine and seriously considering it, you are not a coffee grinder snob and a tiny bit of yesterday's ground coffee in your grinder will not bug you one bit.

Overall, I like it. Works good, less than $40 and the coffee flavor from our regular beans was superb. We used fewer beans with superior taste to the blade type grinder. The small issues with this machine far outweigh the great flavor and for the price, you just cannot beat it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Very good value. Lasts a long time with proper care.
reviews.reviewText: I've had mine for at least 5 years and it's still going strong. To be clear, this IS a burr grinder, but ideally coffee should be ground using a low- speed burr grinder, and this is not low speed. That's one reason it's so noisy. I've since purchased a (MUCH) more expensive coffee grinder and use this for grinding various grains for cooking and baking. I would say that it's a whale of a bargain for the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Miss the old version of the same grinder
reviews.reviewText:
What happened to the manufacturer? I bought one of these 7 years ago and it had a bad motor so we replaced under warranty inside of a year with great customer service from Cuisinart. The second one lasted 6 years. No joke. Perfect grinds. My wife was happy with the espresso grind and I was happy with drip grind. Really happy. Best coffee ever! Better than many coffee shops. Then a few weeks ago the grinder motor burned out (smoke and everything). We had no hesitation replacing it with the same unit. The new unit is junk. Uneven grind. Espresso setting not even close to fine. Same bag of beans that tasted great in the last grinder tastes like heated water with this grinder. I wish I had the older version back. I pulled out my old blade grinder just to get a decent cup of coffee. I am going to return this one and get a different one to see if I just got a bad grinder. Just like the very first one seven years ago, maybe we just happened to get a bad one. That said, that very first one ground fantastically it just had a bad motor. This thing is a horrible grind right out of the box. Hope to get lucky with the replacement.

Update: I returned the one written about above and got a new one. This one works. It doesn't grind the same as my old one - so I am lopping off a star for that - but it does work. I guess the days of this being the best budget grinder on the market are over. That said, the convenience of the bin and variable grind make this worthy of the price. Dang, I just wish the grind was as consistent as it used to be. :(

reviews.reviewTitle: Do just one thing well ... or not
reviews.reviewText:
This is a really snazzy grinder full of features -- choose your grinding level (coarse to fine), choose how much coffee to grind at a time, auto-shutoff, a nice little bin that slides in and out easily. And we liked ours very much for the first month or so ....

Then the motor on the first one just froze and wouldn't unfreeze. No burnt smell like a burnt-out motor, no nothing, just ... nothing.

So we took that one back to the store and got another one, because we liked the design and features very much.

But within a month, the new one has become an absolute nightmare to use. The feeder that is supposed to put beans into the grinder gets choked up (which may have been why the first unit froze up) so nothing is going into the grinder. Which means that grinding enough beans for, say, 6 cups of coffee means grind for a second or two, turn it off, shake it up and stir the beans, grind for another second or two, shake things up, bang it on the counter a few times, grind for a second or less ... and then all the shaking often pops the lid off, or pops the bin out, and then there's coffee beans and grounds all over the counter ...

And the good news is, now in the mornings I'm fully awake (and my blood pressure is probably through the roof) before I've even brewed the coffee because I've had to go through the insane process of beating the coffee grinder into submission.

Okay, maybe that's not good news after all.

I have had this more years than I can remember, sure hope I didn't jinx myself. I cracked the tank a week after I received the grinder and have never had any trouble with it. The grinder is easy to use, multi level adjustment (Fantastic for the types of brewers we use), dish washer safe for tank, grinding plates are easy to clean and are replaceable if need be. I lost the cleaning brush years ago so just use a small medium stiff paint brush to clean. Hopper comes off for cleaning, hand wash only, it's easy. I will send in to have grinding plates replaced as I just noticed wear this last cleaning. The only draw back for me is cleaning the port ground coffee comes out, but this is no big deal.

I have had two of these grinders. This first lasted several years and I have to say that was probably due to my lack of reading direction and the San Francisco French Roast coffee I use. The bean I use is very oily! But I love it! So that being said, here was the problem, not cleaning the build up of coffee beneath the burr and shoot. If you do it with every bag of beans then it will last and produce a great flavored coffee, once you determine the grind that works best for the type of coffee maker you use. Between the first and second one, I tried another brand. It was messy and hard to clean which is absolutely necessary with oily bean! I used it one month and then I went back to this model again. I have now had it about 5 years and still happy with it. Yes, there is a little dust. The mess mentioned on the counter, I don't have that unless I have gotten lazy about cleaning it! I also use it to grind coffee for my expresso machine, and French press. The thing that took me a few years to fugure out and reading the book that came with my expresso machine, is you can buy the most expensive equipment out there, but don't expect the first cup of coffee to taste like you get from your favorite barrista. You have to find the grind than works with your coffee equipment and your taste. AND clean your grinder!

UPDATE 3/15/2018...I wrote the review above at least 4yrs. ago about the 2nd DM-8 I was using. Well that coffee grinder just died after being used daily about 9 yrs. In this day and age that is a miracle, especially since it did not cost a fortune. Cleaning it regularly was the Key! I use a dental hygienist tool & brush and remove all oily built up dust under the burr and around and under where the bean holder screws to grinder and also the shoot. I am sure if we had taken it apart over the year as the above reviewer suggusted we might have gotten more years of service out of it!

reviews.reviewTitle: Died after about a week, terrible warranty "service"
reviews.reviewText: Worked OK for one week, then died. Cuisinart wants me to return it at my expense for possible repair or replacement. The enclosed manual had no trouble shooting or other advice. This company used to make quality products, but has clearly gone downhill and has no interest in serving its customers. After years of buying and using Cuisinart products, I am through with them foreever.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Grinder, but you need to clean it occasionally
reviews.reviewText: I have had this grinder for about 4 years (originally bought at Costco) and it worked great for grinding drip coffee. As others have posted it does seem to grind some fine powder along with the main grind which could be a problem for espresso users, but for drip coffee it works great. It is a little loud, but that doesn't bother me for 15-20 seconds. The only reason mine quit was I didn't clean the internals regularly. It started to slow down and struggle and I finally realized the dispensing spout had clogged and I wound up burning the motor out. If I had cleaned it properly it would have probably lasted another 2-3 years. But for this price, I am getting another to replace it. If you clean it regularly, it should last a long time. Bottom line, if you just need a good grinder for making quality drip coffee, you can't beat this for the price.

I picked up one of these in a local discount store for $25. It's a refurbished unit, but at $25 I figured I couldn't go too far wring. I've wanted a conical burr grinder for a while, but am turned off by the high prices for good ones, and I saw the relatively good reviews for this model.

Mostly, I use the drip or French press methods to make coffee and have found that even on the finest setting, this grinder barely grinds fine enough for that. So it is adequate for my needs and turned out to be a good buy for me. If one wants to make espresso or other brews requiring fine ground coffee, it won't be obtained with this grinder.

I do not see a problem with static that some have noted. Yes, there is some cling to the sides of the receiving hopper, but a simple tap on the counter knocks nearly all of it off. I've found no ground coffee flying off onto the counter as some have.

Overall, an OK grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Crazy Bad Unit...and I'm being lenient
reviews.reviewText:
I had some hopes for the maching but wasn't expecting much for the price....but I expected to at least get a useable unit. THIS THING IS USELESS. Not only is it useless, it causes you lots of extra time and work. I don't know if they changed the grind chamber or maybe I just got a bad one, but there is a 1/8" gap at the top so that the grounds absolutely get slung everywhere. I'm not talking a few grinds like some reviews say, but full on coffee grounds being slung from a 1/8" opening from the front of the unit. Crazy! It's not like the picture...there doesn't seem to be a gap in the pic. But there sure is in mine. I got it on sale at Kroger so maybe they got a bad batch or something. I'm serious, there is NO way to use this thing.
Even if you don't listen to me on this problem, pay attention to the reviews that mention the static cling problem in the grind chamber. Seriously, there couldn't have been more grounds and powder stuck to the sides of the container. I had it set for medium grind and the lowest cup setting for just a few cups and afterward, I'm sure there was at least a tablespoon of grounds and dust stuck all over the sides...hate to think of the amount that would be there when using it to capacity. Please don't waste your money

UPDATE: another user let me know that mine was probably missing the plastic cover for the chamber. It's looks like that may have been the case...mine was missing something. May be a good grinder with that in place. Make sure that's there when you open the box.

I bought mine over 10 years ago from BB&B for $29.00 on sale.
This puppy grinds 2 cups in one fell swoop every single day.
Although made in China, it's still going strong and works perfectly. I'm guessing that's because it's the 10 year old model. Nothing these days lasts that long.
The two problems everyone mentions are present and here's how I solve them:
1. It's really loud. There's a slider to set length of time of grind that doesn't move when set. So every day I just hit the start button and walk out of the kitchen. You'll know when it's done!
2. When I take the little hopper out with the finished ground coffee, I put my thumb over the opening on the hopper. Then I tap the hopper on the counter a couple times and take the top off to unleash the ground coffee. I tap this into a Tupperware cup, use what I want and put the top on the Tupperware. I finish the ground coffee every day.
At found a small, round brush designed to brush coffee out of your grinder at SBUX years ago. I use that to clean the hopper when there's too much coffee built up. I don't have a bad dust problem.

We've had this grinder three years or so, but only used it very occasionally. It's only been in the last few months that it has been used almost daily. In the last week, the threaded plastic shoot at the base of the bean bin, which also holds the grinder piece in place, basically and irreparably crumbled. For the little amount we have used the unit, this is very disappointing. We'll most likely be replacing with something else.

I make a pot of French Press every morning and have used this grinder for about a month.

I can set how many cups I want to grind press start and walk away. This is a nice feature after using a blade grinder. Although it is much louder than a blade grinder so I find myself running into the other room while it grinds coffee.

I have it set on the second to last coarse grind and I would say about 85% of the grind is of reasonable consistency. The other 15% is unbelievably fine, this is not ideal for a French Press. I get a small amount of sediment in my coffee. As shown in the picture this super fine coffee sticks to the inside of the container, although this shouldn't happen in the first place I find it useful because I don't want it in the Press. I would not recommend this grinder, I can get a more consistent grind with a blade grinder.

This grinder is responsible for exponentially expanding my vocabulary of expletives. It is the worst appliance I ever owned. This grinder does not grind a consistent amount of coffee from one day to the next even though I never change the settings or the coffee I am grinding. But the worst thing is how messy it is and how hard it is to clean. When it is grinding at a soul crushing volume, it generates a fine coffee dust that flies out of the sides of the grinder and coats the wall that is next to it along with the counter. I had to put up a shield so my walls wouldn’t be ruined. And the statically charged coffee that results from this unholy process flies all over when you try to transfer it. About once a week, it clogs and the only way to remove the packed in coffee is with a sharp implement. Do yourself a favor and don’t buy this.
Junk

reviews.reviewTitle: Does the Job But Has Static Electricity Issues
reviews.reviewText:
Some grinders create a static charge that results in coffee grounds leaping out of the receptacle as soon as it is removed. Tired of the tedium of major cleanups every day, we decided get rid of our Capresso and try this Cuisinart instead. To our relief, this product has no static charge problem at all [see UPDATE below for more on this]. Like the others, its collector is plastic, so I have no idea why it spares us the messes that others produced, but we're pleased with the outcome. We use a drip coffee maker, and the "fine" setting on this grinder works well for that purpose.

Interestingly, some other reviews of this grinder complain about the very static charge issue that we experienced with other brands, but not with the Cuisinart. Maybe it depends on the environment where the product is being used.

UPDATE: After further experience with this grinder, we began to have some problems with static electricity, although nothing as bad as we had experienced with our Capresso. But we have now changed from the Cuisinart to a Bodum (Bodum Bistro Electric Burr Coffee Grinder, Black), which uses a glass container (rather than plastic) to receive the grounds. That seems to make all the difference. So far, the Bodum has been entirely immune to static issues.

I've owned two of these and with each one I had the same identical experience. It works great for a year and then it totally breaks down.

Here's the problem: after a few grinds the compacted ground coffee blocks the shoot where they fall into the grind chamber. You have to manually clean it out. The grinder wheel is behind this shoot and it can turn as the compacted coffee is dug out (I use a thin wooden skewer). I have typically cleaned this out about 3 times during my year of using this grinder. Twice now after the third time the grinder failed to turn on. Pressing the power bar or trying to get the safety shutoff buttons realigned doesn't do anything. I even tried a couple of electrical hacks recommended on a some DIY sites. The grinder remained dead.

This grinder may be priced well but it's still a lot of money to spend on a grinder that'll only last a year. I'm sure that Cuisinart is aware of this design flaw but has chosen not to fix it since it still sells a lot of these.

Until I come across a better but affordable burr grinder I'm back to using a blade grinder. Maybe the end result isn't as good but the grinder's performance has been rock solid for ten years.

Three months after purchase, our coffee grinder died. I took it apart to see if it could be repaired...it couldn't. When I removed the bottom plate, there was a distinct acrid smell of burned electronics. A little further digging found a large accumulation of finely ground coffee around the burr mechanism. Since the internal fuse hadn't blown and the switches were still working, I suspect that friction from the accumulated coffee caused the motor to draw excessive current, overloading and burning out the circuitry.

If you already own this model, periodically clean out the chute where the coffee exits the burr mechanism. If you don't already own it, I strongly suggest you look at a different grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: After hearing some seriously terrible grinding noises
reviews.reviewText: Junk. I had 2 of these that were purchased from Costco, and both died within 2 years of normal once a day use. In both cases, the screws securing the grinding disks backed out and entered the grinding chamber. After hearing some seriously terrible grinding noises, I could see my coffee grounds covered in metal shavings. Yumm!! Good Luck! I really should have taken advantage of Costco's return policy, but I just threw them away. I should have learned from the first failure that these are junk, but I thought I would give it another chance.

First of all, ignore the reviews by the snobby fanatics. This grinder is not meant for espresso, or for fanatical connoisseurs:

While this is only slightly above the bottom price rung for burr grinders, it's a huge step above even the best BLADE grinders. For people who want a "mostly" consistent grind (which you'd never come close to with a blade grinder) and an overall better taste due to the milling process, this is a great place to start. You're never going to get 100% consistent grinds without, first of all, using a conical grinder (these lower end ones use grinding wheels instead of cones), and secondly getting something that costs about 5-6 times as much as this one. If you're willing to accept 5% lower grind quality, and want to pay 1/5 or 1/6 as much as a high-end grinder, this is the grinder for you.

The build quality is excellent compared to others in the same price range, or in many cases higher priced models. It's very solidly built and the feature-set is great. The one-button grind is my favorite feature. Walk into the kitchen, push the button, wait half a minute, and you're good to go. The bin for holding beans is much larger than most of the competition as well. They say it holds 1/2 lb, but it actually holds 3/4 lb.

I've had one other, cheap burr grinder, and it didn't come anywhere close to this one. I'd buy this one again in a heart beat.

reviews.reviewTitle: Motor died after less than 2 years if moderate use.
reviews.reviewText:
My story is the same as so many of the other reviewers. This product worked decently for the approximate year and a half (go figure - 18 month warranty) I had it I suppose. It got the job done for $50 with a grind that was not terribly consistent but OK. It's near impossible to use without making a mess due to both how much fine coffee dust it produces as well as poor ergonomics. You will also have to clean it regularly if you don't want to infect your fresh coffee with the stale fine coffee grinds that build up on the "exhaust port". It also has no insulation so it IS loud. I probably would have given it a 3-3.5 star based on how well it works as a product and the price point.

The reason for the 1 star review is 2 fold. First, the motor died after an estimated 100 uses, which is unacceptable to say the least. Even worse than that however, is my experience with Cuisinart. As with so many other reviewers they seemed less than concerned both times I called. On both customer service calls the first thing they wanted was a receipt (I bought mine through Bed Bath & Beyond I believe) to prove that it was bought within the 18 month warranty period, which is of course their right to do. Unfortunately, even if/when I do find that, I will have to pay ~$10 to send them them the old one before they will send the replacement that will also charge me $10 for shipping. So on top of all the hassle so far, Cuisinart wants me to pay nearly half the original price of the unit to have it replaced under warranty and go without the grinder for likely 2 weeks or more on top of the week+ I've already been without it before having time to address it. Save yourself the hassle.

I also encourage anyone considering this product to look at the review distribution. It currently has 43% 5-star and 18% 1 star which are both numbers that would concern me. I would not have bought this originally purchased if I saw that first, but I thought Cuisinart was a good company. I didn't go through them all but I have not seen a single response from Cuisinart on any of the complaints. From my experience it's clear that Cuisinart is a company that does not care about it's customers or stand by it's products. I recommend taking your business elsewhere. I will be doing so from now on.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does a good job, but a tad messy to open.
reviews.reviewText: This unit is pretty solid and does a decent job of grinding the coffee beans. A few things I don't like though. I realize ground coffee is always going to be messing, but the way the lid of the ground coffee container is setup, it's almost impossible not to make a mess every time you open it up. Also, the plastic is fairly strong, but mine just recently broke on the inside causing the screws to come loose and shards of plastic to start flying everywhere inside. I just contacted customer service to see what they're willing to do.

Gave it a three because I’ve only ever had the cheapest crappiest kind that holds just a couple of tablespoons. Bought this one to treat myself and it had good reviews.
I really don’t love it. It’s loud, makes a fine powder that sticks to the walls of the container no matter what setting, and it’s just very messy. Plus I don’t feel like beans should get stuck so often.
The best thing is that my toddler can use it safely and feel like she’s helpful in the kitchen...but she’s still covering her ears from the noise.

reviews.reviewTitle: 3.8% of coffee ends up as powder when coarse grinding for French Press
reviews.reviewText: Not a bad grinder, however, as stated in an answer to a question, it is not a connical burr grinder. Also, there's been some mention of powder mixed with the grind, I found this to be true. I've only used it for a coarse French Press grind and there's an objectionably large amount of residue that gets through the pressing after brewing. I've resorted to having to use a single cup pour through with a paper filter, after the French Press brewing, to get a clean cup of coffee. Today I measured the residue left on the coffee filter after it had dried for a day, 70 degrees F and 33% relative humidity. Starting out with 20 grams of Peet's Coffee Major Dickanson's Blend whole beans I got 0.762 grams of residue, that's 3.8%.

I bought this and was thrilled to finally have a burr grinder. The burr style grinders are the absolute best for grinding coffee because they can grind to a range of very consistent coarseness settings.

The good: This is a bur grinder and can handle a lot of coffee, more than most coffee brewers and presses can brew at once. It has a range of coarseness settings from espresso and Turkish all the way to french press. The grind is quite consistent as all proper burr grinders should be.

The bad: Well first of all it's extremely noisy, which is just not Cuisinart's style! That I can live with though.
Secondly the more coffee you grind, the more of a mess you make because the grind hopper isn't the best design. It's deep and plastic which makes a huge static problem throwing grinds everywhere as soon as you open it, and it's difficult to empty if you're not going to just dump everything you've ground straight out into a waiting vessel. This design makes it very hard to pour freshly ground coffee anywhere. All of this I've chosen to just deal with.
Third, It has a selector which times the grinder and automatically shuts it off to grind certain amounts of coffee so that you can leave all your whole beans in the hopper and grind exactly what you need when you need it. The settings would be nice and convenient if they weren't uselessly inaccurate. I still end up scooping exactly what I need and never leaving beans in the hopper.

But worst of all, the noise is caused by high vibration which can be expected from burr grinders. What should not be expected is that over 5 or 6 months of very light use (once a week or less) the vibration has caused all of the plastic around the inside of the burr wheels to fracture and break apart. So far the grinder still operates as expected, but every time I take it apart to clean it, more plastic has chipped away. I expect the entire unit will be completely useless soon.

I am hopping that all of these problems are merely a defect in this individual unit. I may buy another soon but will probably end up getting a completely different brand with a much better engineered design.

reviews.reviewTitle: The perfect bean grinder for the price.
reviews.reviewText:
For the price, this grinder will take care of your bean-grinding needs. I've been using mine for about 3 years now without any issues and have enjoyed the hundreds of espressos that I've made with it.

Pros: Easy to use and set. The settings are consistent and I get just about the same amount of beans every time at the same size. If I want two double shots, the "8" setting gives me the same amount each time. The flavor is great.

Cons: The port to leave the grinding area is small and can get blocked with oilier beans. Not really a big issue other than having to open it back up. Also, if you leave the lid off of the side container and press start...you're in for a huge mess - be sure to have your lid on! These small issues, if you can call them that, keep this from being a 5-star.

Edit: Three days after writing this review it died. Go figure.

I drink a lot of coffee. I start the morning each day with a French press full of coffee, and play it by ear from there. I've used this grinder each day for nearly two years, and it's still going. As long as I keep blowing it out with compressed air every now and then, I imagine it's going to keep going.

Long-term issues:
- Powder in the coarse coffee grind (not enough to require a second filtering)
- Unable to produce sufficiently fine ground for espresso (forget Turkish)
- Fine particulates accumulate on the receiver plastic walls during every use. If you're lucky, they stay there while you pour out your grounds.

Age related issues:
- Cracks in the receiver plastic. I keep expecting it to break outright eventually, but it keeps on keeping on.
- It's forgetting how long to grind, occasionally doubling the produced grind that one setting should make.

Very frustrating machine. I use Starbuck's French Roast beans, and it jams and stops working. I need to unplug and use a knife point to clear the gears every time I use it, sometimes multiple times. Sometimes it just stops and won't restart. One of its design problems is that ground coffee is blown honizontally after it is ground, and the opening through which is travels is too small. I'm in the market for a better machine now - I will probably need to spend more to get better quality.

reviews.reviewTitle: Coarsest setting NOT really coarse enough!
reviews.reviewText:
If you're buying this for a French press, save your Munny. The coarsest setting is roughly 2 times the finest setting, which means it's a struggle to get the press piston to the bottom of the press. Fortunately, I was able to repair a manual, conical burr grinder that I made, which has a much wider grinding range. Coarse to me means crunching a whole bean into around twenty pieces, bigger than 1/8" in size.
I'll be giving this unit to a local charity and hopefully, someone that just needs ground coffee for an auto-drip or percolator won't really care about the coarse setting(s).

reviews.reviewTitle: Improved the taste of my coffee
reviews.reviewText:
My coffee tastes better and isn't that why you go through the extra time and expense of buying whole beans and grinding them.

This grinder is easy to set-up, use and clean. Compared to a blade grinder it is an improvement in taste and convenience. Hey at 5:30 A.M. just punching a button and having fresh ground coffee show up is almost magicial.

Would like to address some negatives I read when considering buying this machine and to be honest almost did not buy it because of some of the reviews.

First the noise - come on! Nobody makes a stealth coffee grinder. It is no noiser than a blade grinder. If the noise bothers you I know you probably complain about a smoothie maker, blender, or food processor. What do you do eat pablum out of a plastic bottle.

The grind issues - not a problem for what I use it for.

Static - yep creates some static, but with a little brush can get all of the coffee out of the container with no problem or mess. Easier to use than the blade grinder which I had to scrape some of the grind out when through.

Durability - can not answer because it is new. But warranty is 18 months and you know I have learned a little secret the longer the warranty the longer it should last and most grinders have a one year warranty. Yes Yoda I am listening.

In conclusion, looks good, easy to use, and the COFFEE TASTES DARN GOOD.

FOLLOW UP ON DURABILITY. Today is July 22, 2010 and unit has been used once or twice daily for nearly three years with only an occassional chute cleaning. I find it hard to believe so many people call it junk. Still looks good and grinds as well as day one. Just remember to take container off occasionally and clean out chute with the included brush. The reason it builds up some dust residue and eventually will impede bean progress. VERY GOOD BUY.

P.S. If you really enjoy coffee try roasting your own green beans - really improves the taste and variety.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good for the price, with a couple of caveats
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this grinder about two years ago at Costco for $25. Up until then we had been using the little bladed Krups grinders, or just grinding at the store. I thought this would make a great gift for my wife who makes the coffee in the morning as it would save her time every day. And it has done just that, day in and day out.

We brew our coffee in a french press and have set the grinder on it's near-coarsest setting, and it creates enough dust that the last cup the press is a bit sludgy. Not not really bother me.

The grinder gave up the ghost today and on taking it apart I deduced that the motor burned out from a clog. The clog appears to have been the result of the plastic collar of the bean funnel wearing where the ground coffee exits into the bin. It has worn away over two years and created a cavity that probably contributed to the clog.

Would I buy this grinder again? Yes, certainly at $25, and probably at $50, but I would clean it's internal workings more frequently and change the grind coarseness now and then to prevent the wear at one spot on the collar.

I calculated that this saved my wife about a minute each morning. That's 365 minutes a year, and over 700 minutes over the life of the machine. That's 12 hours of time not spend with drudgery, at $2/hour. Not bad.

This is the grinder I had before I upgraded to a Baratza Preciso. It's basically useless for grinding espresso. It can be adjusted between coarse and extremely coarse. You can use a lot of force to tamp down the stuff the fine setting produces and get a semi-drinkable cup of espresso, but you're never going to get beyond turd polishing with this machine. You're better off saving up for a few more weeks and getting something more expensive if you're going to make espresso.

For other uses, it would probably be adequate, but if you don't really care about grind quality, anyone can get crappy grinds from the local supermarket.

As other reviewers have noted, it is messy to clean up. I use bolder roasts so the grounds are more oily and that clogs up the works. I started grinding only enough for a pot and left the beans in the mill. After a few uses, the opening to the container would clog. Now I am grinding about a half pound at a time and putting into an air tight container, then I clean up enough to grind a half pound of a different roast. I accept that I'm going to have a mess at the end, so I prepare an area beforehand and work on several paper towels so I can just pitch them out. My biggest problem is that I like a coarse grind and this thing doesn't grind coarse enough for me. It's got a gazillion grind settings, but I don't see a whole lot of difference in them. But I think it is tons better than the 'blade' style mills.

I have had this grinder (or a model number variation) for about ten years with almost daily use. It does the job well for a drip coffee maker. One of the reasons that this grinder has lasted so long is that it is easy to get replacement parts for Cuisinart appliances. Our grinder fell off the counter and top hopper cracked at the internal screw threads. I was easily able to order a replacement. This helped extend the life of the grinder.
The reason that I am giving this model only 3 stars is that compared to a top-end grinder it doesn't have a consistent grind. There is always some fine powder after every grind, even coarse grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great coffee all day long with my burr grinder.
reviews.reviewText: • Being an avid coffee drinker, a title I’m proud of I’ve had to up my game when it comes to coffee grinders. I was able to do so with the purchase of my elegantly styled, Burr grinder. I was first sold on the 18-position grind selector. Not all mornings are created equal, and either is my desire for the strength of my coffee. Plus, I drink coffee all day long, and different times of day require different strengths of coffee. I put a lot of effort into finding the flavor in my coffee beans, and I don’t want it diminished by my grinder. I’ve owed a lessor quality grinder and besides the fact that they have not lasted, they pulverize my coffee beans into something resembling my bowling alley coffee shop’s coffee. My husband and I are the usual coffee drinkers in our home, but when it comes to offering others coffee, the slide dial comes in handy. For my book club I made 3 different types of beans using the setting for 6 cups. We had a taste test, but what I heard most was how delicious my coffee was. Another feature I enjoy is when I know I’ll be drinking a lot of coffee all day; I simply fill the plastic basket that sits atop the grinder which is enough for a few pots of coffee.

This grinder does mill from very coarse (ideal for the French Press - which I bought this for) all the way to super fine. 100% there. You can adjust the dial to just the amount of coffee you need. You'll get the hang of the slider dial with a few pots. Best to grind too little, and have to grind a little more, than to grind more than you need for the pot you are making now.

However, I use flavored coffees, and the the plastic hopper is becoming discolored. The cup where the coffee is dispensed is worse. The plastic towards the top and particularly in the corners - including the lid is completely milky white. No amount of washing will take that away - I've tried. You can feel it has an etched feeling. This is also happening on the bottom as well.

Note: this is not hampering the grinder's performance in any way; it's just a little ugly to see. It looks like maybe, over extended time. the integrity of the plastic might be compromised. And the way the unit is designed, I can't see anything else fitting in there. Still knowing this I would still buy the grinder again.

It does make an loud almighty grinding sound (I can't hear the tea kettle's whistle over it) and comes to a squeaky screeching halt, but for what awaits me in that cup, I certainly don't mind.

reviews.reviewTitle: first one broke, second one's still kicking
reviews.reviewText:
The first time I plugged in and turned on this mill, it worked for 5 second before I turned it off. I was testing it. And that was the last I got out of it. It never turned back on.

The returns process through the manufacturer was very simple, though UPS has yet to come pick up the old machine.

The machine that actually works is not too bad. It grinds alright, but produces quite a bit of coffee bean dust, which finds its way easily into the bottom of our coffee pot. I am sure a paper filter would solve this problem, but we use a metal re-usable filter, so we'll have to deal with it.

It is LOUD. I don't use it after 8pm because I feel bad for the upstairs neighbor. I mean, it's not THAT loud, but it's loud at night when people are tying to sleep, ya know? I also don't use it in the morning. Same problem.

I do like the container that the ground coffee deposits into. It's very well contained... until you open it, and coffee dust spills on your counter. Just open it over the sink and you'll be fine. But otherwise, while it's grinding nothing escapes, and I leave the unused ground coffee in the container for a few days and it seems to stay fairly fresh.

The machine is about twice the size I think is necessary for the average person or couple, but if you're going to make plenty of coffee and need to grind plenty of beans, this machine's capacity is great. It IS as tall as my actual coffee maker, though. And to be honest, I like the settings, even though I make my coffee a little less strong. So I just use a little less coffee than the machine seems to think I need. (It supposedly times it to grind for 4, 8, etc etc cups of coffee.)

reviews.reviewTitle: Very Good Value for the Money
reviews.reviewText:
I have had this grinder for a little while now, and overall I am quite pleased.

This is the fourth grinder I have owned. I bought an expensive grinder a couple of years ago, and when it worked, it did a good job, but the problem was that it constantly "froze up." I have never had that problem with this machine. It has been very reliable.

The two shortcomings of this machine have been noted by other reviewers. They should have used glass for the ground coffee receiver to avoid the static cling, and there is some amount of basically unusable powder produced with each grind.

These shortcomings can be considered as one negative effect: some amount of your coffee is wasted, either as unusable powder, or clinging to the plastic container. At most maybe 5% of your coffee might be wasted this way.

Do the math. At $8/pound, 5% loss is 40 cents lost per pound. To get a really top quality machine that avoids these problems, you might expect to pay $300 more than for this machine. At 40 cents a pound of lost coffee that might be avoided by the more expensive machine, you would have to grind about 750 pounds of coffee to break even. So to me, this is a no-brainer.

IMO, it makes no sense to compare this grinder with some $500 grinder. Compare this machine to others in its price range, and I think you will see that this machine comes up very near, if not at, the top.

This is a well-built, well functioning grinder that works in the middle grind range. Its strength is not in the espresso (fine) or the french press (coarse) grind mode. In espresso mode, the grind in not uniform enough for top-line espresso shots and you can not grind directly into a portafilter. With the coarse grind setting for the french press, this grinder produces lots of fines that can end up in your cup--like drinking sand. All that said, it is a great tool for grinding for pour-over, drip or moka pot methods. Hope this helps you pick the right grinder for your needs.

A sizeable grinder, however took up a bit more counter space than I was expecting. It was quiet which was great for all the settings, so i could truly could have whatever fine of a powder i wanted. HOWEVER, as noted in other reviews, there is quite a bit of residual that poofs into the air. I felt like magician disappearing into a cloud of coffee grounds, and my coffee is too expensive to be wasting it like that, so it got returned. wasn't quite for me.

This item is listed on the manufacturer's web site for an MSRP of $50, so I don't know what's up with the Amazon retailer's price.

Anyway, we bought this about 18 months ago and initially were quite pleased with it. It's noisy, but that's because it is powerful and FAST at grinding. The grind adjustment worked fine and so did the quantity. The output container requires you scrape the grinds and residue from it but that's the price of a classy looking design I guess.

The problem is that about 3 months ago, the automatic grind switch stopped working, requiring that we stand there and hold the 'on' switch long enough to get the quantity of grounds we needed. Then, about a month ago, even that stopped working.

Everything about this unit is heavy duty and it hurts me to throw away a perfectly good coffee grinder just because the switch is non-replaceable (and obviously cheap) but there you go...we are a throwaway society because our manufacturers try to save 3 cents on a switch...

No way I would buy this unit again, because there is no way to get instructions or spare parts for it from the manufacturer. When our Cuisinart coffee maker gives up the ghost, we'll probably go with another brand for it, too, because we're so disgusted with Cuisinart's decision to build something with such a short life span to it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Maybe this one will last longer?
reviews.reviewText: I just purchased my third Cuisinart grinder, This is a wonderful grinder - works very well if it works at all. The first one lasted for about 10 years - way beyond what I expected. The second one lasted for a year and a half - exactly the length of the warranty - and then suddenly stopped grinding. Third one came the same day, thanks to Amazon Prime one-day service. Works beautifully but I have no idea how long it will continue.

reviews.reviewTitle: No longevity but works great in the short term.
reviews.reviewText: I've owned two of these now. They are outstanding for bout a year to a year and a half. After that, they start to slow down (struggles to grind.) Finally they die. No power, no movement, no sound, nothing! For the time they work, they work great. They just don't last. I'm on my second one now and it's struggling. I can tell that it maybe has a month or two left and then it will be in the landfill. I use it 3-4 times per week max. I've always cleaned them periodically and take care of them. The quality just isn't there. I refuse to pony up another $40+ so I'm on the hunt for something better. Save your money.

I picked up one of these a few months ago because it was cheap and I wasn't sure I would be making a lot of coffee. I read all the reviews complaining about how much coffee dust it produced, but I ignored them because it was cheap. The coffee I made with it (using a french press) was good enough to get me to make coffee every day, but full of sediment. I used a coarse grind, which fell to the bottom of the collector, but a massive clump of super fine dust collected against the top of the collector. If I could scoop that out before it fell, I got less sediment, but it usually fell off when I removed the collector from the grinder. So this grinder was good enough to get me to make coffee, but not good enough to make me entirely happy with that coffee. I looked for a better model.

Yesterday I received a Bodum Bistro and made my first pot this morning. The different is significant. No dust from the Bodum, and much more flavor from the same beans and preparation. The Bodum is about $30 more expensive, but worth every cent.

Summary: It's tempting to pick this up for cheap, but if you're anything like me, you'll want something a little better.

reviews.reviewTitle: stopped working after a few months.
reviews.reviewText: Grinder worked fine for a few months then decided one day it was done. Made some funny noises and then nothing. When the grinder was working it was very messy to use. The container that the grinds fall into has a lid that comes off very easily that resulted in more than one disastrous mess. It has 18 different grind settings that range from fine to coarse. There should really only be 2 settings on this because that is all that it makes. Fine or coarse, nothing in between. As for as the "pros" go, its looks really nice sitting on the counter top and can grind a lot of coffee at one time. Again, the grinder worked "fine", just wish it lasted a little longer than a few months for the money spent on it.

I bought one of these several years ago and it still works good as new. My only complaints (and these are probably true for all grinders) is (firstly) that the bottom part is hard to clean. Whereas the cone unscrews and can go in the dishwasher, you'll have to attack the base with a wet cloth and a butter knife to force the cloth into all the crannies. However, despite its filth, mine still seems to work just fine. My second complaint is that the grounds static-cling to the sides of the (plastic) grounds chamber, so I have to knock it around a bit to get them un-stuck, thus spraying my counter with coffee dust. But these are relatively minor issues. I feel I've gotten my money's worth out of this product.

So far I absolutely love my grinder. I hadn't been making much coffee at home lately because I'm a second time new mom and trying to get the kids out the door is somewhat of a challenge. I've been eyeing one of these up for quite some time and then really wanted one after Alton Brown did his coffee episode. I had one of those little "push the top and grind" grinders, but couldn't get the ground the same size, even with using the grinder as a maraca and dancing around the kitchen with it trying to shake up the grinds. I had resorted to the vending machine coffee... *shudder*
I have made coffee every single day that I have been home since I got it for Christmas. My beans are kind of old (but stored in an air tight container in a seldom opened cabinet), so I haven't really held up much hope for them, but every cup that I have had has been by far better than any cup of coffee I've had in forever.
things I wish this had... A silicon seal on the lid to keep out air, an opaque grounds chamber and the ability to grind less than 4 servings at a time. (I'm considering getting a kuerig and would like single cup portions.)
Some people have complained about the noise, but I don't find it any louder than my original maraca grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working after less than four months
reviews.reviewText: Better off to spend a little extra on a good grinder than to pay $40 for this one that stopped working after using it for less than four months. I looked online to see if this was a known problem and if there was a way to fix it. Yes, many people have had this issue and it's apparently a problem with a safety switch. I tried the fix, but didn't work. I guess I just spent $10 a month to grind my coffee. Cuisinart is usually a decent brand too. :(

For the price point, you'll not get a better grinder; you'd pay a lot more for a more sophisticated burr grinder! It grinds evenly, quickly, and makes for a wonderful cup of coffee. I gave it a 4/5 stars because it doesn't grind as coarsely as I'd prefer, but mainly because it can be very messy if you're grinding a lot of coffee. This is a design flaw; the grinds enter the holding container from the side, not the top. These two things are negligible complaints, however, and don't take away from how much I love it! It's WAY better than a blade grinder.

Overall, it's a great appliance and I've recommend it to a few people!

reviews.reviewTitle: Not bad, but a couple complaints
reviews.reviewText:
This unit is very attractive, and does a nice job of grinding, but has a few issues that really detract from my overall satisfaction:
1) Static: Oh my! Almost everyone has mentioned the static, but let me expand a little: When you take the lid off the grinding chamber, the coffee grounds actually fly all over the place due to the static. You start to realize that the plastic grinding chamber apparently is statically charged, and the coffee grounds seem to magnetically repel the plastic chamber, and then when you touch the unit you provide a path for the static to discharge, and grounds tend to go all over the counter/floor/etc. I have had several other grinders and several with plastic chambers, but have never seen any with so much static or so much mess!
2) Clogged discharge chute: I have owned my grinder about three months and use it every morning, and about 5 times now have had to take it all appart when it stopped working due to grounds clogging the discharge chute. This causes the unit to seem like it is broken, until you take it all apart and clean it and un-clog it. And if you keep trying to grind in this condition, it quickly overheats and starts smoking!

Overall, like I said, it does do a good job grinding and it looks nice, and seems like a pretty good deal for the cost, but if you can afford to look for one without the draw backs above you might want to keep looking. So even though the grinder looks nice and grinds well, the mess is an every day annoyance you will be stuck with.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great, when it works. But it seldom works.
reviews.reviewText:
Does a great job, although it can wake the dead as it runs. (Kind of makes it problematic to grind beans in the early morning when my wife is sleeping.)

The downside ... it stops working. I have not ripped into mine (I need a cup of coffee before I can start that but .... AND, it is a big deal to take it apart. You'd think that a thing like this would be engineered so that one could get to its moving parts and clean the gunk out. Noooooooo

Oh, and forget customer support. I was considering other Cuisinart kitchen appliances but now I'll do more homework and find better products from a better company.

So far I like this machine. However, maybe I don't quite understand the cups setting. On the video it said that you can set the number of cups and dump it right into your pot. Perhaps I'm a whimp but that is still way too much coffee. I'll probably still have to use my measuring scoop and do some experimenting. That has worked pretty well so far. The other thing is that this machine is just a bit messy. Not much, just a little.

I picked up one of these a few years ago, expecting my old Bodum to eventually give up the ghost after many years of faithful service. I finally put it into service about six months ago, and today the motor burned out. I had the grind setting halfway between the 'fine' and 'medium' settings. For some reason today, the chute between the grinders and the catch cup clogged up, and it burned out before I could get over and turn it off. Design flaw? I won't be buying another.

We received this as a gift a couple years ago. I am reluctantly a "coffee snob" because of years working coffee retail, was glad to have a burr grinder.

However, this grinder is almost more frustration than it is worth. Because we purchase darker roasts, the beans have the oil on the surface. Because we use a gold cone for our daily coffee, we grind relatively fine. This combination means that we have to clean out not only the bottom part of the hopper but also the innards of the mechanism with a nut pick every couple weeks. The beans and the finer grind collect up quite quickly and clog up both where the beans go down into the burr, and also where the grinds pour out. Cleaning creates a giant mess. The alternative is that the beans will not go down to the burr to grind and we have to continually smack the top of the hopper to get the beans to go down.

So imagine, every time you want coffee, not only is there the noise of the machine, which I could deal with because I have never heard a quiet grinder, but the beans are not going through the machine so we are also running over to smack on the top of the hopper. It makes for an altogether violent coffee grinding experience. My husband is practically apoplectic everytime the thing starts to choke up again.

I can't recommend this grinder, esp. if you like darker coffee shop roasts (or even sumatra) and often grind for cone or use other finer grinds.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does a good job, but not durable
reviews.reviewText: Works great for about a year. Our third one just went down. We only use it 4 or 5 times a week, as we also drink Keurig coffee. For the price, I would expect it to last a bit longer. This time around we are going back to the cylindrical style of grinder, which seems to last longer and is easier to get your ground coffee out of (you often have to brush out the container to get the last cup or so of ground coffee out). Also, it takes up quite a lot of counter space.

I've really like this grinder for the past few years. It works well and I really like the options it provided, but finally the noise (and its quite loud) got to me and I will be replacing it. I live in an apartment and our cats freak out every time we run this. If you or anyone in your household are sensitive to sounds, I would not recommend this product.

Having read some of the reviews here, for me, this purchase was risky business. It shouldn't have been. The grinder works well for brewed coffee applications, and I knew the price dictated that it would not be the best option for espresso makers. If you are a true espresso aficionado, you know that you can not get a decent grinder for that type of application for much less than $100. If you can, you need to post that in your review. Second, plastic + grinding process = static cling for coffee grinds. There isn't a way around it unless you eliminate the plastic, which again dictates a higher priced product. I know of no sub-fifty dollar option that does not utilize plastic as the primary housing component. Further, a 1" paint brush kept near your coffee making area will alleviate the problem. I have used this grinder almost every morning for three months now and have yet to experience the "no grinds in the receptacle" problem, I can't figure out how that happens. The noise is acceptable for a hard working piece of equipment. My son has a Barista unit, priced similarly, that makes only slightly less noise and the receptacle does not lock into place as on the Cuisinart, so if you forget to hold it into place with your hand or some weighted object, you get grounds all over the counter. So if you're looking for a grinder to provide coffee grounds for brewed coffee, the DBM-8 represents one of the best values on the market. If you are wanting espresso grade grounds, look elsewhere.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not worth any price. Horribly inconsistent grinds. Awful taste.
reviews.reviewText:
Really disappointed in this grinder. I'm returning it to Costco Korea, where I live. My model is identical to this, but carries the KR designation for being sold in Korea.

The photos someone else provided showing the inconsistency in grind are true. Mine was exactly this bad. I get a big chunk of dust stuck along the top and down along the back inside the pile of grains -- so basically, this is a useless grinder. Coffee comes out tasting terrible. I had a cheap hand grinder I almost threw out, and I'm glad I didn't. This Cuisinart grinder is going back as soon as I can return it. I have to wonder how many other people have returned these to Costco, and if they plan on continuing to carry them.

Really, I have not experienced a worse grinder than this -- ever. Yes, it runs. Yes, it grinds the coffee. But it doesn't matter what setting you use, you will end up with a big blob of powdered coffee mixed into the grains.

Awful.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great first burr grinder. Have had it for 5 years. No Problems.
reviews.reviewText:
I have had this great little grinder for 5 years now and have enjoyed a fantastic cup (or 4) of coffee every morning with it. I was actually very surprised to see it getting such negative reviews on Amazon. It is super easy to use and to clean. I am no grinder aficionado, but I am a complete coffee snob. Since I bought this, it has consistently made a great cup of coffee every time.

My only complaint (there is always one of course), is that like other people have said, it always grinds a teaspoon of super fine grinds into the container no matter what setting you put it on. This isn't a big issue though as they collect right at the top of the container in a little pile that sticks to itself (coffee is oily ya know). I do French Press, so it means I need to swipe this out before I make my brew, otherwise I get extra grit in my coffee. This takes a whopping 5 seconds out of my day, and while I wish I didn't have to do it, I need only point out that this nice little grinder was only $39. It's a great deal and a great first step up from the push button thermos grinder.

First of all, I will have to admit I'm new to grinding my own beans. However, I was wanting fresher coffee so I picked this baby up at Sam's club for 30 bucks. Although I've not had it long, I really love how easy and NEAT it is. No mess, no cleanup, and I don't use a measuring scoop any more.

If this thing holds up over time (and I know that some of the reviewers have had trouble with failures), it is a great value. I'm already addicted to it... I never thought someone could make grinding your own beans EASIER than buying them already ground. I'm pretty lazy, and I usually don't dump out old coffee until I'm ready to make the next pot. If you hit the button first, then start rinsing your pot out, filter, etc, it has the coffee ready and measured for you by the time your done! It actually makes my routine FASTER!

On the loudness--It would probably wake up a light sleeper because it is about as loud as making a margarita in a cheap blender. However, mine does not have a high pitch, and I don't mind the sound to have fresh ground beans. For 30 bucks, what do you want? At this point if it breaks, I would probably take it apart and try to fix it as I'm totally amazed by it. I will follow up if I have trouble.

reviews.reviewTitle: Another poorly engineered product from Cuisinart
reviews.reviewText:
I have now formally decided never to buy a product from Cuisinart. This coffee grinder broke this morning after owning it for about six months. Oddly, it broke at the screw threads that attach the coffee bean bin to the main part of the grinder. The threads were made of cheap plastic, not steel as would be expected for such a vital part.
This is the third Cuisinart product that has failed me in the past year. I also had a coffee maker (COD 4000PC) that just stopped working. For a while I was able to push all the buttons, and suddenly it would begin to work. Finally, nothing would revive it.
I also had a Cuisinart popcorn popper that was a gift to me. It lasted about a month, when a small plastic (cheap once again) snapped off on the lid. Unfortunately, this small piece had to be in place to turn the popper on at all.
Cuisinart is able to get a price premium for its name. No longer. Cuisinart has cut so many corners that it is no longer worth the investment. Any investment at all, that is.

reviews.reviewTitle: A Workhorse - albeit a loud and messy one
reviews.reviewText:
I have had this mill for about four years, and it certainly does the job, and shows no signs of slowing down. I have the same problem as other reviewers in that about a teaspoon of coffee dust collects on the top of the bin and when you open it up after grinding, ends up all over my counter. I try to remember to ONLY open it over the sink, but no matter what I do it seems I am cleaning up the counters after a grind.

I have not had any other coffee mill, and believe that most could be noisy, but this thing sounds like a jet taking off in my kitchen in the morning. If it is particularly early and quiet in my house, I have been known to take the thing out into the garage to do the grinding so as not to awaken the whole house. Other reviewers have said it is fast compared to other mills, but to me it seems like a lifetime waiting for the thing to shut off. At times I decide I can't take it and dive onto the thing and shut it off after it does enough for about six cups. I would rather make a smaller pot than listen to the noise!

It does a good job and my coffee brews up perfectly every time so I'm not complaining too much.

I used one of those little blade coffee grinders for years and years. I remember it costing ten bucks. Alas, it gave out. By then I owned a Cuisinart Coffee Maker and bought this Cuisinart Coffee Grinder because they made a nice mated pair for the kitchen.

The Cuisinart Grinder has worked flawlessly for almost four years now and my complaints are very minor. One, it's very noisy, especially early in the morning when I'm the first one up and want my coffee before the others awake. Second, the plastic parts are fitted together very precisely and if any joint gets just a little bit clogged with coffee grains, the device won't work. I've gotten used to this problem. Third, the calibrations seem somewhat off. For example, if set it for four cups, it will grind enough coffee to easily make 8 cups of rich coffee. I've gotten used to this one too.

In any case this grinder does a fine job of grinding coffee to the desired fineness. It has preformed flawlessly in every way and my complaints are very minor.

Gary Peterson

I've been using mine for years without ever cleaning it and the only issue I ever had was that the timing for the amount of grinds you select has quit working. It just keeps grinding instead of stopping at the selected amount of grinds. No big deal to me I just stop it manually after counting the time myself. I think the coarseness of the grinding you do has a lot to do with how often it must be cleaned. I only ever grind on the coarsest setting just because that's how I prefer my coffee ground. I think it is the least bitter that way.

reviews.reviewTitle: you will not find a perfect electric burr grinder for around 50 bucks
reviews.reviewText: Really decent grinder for the money. However, you will not find a perfect electric burr grinder for around 50 bucks. The main issue I have, is that although the grind is consistent, this coffee "dust" sticks to the sides after grinding. Regardless of what grind size you set on the machine, you will always get this extremely fine dust forming on the sides and close to the top. If using a french press, you will need to scoop these chunks of dust off, as they may seep through the metal filter (they conveniently clump up, so they are easy to separate from the main grounds). This is not a huge issue, and pretty easy to deal with. Also, everything sticks to the sides of the plastic container, making grinds extremely hard to get out. However, I made a ghetto contraption to fix this. I put plastic wrap on the inside of the plastic container to form a bag, where all of the grounds pooled to the center. I had no sticking issues, and it fixed the problem perfectly. I will warn that this grinder is very, VERY messy if this bag modification is not performed. Grounds will end up in random places on your counter. Once again, it is a great bargain for an electric coffee grinder, but it is not going to be nearly at the level of $100 plus grinders. Also, the finest grind might not be fine enough for espresso makers. If you are shelling out the cash for a good espresso maker, you should probably shell out the cash for a good grinder, or at least buy a hand grinder.

First off, there is no way you can grind coffee with this item without making a mess once you're ready to remove the container with the ground beans.
Second, using it 3 or 4 times in a row seems to tire out the lethargic noisy 140W motor and it actually stops grinding. However, don't throw it the dumpster yet. Let it cool down and it will start up again. Meanwhile have a regular blade grinder handy to continue grinding coffee.
Third, as some people already mentioned, you will have to do some tweaking if you want the perfect grind by bringing the burrs closer together.

I've been using a blade grinder for years, and finally decided to make the upgrade. I do not regret the decision. I've had this machine for about two months now, and I like it.
I do have a couple of issues:
1) Static cling: The plastic cup that catches the grinds builds up a static charge. when you pull it off the machine you might get fine grinds shooting out of the opening of the closed jar onto the counter. When you take the lid off the jar, it will definitely shoot grinds into the air. I don't know if that is an issue with burr grinders in general, but it is annoying. I open it over the sink to avoid as much mess as possible. I don't think glass would avoid the issue either. I think a metal grounding wire would have to be built into the container to avoid the buildup of static completely.
2) One good thing about a blade grinder is that you can measure exactly how much coffee you want to grind. I don't like whole-beans sitting in the hopper day after day because they dry out very quickly. This machine has a switch to choose the amount of coffee to be ground, and i think it runs on a timer although i haven't tested it. It does seem to be accurate and precise IF the hopper contains more beans than you plan to grind. If you measure just the amount of beans you want to grind, they tend be bounce around in the hopper. If the beans are bouncing around in the hopper, they probably aren't going into the grinder. You need more beans in the hopper than you plan to grind, so the excess will push the beans down onto the grinder.

Other notes:
A) I used to clean my blade grinder using a bit of uncooked white rice. Simply place it in the grinder and buzz it for a few seconds. Wipe out the dust, and viola, the grinder looked brand new every time. I have not attempted that technique yet, but I wonder if that would work for a burr grinder as well. In fact, I have not cleaned my machine at all in the two months of i've been using it (once daily, 8 cups, medium grind btw).
B) It is a bit loud, but apparently all burr grinders are loud, and this one is about average.
C) I do like using the machine. I've been getting good tasting results with my drip coffee maker. The grind is consistent which is the bottom line for a burr grinder.

I have had this coffee grinder for several years, and the other day it quit working. If I ever knew that the top screwed off, I had forgotten it, and I was convinced that I was going to have to buy a new one. Today I decided to read the reviews of this model, and I owe a big "THANK YOU" to the gentleman who included the info about the top unscrewing! My grinder is working again! I do think he did it an injustice giving it only 3 stars. This is a great little machine! I do agree that it would be preferable to have a glass container for the grounds, though. By all means, spend $400+ on another one, if you're rich and/or need a status symbol, but I recommend this one for the average household.

reviews.reviewTitle: This coffee mill could be unsafe
reviews.reviewText:
I have had my Cuisinart coffee mill for a couple of years. I was fairly satisfied with it. My major complaint for most of the time was that the slider grind selection switch needed a LOT more resistance because a person could change the setting way too easily. I also found that the volume of the grind tended to be inconsistent.

Then, in the last few weeks, the grinder developed what I consider to be a very unsafe habit. It would spontaneously start without me even being in the room. At first, it would grind for the amount of time set on the selection slider and stop. A week or so ago, it started spontaneously, emptied the bin and kept running. I could only stop it by unplugging it. I plugged it back in and it stayed off until I left the room, when it did it again. I consider this a safety problem. What would have happened if I was not at home when it started to run spontaneously and did not stop. I am concerned that it could have overheated and started a fire.

Well, now, I don't have to worry about that problem anymore because it flat out died. I paid too much for this grinder to get the little service out of it that I got. I tried to contact Cuisinart and got no response. So, you folks can make of that what you want.

BTW, the only people here are me an the cats--and I don't think they are into coffee. Also, even though this is an old house, I don't believe it has any ghosts, and if it does they have not shown a preference for practical jokes.

reviews.reviewTitle: Motor fails due to coffee dust buildup under burr
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this product at Costco for a very good price after inspecting it and finding it to meet almost all my needs, and it seemed to work very well for a while, but after about 3 months the grinder motor stoped working. Cuisinart sent me a replacement with the demand that I return the original which cost me $20 in shipping, almost half what I paid new, and after about another month the new one died. It seems to me that what burnt the motor out was coffee dust collecting around the burr's causing too much friction for the motor to overcome, there is realy no good way to clean under the burr's (and I would never be able to get my wife, who uses it the most, to do that) so it's off to the store to find another, hopefully better grinder that will last a little longer, the Braun one I had before this lasted years and did a fair job, but I can not find it around anymore.
the other thing is there is no rubber seal between the ginder and the receptical for want of a 20 cent part the coffee does go everywhere.

My wife bought this and I officially hate it. It grinds the beans just fine but the mess it makes is awful. When you pull the hopper out it sends a spray of coffee dust and then what has been ground sticks to the hopper and it's very messy trying to get it all out. Even with a brush you end up with coffee dust all over the counter.

reviews.reviewTitle: Average grinder thats decent for the price.
reviews.reviewText:
I overall would not recommend this grinder due to two issues. First, it is very loud. It's very obnoxious and I feel bad when I used it in the morning when people were trying to sleep. Second, it always left powdery coffee dust after every grind that I had to brush out especially if I want a french press. The machine did grind the coffee accurately in my opinion though and it has lasted me the last four years. However, I don't grind coffee every day so maybe it would have broke within a year.
