Overall opinion: It's not bad for the price but it's worth investing in a more quiet and better grinder like the encore.

I received a DBM-8 as a gift 3 years ago. The best attribute is the lack of mess on the countertop due to it's container system and additionally it holds 1/2 pound of coffee in the above storage container. After 8 months the motor quit, I had used it once every day. I called Cuisinart - they sent me a refurbished model that quit 6 months later. 2 months later I received another DBM-8 as a gift. Same story -the motor quit less than one year later. Cuisinart was once a top of the line product. However since it's now owned by Conair - perhaps the quality has seriously declined.
My new grinder is Capresso. Quieter. Less room for the grind but I am hoping the Capresso will be a much better long lasting quality product. I could have called Cuisinart to see if they would replace the product but I have that sinking feeling another refurbished inferior quality product would have arrived.

I have had this for over a year now, and am about to throw it away it is so bad.
Consistently jams with beans and won't grind.
Often jams intermittently so it grinds a few, then whirs for a while without beans, then starts grinding again. That meas the amount of beans is inconsistent because the quantity setting is a timer assuming it is grinding all the time.
VERY MESSY to empty, and almost impossible to transfer the coffee grounds to the pot without making a mess.
Very noisy

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working after three months. And it was a ...
reviews.reviewText: Stopped working after three months. And it was a wedding gift so we have no recourse, the warranty won’t be honored without the receipt. It’s also the loudest thing I’ve ever heard at 6am, it’s unbearable. What a piece of junk. Save your money and get a $20 one. We had to pull out our old grinder that still works after five years after this fancy one broke.

Bought this at my local BBB, since I needed it ASAP. I have tried practically every grind setting and the coffee tastes exactly the same every time. This isn't a good thing. I have tried various types of beans and there is absolutely no difference in flavor. Is this a defective machine? Anyone have any luck on the various grind settings? Using this with a Bonavita 1800. I have an email in to Cuisinart customer service to see if something can be done.

reviews.reviewTitle: I Use This In My 4-Cup drip
reviews.reviewText:
I Love It. Why?

1) Got it cheap, $18
2) Burr tastes better, even in drip maker
3) Premeasures for my 4 cup, so I just hit the button. So much faster than using my whirly grinder than I make coffee most every morning now instead of buying out.
4) Coffee dust not a big deal for me. I tap the "catcher" on my counter once or twice while tilted, then pour coffee right into my filter. Fast prep, yeah!
5) For cleanup, catcher goes into dishwasher weekly and I use a dry paper towel to polish out the dust between washes.
6) I have dark countertops, but w my methods, no dusty mess.
7) Has easily PAID FOR ITSELF since home coffee so much faster/easier.
8) Motor still beefy after 2 mos.

I don't french press often (cholesterol) so no issues there.

UPDATE: 12/31/2013

While I don't brew coffee everyday, this grinder is still going strong after all this time. Not bad. Never had a problem so far.

reviews.reviewTitle: A fine grinder with too small of a hopper.
reviews.reviewText: All of the functionality of this grinder is great, super easy to use, super easy to adjust, it works. The hopper for the beans though is too small! Given coffee pretty often comes in 1 lb bags, it's frustrating that the hopper holds maybe 80% of a pound, so I fill it up and then I'm left with a rolled up bag of a few more days worth of beans sitting around. Not a deal breaker or anything, I still like the grinder, it just seems like an obvious oversight.

I've had one of these units for 10 years. It's been used daily, and cleaned infrequently. I've dropped the plastic collection container so many times while washing it that all of the edges are chipped. Yet it soldiers on reliably.

The criticisms others have mentioned are mainly 1) it's loud, 2) static build-up in the collector is annoying, and 3) grinding size is inconsistent. All of these are true. But if your goal is to have a relatively consistent coarse (french press) vs. med (drip) vs. fine (stovetop espresso) grind size at a decent price point, this machine can't be beat. As a side note, I have used 99% very oily, dark roasts and the machine handles them with aplomb.

If you're a coffee snob looking to find a burr grinder for your $600 espresso machine, this might not be your first choice. For anyone else, it should definitely be.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stay away, junky product that breaks
reviews.reviewText: Stay away this product broke after 6 months and their warranty process is bizarre. After six months of use the product totally stopped working. I tried to get a warranty replacement. After contacting them twice about replacement they told me to mail them the power cord and $4 and they would replace it... What a bizzare company. Never again.

reviews.reviewTitle: OK, given the price, however I'm already looking for better
reviews.reviewText:
I have had this grinder for about a year now and I'm increasingly finding myself looking for an excuse or an alternative purpose so that I may dispose of this grinder. It works OK but has a few very annoying characteristics that I just can't see past:

1. Probably the most important feature of all is uniformity of grind. I use the coursest setting for french press coffee prepartion but this grinder still produces a lot of powder - there simply is no way around it. It is also very messy because of this. My counter tops are light and I cannot make coffee without making a mess - it is impossible. Just the act of removing and replacing the recieving container dumps powder everywhere.

2. Too much plastic - if the recieving container were made of glass the coffee would not cling to it. The faux stainless plastic doesn't clean or shine very easily and should be used by law enforcement to record fingerprints.

3. This is nitpicking I know but I'd like to be able to remove and replace the coffee bean hopper without spilling beans everywhere. In fact, having two hoppers that are interchangeable would be even better - there should be some sort of stopper in the bottom that is only oppened when the grinding begins.

reviews.reviewTitle: Groind chamber static isn't an issue
reviews.reviewText:
Used it 3 times, if things change will update review:
The grinder burs seem to be metal, used a magnet to check.
The ground chamber does get a little "foggy" with grinds, I used it on setting 2.5 for Nespresso pod refill, so finer would probably stick more from static. HOWEVER, just a shake or knock and 90% falls away, so doesn't seem to be much of an issue. After 3rd grind, I simply washed out real quick under running water, it took no effort. So "static" doesn't seem to be such a big deal as some made it out to be, at least for me.
Overall seems well quality for $45 and has enough grind settings from 1-9 with 1/4 increments, that "click" so easy to tell the setting.

reviews.reviewTitle: better than a blade grinder for coarse-grinding coffee
reviews.reviewText:
Asked for a burr grinder for Christmas, as an upgrade for my blade grinder. It's definitely meeting that need, as it grinds much more consistently than a blade grinder, and at a decent price for an entry level electric/auto burr grinder. That said, I have two main complaints about this grinder:
1) The plastic bin that holds the ground coffee is just a bad design all the way around. The small opening is prone to clog if you don't keep it clean, and it's messy, especially on the finer grind settings. It holds just enough static electricity that the coffee clings to the sides, and so you have to make sure to cover the hole when tapping it on the counter to get the coffee off the sides, and when you are trying to pour the ground coffee out into your maker you're likely to end up with some on the counter, because even if you try to use the corners as a way to direct the coffee, some still clings to the bottom and falls out as you upend the container.
2) There needs to be a pulse setting for the grind. The pre-defined increments aren't granular enough, and so if you need "just a little more" coffee than the 4 cup setting, but less than the 6 cup setting (i.e. if you measure by weight), you may have some trouble. Otherwise, you end up having to measure the unground beans and add the right amount every time (so that it grinds 'til it runs out of beans), which sort of makes the hopper less useful.

I think the sweet spot for this grinder is for someone who wants to have consistent freshly ground coffee for drip coffee makers or a French Press, as it does volume and coarser grinds well. I use an Aeropress for my usual coffee maker, and while this grinder works for that application, it's definitely not the best choice. If you're looking for something affordable and low-volume that handles finer grinds better and don't mind a little manual labor, search for ceramic burr grinder and go with the Kyocera or Hario hand crank models.

reviews.reviewTitle: Reasonably good burr grinder for a good price
reviews.reviewText:
Near as I can tell, if you want an electric burr grinder for $50 or less, you have two choices: the Melitta 80395, and this Cuisinart. I've owned both, and prefer the Melitta.
First, it's quieter; a big plus in the early morning before you've had your coffee.
Second, both are easy to use with simple, intuitive controls but the Melitta has a slight advantage; it's a little more straightforward, and once set retains settings better than the Cuisinart. It's also easier to clean.
Third, if there's any difference at all in the grind, the Melitta seems a little more even and consistent; but that could be my imagination.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a good choice for espresso, but might help break your lease
reviews.reviewText: Got the "Supreme Grind" and only kept it for one day before returning it. Despite its coffee-house looks, it's cheaply built and horrendously noisy--don't use this at night in an apartment if you like your neighbors. Despite the snarl of its (apparently well-hidden) jet engine, it does a very inconsistent and inadequate job. Even at its finest setting, it produces coffee bean chunks that vary from drip-grade coarse to not-so-fine. If you've got an espresso machine that won't give you that crema unless you feed it consistently finely ground coffee, you'll be disappointed with this grinder. Your espresso machine will blow water through the coarse bits and give you 15-second weak shots. On the other hand, if you need a grinder for drip/filter or French press coffee, this grinder will probably satisfy you since that equipment isn't nearly as "picky" as espresso machines are.

I bought this from Macy's. It grinds really nicely, and I really enjoyed using it. It makes an excellent cup of coffee too. I did have a problem with how long it lasted. I make hot coffee maybe 4-5 months out of the year total. I had it for about 2 years before the motor died, so figure one year of daily use give or take. No way to repair it so it's in the trash.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent, but not the best grinder for French Press
reviews.reviewText:
We've had our DBM-8 grinder for about 4 or 5 years and it finally gave out. That's about $10 per year of use. Not bad.
This is not the best grinder if you use a french press (or "freedom press" as we call it around here). It will produce a coarse grind but if you run the grinds through a fine sifter, as we do, almost half of it falls through. That means that the grinds would have also snuck through the mesh of the press, producing silt in coffee.
Time to move on to a better coarse grinder. I'm sure it will cost more than $50. Any suggestions?

reviews.reviewTitle: It's been working for 7 years and still going strong!
reviews.reviewText: When I first purchased this I had the choice between this model and the cheaper cuisinart model. I splurged and went with this one. It has worked excellently, consistently, for seven years now. The grind adjustment provides a coarse grind that is just right for a french press. I came across another burr grinder with a grind adjustment option, the Krups GVX2 at a second hand store for five dollars, it looked hardly used and I bought it as a back up in case this one ever died. The Krups does not provide a truly coarse grind like this cusinart does but the cuisinart does not provide the talcum like fine grind that the Krups does. For me this is fine as I need the coarser grind for a french press. I only grind one or two cups of coffee at a time so I have never overtaxed the motor. It is as good now as it was when I bought it. The one problem I had was that a tab on the bottom of the grind chamber broke off. That tab was necessary for this to operate as it is part of a safety mechanism. It engages a switch when the grind chamber is in place. Since the machine will only grind when that grind chamber is in place there is no danger of spraying coffee grinds over the room. It was easy enough to buy a replacement chamber from cuisinart. If you are going to make expresso, I would recommend something that grinds fine such as the Krups, for everything else this grinder works great.

I make a 4 shot espresso every morning. Never miss a day.
For years I had a Capresso Burr Grinder and decided to take it apart and clean it thoroughly. Somehow I had lost the 3 internal bearings and my wife suggested replacing the grinder.
So, I received this Cuisinart Grinder as a Christmas Present to replace the Capresso.
Bad move for a guy that only enjoys espresso.
At the finest setting for grinding beans, the grind is way too coarse. No crema, just brown water.
Ordered another Capresso and the Cuisinart is boxed up ready to be returned.
Can't wait till Wednesday when my new Capresso 565.05 Infinity Conical Burr Grinder, Stainless Steel arrives.

reviews.reviewTitle: Industrial Grade Grinder for a Reasonable Price
reviews.reviewText: My company runs on coffee, and our coffee supply depends on our Cuisinart DBM-8 grinders. We bought a couple of these grinders three years ago, grinding a half dozen pots a day, and they're still going strong. Once in a while, the grinder will get clogged up, particularly when we've been making a finely-ground, dark and oily brew. A quick clean-up of the clogged output has restored the grinder to full operation. I like the fact that the grinder can be automatically set for anywhere from 1-18 cups, and the grind set for a course grind suitable for a French Press or a fine grind suitable for a strong dark pot of coffee. We went through (and in short order broke) a couple of more flimsy grinders. The Cuisinart DBM-8 has held up extremely well and continues working well.

reviews.reviewTitle: What an absolute mess this makes
reviews.reviewText:
I like this grinder but a few things:
1.) It makes an ABSOLUTE MESS EVERY TIME I use it - there is some kind of static electricity or pressure that comes off the receptacle that causes ground coffee to fly everywhere each time I take the fresh ground receptacle lid off.

2.) The ground receptacle is not large enough.

3.) It is very noisy.

reviews.reviewTitle: Muffled with a towel - and best price for grind
reviews.reviewText:
Similar to others input - nice price, works well, loud, design of grind container is poor but gets job done with a bit of mess - I've found it best to immediately dump grounds into a container and then scoop them out as needed
Using a towel around it has muffled and lowered noise to a tolerable level - I cannot comment on the safety of this - try at your own risk - I'm not a grinder designer or electrical engineer but my ears are less bothered now

Good grinder. I got it as a gift over two years ago. I clean it after the hopper empties each time (use Q-tips to get the nooks and crevices). I don't appreciate the static build up or the dust that accumulates at the top of the grounds chamber where the lid attaches--especially since coffee should be uniform for consistent quality. But I drink a lot of coffee, and so I usually store it away until the end of the week, then I use it to make a cup with a paper filter.

I'm looking into getting a manual burr grinder just so I don't wake up my wife with the grinder motor every morning. I'm also looking into this option because I'm trying to cut back to just two cups a day, and I prefer the pour-over method.

If someone knows of a good manual coffee grinder, let me know.

Mine suffered premature failure after only 4 months of use. At first mine made a different noise than it had before, then quickly failed to run at all. This was accompanied by the aroma of melting electronics.

In addition to the failure listed above, the machine is loud enough to wake the dead, seriously like 90 dB. I several times refused to run the thing in the morning for fear of waking my roommate who lives upstairs.

reviews.reviewTitle: no better than a whirly blade for a uniform grind
reviews.reviewText:
I have used this product for a couple years. I have always been disappointed with the extra fine grind (dust) that comes through, but just figured that you couldn't do better. I don't know if it is the plastic burrs or what, but the fact of the matter is that you do not get a uniform grind. Recently I had used one of the 80$ Capresso burr grinders and was amazed by the uniformity of the grind, none of the dust was present (they have steel burrs).
So what I'm saying is that if you just want to grind coffee, there is no need to buy this, just use a 15$ whirly blade grinder. If you want a uniform grind, don't look here, save up 40$ more and buy a Capresso.

2 stars because the output is smaller than the input beans.

Let's start at the beginning. When grinding coffee one must stay by it and shake it to keep the coffee beans feeding into the grinding hopper. Then to take the lid off the holding bend, coffee goes onto the counter or it drops from the lid. One cannot empty the finished ground coffee directly into the coffee maker's basket as the basket is square and large too big so grinds goes everywhere. An alternative of using the measuring spoon to get coffee grinds out of the square bend is, well you know, it doesn't work. The good news it that the grind setting works.

Summary: the grinder should have been designed so the coffee beans could fall freely in the to grinder. If a lid is needed, it should be designed so coffee would not stick to it as it does now with the groves around the sides, maybe with a tap and with easy opening. The bend should be round and smaller than the coffee maker filter for easy empting.

We received this grinder 2 1/2 years ago as a gift. It has been used daily ever since and has provided excellent service. It would be even more reliable if it had fewer features. Ours failed when the timer brains malfunctioned. An explanation of how the controls work is necessary here. You select how many cups worth of grounds you need with the slider switch and then push the start button. After a certain amount of time determined by the slider switch position, the machine stops automatically. Unfortunately, ours started automatically at 2:30 AM a few weeks ago, which was truly hair-raising, since the grinder is pretty loud. Our solution was to make do by moving the slider to "OFF" after grinding, which worked well for a while.

However, one of us didn't move the slider to "OFF" after grinding a few days ago. We later noticed the bean hopper was empty and the grounds canister was very full, so we deduced that it had started itself again and ground all the beans that were there. Today we tried to grind some more and it failed to operate. I took it apart to investigate and discovered that the motor is fried. It must have run until it burned itself up.

If the grinder had a simple on-off switch, this would not have happened. Cuisinart food processors are made this way. Why can't the coffee grinders be the same? Probably because the motor is not designed for continuous duty. We're now trying to decide whether to buy this model or something else.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stylish, but short life and poor performance
reviews.reviewText: It's an attractive grinder, holds plenty of coffee and it worked great for about 6 months. After that, I started having problems. The first problem is that the grinder got backed up with coffee. That's not a big issue - it can be cleaned with a toothpick. The cup, even after a thorough cleaning and drying, would have places where the coffee would stick, building up over a few grinds and never releasing without scraping it out. Scraping the coffee just seemed to make it worse. I gave the whole grinder a thorough cleaning on the outside, and the cup as well. After that, the cup started slipping out when grinding and it has to be held in now while grinding. Now the whole thing has gone out (after 1.5 years) by getting caught, on of all things, a coffee bean. I'm definitely willing to spend $20-50 more to get something that will last.

Fairly consistent grind. The time setting leaves a lot to be desired. If you move it a fraction it may add 50% to the amount. Once you determine where to set it, it's a minor deal. I wouldn't recommend it if you make less than 4 cups at a time and vary the cup amount. I set it near 4 for 8 cups and halfway between 4 and 6 for 12 cups. There needs to be a positive stop on the adjustment with more accuracy. Still good for the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good grinder but beware of STATIC!
reviews.reviewText: Purchased for my husband as a Christmas gift. He likes it except for the STATIC that I hadn't heard about. Evidently, dark roasted coffee beans cause a static build up & makes a mess if you try to get the coffee out right away. I did some research online concerning this & found so many were having the same problem. There are various solutions to try but he just lets the ground coffee sit until the static dissipates. We only grind dark but I read the lighter blends don't have so much of a problem. Seems to work for him. Overall, the grinder works very well & he'd recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: but this is a terrible grinder. I have used several different burr grinders ...
reviews.reviewText: I'm sorry, but this is a terrible grinder. I have used several different burr grinders over the years, and this is hands down the worst. It is LOUD! So loud, in fact, it scares my cat out of the kitchen. The grind is terribly inconsistent. I get fine, mixed with larger pieces of bean. The quantity selector is not granular... in other words, there is nothing between 0 cups and 4 cups. I only have time for a single cup during the week (really equals a "2 cup" setting if it had one). The plastic capture bin is all static! The grounds adhere to the sides, and then when I try and pour the grounds into my coffee maker, they go all over the place! I hate it so much, I'm just going to just throw the thing out after 2 weeks and go back to my beloved Capresso, which is more expensive, but has NONE of the faults I've described here.

I am on my 2nd grinder. My first one lasted over 7 years and I have had my current grinder 2+ years now, and I love it! Blade grinders to grind up all the beans completely and burn the beans up. This burr grinder is excellent. I adjust the grind to my liking and away I go. Excellent fresh coffee every morning. The only down side is it's very noisy compared to a blade grinder. It's still so much better I deal with the noise and Cuisinart has never failed me. Down the road after years of use on my 2nd grinder, I'll still look for this one to buy again. No 5 stars due to noise.

One of the things that attracted me to this grinder was the fact you could put all removable parts in the dishwasher top rack for cleaning. When I did so however, the bean hopper had some condensation at the bottom and the grinder would not work until that dried itself out (a couple of days later). In addition, the plastic grind chamber came out of the dishwasher etched -- it looks dirty. After only two months, I ordered a replacement grinder chamber and will hand wash only now. As for the bean hopper, I will wipe clean from now on.

Needing to replace our old blade grinder, we chose the DBM-8 for its apparent adjustability, ease of use, large capacity hopper, and price.

After 3 months of use, we've replaced it with a Capresso burr grinder.

Why?

It's incredibly noisy; we had to move it out into the garage. Its grind is inconsistent. You can hear a period of a second or two when no beans at all are between the burrs. It clogs easily, even when grinding at the coarse setting. It's difficult to clean the recessed area below the lower burr. The ground coffee receptacle has a lid on that's difficult to remove — the last thing you want when dealing with something that's full of fine particles. The square shape of the receptacle, combined with the presence of a smallish square hole in the side through which the grounds are deposited makes for difficult removal of statically charged grounds.

By comparison, the Capresso is quiet, its conical burr grinds consistently with less static charge, it's easy to clean, doesn't clog, and has a well-shaped basket.

Stay away from the Cuisinart.

I bought this grinder hoping that it would do as advertised: grind coffee for an espresso machine. The finest grind that this machine offers is too coarse for a good espresso machine which is not a huge surprise considering the price of the machine.

That fact alone would not cause me to write a negative review, in fact there are many features of this grinder that I like: the automatic timer feature being my favorite. Set the dial to the number of cups you intend to brew and it will grind the appropriate amount of grounds. This is a positive feature and was the reason that I chose to keep the grinder instead of returning it to the store.

The grinder worked very well for about 3 months (long enough for the return policy to expire) and then started to die. At first, every few times you pressed the grind button it would do nothing. Sooner or later it would finally start grinding. After a while, the machine stopped grinding all together. It is now dead and sitting in a cupboard.

I admit, I did not bother with the warranty, at this point I don't care as I now use a blade grinder.

I do not recommend this product even though I would normally recommend Cuisinart products.

I never write reviews but I have to speak up for this one. I like it in general. The hopper is a cool feature and the capacity is good. BUT I had one for about 6 months and the motor died. I’m a one-cup-a-day drinker. So I went back to my small one for a while. I missed the Cuisinart so I bit the bullet and bought another one. I used it for probably four months then more or less quit coffee. Used it 2 more times for guests and that was it. Dead again. DO NOT BUY!

reviews.reviewTitle: The 4th one purchased in just two years, Not Again....
reviews.reviewText: I am generally such a huge fan of Cuisinart, which is why I purchased this Burr Grinder. I like how easy it is to use this and it really does have a sharp appearance, and I love it while it lasts which is why I purchased 4 of these in only two years before deciding this is my last one! Each one worked great until one day it just quit working. My husband took the last one apart hoping he could fix it however he found that the inside was all corroded, and there were a couple screws that seemed to belong nowhere. I think that after the 4th grinder, it's safe to say that Cuisinart may need to go back and do some fine tuning on this one, some think this is too loud, but most electric grinders are, and the noise doesn't last long. Still, I wouldn't recommend this grinder just because they just don't seem to last very long, and we only use ours once each day in the morning, and that's it!

We've been using our "re-manufactured" unit every day for 6 months. We have been so happy with it, I thought I should drop a note here and report. I was so surprised to see so many negative reviews. Everything about the grinder has been a positive experience at our house. It's a little noisey but no screeching and dog howling here. It takes up very little room on the counter. Easy to fill and empty. Stays clean with a few whisks of a rounded brush I got years ago at Starbucks. The best is that we have never had such consistently good coffee. Our coffee is good every day. We use a variety of beans from a local roaster and from Gevalia. Some oily. Some dry. In the past we had good days and so-so days with the same beans and assumed it was the amount of coffee we ground, the inconsistent grinding of our blade grinder, water temperature, etc. No more. With this grinder it's great coffee every day. I'm going to look it over and see if I have build up, though. Too many reports here of burnt out motors. So far, so very good. I recommend it highly.

I enjoyed this product for the short time that it worked. I got this item for Christmas 2016 not even 6 months later it stopped working. After a lengthy and difficult customer service encounter I received a replacement. All was working good until the replacement broke again a few weeks ago. Since it broke I have been trying to contact customer service we exchange a few time until complete silence on their end. After dealing with the customer service of Cuisinart I will be very wary before buying their products in the future.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not the very best, but recommended.
reviews.reviewText: This is a very good burr grinder for the price. Of course, you could pay much more for a 5-star grinder. I have not reached the status of a fully certified coffee snob (so close!), so this is the one for me. I have found that the #18 course grind puts out more fine then I need, but because I double filter my cold brew, it does not present a problem. The burr wheel bound up after a bit, so now I occasionally use a wooden swizzle stick to poke out the fine build-up in the burr chamber and discharge opening.

Too messy. Grinds go everywhere when taking lid of top of where the grinds end up. Cleaning the tiny hole where grinds come out is hard and messy. Coffee has no taste compared to when we use our manual grinder for French press. Nice to have multiple settings but the setting for drip coffee is also leaving coffee watery and tasteless compared to just buying my pre ground coffee. Would try capresso next time based on reviews but this was a gift so will use.

Bought 2, the one for home has lasted years. The one for the office lasted 6 months, and died suddenly. Loud, as others have noted. Does a good job grinding - we use the largest grind size for French press. Poor internal design: ground coffee eventually fills odd internal spaces, and when we tried to shake it out we got ground coffee all the way up into the timer switch housing. Took some time to shake that back out and get the switch to work properly again.

I bought this coffee grinder from a brick and mortar store. Using was great, but, it completely quit in about a year. I guess the motor isn’t built to last. I didn’t reach out to the mfg. it just went into the trash.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor Design Concept, Poor Performance, Get a Conical Burr Instead
reviews.reviewText:
Back around the year 2004, a hurricane hit my area and I lost power for 8 days. My blade grinder was useless to me, so I did the best I could with a bag of coffee beans, a hammer, and a 9" chef's knife. After that experience, I purchased a hand cranked, conical burr grinder made in Germany. The coffee tasted so much better, I ditched the blade grinder.

Now 8 years of hand grinding has become kind of a grind (sorry!), so I decided to get an electric burr grinder. I settled on the Cuisinart since a friend of mine recommended it. But there were issues right from the start, and these stem from the product's design.

First of all, this machine is a burr grinder, not a conical burr grinder. This means that gravity alone won't get the grinds out of the burrs, the burr wheel needs to spin at high speed to fling the grinds out of the burr wheel. The result?

*The brew came out more bitter using this machine; I grind medium to coarse for drip and sometimes pressed coffee.
*Inconsistent particle size; there is more dust than with the conical burr, which probably explains the bitterness due to over extraction of the dust.
*Overheated particle; spinning the grinder so fast to fling out the product puts way too much mechanical energy into shearing the beans. The energy is imparted to the flake / ground / particle as heat, which alters the flavor in the grind. Not good to re-roast the coffee!
*Noise!!! My lawn mower makes less noise than this grinder.

So, just three weeks into using this machine, it finally just stopped and wouldn't start, not even after cleaning. What a relief! The folks at BB&B were good about taking it back.

Now I'm on the hunt for an electric conical burr grinder with a reduction gear. Slow grinding is important. Consistent particle size is important. Yes, they cost a little more, but for the price of a couple of bags of coffee, you can get a machine that gives you better flavor out of your beans. I will never consider a flat burr grinder again; either they grind slowly and you have a lot of grinds left in the burr wheels and delivery chute that get stale and go into your next pot, or they run too fast and get hot and dusty.

Now, the noise is gone, I have great tasting coffee, and I'm ready for the next hurricane. (I'm keeping the hand crank.)

reviews.reviewTitle: You need to spend a bit more for a decent burr grinder
reviews.reviewText: If you are switching from a blade grinder to a burr this may be a bit of an upgrade. however, this is probably the lowest quality burr grinder there is. The purpose of buying a more expensive burr grinder is to get a more uniform, consistent grind. This product will not provide that. With every grind, there was really fine powder and coarse grounds at the same time. A really good burr grinder will have solid metal burrs doing the grinding. This has two thin metal plates attached to plastic pieces. If you want a good burr grinder, go with a Baratza. If price is a concern, I have also had luck with Capresso 560.01 Infinity Burr Grinder, which is less expensive than most.

Cuisinart has had problems with not only their products but with customer service as well. Currently they are recalling a multitude of food processors due to the blade breaking apart and causing injuries to people's mouths and damaging teeth. This particular grinder is noisy and suffers from "fly away" coffee grinds.....problems with longevity of the motor and the electric on/off switch are also big negatives. Look elsewhere. This is NOT a good grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stay away unless your hobby is appliance repair
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this unit for about 3 months. When it works the grind is decent but getting it to work is a problem.

For the last week or two my unit would operate sporadically. Sometimes it would not turn on unless I jiggled it, moved the hopper, took out the bin and replaced it, etc.. Yesterday it would not start period. After googling around I found that these units have two safety switches - one on the hopper and one on the output bin so that it won't operate if these are not in place. Seems like the switches they use are junk and go bad pretty easily. Took mine apart (because who has time to try to replace under warranty - I NEED my coffee now!) and found that the safety switch on the hopper was faulty. Easy solution was to take it out of the circuit so it is always "on".

Put it back together and it works! Made a pot of coffee and could move on with my life. Today it didn't want to run again. I have to move the cup selector back and forth so I fear this switch/timer circuit is going bad. Unless small appliance repair is your hobby, do your self a favor and stay away.

reviews.reviewTitle: Can't go the distance...gasses out in 90 days
reviews.reviewText: We purchased two of these and both failed within 3 months after daily use. I thought the first failure may have been a fluke and bought the same model as I liked the size of the 'hopper'. It held about a 1/2 pound bag of whole beans and still fit easily under the counter, etc. Unfortunately, the second device failed as well. Although we used it almost every morning (set at about the 4th dot and 12 cup setting), I'd expect these to last much longer. I've had smaller units with hoppers that could only store about a 1/2 cup worth of beans last more than 2 years.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does a good job at grinding various kinds of beans with little ...
reviews.reviewText:
This review is for the cuisinart supreme coffe grinder.

Does a good job at grinding various kinds of beans with little effort.

Pretty noisy, but this is a tool after all, and you are grinding hard beans so that should be expected.

The grinder has an 18-position grind selector, from ultra fine to coarse. Cup adjustable grinding by sliding dial from 4 to 18 cups

We picked this grinder so we could do larger amounts of coffee beans. You can select portions up to 18 cup portions. That works nicely, but when emptying out the canister used, it is very messy. Fine coffee grounds end up in quite a large area. I've taken to working over a paper towel to help guide the mess. This doesn't always help. The mess is disappointing.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works just fine for a mid-priced coffee grinder.
reviews.reviewText: I have had this attractive bean grinder for a few weeks and have used it 4 or 5 times. Very easy to use and the consistency of the grounds is good although there is some powder and some of it stays in the square spout. The little brush doesn't get it all out so you have to tilt it forward and tap it. And that process means some cleanup on the countertop. But it's not a big deal. Other models probably do the same thing. It is a bit noisy but you can walk away and come back when it's finished. I am happy with this mid-priced coffee grinder. The coffee tastes really good.
I have used this daily for more than 3 years now and it still works well. Different grinds different beans never had an issue. I wish all appliance purchases would work out like this.

reviews.reviewTitle: After two of these, I upgraded to a Capresso
reviews.reviewText:
After going through two of these Cuisinart grinders in six or so years, I decided to spend another $24 and get a Capresso 560. The Cuisinart works fine but is very loud. I'd usually start it and leave the room to avoid the din. Conversation is impossible when it is grinding.

And both broke after a couple years.

I took my broken Cuisinart apart this morning: the grinding burrs (where the work gets done) consist of two opposing plates about 3/8" thick. The conical burrs on the Capresso look to be about an inch -- and are easy to clean.

The Capresso grinds more slowly, generates less heat and static -- all good.

So for me the extra $24, was worth it.

We had this grinder less than 45 days before the engine completely froze up and burned up. We use a very fine grain for brewing and perhaps it was too fine, but it is incredibly disappointing to see that the engine could not handle grinding a few days a week. Perhaps it was a lemon but we are stuck with no grinder and no help as it was a gift.

I've used the Supreme Grind DBM-8 for around 20 months and like the grind very well. Noise level is high, but to me worth the quality of the grind. I cleaned it regularly so that the opening to the ground coffee chamber wouldn't fill up. Around 4 months ago, it started working of and on. One day it would grind, another day it wouldn't. I still kept using it when it wanted to work. The problem progressively worsened until 3 weeks ago, when it stopped working. I could hear the motor start and then quickly stop so I asked Mr. Grampy Fixit to take a look.

The bottom line that he learned is that the circuit board has too much on it. Electrical power gets to the circuit board, but because there are many electrical connective parts and at least one is not working, power gets no further. Cuisinart used to be an assurance of a long-lasting quality product, bought my first Cuisinart processor in 1974 and it lasted around 20 years. I think it was a French product made in France. But I won't buy another Cuisinart coffee grinder and probably will pass on other Cuisinart products from now on. The design may be good, and production in China may be the problem, but it isn't my problem any longer!

This is neither an expensive nor a fancy coffee grinder, just one that gets the job done at a great price. You can pay 2-3 times the price of this grinder (or many times more), but why would you.
I've owned this product for several years, and it's still going strong. I use mine EVERY day. As in every day.
There is a wide range of settings, from fine for espresso to rough for french press. It provides a consistent grind on the largest setting, making for really good french press coffee.
I highly recommend this machine to everyone. Stop buying pre-ground, inferior coffee. Get this grinder, buy your beans whole, and grind them as you use them.Bodum Chambord Coffee Press
I purchased this as a gift for my son and he loves it! In his words, "It's a beast!" I am so happy that he is satisfied and happy with it. 😀😀😀😀😀💪💪💪💪💪💪

reviews.reviewTitle: Never an issue. Money's worth for me.
reviews.reviewText: I have owned this grinder for four years now. Only now am I investing in an expensive Gaggia 8002 MDF and not because the Cuisinart has failed but, because I will need a better grinder to make true expresso. The Cuisinart has performed beautifully from rather coarse grinds for French pressing to medium for drip and fine for Moka pot. I have never taken it apart to clean the burrs although I probably should. The grinder which was an upgrade from a blade unit has delivered my money's worth over the years.

I absolutely love this grinder. It serves my needs quite well, especially for the price and I keep it clearned up...about once a week I unscrew the hopper and brush all of that stuff out and turn it upside down and tap, and also brush out the shoot. Takes maybe three minutes....big deal. Also, the static thing doesn't bother me, as those would have been fines left in my french press coffee. A little bit makes for richer coffee but if it weren't for them sticking to the side and being easy to brush off I'd probably have somewhat sludgy coffee.

Wanted to like this sleek design when I saw them dumped at COSTCO for $30 recently.
Reviews weren't encouraging, but this machine looked like a great value. However, it WILL NOT grind fine enough for any espresso machine. Worse, its distribution of particle size is poor, as much dusting occurs due to the integral high speed blade. Thus it's very noisy, heating beans somewhat, like a cheap blade, and also deceptively slow.
The hopper design is a saving grace, but the receiver bin is awkward to load and fragile.
Use is therefore restricted to less-critical pour-over methods where uniform particle size isn't as necessary for decent extraction. (Therefore not so good for presses, either.)
I bought three of these, but the two unused ones are going back, as it's not really better than a $20 blade grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Decent but motor stopped working after ~1 year
reviews.reviewText:
I really loved this grinder. I bought it at Costco and it seemed great. After about a year it just stopped working. I use a Bialetti for my coffee and I like to grind it fresh daily so this worked well for me but it was also nice to grind a lot when needed if I had people over so the large chamber was useful.

Once criticism is that the coarseness settings don't appear to make a difference in what the grounds come out looking like. Maybe I'm blind. I also don't like that the beans get stuck in the blade area and it is hard to clean that part of the unit.

Costco has stopped carrying it so they just gave me my money back. I suspect they stopped carrying it because so many people were returning the item.

i went into a discount store looking for a coffee grinder. They only carried this model. It was reconditioned and under 25 dollars. There were no department stores in the area, i had no options, so i bought it. i had always used ground coffee and had no idea what the difference was between a blade or a burr grinder. OF course i was amazed with the results and delighted with the product! I have been using the grinder almost daily for about 4 years and it works perfectly. i clean the grinder by running a "fine" cycle with 1 TB. white rice. while I do agree there is problem with static cling and the teaspoon of coffee powder that results, this machine meets all my needs. ALso, i do unplug it after every use as reccomended and wonder if this has any bearing on life expectancy.

I;ve had this grinder for the past 3 years and it has worked like a dream. It is easy to use, has multiple settings for fine to coarse grind, and is easy to clean. I've used it to grind beans for my 12-cup coffee maker and by Bodum. I buy 4-6 bags of beans from Costco frequently and mix the beans together, then grind. I ahve ground 2-3 large bags in one sitting and the machine has never over heated, jammed, or not performed as expected. I've used Cuisinart products for many years and I have never been dissatisfied with their performance and longevity. I would recommend this grinder to anyone who like to buy large bags of beans and grind their own coffee.

reviews.reviewTitle: It work until it suddenly doesn’t.
reviews.reviewText: I received this exact model as a gift in 2009 and it lasted me seven years. I bought another one to replace it and it lasted me 13 months. No signs it was breaking down or having trouble, just would not turn on despite pulling everything apart and cleaning it; no response from the grind button. I love the versatility of it, being able to decide what kind of grind and how many ounces to grind, but I don’t like having to replace a product every year. Not worth the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for a basic entry grinder, with one major flaw!
reviews.reviewText:
I've been using the DBM-8 for about 3 years now and it has performed well throughout its service life and continues to be reliable. I usually brew with a french press and more recently, a Chemex. I've consistently made coffee with this grinder exclusively and it has met my expectations as a quality entry-level grinder.

I have recently been becoming more educated about quality coffee and more precise equipment. That being said there are some parts that are a bit lacking in the DBM-8. For one, this machine produces a high amount of 'fines' (coffee dust), which is excusable for a grinder priced so reasonably. Unfortunately, espresso is certainly out of the question, as the aforementioned fines production is detrimental to espresso. Also, the lack of variability in grind selection makes proper espresso impossible with this machine. The only other point I can dock this device on is the complete lack of internal cleaning options. There is simply no way to reasonably open the machine up and clean the burrs. You certainly don't want to use flavored coffees in this machine because any other high quality bean will be tarnished by whatever's been previously passed through the machine.

The bad parts aside, this is a great machine for the basic home coffee brewer. I've never had problems making french press coffee and I'm sure it is fine for drip machines, aeropresses and manual brewers alike. If nothing else you will certainly get a good service life out of the device, just be sure to never put any spices through this thing!

reviews.reviewTitle: When you get fine powder into your coarse grind (which is the normal ...
reviews.reviewText:
Ground is not consistent. Grinder consistency is the key feature of a grinder. Everything else is of less importance. When you get fine powder into your coarse grind (which is the normal outcome of this grinder) then your coffee will taste bitter.
This machine is useless as a coffee grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's not bad, it basically does what it was meant to
reviews.reviewText: It's not bad, it basically does what it was meant to. Unfortunately the container used to catch the ground coffee is made of poly carbonate plastic which means static! When pouring the ground coffee in to the coffee maker basic, ground coffee statically jumps around everywhere! I have to spend a few minutes a morning wiping up all the ground coffee that jumped out onto the counter and floor.

reviews.reviewTitle: Clean It and Fix Slowing Down Behavior!
reviews.reviewText:
My wife has had one of these grinders for years now and loves it. Suddenly; it slowed way down and even stopped. CLEAN IT! The hole where the grounds come out of the grinder and into the coffee holder can get choked with ground coffee. I think this occurs if your beans are slightly damp. Simply poke a Q-Tip into the hole and knock the mung loose. Voila!

(BTW, Costco still sells this same model and they certainly wouldn't if they got complaints/returns. Of course Amazon carries these also: Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill)

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't be fooled by Cuisinart name
reviews.reviewText: Let me start by saying I have never left a review for a product before, however, this inferior product requires I weigh in on it. Save your money and do not buy! My husband purchased one for me for Mother's Day 2013. It is exactly 7 months later and my 2nd one just died this morning! The first one lasted 41/2 months and the latest one 21/2 months. Basically the motor stops working. I could tell last week something was going wrong because I could hear the motor sputtering while it was running. It initially started to grind less than the desired amount, so I started to stir the beans while grinding...thinking this might help. This did not prevent the inevitable from happening and within 2 weeks of hearing the struggling motor, it died completely. This is wholly unacceptable and I am out the $80.00 I spent on the first one, due to buying on-line. Fortunately I purchased the 2nd one locally, saved the receipt, and will be promptly returning it. One might be asking themselves why I bought it a second time...I thought the first time might have been user error (not really sure how I could have caused it, however, it is a morning product after all, and you just never know what takes place before that first cup of the day...plus, I was giving the name brand product the benefit of the doubt!) This could have been a disastrous morning, of epic proportions had I not saved my Salton blade grinder from 30 years ago! Buyer beware!

reviews.reviewTitle: Reliable grinder, used daily for 6 years.
reviews.reviewText:
Bought one of these 6 years ago and have use it daily. Grind is very consistent for the price. Cleaning is easy, although needs to be done frequently because it seems to launch the grinds everywhere. Most land in the container but a lot end up on the walls around the container.

Woke up this morning and the power on it seems to have died. But like I said, 6 years on a $40 grinder was a great value in my eyes. Would recommend to anyone not wanting to spend over $50.

Been standing up to the abuse a firehouse can dish out and many different people using it. Happy with the price and how much better the coffee tastes. Easy of use is only handicapped by inability to wash was all parts that come in contact with the grinds. Consistent grinds with flavored or regular grounds. A little loud but what grinder isn't. Hasn't slowed down or had any problems at a four to six pot a day rate every day for a year. I wish those silly British vacuums were built at least half as well. Have one for my house as now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not bad for an inexpensive grinder
reviews.reviewText: I've had this grinder in daily use for about 18 months. The grind is good, but not great, in that there is some inconsistency - mostly that the grinder always produces a bit too much "fines" no matter what the setting. Since the grinder has a plastic box which is prone to static cling, the fines also tend to build up over time. The grinder is louder than I would like. I take the edge off that by tossing a dishtowel or two over the top. Finally, I'd like a larger capacity bean hopper. Still, for the money, it's not bad! It's a workhorse. I've never had a single problem with it, and the burrs never seem to dull. If you're looking for a reasonably-priced upgrade from a blade grinder, this is one to consider.

If this grinder had a good espresso grind and a quality, sensible switch system, I may give it three stars. But having so much plastic in the system makes for a static nightmare, leaving coffee grounds all over the counter. Don't even think about trying to pour from it, and grounds are literally lifted from the scoop as you bring it out of the container. I'm not trying to do a deep clean every morning.

I purchased this grinder, despite some of the reviews that I read, because I had previously owned a cuisinart grinder that I was very happy with. The thought of a grinder that would store the beans and I could quickly grind just what I needed sounded great. And it does give you options for your preferred grind, which is nice. However, it does NOT grind the amount that you select. It also does create huge amounts of coffee dust, as previous reviews suggested, that spreads well beyond the area that you are grinding. After 2 months of use, I have just ordered a new basic grinder, and this will be going to the out of use appliances shelf we have managed to maintain within our house.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great little grinder, if they have fixed the switch problems.
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder replaced my 20 year old Braun blade grinder. The grind is extremely even and produces a better tasting coffee.

The quantity is calibrated for medium grind, but it was easy to find the right setting for the grind I preferred. The plastic container does build up static; sometimes the grounds even jump out of the container. I wouldn't say it's messier than my old one, but with the auto feature I now grind daily, so it's messy every day. I can live with that.

The finest grind setting is still a little more coarse than what I'm used to with espresso, and it is a bit of trouble to clean out and switch to decaf.

The biggest negative is that I had the same switch problems others mentioned; mine died after 8 months. In Cuisinart's favor, they actually shipped me out a new one before they got my bad one. It's possible they had a bad batch of switches and now realize it.

If you decide to get this grinder, be sure to register it! That made it easy to get a replacement, and they didn't require additional documentation. If they've fixed the switch problem, it would be a five star purchase.

I like to make a good amount of coffee everyday. So I like this because it has options, it's easy to clean, easy to use and does really well with grinding. Worth every penny. Have had it about 2 months at this point and it works like a charm!

I love this machine. I have used it every morning for 5-6 years now. I prepare about 4-5 tbs of grind for my 12-oz. cup via. AeroPress. It is totally dependable...over and over again. Also, I like waxy medium roast beans. This machine has the torque to get through it. Cleaning is occasional at best--never required. I get the folks that say they need a finer grind for their espresso. For a pour over or coffeemaker use, this is a great price for a great performer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Loud, inconsistent grind, and breaks easily
reviews.reviewText:
I have to agree with most people that this is not a great grinder. I received this as a gift and I liked the idea that I could adjust the grind settings for different uses. I have to say that the grind from the machine is fairly inconsistent and my expensive espresso machine does not work well with the grounds from this grinder.

The machine is incredibly noisy. I get a lot of comments on the noise it produces when guests are over. I also thought all grinders were this noisy until my brother used his new grinder recently and it produced 1/10 the noise as this one.

Lastly, I've had the grinder over 1 year and the plastic chute connected under the hopper just recently split entirely from the hopper - so this needs to be replaced. The part is only $8, but with shipping it will be $15 and already half the cost of the entire machine. I may be looking for a total replacement.

reviews.reviewTitle: This electric burr grinder does a great job of shortening task and delivering evenly ground coffee ...
reviews.reviewText: I gave up on blade coffee cutters and started hand grinding with a burr grinder. Interesting at first, it lost its allure to need for quick cup of coffee. This electric burr grinder does a great job of shortening task and delivering evenly ground coffee in a variety of grinds. Hand grinder is on display as antique in my kitchen.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Grinder - Can work for espresso under proper conditions
reviews.reviewText:
I recently received the Cuisinart EM-200 espresso machine Cuisinart EM-200 Programmable 15-Bar Espresso Maker, Stainless Steel Along with this grinder as a birthday present from my wife. I got a little worried after reading some of the reviews, but the more research and experimenting I have done, the more I have discovered how capable this grinder can be paired with my particular espresso machine.

First, One of things I have read repeatedly in reviews of this grinder is - "Does Not Grind fine enough for espresso." The problem here is that this is a blanket statement. Many people assume that espresso must be ground to a fine powder. These are usually the people that also assume espresso is a particular type of bean, or has to be a dark roast.

To clarify, the espresso machine mentioned above uses pressurized portafilters. Many espresso purists will balk at this, but they are not all bad. Through a lot of research I found several articles talking about how pressurized portafilters are good to learn on. They do not require as fine of grind as non-pressurized versions, and they also require less tamp. If you use too fine of grounds and too hard of a tamp, you will most likely choke your machine with a pressurized portafilter.

I have had good results on the next to finest grind setting, and the finest setting depending on the bean. These settings are much finer than a blade grinder, and you get less heat transfer to the beans.

I cannot attest to the durability as I have only had it for a month. I have had no issues cleaning the grinder. I have found that less oily beans will provide a little more consistent grind. For instance, I got really nice grind from some Illy medium roast decaf beans the other day.

Expectations:
I don't think this grinder would grind quite fine enough for a traditional style protafilter, but many home machines are pressurized, so it isn't an issue. I think the disappointment lies when people expect this to be what it is not. If you spend $800 on an espresso machine, and $50 on a grinder then yeah it probably won't live up to your expectations, but then again those expectations are unrealistic.

Bottom Line:
Paired with the Cuisinart EM-200 I have gotten fantastic results. The unit feels solid, looks sharp and so far has performed well. Don't simply assume that you cannot use this grinder for espresso without doing a little research first.

Not a good grinder. For one, it grinds the beans at too high speed. It creates a huge mess due to static buildup from the speed at which this thing obliterates the beans. This unit is not easy to clean and becomes less and less efficient over time due to grounds residue buildup. I do not recommend it. Better to invest in a Baratza or Oxo grinders.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excited to get it, not very happy once I had it..
reviews.reviewText:
I found this burr grinder and read all the reviews and thought this was the perfect thing for my morning espresso. When I got it and used it for the first time, I was immediately disappointed. Despite my choosing the fine grind setting, the ground was not fine enough for an espresso machine. The finest grind I can get out of this grinder is somewhere between a drip grind an an espresso grind - but not fine enough for a real espresso machine.

That really bummed me out, but since I wasn't in the financial position to buy another machine, I just kept this one and used it despite it not being able to grind the coffee beans fine enough. Then, after about 3 months of use, it just stopped working! I thought it was maybe because it needed cleaning - so I took everything apart and gave it a good clean. Unfortunately, it still wouldn't come on after the cleaning. So now, it's going back. I'm very disappointed because I have to back to my old standby wheel grinder which isn't optimal but that's all I have now until I find another burr grinder I feel comfortable enough buying.

My first one lasted a few months over a year and the motor went dead. The second one I have one year and the motor is dead wit no replacement from Cuisinart. This " fine Chinese engineering" in inaction.

I own a bed and breakfast so grind coffee each day. I have had this for six months now. I have experienced some major issues that were there right out of the box, so the issues did not happen from heavy use. The grounds end up everywhere. The grounds continue to fall out of the grinder once the cup is removed. It also clings to the plastic container rather bed. As the grounds end all over the base they become lodged in the crevices which prevents the cup being placed in a position where it will allow the grinder to turn on. Surprised at the poor design from a brand like cuisinart

reviews.reviewTitle: Meets my needs reliably at the right price
reviews.reviewText:
My brewing method: I grind beans as needed, boil water in a tea kettle, and use a plastic cone with paper filters. Usually two mugs a day. I've had the... hold on... just turned my unit over to check - grinder model #CCM-SA - for somewhere around six years. (It looks exactly like the "CCM-16PC1" now being sold in 2011.) I've only cleaned it a few times but should probably do so more often. I've never had a real problem with the unit; it just does its thing, every time. Consistent grind? I don't care. In fact, I sometimes swing the grind setting thingie back and forth while it's working so I'll get a variety of fine to coarse. Call me crazy. Foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds. (If you're into French Press or espresso or whatever requires a precise grind maybe this unit isn't for you.)

Static cling? Yes. What this means is that once every week I use a brush instead of just knocking a spoon against the plastic bin to knock the grind out. I use the opportunity to wash the bin. As a negative this is not worth even a quarter of a star deduction. About a year ago all that spoon-knocking finally started a crack forming in the plastic bin. The crack grew only very slowly. (The bin must be made of Lexan or some other amazing plastic.) I contacted Customer Service and they sent me a new bin with a minimum of fuss or bother.

For decades before this I'd been using those small bladed grinders - one after another as they broke. If that's your current situation I can say that the improvement is definitely worth the roughly doubled price tag. With luck the frequency of replacement might be halved, so the cost will work out the same in the long run. A burr grinder is going to take up more counter space, but it makes better coffee. If/when my unit starts to break down I'd not hesitate to buy another.

One word of advice: once you've figured out exactly where to set the sliding time control for the amount of coffee you need, make some sort of permanent mark as a reference. It's easy to accidentally knock the control slider out of place and suddenly you're getting coffee that's too weak or too strong. Of course, you may want to slightly alter the setting depending on the strength of the beans you've bought; having the average point marked is even more valuable then.

Noisy! I wouldn't mind the noise if it weren't so messy- every time I remove the ground coffee, the cup that holds he grounds can't be put back in place (in a way that you can keep grinding) until the whole thing gets cleaned out- hard to explain but I hate this machine for that reason. It grinds coffee wel but I dread having to chase all the grounds that have to be removed from the opening that releases the grounds into the cup- I wish I had read reviews before buying at a William Sonoma. I'm stuck- hopefully you're not yet! Keep looking and read reviews.
I've had this grinder for over 5 years, it has always worked, given same grinding results. I have seen the many negative comments, it makes me wonder if quality control is failing to do their job.

reviews.reviewTitle: Video Review for the Cuisinart DBM-8 Burr Grinder
reviews.reviewText:
The Cuisinart DBM-8 Burr Grinder is provides an highly consistent grind at a very reasonable price. It does have flaws, but once it is viewed against products that are 2x its price. I will caution that it is not easy to clean the "guts" of the machine so this may not be the machine for you if you plan to grind a variety of coffee styles or spices. Trust me if you burr grind fresh vanilla coffee beans and then follow it with a bold French Roast... your French Roast will have an unexpected flavor!

Pros -

- Inexpensive
- Multiple settings for grinding - everything from fine to French Press coarse.
- One-button to push then you are able to walk-away
- Not much to clean - but clean-up is a snap.
- 1/2lb bean capacity
- Nice finish - it does not look "cheap". From the looks you would expect that it cost 2-3x the actual price

Cautions-

- Again, it is impossible to clean the inner-workings of the machine so you will have residual that will be mixed into your next grind.
- Not overly powered - at times it seems like it is straining which makes me worry about long-term durability.
- Pretty loud - I am not sure if it could be made "quiet"
- Pretty large footprint - you may want to make sure that you have counter-space

Final Verdict - I may change my review if the Cuisinart DBM-8 dies a quick death, but for now it has surpassed my expectations. There are better burr grinders available, but be prepared to spend considerably more money.

5 Stars

Like all other burr grinders in its class this one makes a lot of noise. Mostly from the plastic hopper and thin walled case. I usually take it into another room in the morning so it doesnt annoy or wake up anyone. It does a good job of grinding but doesnt quite get the grounds fine enough for my tastes when making an espresso. Overall, no doubt better than bladed grinders but not exactly what Im looking for on a grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great value for a conical burr
reviews.reviewText:
I've had this grinder for 2 years now, and it is a great value for a conical burr.

Regarding static. I used to laugh at the reviews complaining about static electricity. This winter, after 18 months of use, my grinder started having the same challenges. Now it is somewhat impossible to transfer the ground coffee to your machine or drip system without grinds going everywhere. My solution is to wipe the counter with a wet cloth after using, and sweep the floor more often. I anticipate the problem will lessen as the humidity levels rise throughout spring/summer. I also own a Maestro Plus, and that grinder has no static electricity problems but did cost 3 times as much.
I’ve had this for five years, it works great, it does beans from fine for espresso, all the way up to course for cold brew.

I got his grinder because I thought getting a burrito grinder would get me a consistent grind size for my pour over coffee. The problem with this grinder is is pulverizes some of the coffee into a fine powder. So you get some coffee the size you want.l, and some as an extremely fine powder. The one powder then clogs the filter and ruins the pour over coffee. I really hate this grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Rarely works properly, jams frequently, messy, loud
reviews.reviewText: Would not buy again. It is overly noisy/loud, gets messy after a few cycles, accumulates coffee powder in the container and grinder, and it jams frequently, screwing up my whole measuring ratio and cup of coffee. I often have to stick a knife down the top to un-jam the beans. Very disappointing and frustrating that you never know if it's going to work right. Can't wait until it stop working so I can buy a different grinder.

This was an okay grinder, but disappointing after 30 years (yes, 30) of outstanding service from my previous Krups burr grinder. This Cuisinart grinder didn't grind consistently on the medium to finer settings. Some of the grounds would be quite fine--what I expected from the chosen fine setting--yet most of the grounds would still be in the medium range. The container for the grounds was delightfully static-free when removing the ground coffee. If you make only drip-style coffee, this would still be a good choice; if you want a consistent find grind, you will want a different grinder. I read many Amazon reviews before buying this burr grinder, and felt pretty confident about this machine (though I purchased it from a different store). I owned it for 2 months, then returned it.

I CAN"T HEAR YOU, I'M GRINDING COFFEE RIGHT NOW!!!!
VERY LOUD, that's right, you heard me, this grinder is ridiculously loud, lots of static (although it's not the only one with that characteristic), inconsistent grind, a pain in the shorts to clean.
The problem: the burr itself spins way too fast causing the coffee beans to bounce around and therefore it does not produce the desired results. I could put up ith the noise if it would just grind the coffee beans better, but the final result is so uneven, that I'm wasting good coffee beans by using an inferior grinder.
Got fed up with it, and now, its resting comfortably in the appliance graveyard!!!!
I have a hand grinder that does a far superior job than the Cuisinart grinder, however, I've become way too lazy to hand grind beans every morning!
I recently purchased a Capresso, and we'll see how that works, I know someone (a bonified coffee snob), who has one, and it does the job quite well, comes apart easily for cleaning, and runs a little quieter. We'll see!
I can't really recommend purchasing one, there are better machines available.
Don't waste money on this machine!!!

They have a small port for sending grounds to storage bin. Oily beans plug it up even after a few hopper cycles. Then it will slow down or act weird then they get bad reviews for really just needing a cleaning.
Cleaning out that port is a must on a very regular basis.
My Cuisinart grinder has been grinding for 6 years and has had to have processed a few hundred lbs of beans in that time...still grinding away.
Thanks Cuisinart for a grinder under $50.00 bucks that keeps on Grinding...

reviews.reviewTitle: Who knew some grinders were good AND BAD? lol
reviews.reviewText: Have had this grinder for about 5 years. Its finally seized up. You get a lot of very fine grind along with the actual grind selected. I think this time we'll try a more expensive grinder. Its not what most coffee enthusiasts want, but I grind enough for a week.

reviews.reviewTitle: The finest setting does not provide fine enough grains that can ...
reviews.reviewText: This is NOT for espresso. The finest setting does not provide fine enough grains that can give me enough pressure on my portofilter. May be good for pour-over or other types of coffee... but definitely a big NO if you are into espresso or Turkish...

reviews.reviewTitle: Stops working every few uses & needs cleaning
reviews.reviewText: Worked great for a month then just wouldn't turn on. Took apart to clean & blow out & bang a couple times & works for a few grinds then stops again. After 2 months I can't get the thing to start for the life of me & I'm an engineer
I had this great coffee grinder almost year and half and it just stopped working out of blue! I am very sad because I liked the most how much coffee it could hold!

I purchased 2, one was for my cousin. His died in about a year, but mine is still going fine. However, I am about to purchase this one again from Amazon as a backup. It was $50 at Target this past week when we checked. Does a great job.
Some pretentious reviews almost stopped me from buying this. Glad i didn't listen to them. It works perfect for me. I typically do French press or pour overs.

Liked it till it ceased to work after about 6 months usage. We love our morning coffee. Liked the choice for fine grounds. So frustrated when it simply quit. Now it will sit in the back of the cupboard until I find the moment and inspiration to use screwdrivers and q-tips to clean out the innards. In the mean time, which will most probably be forever, I am putting our magic bullet into play. So sad.

This grinder started out good but after a few months the cup size selector switch became lose and won't stay in the notch. Now it changes the amount constantly. Now I have to grind more than I need, measure out the right amount and save the rest for the next pot. $43 for a useless grinder.
This thing is loud! Did barking, kids crying, earplug needing loud. Don't buy this if you want to have a peaceful home or want to avoid hearing damage. Grinds as expected.

reviews.reviewTitle: THis item is not a true conical burr coffee maker ...
reviews.reviewText: THis item is not a true conical burr coffee maker. The coffee maker does not crush the beans with the burr itself, but uses the flat burr to whisk the coffee beans against a blade. This means that the coffee grounds even in on the coarsest setting can range from 1mm to even 1cm in size. This does away with the whole benefit of a burr machine over a blade, producing even sized grounds. The size of grounds produced on the smallest setting is totally unusable for espresso or turkish coffee. This size of grounds produced on the largest size is enormous.

First of all - I really love this grinder. It holds 1/2 lb. of beans, so you don't have to fill it every time you use it, and it works great - for a little while. My first one lasted about 2 years, and then just stopped. I thought I'd try another - maybe it was something I did? Nope - it's just not durable. I like fine grind, and it did the job, but only for about 9 months this time. I give up. My advice? Be prepared to spend $50/year (or so)- or pass on this product. Luckily, I had a backup grinder or this review would be far more critical because I wouldn't have had my coffee this morning!!!

I recently received this as a gift after my old school 10 yr old grinder was apparently an eye sore but still worked perfectly. I got maybe a total of 25 days worth of coffee and now it is kaput. I’ve cleaned it and made sure it wasn’t clogged using toothpicks and chopsticks etc and to no avail it won’t start up. Now I am sitting here, with no coffee and debating on if I even want to use the warranty?!

reviews.reviewTitle: good value, but grind is not uniform
reviews.reviewText:
We've used this grinder every morning for the past two years. For all that use, it seems to be holding up well - no concerns about durability.

Like previous reviewers, the plastic parts are a bit of a disappointment. Coffee, especially dark roasts, tends to stick to the sides. Of greater concern is the uniformity of the grind. Although the bulk of the grounds are nice and uniform, and can be adjusted based on your preference, we always seem to end up with a "chunk" of VERY fine grounds at the top of the grinder. We try to pick this out, since it can wreck the taste of the coffee.

Despite these concerns, it's a decent grinder for the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great grinder but short life span.
reviews.reviewText: I was happy with this at first, but it lasted only one month (about ten uses) then the motor seized. I returned it to place of purchase to exchange it, but by that time they were out of stock. I don't think Cuisinart is making quality small appliances anymore. I've read that they put their name on other manufacturer's merchandise under contract which is believable. I also bought a Cuisinart coffee maker, which lasted only two months. I've switched to a blender to grind coffee, and with some practice it works just as well.

reviews.reviewTitle: I like this grinder very much when it is working
reviews.reviewText:
I like this grinder very much when it is working. However, the motor on my second one just slowed down and quit, just like the first one. I'm going to have to try something else.

UPDATE: I use the finest grind for my coffee and over time the fine powder compacts around the grinding wheel. I used a knife to break up the compacted powder and blew it out with an air hose, and now it works like new. I was happy to get back to a great cup of coffee with beans from Coffee Craft delivered to be fresh every three weeks.

We use very oily coffee beans and subsequently it jams. The ground coffee builds up at the exit hole and I have to use a small, sharp knife to dig out the packed coffee. It works well for a while and then it whirls and whirls with nothing coming out. Not a fun job.

This grinder worked very well -- for about a week. Then we started having difficulty getting it to start. We examined it carefully, cleaned it thoroughly but it would start only if we held the start button down the entire time it was grinding. After another week, it totally quit. In reading reviews online, it appears that this is fairly common problem. Cuisinart normally makes better products than this; they need to resolve this issue.

reviews.reviewTitle: #7 Plastic & leaves a fine dusting...but excellent grind overall.
reviews.reviewText: I use an electric espresso machine during the week and a french press on the weekends, so having a coffee mill that adjusts accordingly is crucial. The finest setting is perfect for the Bialatti electric espresso machine, creating a powdery coffee grind that extracts a lot of flavor. And the highest settings create a perfectly course grind for the french press for those weekend mornings when I have more time to linger over my cup(s). When grinding, however, the mill does produce a fine dust that gets all over the counter, so that's a bit of a pain. Perhaps most disconcerting, however, is that both the coffee bean holder & the grounds holder are made with #7 plastic, which is reported to be one of the less "stable" plastics (in other words, it releases toxins into food--especially if scratched). In the end, the price is good and it does the trick. But I wish that Cuisinart would opt for better quality plastics (or better yet, safer materials altogether).

Bought this at a store. Used it maybe 20-30 times over about 4 months and it died. The plastic bean chamber that threads into the drive using a plastic shaft cracked, I guess from changing the grind size.

Fortunately, a replacement ordered at Cuisinart.com only cost 8 dollars.
