Unfortunately, a month after ordering it and receiving two shipping dates, I just received an email telling me that "due to high demand, the product is out of stock" and they hope to ship in 30 days. A replacement part that is out of stock due to high demand is not a good thing. I cancelled my order and bought the Capresso model thru Amazon..hopefully it is better. At least they didn't charge my credit card.

Oh, by the way, the unit didn't even work that good...the consistency of the grind was no different than my ten buck blade grinder.

I purchased my Cuisinart Grinder from Costco a few months ago and it worked great for about 2 months. Then arbitrarily it just stopped working. I thought it was because of something I did, so I re-read the directions in order to try and trouble-shoot the issue and found nothing in the instruction booklet that would give me a clue. Finally, I had to chalk it up to poor quality. If you are looking for a good value, don't purchase this coffee grinder. FYI...I purchased another Cuisinart coffee grinder from Bed, Bath & Beyond (different model) and had the same issue! I would recommend steering clear of this brand for coffee grinders. (Their other products work great)!

Don't be fooled. This is certainly not a real burr or conical burr grinder. I'm sure you can tell by the price. It's essentially a blade grinder masquerading as a burr. You'll get a massive particle size distribution in this thing. It's impossible to not get super fine grinds in with whatever your desired grind setting is. Unless this was free, just go to something that will actually get the job done.

Junk. Three times I've owned this grinder. Once I bought it—it lasted maybe a year. Two more times I received this grinder as a gift... and it breaks in the same way. This last time, it worked from January to April. It slows down until it stops, the wheels burn out, and it won't turn back on, despite frequent cleanings. A waste of money. If I had spent three times the price on a better grinder, I would have saved money (since I now have to buy a FOURTH burr grinder... it won't be this one).

I've purchased two of these and they worked fine for my needs as long as they lasted. Various plastic parts completely broke off after a little more than a year. The top receptacle completely broke off one and the inside plastic piece that keeps the beans from flying around broke off the other. One of them just stopped working completely. One of the grinders was hardly used being at a weekend lake home. Would not recommend. Blade grinders may not be good for the coffee but the one I had lasted forever.

I bought this grinder as my first grinder, it was priced reasonably and it's a burr grinder.

When I first started using it, it wouldn't start at all. I eventually figured out that the safety switch wasn't working. I had to put a piece of tape on the bottom of the grind bin to activate the switch that tells the machine that the bin is in place and ready to use. When I did get it working, it started shooting ground coffee all over the place, because the grind bin was too short, leaving about a 1/4 inch gap where it should have been totally enclosed. I didn't want to waste additional money on returning the unit, and I really couldn't wait for a grinder, so I double-folded tape around the lip of the grind bin so it would cover the gap and make less mess on every use, which it usually did anyway. Even if it was of an adequate height to fit the unit, it still makes a big mess because there is coffee powder all over the underside of the unit every time you use it (where the grind bin goes).

It was quite noisy in comparison to my current grinder, the Cuisinart DBM-8 is about the same volume as a vacuum cleaner. After months of daily use, it started sounding funny, like a low rumble. I would now compare the current volume level to a lawn mower. Fearing that the unit was going bad, I got a Capresso Infinity, which is a superior product in so many ways. No mess at all, and the grind is much finer and more even, which is a must for good espresso. It is also exponentially quieter, you could even hear talking over it. Unfortunately I didn't have the luxury of trying them out before my purchase.

I am not expecting the Cuisinart to perform at the same level as the Capresso Infinity, but the point is, don't waste your money on this pile of garbage, there are many options in the under-$100 category to choose from.

reviews.reviewTitle: By far best grinder for the money
reviews.reviewText: I needed a wedding shower gift and since the bride and groom love coffee and I love this grinder I thought it would be perfect. For some reason I started reading the reviews and frankly I was shocked. I have been using coffee grinders for several years and I have owned this one for at least six. It could break down tomorrow but I have absolutely zero complaints if it does. I liked the grinder so much I also purchased the Cuisinart Coffee On Demand coffee maker. I'd recommend that too. Not only has this grinder outlasted all the others, for an inexpensive grinder it has the same exact features as the pricier ones. I can't believe some of the things people have complained about.First when you are grinding you do not ever leave the grinder. With anything like this there is a chance of beans getting caught and bogging down the motor. If this happens you should stop it immediately and clear the blockage. Otherwise you can burn the motor up. I have seldom had this happen but it's the owner's responsibility to stop the machine when it does. Expensive grinders are not an exception to this.Second, yes there is some static in the plastic and every time there are a few grounds that make their way to my countertop. Simple solution: dampen a paper towel and it wipes right up. Not too complicated and well worth having freshly ground coffee every day.Third, at the end of a grinding cycle turn the machine back on to make sure all the coffee has cleared the chute. Run it without any beans so that nothing is left to block the free flow of ground coffee. It will sing loudly but you do not want a clogged chute. At least once a week wash the plastic container to keep your coffee fresh.Last, if you don't like noise perhaps you should think about buying your coffee already ground. I love this machine and with a just a minimum of care it will grind a perfect coffee for several years. I know sometimes there can be defects. If that is the case it is not because this isn't a great grinder.That's going to be my gift to the lucky couple because I don't think I can get anything better even at the higher prices. Learned a long time ago more expensive doesn't mean better.

reviews.reviewTitle: Customizable, great grind (especially for the discounted) price! Customizable
reviews.reviewText: Works very well. Fast, relatively consistent grind. It can sometimes be a bit annoying to get all of the grounds out of the corners of the chamber, but it's a lot easier than my previous disk grinder. You will need to play around with the coarseness/cup settings to know how much you'll need for a given volume, but once you do it's really easy to grind and go. eg. We like it strong and grind 12 for 10 in the carafe.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not the quality I expected from this company
reviews.reviewText: Bought mine in early December and it died in mid March. Wow, you would think this thing would last longer than 4 months. When it was working it did a nice job on coffee beans. But mine just stopped working all of a sudden. I bought a Cuisinart because I had always thought they made good quality products. I made a mistake on this purchase. I would not recommend this product as the motor is likely to give out as it seems from other reviews that this happens with some frequency. Wish I had read the reviews before I bought this.

reviews.reviewTitle: I finally gave up on this one after having it die three times!
reviews.reviewText: This is the absolute worst grinder. When it works, it's extremely messy. Coffee grounds everywhere. Be prepared to do a lot of clean up afterward. This unit died 3 times, and was replaced THREE TIMES!!! Twice on the warranty. It's an absolute piece of crap! Do NOT buy it!!! The ground coffee will not exit into it's container, instead it just plugs up, becoming impacted as hard as rock. The unit does not come apart at all to clear the pathway, and is completely unserviceable or cleanable by the user. It's designed to be a 'throw-away' item. I will never buy anything from Cuisinart again!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: I don't like this grinder for several reasons
reviews.reviewText:
I don't like this grinder for several reasons: it's very noisy, the ground coffee reservoir is difficult to pull out and put back, and you have to hold the lid on or else it can fall off and you end up with coffee all over the place. I compared prices and found it can vary from 89.99 Canadian to 49.99 (bought one at 89.99, but returned unused when I found it at Costco for 49.99. If you are looking for a burr grinder do your research. The one I owned previously was purchased at Starbucks and it lasted for years.
I will continue to use until it is time to replace, but unless there are some design changes made by Cuisinart, I will not buy this again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Motor 140w, and Coffee ground not adequate for expressing.
reviews.reviewText:
My KRUPS 208 lasted decades. So, Tried one and my 2 concerns are (a) 140 watts motor and (b) the machine controlled coarseness of ground -- Fine setting does not give fine coffee. Manufacturer should list Motor power in bold on the packaging, and not underneath unit in tiny font size.

Going back to KRUPS 203, both motor 200watts and operator manual control to make ground finer "I can control fitness of coffee ground.

Although this is a handy device, I've grown to dislike it. The problem is simple. On any given setting, the grinder doesn't consistently grind the same amount of coffee. Hence, your coffee is often too strong or too week - usually too strong it seems.

Crappy product through and through. I like my grind fine and this product can't handle it. Grinder keeps jamming have had to exchange it twice at Macys. Additionally the plastic grind container is messy do to static electricity i.e. the coffee sticks to the plastic. The plastic lids spills coffee on the counter overall poor product design. David 415-867-4228

It looks nice, and easy to use but it does NOT grind very well at all. The "coarse" grind creates big shards of coffee that nobody would ever use to brew drip coffee and the fine grind is more like what you WOULD use to brew drip coffee, not fine enough to brew espresso at all. Its annoying because in the directions for use it says that the fine grinds are very compact which is not true. It isn't only a fluke on this particular machine because I have had two of the same machine. One I bought six months ago and took it back and another that was given to me. Don't buy this. It is a bad product.

I was very excited about getting this coffee grinder, but after bringing it home and trying to use it to grind beans for making espresso, I found out that it doesn't grind fine enough for espresso. Unfortunately, the espresso comes out light and watery because of this. That's really the reason I got this grinder as opposed to a cheaper one, because I thought I could have flexibility in what I could make fresh since I like espresso and my partner prefers regular coffee. The coffee it makes is really good, but I don't understand why it has so many settings if it can't make the full spectrum of coffee.

I wish I could comment on how this grinder performs, however after buying two models I never got a chance to use it. The first model I bought would not turn on. I was able to exchange it without issue. The second model did turn on but I washed it before using it and the screws on the ceramic grinder rusted. Don't waste your money on this.

This burr grinder was given to us as a gift. Over the last four years, FIVE Cuisinart products have failed us, including this one this morning. We have used it daily and have never been happy with it. The grind was extremely inconsistent, the timer rarely delivers a consistent amount of coffee, and at least every other time it was used it clogged itself up (creating a lovely screaching noise while it searched for more beans). The plastic parts are cheap. The amount of coffee dust that clings to the sides is pretty annoying, and trying to get it out makes a huge mess every morning.

Finally today we threw this junk in the trash. A plastic internal threaded piece broke and if not for the backup KitchenAid grinder we have had for ten years we would be at an espresso stand buying our morning coffee.

Awful.

reviews.reviewTitle: I was very upset this grinder did not grind better then it does
reviews.reviewText: I was very upset this grinder did not grind better then it does. However, I think I expected it to be more then it was, a $25 grinder. So I gave it a 4 out of five. Do not buy this an expect it to produce something suitable for an espresso machine. For anything other than espresso, it does just fine and has a nice finished feel. The hopper is easy enough, the ground receptacle is not so smooth to remove and replace but nothing difficult.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poor quality. Stopped working after just a few uses.
reviews.reviewText: I received this as a Christmas gift. By the end of January, after just a few uses, it inexplicably stopped working. I made sure the chute it was not clogged and followed all of the steps in the manual. Online research shows that numerous people have had this problem and it appears it may be due to faulty fuses and/or safety switches. Looks like I will be grinding my coffee at the grocery store.

reviews.reviewTitle: this grinder worked great the first time I used it
reviews.reviewText: this grinder worked great the first time I used it. Only once. It does not grind on all settings, and I have to hold the grind button down to get it to grind, thus I don't know how much coffee has ground for the amount of cups of coffee I want to make. This was the whole reason I bought this grinder. It's loud and lousy. Don't bother with it.
I love this coffee grinder! I received it as a gift about 6 years ago and I use it every day. It’s by far one of my favorite kitchen appliances!

reviews.reviewTitle: It was fine at the beginning
reviews.reviewText: It was fine at the beginning, but then the motor died after about six months of light use. I have the Cuisinart Coffee Maker with Grinder so I understand how often these things need to be cleaned (and let me tell you, they don't make it easy to do). The problem with this unit is that there was no warning…no funky sounds, no lack of grinding, just suddenly a dead motor (smelled like burned rubber). I would not buy this again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Burnt out motor in one week
reviews.reviewText: Got this as a Christmas present. Worked beautifully for one week and then burnt out. Tried cleaning, taking apart, everything but it appears to just have burnt its motor out in a week. Don't buy it.

I have owned the DBM-8 Grinder for almost six years now. It has outlasted three coffee makers. I use a Kuerig K-Cup machine right now. The taste of your coffee is only as good as the coffee you grind; if it's a little bitter add a pinch of salt to the coffee before brewing this will take the bitterness out. I do not worry about the powder near the top after grinding. Bang the holding bin on the counter before opening the cover and mix the powder with the ground coffee. I adjust the grind settings by the strength of the particular brand of coffee that I use, some times finer for a more robust flavor. I take the thing apart maybe once a year for cleaning if I think about it. People worry too much about the small crap; it's just a $50 grinder after all.

reviews.reviewTitle: Too many problems with this grinder
reviews.reviewText: The grinder worked just as it should for the first three months then it would periodically stop. I would take the grinder apart, give it a complete cleaning and brushing because I thought that coffee had built up over a sensor but that didn't seem to be the problem because after cleaning it would work fine for a couple of grinds and then stall again. I'd spend thirty minutes or more cleaning to make sure nothing was clogging the machine or some a possible sensor. None of this worked and the grinder continued to get worse such that it now will not grind at all. It just stalls and grinds for maybe a millisecond and then shuts off. Very frustrating because I expected years of faithful service from this Cuisinart product. Now it sits in a drawer collecting dust and I'm thoroughly unhappy with it. The cost of shipping for reconditioning makes it prohibitive and no guarantees that it will work afterwards has caused me to look elsewhere for a better grinder.

The reviews I read almost made me not want to give this grinder a try. I'm glad I went ahead.

I have been using a La Pavoni burr grinder for the past two years and have just about worn it out. I was pretty happy with it except the hopper was relatively small and it would start on its own.

The Cuisinart grinder is exactly what I wanted. The hopper is a good size. The beans flow into the griding mechanism very easily. Anyone who has trouble with their beans clogging up in this area must be using beans the size of marbles.

The Cuisinart has much better control over the size of the grind than my La Pavoni as well. Since using the Cuisinart to grind espresso, I have been able to increase the amount of crema on my shots. For that, I am very happy. I typically make espresso one or two shots at a time and I have had no trouble adjusting the grind time to get the proper amount for just one shot.

The only complaint I have has to do with the plastic grind reservoir. The static energy charge on it does create a mess when removing the grinds. However, this was true with the La Pavoni and I suspect will improve with time.

I just wanted to grind a pound of coffee. Went to a troubleshoot site, found 144 pages of people complaining about this grinder, 144 Pages!!! And about 8 complaints per page! Guess Cuisinart doesn't practice RWT (real world testing) because this grinder is a big failure. I'm taking it back to the store and will look for another brand. The problem I believe is too many safety switches, all those little buttons must be pressed or motor won't turn on. One site suggests to open bottom, remove fuse, and solder wires together. Too much trouble, just make a grinder that works.

This stopped working for me after a few months. And while it was working, I was unimpressed. My roommate had a capresso burr grinder, and when he moved out, I thought i'd save some money and buy the cuisinart. Waste of money. First of all, it just doesn't grind quite as finely as I would like for espresso. Second, it is a freaking mess and really hard to use without getting grinds all over the place. Third, the grounds are not all of a consistent size.

All in all, I ended up buying a capresso after all and I am pleased.

We love this grinder at the restaurant. I have owned $500 industrial espresso grinders...with that I pay $120 for a show up fee when it breaks down (which is often). O'course they live hours away and appointments can't be made in a timely fashion AND THEN, i have to pay for the parts needed..... which may or may not be on there truck!!! Dare I say, I still don't have a working grinder because I have to wait for their return, in another week!
........... Revenue lost in so many ways!!!!EEESH

If the next pretentious reader wants to dish out judgmental comments for for a less expensive product, go ahead, It wont be me. "Just because a wine is expensive does not mean its of good quality".

I can't/won't toss any more excessive money out the window when restaurants are failing every day ( for lack of quality, poor management, the economy, you name it).

It's now me and my Cuisinart! HMMM imagine that!

Soooooooooooo, you see, I chose to find a less expensive way to still create a great espresso product, a choice that has been worth the time and money ten fold.
This little grinder is predictable, in what you ask of it. THANK YOU - THANK YOU - THANK YOU!! It is used many, many, many, times a day. We keep it clean and there you go, it works well and consistently!!

If I gave it a song and dance it might wink at me, for all the fond words and hugs it has received over the past two years.
Thank You little espresso grinder, my wallet thanks you, my restaurant thanks you........you ARE the little engine that could!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Great product, but doesn't grind fine enough
reviews.reviewText: Easy to use and fairly easy to clean, and the grind is consistent. However, it grinds coarser than it should. I set it to the finest setting for drip machine coffee (which should be medium), and is still too coarse. So you can forget about a true fine grind. There are ways online to hack this, which I may try.

reviews.reviewTitle: Okay product, but doesn't help me with Espresso Grind
reviews.reviewText: The fine grind on this unit leaves a bit to be desired. I bought this Cuisinart to get a fine espresso grind for the whole bean coffee I was buying. The finest setting creates a ground that is similar to any generic store bought coffee. It's ended up gathering dusk because I would have to grind it in the Cuisinart and then follow it with the Krups mini grinder (which does a fantastic job in itself). Now I just skip the Cuisinart and use the mini grinder from Krups. If you are buying for your normal every day coffee pot, then go for it. Otherwise, I couldn't recommend it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good espresso grinder. Messy on account of static.
reviews.reviewText:
As others have said, this does the job really well for the price. It may not be a professional-grade superstar, but it's still a big step up from the old blade grinder that you have to stand there and hold, hoping you get the timing right and never getting consistent results.

I have had this grinder almost a year, and I've used it daily without any problems. With the "fine" grind (a few clicks above the finest grind setting), it makes beautiful espresso with a rich crema using my Starbucks Barista espresso maker.

My biggest complaints are that:
1. This builds up a ridiculous amount of static as it grinds, so when you open the lid of the container to scoop out the espresso, coffee grounds literally go shooting out all over the counter and stick to both the lid and the sides of the container. Very messy. It helps to keep the lid on and bang it against the counter a few times to knock the grinds down into the bottom of the container before opening it.
2. On the fine grind setting, the little chute into the container can clog up pretty badly after a while (a couple of months, in my experience) if you don't brush it out regularly.

Overall a good machine and definitely worth the upgrade from a blade grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Poops out after a few years' use
reviews.reviewText: I purchased this coffee grinder (from a local shop) about 2 years ago to replace my first grinder (purchased 25 years earlier). I chose the Cuisinart DBM-8 because it was the same model purchased way back when (when manufactured by another company). However, the Cuisinart machine died this morning, functioning for less than 10% the lifespan of the first grinder. It had never ground coffee according to setting. Whatever the setting, it produced fine grounds mixed with a high degree of dust, which meant the machine frequently clogged. Although it was easy to clean, dust is subpar for french press coffee. Yes, I should have returned it earlier (when it was still under warranty - 18 mos.), but that's water under the bridge now. Anyway, I just wanted to chime in about this machine as I am shopping for its replacement this morning, which may be a Bodum model.

I've purchased this grinder in August 2012 and after using it for 6 months the motor burned out, I paid almost $ 60.00 for this grinder, am I the only one who encountered this problem? I'd expect more from a company like Cuisinart......this should not happen after 6 months even though I used this grinder every day (once a day), this is "garbage" made in China, need I say more?
The next grinder I'll purchase will not be a Cuisinart again, so buyer beware!!

I used it about three times a week for 2 years. All the comments about fine dust clinging to side of bin etc. are what i observed. One day i pushed the button and heard the motor but nothing got ground. Checked the hopper and it was loose at the base where the hopper usually screws in. Just pulled the hopper up to see plastic shrapnel. I put it aside for a few months because I was so disappointed in it. I finally took a closer look and saw that one half of the burr mechanism, made of metal, is screwed into the plastic tip of the hopper funnel. Did not see buildup of grounds-- just that the plastic part shattered--right in the exact places where the screws are located to attach the burr plate to the funnel. Why this manufacturer would make ANY part connected to the burr mechanism out of plastic is beyond me. I found I could replace this piece (hopper clear part + funnel brown part + attached metal burr plate) for $12 so I'll give it another try. Good grief!

As long as it was working it was terrific for the price. It's probably still under warranty, but I didn't save the receipt. The upper burr is attached to a flimsy plastic spout through which the beans fall. The torque from the motor will eventually crack this tube rendering the grinder useless and in two pieces. Also, the on off switch is secured inside the case by two thin (1/6th inch) plastic rods which go through the switch and are melted on top. The least stress pulls the switch off the rods making it inaccesible to the outer sliding switch...You then can't turn it off. Save your money and buy a decent grinder. I've seen factory reconditioned solis maestro's for $53 on the internet.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'd rather use my old blade grinder, thanks
reviews.reviewText: When my old cheapo blade grinder died (the black plastic knob on top of the blade came off, and bounced around in there with the beans - yikes!), I saw this model on sale elsewhere and asked my husband to get it for me for Christmas. What a mistake. The combination of coffee dust and static cling is incredibly irritating, as is trying to get it all to grind - there's always one or two pieces bouncing around, refusing to go down through the grinder, which means I run the noisy thing longer than I should. There's coffee dust all over the place, all of the time. The coffee isn't very evenly ground either, IMHO. Does it make a better-tasting cup? I'm not enough of a pro to be able to tell, but I know it was a MUCH simpler process with my blade grinder, and a great deal less messy. I regret asking my husband to buy this big, loud, messy monstrosity for me. I actually grind coffee less often. The only reason I'm not giving it one star is because some of this might be my own inexperience, and I have yet to try using it to grind finer-grind coffee...if it makes a good cup of Greek coffee or espresso, I might forgive it.

This is a piece of junk. I have had two now and they both plugged up and burned up the motor. The container for the ground coffee plugs up and the ground coffee cannot get out of the grinder and into the container. This should not happen and there is no solution except to clean it out EVERY time you use it. Who has time for that!! Do not buy this no matter what the price.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don’t waste your time and money!!!
reviews.reviewText: This grinder is trash. The first grinder lasted over a year before it stopped working and decided to go with another brand grinder. We setup a coffee bar in December and wanted a nicer looking grinder on display so tried Cuisnart again. This time it lasted only 6 months before shorting out. Will not make the same mistake again.

I got one of these for Xmas. It makes a wonderful grind but it's so poorly built it completely fell apart after only 2 months of daily use.

If I were just rating the quality of the grind I would easily give it 5 stars. We used it for both espresso and french press and never had any complaints.

But I could tell from day one how flimsy the unit is, and it didn't take long for the hopper to pretty much disintegrate. It didn't look so flimsy in the pictures when I bought it, but looking at the pics again you can see the poor quality of construction if you look closely.

So for $20 I might give it a good review, but this thing is almost $100 and for that much money I expect at least a little bit of durability.

We just ordered the Kitchenaid grinder from Amazon. It's a bit more pricey but it's solid metal construction and both the hopper and the bins are glass instead of cheap plastic. It looks like it will last 20 years, and all the other burr grinders I looked at in this price range look like cheap plastic too. Even some of the really expensive ones look cheap. Maybe some people don't care that they pay good money and get poor construction but I do. Frankly, the quality of construction is almost insulting.

So maybe for light duty if someone is extremely gentle with the unit it might be a good grinder, but for daily use I'd say pass. To me it doesn't matter if it's half the price of the Kitchenaid grinder if it won't last.

it works well with a cheap little espresso maker if u have a nicer one that u spent hundreds on i would get a breville smart grinder tho but for $50 its great. i have only done fine grind and one the finest its basically dust i usually use 2nd from last for espresso comes out good. a word of advice if u want best taste only use on kind of best in t like i just use Starbucks espresso roast

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not waste your expensive coffee in this thing
reviews.reviewText: Exists purely for misleading you into thinking that you might get somewhere close to a conical burr grind on a budget. Produces nanodust and boulder chunks on the medium setting. Do not waste your expensive coffee in this thing. The more common regular blade (spice grinder) grinders are better and cheaper than this.

I recieved a Supreme Grind Burr Mill Model # DBM-8 for Christmas. I was extremely disappointed IN the LOUD NOISE IT MAKES WHILE GRINDING. So loud that we can hear it outside of the house. Unbelievable for a Quisinart product. My cheap $15.00 grinder is quiter and faster. Getting the grind and the cups to match what we like was a game in it self, requiring a lot of pots to get it right. Thank goodness it was a gift because I would never buy it on my own. It's going back into the box and I'm using my cheap model. This way I won't wake the dead, NOT KIDDING!

It worked well when it did... then it just randomly stopped working. I got it in December. I plan on contacting their customer service because I registered for the warranty, but the major downside is it didn't last that long

Edit, I had to knock it down a star because I saw others had the same problem :/.

I've had cheaper grinders that worked much better. The lock mechanism that holds the receptacle is not burly enough to handle even a small bit of the astronomical amount of rogue grind mess that this machine creates. It often kicks the receptacle out of position from it's own vibration. I should not have to clean as much as I do.
Extremely loud with high pitch noise. Cleaning is very difficult. Grinds ultra fine coffee whether you like it or not on medium or finer setting.

reviews.reviewTitle: Don't get the beans wet. Flavored beans clog grinders.
reviews.reviewText: Had this a few years and find it very reliable. You'll need to brush it out on occasion but that should go without saying. Nice how it dials in to the amount needed, which few grinders do. Would buy again.

reviews.reviewTitle: This is an okay grinder as far as mediocre grinders ...
reviews.reviewText: This is an okay grinder as far as mediocre grinders go, but compared to the Bodum grinder it's just dreadful. This grinder will 1) take forever to grind, 2) get grounds EVERYWHERE and cling to the plastic, and 3) get a fairly uneven grind. Do yourself a favor and get the Bodum Bistro Burr grinder, the difference is well worth the ~$30 upgrade!

I don't know why I didn't pay attention to all the reviews complaining about this model. It wasn't that great before it died (very loud; imprecise grind and amount gradations; that really annoying staticky plastic that makes grinds cling to it). I used it daily for a year or so. This morning nothing happened; it's dead. I checked attempted fixes online; no dice. Now I have to make a trip to Bed Bath and Beyond (ugh) for a grinder before I can have my damned coffee. I doubt I will ever buy another Cuisinart product.

Bought at a non-Amazon store - to go with my espresso machine. At the finest setting the water flows through the portafilter with no backpressure. Will not grind espresso for your Gaggia machine. Also know that this will not make Turkish coffe, Brian Jones, etc.

Does OK with french press grind. I'm sure it probably does adequate drip, too, although I do not make drip. I'd suggest, though, that the only improvement over a blade grinder is ease.

I'll be donating this to Goodwill - at least someone will not have to pay $50 for it and I'll get my money's worth in tax deductions.
18 month warranty, but must pay to ship back to factory plus $4 for them to send it back. Not worth the hassle or money.

Works great for a while, but then it will die inexplicably. Ours died outside of the warranty window and Cuisinart customer service basically said, "So sorry!" So it's a disposable coffee grinder! Nice! Oh yeah, to echo others, it's really loud. We put ours in our garage to grind so that we could prep our coffee at night without waking the kids. It also scared the bejesus out of our toddler when we used it during the day.
This grinder does not have a consistant grind. Good price, but it's worth spending more for a consistant grind. Try compresso models that specify conical burr.

reviews.reviewTitle: Stopped working after a few months
reviews.reviewText: Turned out to be a worthless piece of junk. Worked fine for a couple months then the burrs would run without coffee grounds coming out. Empty the beans disassemble shake it out, after a few attempts it would start running again. This happened several times. Now it’s just stopped working at all. How is this thing an Amazon Choice?

My old cheap coffee grinder broke and I was about to buy a new one when I found this in my house. I still has not figured out how this brand new coffee grinder got here but I've been using it and I can't stand the noise (I need to buy a new one and I'll do it right now, on Amazon). Well, this thing is LOUD. I have to block my ears when it grinds coffee and I do not allow my child to be near, it'll really ruin your hearing. It looks good but the loud noise is not worth it. Save your ears, people.

My wife bought me this for my birthday a year ago and after 2 months the switch stopped working. It won't stick so you have to stand there and hold the switch down to grind your coffee. Recently the opposite happened and now the switch is stuck in the "on" position so you have to operate the unit by plugging and unplugging. Just today, the motor gave out. All this within a year and I don't even use the thing that much. Looks nice and I like the design, but it's total junk. Do yourself a favor and buy something from another manufacturer. That's what I'll be doing today.
Researched a cheap one that works great. I have an older model. Ordered it on Thursday, got it on Friday, gave it to my daughter as part of her bridal shower gifts on Saturday!

reviews.reviewTitle: I’ve had 3 of these now, none of them ...
reviews.reviewText: I’ve had 3 of these now, none of them lasted more than 2-3 Years. My 3rd one just died and I won’t be buying another one.

I've never had great success with this product. From day one, it has produced a coffee powder with any selected granularity. As a result, you often get sediment laden coffee that's never the strength you intended. The output bin is annoyingly attractive of the coffee silt and grinds, which can be a plus as it helps to eliminate some of the silt produced. It's so bad, there's a 5:1 ratio of desired grounds to powder.

My first one failed because the timer, # scoops, selector failed. Took it apart and it's just a cheapo potentiometer created with a resistive strip.

I've moved on to a $10 hand grinder that produces, although not perfect, consistent grinds that make it superior to this appliance.

My wife and I got this grinder around 3 months ago. There were really no issues with it until today when it stopped working. I cleaned it thoroughly, thinking it wasn’t working because of stray coffee dust. It still isn’t working. I will attempt to get a refund or replacement through Cuisinart.

reviews.reviewTitle: Lasted a little over a year and then quit completely ...
reviews.reviewText: Lasted a little over a year and then quit completely. This is the second and LAST Cuisinart product I've bought, both of which turned into complete junk after a year. Will be steering clear of this company from here on out.

Best for the money. Better than blade models costing almost as much. Save those for your spices. I say you can't beat this one until you pony up $140 or more for the Capresso. Not good enough on fine for expresso and too many little grounds mixed in with the coarse for perfect french press brewing.

I killed my first one by removing the collection bin while grinding. Cuisinart swapped it for three dollars. I have tried many. This one is convenient, attractive and the best under $50.

reviews.reviewTitle: It does what it's designed to do.
reviews.reviewText: Well getting ready to buy another one. One of the reviews that follows says if it isn't broken don't fix it well mine finally gave up after almost 12 years. And that's what multiple uses per day so after I finish this review I will have another one en route by end of day. You cannot go wrong with this one.

It's ok....have to frequently take apart to clean. HOWEVER the biggest downside is the noise....it sounds like a rocket ship taking off...you can hear it outside of my home with windows and doors closed.

I loved this grinder initially, as I received it as a gift two Christmases ago. It did light duty but the grind was not consistent. It died this Christmas and I will not purchase again. I expected more durability from Cuisinart.

reviews.reviewTitle: Disintiegrated a few months after warranty
reviews.reviewText: I loved this grinder until yesterday, when the grinder mechanism disintegrated. Blew all the screws and ground them up with the coffee! Of course, it's just out of warranty, (18 months) so I have no recourse but to buy another one. Obviously, I won't be replacing the new one with the same brand. I'm bummed, because Cuisinart products have been pretty reliable for me in the past. I really think they should at least try to make products that last a good while beyond the length of the warranty they offer.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not waste your money on this piece of garbage.
reviews.reviewText: Very disappointed with this product. Began malfunctioning after six months and only worked intermittently. Cleaning the unit as described here made no difference. This piece of sh!t product finally died after 12 months. I will never buy another Cuisinart product again. I will never again be seduced by the implied quality of Cuisinart. To break so quickly was not what I expected. I had a Braun coffee grinder that lasted for over twenty years before one of the blades finally broke, and I unfortunately paid too much for this pathetic pile of chinese made crap replacement. If you buy one keep your receipt, you will need it, I misplaced mine. Very unhappy consumer.

I've had this grinder for several years. I bought it at Bed, Bath and Beyond for a much higher price than it is now at Amazon.
I've had other grinders, but what I love about this is that there is no mess. Just grind as much as you want into the bin and then measure out.
So easy. Some people have complained about a little coffee dust at the top of the bin, but at this price - who cares. I usually make drip coffee
so nothing goes to waste. The bin is dishwasher safe.

reviews.reviewTitle: Acidity from Coffee Beans is dissolving the Hopper and Grounds Container.
reviews.reviewText: Don't buy this grinder, the plastic hopper, and the plastic bottom ground holder are both being slowly dissolved by our coffee beans. The acidity of the oil on our beans is the culprit, but for something that holds coffee beans, this should not be a problem. We have only owned this grinder a month, but there are very visible issues with the plastic in this grinder.

I tend to be skeptical when people say a product seriously quit working after a few months. I assume they just got a lemon. I'm joining the crowd of people who say this things motor just suddenly burnt up. I don't remember the purchase date. Maybe we got 6 months use out of it, and that was only using it a couple times a week. Worked great for the very short time it lasted, so it's scraping by with 2 stars from me.
I love my coffee grinder. It's the best one I have ever had. Looks great on the counter too. Excellent quality!

I paid less than $40 for this unit yesterday and used it this morning for the first time. I forgot to put the cover on the ground coffee container and had a REAL mess all over the counter and onto the floor!! After getting it together correctly, it did a decent job of grinding. I am not that fussy and I think it is decent for the price. Wanted a conical burr grinder but could not justify the cost. This works just fine and time will tell how long it lasts. It's a nice looking unit and simple to operate.

I purchased this item less than a year ago and have been very disappointed. Usually Cuisinart products are top quality but this grinder required constant cleaning, almost after every basket if the grind was on medium to fine. The hole between the grinder burrs and the collection cup would clog with coffee, requiring frequent and very messy cleaning with the brush and a toothpick. I finally gave it up and went back to the old Krups blade grinder. Frankly, I can't tell the difference in taste, and the Krups has lasted ten years. Sorry, but one star is all this machine rates.

Ok, have had this for bit more than a year, and its my first grinder,worked well,and was looking on amazon to see what I would replace it with, and was unaware others rated it so high. However, it doesnt appear there are many choices in the same price range, and do not want to hold button down while I grind.

I would hate to think that I will have to order the same thing; um yes the grounds do tend to stick to the plastic, but cant believe its any different for other grinders

UPDATE: It's now been over 4.5 years and this machine is going strong. Still some static, still not cleaned it on the inside, still not doing extra fine grinds. For everyday coffee with a medium grind, it's a workhorse!
----------------------------
At the risk of sounding like a company shill (I'm not), this September will mark 3 years for me with this grinder. It's the only burr grinder I've ever owned and I don't brew anything but regular coffee w/a regular coffee maker (also Cuisinart) so I can't speak for the fine-grinding, but it's worked great for me and my wife over 3 years of daily use. Really changed my coffee-drinking experience.

Came on here to look for one for my brother and was astounded to read all the reviews of these failing. The only problem we've had is that the static in the plastic container that tends to hold onto the grinds a bit and cause a little mess on the counter from time to time. If you're fine with a little residue in the container and occasionally wiping your counter after pouring the grinds in, then it's a great grinder - especially for the price!

reviews.reviewTitle: Burned out after a few bags of coffee
reviews.reviewText: It worked well for few months then burned out. I don’t use it that much, so I got it to sorta work for several more weeks. It’s is now completely burned out after maybe five bags of coffee. I left it sitting for too many months to use the warranty. It appears this is a common problem

I have had this grinder for a little over a year now. I love the design of the unit. It still grinds the beans great but, about two months after I started using it, it does not grind the right amount of beans anymore. It grinds more than it is set for, which is very frustrating. So the cup setting is worthless. Beware if you have a problem with the grinder, keep your receipt. When you call Cuisinart, they run the serial number to see when the unit was made. So they go off of that for your date of purchase. The problem is, if it set in a store or warehouse for a long time, your screwed if you can't supply a receipt to prove when you actually purchased it. Also, you have to pay for shipping to Cuisinart and inclose a check for $4.00 for return shipping. If it wasn't for the problem with grinding the wrong amount of cups, I would recommend this product.

Clogs constantly, very difficult to use. In theory should be a great device. However, our unit clogs often, many times multiple times during one attempted use. Grind coarseness does not matter. This requires emptying out the bean holder, pouring coffee beans and ground coffee with some of it spilling all over the counter. Is it because we use organic French roast? Anyway, my wife has developed an extreme hatred of this frustrating machine!

Update: Found out there are cleaners on the market. Also, dark beans are oilier and may clog the system faster than light beans. Will update this review if we find something that helps. Still, should not be such a pain to use!

Best for the money. Better than blade models costing almost as much. Save those for your spices. I say you can't beat this one until you pony up $140 or more for the Capresso. Not good enough on fine for expresso and too many little grounds mixed in with the coarse for pperfect french press brewing.

I killed my first one by removing the collection bin while grinding. Cuisinart swapped it for three dollars. I have tried many. This one is convenient, attractive and the best under $50.

I bought this grinder based solely on the printing on the box, that says exactly this:

"The Right Grind: Turn the hopper to any one of the 18 grind settings, from ultra-fine for espresso to extra-coarse for percolated coffee."

It DOES NOT grind fine enough for any espresso machine. Not even close.

Some reviews here say you can't expect fine grinds in a cheap grinder. Well that's fine and dandy, except this grinder specifically claims that it does - I feel that's false advertising. I bought this to replace my old $50 Krups burr grinder which actually did grind fine enough for espresso for years until the burrs began to wear and I had to grind the coffee multiple times.

I was attracted to this grinder due to the Cuisinart brand (I own a Cuisinart food processor, which is great and ironically grinds coffee better than this coffee grinder, but I don't use it for that since the coffee grounds scratch up the side of the container.)

Now I'm faced with having to figure out how to return this, and of course it's a complete mess once you grind a single time, and I'm sure I'll have to spend hours cleaning it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Imagine a morning without coffee.......because the grinder died
reviews.reviewText: Just threw my second one in the trash! First one lasted five months, this one about six. Does a fairly good job grinding the beans, but the motors are junk. Used one daily, but and well maintained, but the motors in these are weak. Try something else!

reviews.reviewTitle: NOT A CONICAL BURR grinder. Deceptive description
reviews.reviewText:
I have a Cuisinart DBM-8 flat burr coffee grinder that I bought elsewhere. There is only one version of this model.

DBM-8 is not and has never been a conical burr grinder, as listed and described by this vendor.

Conical ceramic burr is a big buzzword right now. The cheap ones are over $300. If you are going to use this with a high end espresso machine, this model is not likely to get the job done to your satisfaction. The grind is not fine and perfectly consistent in grain size. I question why deceptive descriptions are allowed here at all.

In fairness to the Cuisinart DBM-8, it does a good job of grinding beans for drip and French press makers. I'm sure it's a very popular choice in its price range. If you want to compare the same model number with a truthful description, look at this one.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B00018RRRK/

You can see that it does get good reviews from people who bought it for what it is.

reviews.reviewTitle: I don't know how I ever lived without this.
reviews.reviewText: Wow! I just got this for Christmas and it's amazing. You can set the number of cups' worth of ground coffee you want and push "start" and leave it alone to do its thing grinding the perfect portion of the perfect size (fine, medium, course and everything in between). I love it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mine has pretty much died already AND it's very messy to use
reviews.reviewText:
I did not buy this from Amazon. Bought it at Target but didn't use it right away and now it's too late to take it back.

Mine has pretty much died already AND it's very messy to use. It is very bogged down and about to die, so I will take other reviewer's advice and try to take it apart to clean it to see if I can get it to work right again.

I did like that it did produce a better grind than my old blade grinder, and my coffee was so much better. I would give it only one star because I've only been using about a month and it's on the fritz, but it made my coffee better when I used it so I'm giving it two stars. Too bad it's a messy POS.

*next day revision*
Gave it one more star. Took other reviewer's advice, took it apart and cleaned it out with a chopstick. Had grounds packed tight inside grinder and chute was clogged. Put it back together and it worked again. Still very messy and a pain in the butt, but it works again and makes better coffee than a blade grinder. Since I'm cheap I'll stick with this for now and put up with the mess and hassle of cleaning it. I should take away the star I just gave back because I went out and spent $15 on a new blade grinder because I thought this burr grinder died on me. Overall, it's so-so. But it's affordable and OK if you know how to deal with it's issues.

I wish this grinder could hold more than 1/2 lb. of coffee, I feel as if I'm constantly refilling it.

When it works, it's great. I get a fine grind for my drip brew.

The big problem is, it only lasts about a year before it breaks, then needs replacement . I've gone thru about 5-6 of these since I started using this model 5 years ago. Compare that to my single usage grinder which would last a good decade.

So far worked out great, I bought this as a gift for my mom. She thinks it is the cutest thing, and it matches her cuisinart drip coffee maker. She hasn't used it yet because she has a whole bag of ground coffee already but she can't wait until she buys some fresh beans to grind. Update to come. with a more accurate star rating.

I bought this burr-grinder from Cuisinart. It was refurbished, but the price was excellent. I used it to grind my espresso beans for my Cuisinart Espresso Machine. A match made in heaven! A more consistent grind than the machine at Starbucks! Then it quit working 2 days ago (Saturday). I called Cuisinart this morning. Because it was refurbished, it only had a 90 day warranty. Had it quit 2 weeks sooner they would've replaced it. Because it lasted 113 days, I'm SOL!

I loved this grinder for 2 years until it just - stopped working. Plugged it in, turned it on - nothing. It gave up the ghost. Laid an egg. We couldn't figure out how to fix it, so we just threw it out. It is now gracing a landfill. I won't buy another.

reviews.reviewTitle: This Mill Grinds Too Much Coffee
reviews.reviewText:
I have had the DBM-8 coffee mill for several months now. I am not one to have great expectations for coffee mills and I have adapted my use to manage the quirks in the machine. For example, when the mill has finished grinding, I pull out the bin and rap it on the counter. This kicks loose the powder clinging to the sides of the bin, making it easier to dump it into the coffee maker basket.

There are two features of this mill that can be liabilities. The first is the automatic portion feature. Slide the slider to the number of cups of coffee you are making and press the Start button. Very simple to use, but I have discovered it grinds a lot more coffee than I like to use. For example, if I am making 4 cups, and I set the mill to 4 cups, I get about 6 tablespoons of ground coffee. Some may like their coffee that strong, but I prefer the old one-tablespoon-per-cup rule. As a result, I’m left guessing which setting will get me closest to the amount I need, or using a coffee scoop after all. Using a coffee scoop to confirm what the mill should be doing automatically bugs me.

The other feature is the nice, big bin to hold the whole beans. It’s great unless you like to switch coffees from time-to-time. I like to use a different coffee on weekends. To do that, I have to empty the bin and reload it with weekend beans. Monday mornings I reverse the process.

In all, it is a pretty good mill for the money. I just wish it would deliver the correct amount of ground coffee for the setting.

reviews.reviewTitle: I'll return to my old brand
reviews.reviewText: After my Capresso died after 3 years of daily use, I decided to purchase the Cuisinart. It was less expensive. The design of the Cuisinart coffee bin makes it difficult to see the amount of beans remaining. The container for the ground coffee is difficult to empty without spilling, and is difficult to re-insert. And this grinder generates a lot more "sludge" than the Capresso.

I used this product for about 13 months before it expired because the outlet for the grounds clogged (don't remember reading a caution about that in the manual) There did not seem to be any way to clean out the interior...I would have thought some maintenance would be necessary. The most annoying feature of this grinder is that it is absolutely impossible to grind the beans and remove the grounds from the receptacle without coffee flying everywhere. I had been operating it in the sink in an attempt to minimize cleanup. I am glad it is gone!

This grinder looks great on paper. It however has one flaw. The container which holds the ground coffee does not fit into the grinder properly. This causes coffee grounds to fall down along the back of the unit. When enough of these build up the container which holds the grounds will slip out and the machine will lose how long it has been grinding and reset. Makes it a pain. I had Cuisinart ship me a unit under warranty and it still has the same issues.

If, as I was, you are looking for a grinder that will give you a uniform grind that will allow you to make coffee in a French press without all the silt, this "burr" grinder is not what you want. No matter what grind setting I use, for every four or five tablespoons of beans ground, there is at least a teaspoon of very fine powder. Much of that clings in a clump to the side of the bin opposite the hole the ground coffee is blown out of into the bin. I suppose one can try to separate and throw out that powder, but there will obviously be plenty left mixed in with the grounds that will end up in the coffee poured from a French press.

Frankly, I think a $15.00 chopper leaves one with less powder than this machine, especially if one chops in bursts and gently shakes the chopper a few times during chopping to mix the beans a bit. Also, with a chopper I find that most of the powder, in smaller amounts and not as fine as this machine generates, is at the bottom of the chopper and the ground coffee can simply be poured out leaving the powder.

Cleaning this machine is, of course, much more involved than cleaning a chopper and it does not appear to me that one can actually really get the grinding mechanism in the machine body cleared of the powder it produces. Maybe you could if you keep an air compressor and hose handy in your kitchen, but I think that's not a common kitchen appliance.

reviews.reviewTitle: Appreciate the precision, but a bit messy
reviews.reviewText:
This is the first burr grinder we owned. We tend to grind fine. This grinder is far more messy then any previous grinders we've had. Next burr grinder we buy will be with anti-static technology. Didn't know to look for that previously. After about a year the motor burnt out. The grinds get stuck, where they pour out. We've since learned to clean it with a toothpick or sharp object. Consistency is ok. It is a hastle to empty and change coffee beans. But the convenience of not having to fill each day is nice; a trade-off.

1/2/2016 Update: When the motor burned out, Macy's replaced it free, because it was still within the warranty. We are still using the replacement model to this day and it works fine. We like that it gives a consistent grind based on settings. Since almost every coffee has it's unique optimum setting, we appreciate being able to precisely changes settings for the particular coffee.

I've had this grinder for almost 3 years now and it is still going strong. The grind is good and the bean hopper mechanism is excellent. I was motivated to write this review, though, because I am tired of the noise. I cringe every morning I turn it on because the thing is so loud. Some times I cover it with a kitchen towel or two to dampen the noise. I have often fantasized about making a quilted cover similar to a tea cozy that fits the machine so I can slide the hood over it while it grinds. The other downside is it makes a big mess of ground coffee on the counter when you remove the lid due to the static electricity mentioned by others. Now my routine is to remove the container and tap it in the sink a few times to get all the grounds to settle before opening it over the sink, but even this method does not completely avoid the mess. All this has made me consider getting one of the all-in-one grinder/brewers to avoid the mess and so that I can set the timer to go off when I don't have to listen to the noise. Alas, I am an espresso drinker and all that integration is available mainly in investment-grade setups.

When we received this as a gift we weren't particularly thrilled because it's big and noisy and we liked our little standard (spinning-blade) Krupps just fine. But even though it's noisy it's nice that you can set-and-forget the pot size and grind grit and fill up the pot, etc. while the beans grind. So all in all we like it and were disappointed when it broke.

Now, the break probably had something to do with a user error issue, but I won't get into that here. But the reason I'm bothering to write this review is that when I emailed Cuisinart support to ask about repair/replacement, they were extremely responsive and immediately offered to replace the thing for $10. But I was busy and didn't get around to sending the old one back for a few days, and within a week a brand new one just showed up on my doorstep even though I never even paid the shipping cost. So I was pretty stoked about that, and it made me feel obliged to recommend the product on account of the good service you'll get if anything ever goes wrong with it.
Worked for about 12 months before the top cracked and motor died. Perfect if you want a grinder that’ll last you a year. JUNK.

This unit has a known issue with a switch. I bought one for me and one for my parents for xmas. My switch died after about a year, and my parents lasted about 3 months longer than mine. Both broke in the same way. Now you have to hold the button down for it to work. You used to be able to set the amount (4-18 cups), walk away, and come back when it was finished. We don't use it anymore because of the broken switch.
You will find similar complaints in user reviews. If you only want this to work for a year, buy it. If you expect it to last longer, buy something else.

reviews.reviewTitle: After about the 5th use it would not turn off ...
reviews.reviewText: After about the 5th use it would not turn off and then it would not stay on past several seconds. Now 1 month in the switch doesn't turn it on even after numerous cleanings.
This grinder works fine for grinding drip or for a coffee press but the finest setting is not near fine enough for espresso. Other than that it is just OK.

reviews.reviewTitle: HAD IT FOR 5 YEARS AND STILL GOING STRONG!!
reviews.reviewText: I was shopping for other coffee bar products when I came across these reviews for the DBM-8 and I couldn't beleive how many people claim that they have had a negative experience with this product. I've used it almost every day for the past 5 years for drip coffee, french press, and espresso and have been happy with the grind consistency. 100% reliable...adjust the coarseness for the grind, push the grind button, and it goes to work. I have never busted out my magnifying glass to inspect the grind conistency on a micro-level but in the wire mesh filter for my coffee maker, glass for french press, or metal espresso filter after grinding at each respective coarseness settings on the grinder this little machine produces a consistent grind. Yes, making espresso the old fashion way like this is messy but don't blame the grinder. Absolutely recommend for this price.

When it works, this product grinds well and is convenient.

That said, my first one ran well for several weeks, then simply would not start again. Cuisinart replaced it under warranty. Same story for the second one; ran well for several weeks, then, for no obvious reason, stopped working.

Being an electronics engineer, I took it apart, thinking that it might be a simple failure that could be fixed with a soldering iron. Everything looked just fine inside. There must be an over-stressed component that does not fail in an obvious way.

I would love to love this product, but there is something in the design that is poorly chosen. The engineers who designed this grinder should be ashamed of themselves. I am giving up on the product because of very poor reliability.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked good, but burned out in a few months.
reviews.reviewText: This grinder worked pretty good, had a setting to determine how many cups of coffee and which grind you preferred, then ran by itself. However, I would sometimes grind a pound of coffee at a time, and this grinder got very hot and eventually burned out in just a few months use. This is probably good if you grind your coffee every day, but for large quantity grinding I'd look elsewhere.

After purchasing my Espresso machine, and reading the manual it states that you MUST use a Burr grinder NOT a blade grinder. Did a lot of looking on the internet, but when I went to the store I ended up with the Cuisinart. Now, what is impressive is the 8 settings, but usually use the Finest grind for my machine. Now with 8 settings I was able to test a little to see which setting would give me the best crema. One review is right about the plastic container and that the static makes the coffee stick to the sides, but as you try to cut costs Glass is expensive. I like that you can just grind just what you need 2 cups, 4 cups, 12 cups or shut the grinder off in the middle of grinding. Granted I grind about 1/2 lb. at a time, and then clean my grinder up with the included brush, thus haven't had any jams. So far after three months of use its still working fine and about two pounds of coffee!

reviews.reviewTitle: AVOID: short life and poor grind
reviews.reviewText: While this machine lasted about 2 years, I only used it an average of twice a week. Worse is the fact that its finest grind setting is woefully inadequate for good espresso. I replaced it last week with a Capresso Infinity, and it has made a world of difference in the quality of the espresso I'm getting from my Saeco Magic Cappucino Plus. I'm not an expert barista by any means, but the finer grind I get from the Capresso is more than worth the extra $35. I might also add that it's much quieter than the Cuisinart, which is loud enought to wake the dead.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does good work but is loud
reviews.reviewText:
This grinder is very easy to use and clean. The entire hopper can unscrew which allows you to get to the inside for cleaning. The design is good but a bit large for a small kitchen.
Pros:
Easy to clean
Easy to use
Simple design

Cons:
Very loud - will wake up people in the morning :)
Plastic receiving container develops static electricity, which causes grindings to stick to it.
As the device is used, find buildup accumulates on the exit hole, thus causing grounds to get trapped inside and grind longer than they should. This results in a finer grind than expected. Accommodate by either cleaning or selecting a coarser grind.

Do not buy this grinder. I have returned two of these to Cuisinart in the last two years and my third just stopped working. I only used it once a week and the motor burned out after a few months. Although Cuisinart has a good return policy, they charge $10 for shipping. I finally had enough and put the $10 towards a Capresso model.
Opps, posted this on the wrong machine as Gilda would say .., nevermind

reviews.reviewTitle: Grind well and love the extra flavor and great taste from the whole ...
reviews.reviewText: Grind well and love the extra flavor and great taste from the whole beans. Set the dial for our pot and so once it is set it give the correct amount of ground coffee each time.

reviews.reviewTitle: JUNK - Can't believe I actually bought this two times ...
reviews.reviewText: JUNK - Can't believe I actually bought this two times. Both motors failed in short order. I have a Mr Coffee grinder that is over 20 years old and still works. Needed a unit with a bigger hopper. This is not it.

I have owned 3 of these. It works great until it doesn’t! We grind a lot of coffee but due to the oils in the coffee, this machine gets clogged and stops working. Very difficult to clean. I have tried toothbrushes pipe cleaners, etc to get into every crevice but nothing works for long even if you get it half way clean.

If they would have used some of the decorative metal on the outside on the working parts inside it would be a good grinder. Plastic threads at bottom of hopper broke after light duty use. And they gouge on the shipping for the replacement part.

We bought this burr grinder thinking that it would be an improvement over a blade grinder. After using it a few times we changed our minds and eventually threw it away. The price is pretty cheap so I wasn't too upset by the fact that the grind was just as inconsistent as blade grinder. We're just trying to grind coffee for a drip maker so we don't need a perfect espresso grind. It has a nice big bean hopper but the collecting jar capacity is much smaller so you can't really grind a whole bag of coffee in one go. This is not a big deal but you need to keep an eye on it. Keeping an eye on it is a real problem though. The machine makes an unbelievable squealing noise while grinding. I thought blade grinders were bad, but this is intolerable. The only solution is to shut the thing off or leave the room. However, you can't do the latter if you have just filled the bean hopper, or else the collection jar will overflow. Finally to add insult to injury, the mill would get jammed on beans because the motor is too weak.
Overall, it was a waste of counter space.

Pros:
1. Compact design.
2. Esthetic styling
3. Capacity of bean hopper
4. Does not overheat ground coffee

Cons:
1. Makes horribly loud squealing noise
2. Frequently gets clogged
3. Small size of collecting jar (must empty 4-5 times for each fill of bean hopper)
4. Inconsistent coarseness of grind

reviews.reviewTitle: It is terrible. I've used it 3 times
reviews.reviewText: I received this as a Christmas gift. It is terrible. I've used it 3 times. In its first three uses it produce a lot of fine grounds instead of a consistently sized coarse grind, which it was set to deliver. I went use a few days ago and it ran as though it had a short then stopped. I cleaned it tonight, made sure everything was assembled correctly and it is totally dead. What a piece of junk. I'll try to return it to get something different.

When it worked it was just okay, noise and coffee dust noted. One day it ground beans for a french press, the next day it was caput. This has happened TWICE. I shall not be getting yet another. Before owning a burr grinder, I had used one of the cheap whizzer varieties which was less than satisfactory, but I was also brewing coffee with a Mr Coffee drip machine. Then I took a "step up" and purchased a french press and then another "step up" and got the Cuisinart grinder. Now two french presses later (these guys are very delicate - they break easily) and two dead coffee grinders. I am back to square one. Purchased an aeropress - the day it arrived was when grinder #2 died. Is it really that hard to manufacture a decent grinder?
Great product. I've had mine for a couple years now and it has lived up to daily use with no problems. It's loud but I'm not sure if there's such a thing as a quiet grinder.

I see bad reviews, but mine has done an excellent job for years not only in-home but on the road in my teardrop compact travel trailer. I have ordered a replacement in case mine ever dies but for now my old ( at least four years) is still grinding away.

If you prefer a fine grind, be prepared for the machine to clog regularly. We have to use an air compressor to clean it every 6 weeks or so, and even the finest grind is too course for our espresso machine.

I've only had the grinder for a few days but am very happy with it. It won't make less than four cups worth, which is fine for me. Another reviewer pointed out the 'static cling' of the coffee dust to the plastic ground bin, and I see this as a good thing. Though it nearly uniformly grinds my coffee coarsely as I set it for my french press, there is a bit of coffee dust that I'd rather cling to the bin than go into the press. And it's easy enough to clean out with a boar bristle pastry brush. I just hope it lasts longer than for some of the other reviewers, but so far, no complaints.

Received this as a gift based on its ability to perform irregular cuts, but after using it I can't tell a noticeable difference between the irregular cuts and whatever I was producing before. And now in addition to less counter space, I'm forever cleaning up stray coffee grounds everywhere because the container where the grounds are dumped is too big for a regular coffee maker. The switches and settings feel cheap, wiggly, and non-durable for the price.

Seems to work OK, no louder than I expected, makes good coffee, it's just messy and cheaply designed for an appliance looking grinder. Had I found this myself and if I did need a grinder this substantial, I think I'd opt to spend a little more money and get something of better quality. Instead I'm going back to my $20 Braun cylinder which has faithfully produced good coffee for 8 years without mess or issue.
Complete garbage. After one use it stopped working. I used a gift card to purchase this piece of garbage, so it is already in the garbage can. Stay away from this abysmal piece of trash.

While this was a good machine while it lasted, it only lasted for 23 months. The warranty is 18 months. It just made a big "POP" and then the smell of a burned out motor wafted my way. We took it apart and a capacitor inside blew off. I have a tiny spice mill grinder that has lasted for over 10 years, so I guess I'll go back to that until I find another counter model.

reviews.reviewTitle: Too bad I can't say the same for my Cuisinart 1200 ...
reviews.reviewText: Have had mine over 14 years and use it every day, money well spent. Too bad I can't say the same for my Cuisinart 1200 coffee maker.

reviews.reviewTitle: ... french press coffee or drip coffee it works just fine, i did find it a little loud but ...
reviews.reviewText: this coffee grinder has lasted six years with constant use and for making french press coffee or drip coffee it works just fine, i did find it a little loud but what do expect from something that grinds coffee as fast as it does. The only problem i found with this grinder is that it simply cannot grind espresso fine enough to get a decent cup of espresso and for me that is why it got three stars. If you are grinding regular coffee this thing is a 5 star product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Espresso grind uniform and fine. Least messy
reviews.reviewText: The first relatively inexpensive to deliver the goods. Espresso grind uniform and fine. Least messy. Won't start if receptacle not in place. I had to return several others. Not this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Will never buy any Cruisinart grinder or coffee maker
reviews.reviewText: I first bought the high end auto Cruisinart coffee maker with the build-in purr grinder, after 3 months the grinder does not work anymore (despite cleaning out all the dust numerous times). Annoying, but the coffee maker still works, so I went out and bought the Crusinart purr grinder ($70 model), worked about 6 months, motor burnt out. Luckily, I kept the receipt, so exchanged to a new one. The new one worked for 2 months, motor burnt out again. The broken one still sitting here waiting for a return. So I thought maybe it is the purr model, so went out to buy a cheaper Crusinart blade grinder (against my will, that specific Macy's only carries Crusinart in-store), used 1.5 month, the motor burnt out again. I don't think this is coincidence anymore, it is Crusinart. Don't buy this brand! I certainly won't.

The grind was inconsistent. There was always a lot of coffee powder after each grind. This would not be a problem for a traditional coffee maker with a filter, however, I use a French Press and it leave coffee powder in my cup.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good... but broke down after 3 months :(
reviews.reviewText: Received this as a gift-- and we wanted to love it... unfortunately it broke after 3 months of daily use. We tried everything to fix it, but to no avail. Amazon was kind enough to send me a return label for the broken item and credit our account. When it worked it was an efficient, quiet and good little grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: very inconsistent grind for a burr
reviews.reviewText: I found this grinder to produce a lot of fine dust even for the price range (~$40). for a drip maker, I couldn't just grind and dump in the basket, id have to go through and sift out large clumps and pockets of dust or risk bitterness/an overflow in the brewer. its also very loud and has a lot of static in the hopper, but my main gripe is the grind consistency...

Owned this grinder about 1 year. Worked fine in general. It is important to remove the hopper and clean the grind surfaces and, more importantly make sure the opening into the grind container is cleared from time to time. It clogs much more readily with the oil coated beans. Dry beans, such as starbucks, are much less likely to stick in the opening. The reason my 1 star is that the threads on the hopper disintegrated after a while and the hopper would no longer screw into the base. The threads are made of plastic and are a bit delicate. Would have made more sense if they were steel, as this part of the hopper is an integral part of the grind chamber. Well it is the trash hep for this one.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grind setting for espresso not fine enough
reviews.reviewText: What a waste of time and money. If you are an espresso enthusiast, don’t buy it. The finest setting is not fine enough for a standard espresso machine. Still needs like 2 or 4 more finer settings than what it does now.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grind not fine enough for espresso. You get what you pay for.
reviews.reviewText: Unfortunately the grinder does not grind coffee fine enough for espresso. The manufacturing tolerances for a true espresso grind are out of reach for this cheap product. The Burr plates cannot be set close enough to get the grind required. Please let me quote a product description of the DBM-8 which is very misleading "Customize your grind with 18 different levels to choose from. Select an ultra-fine grind for espressos or choose a coarser grind for French presses".

I have had two of these second one was a free replacement because the first one DIED after a couple of months. This is hands down the WORST grinder I have ever owned - I would rather grind the beans between my teeth first.

Problems: You need ear protectors on before grinding, LOUD, huh, about as loud as the Space Shuttle taking off from five feet. Grinds are sooooooooooooooo inconsistent. Doesn't grind like the selection indicates. Static cling doesn't even describe it, I have to keep a small brush beside the grinder in order to get all the stuck grinds out of the hopper. Continuously clogs up need to clean it out every other day. Total and utter junk I wouldn't take another one if it was free...!!!

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinder motor died after only a year and a half
reviews.reviewText: I’ve purchased two of these in the last three years and both dies after about a year and a half of use. The motor just stopped working and Cuisinart wouldn’t honor the warranty. Won’t be buying another one of these machines again.

Well, after many years, my Burr Mill grinder broke this morning. Found the identical one on Amazon and will buy again. I love the versatility of this grinder, as well as the large coffee container. And the price for this quality can't be beat. I highly recommend this product!

reviews.reviewTitle: I bought my Cuisinart Supreme Grind less than a month ...
reviews.reviewText: I bought my Cuisinart Supreme Grind less than a month ago, and it already quit working. The motor is fried from normal use. Save yourself the anguish and spend more on a coffee grinder. This one is a POS.

I've used this coffee grinder for about seven months and have mostly been happy with it. It consistently yields a solid grind with very little powder or inconsistent sizes to the grinds. I've never tried to make an espresso grind with it (I suspect finding any good espresso grinder in this price range is unrealistic) but have used it for both french press and my Bonavita coffee maker. I've found that the many grind options are great for drip coffee as I can experiment with finding the perfect grind depending on the roast I'm using that week. I tend to like lighter roasts and avoid the stout bitter taste of a dark roast but I've found I can usually manipulate the texture/taste of the coffee quite well with the grind settings. It allows me to enjoy some roasts I might normally avoid if I couldn't get the right grind texture.

My main criticisms of it (like others on here) is not the quality of the grind but the usability of the grinder. The grind receptacle is made of plastic and thus you get a lot of static cling.
