When pouring the grinds into your coffee maker, it can often make a little bit of a mess, and in fact, I've gotten to where I pour the grinds into my filter over the sink. Otherwise, I get grinds in the coffee maker or on the counter. The receptacle also doesn't always slide neatly into the grinder. I've found that something as simple as putting the receptacle back into the grinder can be a little irritating, especially when doing this in the morning before really waking up (the cruel irony, I suppose, of coffee equipment is that you use it before you're fully alert).

These are all things I've learned to live with, though if the new Bodum grinder had been available seven months ago, I probably would have bought it instead. But based on price range of the machine and quality of the grind, I very much recommend it. Just anticipate a couple of annoying user issues.

We received this as a gift about 7 mos ago. Seemed to work ok...not spectacular. Didn't notice a difference in coffee taste compared to the cheaper grinders GE, Braun & Mr. Coffee make. About 2 wks ago...after only using it a couple times a week since we owned it...the machine completely died...motor gave up and although my husband opened the bottom hoping it might just be a loose wire...no such luck. I would greatly discourage purchasing this ..just because I'm not the only reviewer who had the machine die on them. Cuisinart makes a great coffee maker...we love ours...and wouldn't trade it for anything...but they need some new engineers working on their burr grinders...cause the current people assigned to the design of this machine...haven't got it right!
I like this coffee grinder, but it is LOUD. Wakes up our kids every time we use it, so we've started having to grind coffee at night or after they've woken up which is less than ideal.

This grinder does a fairly consistent job of grinding (take into consideration, you've paid well under $100) and has been grinding for nearly a year for me, without fail. Sometimes going through nearly half a pound of beans at a clip. My previous blade grinder burnt out in six months. I use this for the French press coffee maker, and I do find that it is best if ground on medium, though the manufacturer of the grinder recommended coarse. Dellcious!
The auto stop doesn't now work.

reviews.reviewTitle: Easy to use and clean --in fact
reviews.reviewText: If you grind beans, this is the most convenient way to grind 1/2 lb of beans. Easy to use and clean --in fact, pretty much idiot proof

The grinder does a nice job grinding the beans. Do wonder why they make it seem like there are a lot more grind settings when in practicality there really are just 3 distinct settings. The only issue is durability - they don't last long. I've burned through 2 in the last 3 years. I grind half a hopper once a day 5 to 6 days a week and two units burned out and stopped working at 1 year to 18 months. Since they are in the under $50 group I got tried a second one but this time I'm going to get another brand.
Setting I was mostly looking for was nr 18 which should be for espresso coffee preparing. Instead, I got grinded coffee good for drip preparation only. Will return to store.

Would downgrade to 2 or 3 stars. Can't revise the 'stars'
This grinder may be loud, but it does a great job in a short time: What I said then.

After 1 year (13 months), the timer (# of cups to grind) just quit. It stills grinds coffee if the button is held down - but who wants to stand there? Can prop something heavy to hold it down, but that limits the grind options.
Will spend the time looking for another brand. Cuisanart used to be great, what happened?

To reiterate what other reviewers have said: a burr grinder at this price is not going to be at all perfect. That said, it's definitely beyond serviceable, and I find it very useful when grinding coffee for my stovetop espresso maker--notice my overall level of investment here. It does, however (and at least one other reviewer mentioned this as well), leave a fine layer of dust in the chamber full of ground coffee. While this won't bother you on the finest settings (for espresso and Turkish coffee), when grinding coffee for a French press, it's a mite obnoxious because you end up with little bits of dust at the bottom of your cup--precisely what I wanted to avoid by buying a grinder. Overall, if you're cheap like me, you'll enjoy this grinder. I certainly like it very much and it works great for espresso.

reviews.reviewTitle: I should have bought a better one because this couldn't hold up and now I ...
reviews.reviewText: I should have bought a better one because this couldn't hold up and now I wasted a good chunk of change. I chose it betting on performance similar to my many other cuisinart products...Bad logic! I used the grinder daily. Grounds were inconsistent. This was a problem as I sought coarser grounds- not the powdery stuff everyone sells. It seized eventually. When we cleared the jams the rotating mechanism/cogs literally broke apart. CANNOT SUSTAIN CONSTANT USE.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not cheap but not that well made.
reviews.reviewText: Notorious for breaking down after a few years. You can try to fix it yourself or just be disappointed.

I will be returning mine. The thing works fine but it is a messy machine to use and it’s just not for espresso. So if you like a dirty machine not for espresso it’s a sold 4-5 star product just not for me.

reviews.reviewTitle: Mmmmm...Arabica with a hint of ground ABS plastic
reviews.reviewText: Device operated well for 3+ years then wouldn't operate unless I maintained pressure on the hopper to engage a safety switch embedded in the base of unit which prohibits operation when the hopper is unscrewed. Not much chance I'd be attempting to shread carrots using this device, but I'm sure it has saved countless finger tips. I ultimately located a radial crack in the threaded section of the bean hopper which I glued to restore the function of the safety switch. The following info was discovered during investigation to potentially defeat the safety switch. I removed the bottom rubber feet, removed the base and was greeted by a 1/2 cup of grounds that spilled out. Removing the top I had at least a cup of ground coffee plop out in compressed coffee cake form. Why? The burr grinder includes a set of agitating metal blades to expel ground coffee from the grinds collection area below the grinding surfaces. The action of the blades on the ground coffee itself had scoured the sides of the ABS plastic body and ultimately wore a slot in the grind collecion reservoir inside the grinder chassis. This opening allowed coffee to enter the interior body of unit. I initially thought it was an ABS casting defect but then saw a distinct wear pattern. Looking down at the chamber with the discharge chute at 12 o'clock the most wear was at 11 and tapered off counter-clockwise. The scouring energy of grounds builds at 1 o'clock and is greatest prior to exiting the discharge chute at 12 o'clock. I urge Cuisinart to review this design. There are several issues of concern. The risk of fire from coffee collecting within chassis and proximity to motor, electronics, etc. The health risk of brewing ABS enriched coffee. Now, who can recommend a full metal chassis burr grinder? Follow Up: I repaired the damaged area with a piece of sheet metal that I glued into the damaged collection area. 6 months on the grinder still chugging along.

reviews.reviewTitle: Doesn't grind fine enough for my espresso machine.
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this one last week. Looks pro but it's too big for a countertop.
But the real beef i have with it is that it can't grind the coffee fine enough for espresso. I also own a Krupps at home and I set it at three pegs from the finest grind. The Cuisinart is maxed out and not even close to the grind of the Krupps, which BTW is less expensive.
It does seem master the coarser grinds though, nice and evenly.

reviews.reviewTitle: Better than a blade grinder, but not built to last.
reviews.reviewText:
Our unit lasted a little less than a year with daily use. Before breaking (more on that later) it performed only... okay. Certainly better than the whirly-blade grinders, but don't think that you'll get the equivalent performance of a $200 machine. Grounds are less uniform and the poster that mentioned the fine powder, no matter the setting, is absolutely right.

Build quality is certainly not top-notch, which is expected at this price point. Build quality is to blame for the failure of our unit - there is a column at the bottom of the bean reservoir and the top plate of the grinding mechanism is attached to the bottom of that column. Beans flow from the reservoir, through the column and in to the grinder. While the top grinding plate is metal, the column that it is attached to is plastic - this is the part that broke on my unit, rendering the unit completely useless.

Buy this unit if you don't want to spring for something four times as expensive, but be aware that it'll have less than 1/4 of the life-span of the more expensive unit and it'll be outperformed by a noticeable margin.
It's hardly been used and just quit.

I love the fact that it’s at least 11 years old and still works. It has stopped working twice now, but that was due to a bean jam. Easy fix! Will definitely purchase a replacement when the time comes.
Way to messy. I have a capresso burr grinder but got this one for my daughter and the static is unbelievable. I tried it everyday for a week and it’s just to messy and wasteful. It’s also quite loud.

This grinder works really well for a french press. I do not really brew espresso much, or drip ever, so I cannot comment on that.

It does produce a very small amount of dust, but like other reviewers, I find that the static keeps it on top of the grounds I want to use. I simply scoop out the 1/4 teaspoon (maybe even less - really small amount) of the powder and the use the other grounds.

I was given this and contemplated returning it and going with a more expensive model because I am a quality freak and read tons of reviews. I am happy I didn't - for french presses, this is more than adaquate. Compared to the comercial burr grinder I used to use where I buy my coffee, this one grinds pretty close, if not as good.

We got this as a wedding gift, not on my list. My husband just threw it in the garbage after three years, literally in the garbage. The thing was poorly designed, very messy, it should come with a skewer to clean out the grinder part, instead you get a little brush that doesn't even reach!!!! The container that holds the ground coffee is square making an even bigger mess when you dump it into the coffee filter! And because the container that holds the beans is poorly designed we had to shake the grinder to get the beans down into the grinder portion. Don't buy!!!!!!!

Received this as a Christmas present in 2014 and the machine is working just as good as it did a year ago, we use it for our Keurig as well as French Press on the weekends.

Love this machine, best grinder we ever had!

This is the best grinder I have ever used. I have used it everyday for one year. I have not had one problem with the machine. It is very well made, and, the grind is perfect. Yes, it does cost more than your run of the mill grinders, but the coast is well worth it. Fill it with your coffee beans, set the time required, then set back and when done it shuts off on its own. You chose the grind, it has many grinds. This is the one to buy.

Cal Morris

It was good while it lasted. Did the job well. It only had minimal use, as in once a week or less. One day I plugged it in and it didn't work. Completely dead. Nothing was stuck, it was just DOA, kaput, no sounds, nothing. Disappointed that it didn't hold up to minimal use.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great Burr Grinder for the Money!!!!!!
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this Cuisinart Burr Grinder several months ago at Sam's. It has met and exceeded my expectations. I have owned other, more costly, grinders and this grinder, in my opinion, is superior. First off, it has not jammed since I've owned it and it grinds the beans to perfection. You can go ahead and spend more money on other fancy burr grinders, but save your money and give this one a try. It is durable and you will see that it is money saved and money well spent!

Here it is June 2008 and the grinder is still going strong and grinding one excellent cup of coffee after another. I wish there was a SIXTH star!

Bought this from another consumer electronics place. Very loud, uneven grinding, and it died after light use four months in. They want 10 dollars to replace it, and they want me to ship the cord back as well! Not impressed in the least.

This grinder is made almost entirely of plastic, which breaks. In fact, the burr grinding mechanism, which is metal, is attached to the plastic cone where you put the beans. This whole cone then screws down into the base. Since this cone is plastic, it breaks and you are SOL! Lousy design; do not buy.
Good Product,when the grinding is completed, the electronic timer automatically closes.

reviews.reviewTitle: this grinder fell apart within a year
reviews.reviewText: My wife and I got one of these for Christmas. I've been disappointed with this and other Cuisinart equipment. The upper burr (grinding plate) is attached with screws to not very sturdy piece of brittle plastic of the hopper tube which broke into 20 pieces with less than a year of less than once per day use. The only fix is a new bean chamber, and that doesn't fix the burrs that are no longer sharp from grinding the plastic into our coffee. The result is too much fine coffee powder mixed with the ground coffee. I hope I just got a defective unit. I'm looking at the bunn or the kitchen-aid to replace it.

reviews.reviewTitle: outer cosmetics obscure cheap internal components
reviews.reviewText: Works great when it's new. Noisy, but all burr mills are inherently noisy. Problem is that the internal workings are housed in bakelite and that gives the unit a short life. Under daily use, you can expect the unit to fail within the first 24 months, and when the bakelite internal components shatter, it sounds like the unit will explode! A+ for quality of grind. An F- for durability.
Great design and easy to use

reviews.reviewTitle: Cuisinart CCM-16 Series BURR MILL GRINDER
reviews.reviewText:
I had this grinder for a year. It is an average grinder. IT is very noisy,and somewhat messy. ON a plus side it has a very large range selection of grinds and number of cups
selection to keep consistent taste of coffee. One day I dropped the plastic cup and it chipped a corner so I had to use tape to keep the grinds in.
And now I am looking at other coffee grinders such as Mr. Coffee or Kitchen Aid. The thin plastic coffee cup makes it uneconomical to purchase because any drop
of this cup will make the machine useless.

reviews.reviewTitle: I bought one of these five years ago, and ...
reviews.reviewText: I bought one of these five years ago, and after 3 1/2 years, it stopped working. I bought another one after that, and it has stopped working also. I guess these are very cheaply made. I will go with a more expensive one next time. Would definitely not buy another one.

Advertised as a Burr Mill but it does most of the grinding with blades that whirl like a spice grinder. Creates a LOT of powder - even on the coarsest setting. And it generates a lot of static. When you try to pour the ground coffee, it jumps all over the counter. Does a slightly better job grinding flavored coffees.

Overall, you would be better off using a spice grinder and pulsing the motor until you achieve the grind you desire. Don't waste your money on the Cuisinart DBM-8. It's not a good product.

I purchased this grinder in June 2011 for use with a french press. I was satisfied with the grind produced using the coarsest setting, although as other reviewers have noted, the grinder does produce some dust. The unit burned out after 13 months. I may perform an autopsy to see what failed, but am sure it is not fixable as it put out a considerable amount of (nasty) smoke when going through it's death throes.

reviews.reviewTitle: So many features.....so little to like!
reviews.reviewText:
Absolute waste of money!

This unit has all the features you would want.......but it isn't worth buying!

It is so noisy it scares my grandsons (me too)!

On the same setting it would grind anywhere from a couple TBSP to a full bin.....no rhyme or reason!

No matter what setting it was on, it created everything from talcum powder fine dust to coarse grounds and everything in between!

The flakes and dust were all over the area in my kitchen where I used it after just 10-12 uses!

Thankfully, I bought it at a place that has a liberal return policy.
Works great. I love mine, and bought my son one for Christmas. I think he likes it

reviews.reviewTitle: I have had this coffee grinder for about 6 years ...
reviews.reviewText: I have had this coffee grinder for about 6 years. It is still working as well as the day it was purchased.
I just purchased one from Macy's to go along with my new french press and it was DOA. It looks like my search for a reasonably priced coarse grinder continues.

For the price and ability of this machine, you might as well get a cheap normal coffee grinder. It isn't anything special and on top of that it is extremely loud. I owned this item for a little over a year and it just stopped working. Cheaper grinders have a much longer life. I suggest going up in price point or just getting a cheap coffee grinder.

This burr grinder has worked well for me for 3 years. Variable from fine to course grind, One third to one half pound of beans at a time. Doesn't leak and easy to clean. Way too loud to use in the morning if others in the household are sleeping. For under $50 bucks a good buy.

I bought one of these at Kohl's on 12/27/11. It worked just fine but stopped working by February, so I exchanged it at the store. I only used it when I found 2 pound bags of Starbuck's French Roast at T.J. Maxx for $14.99 and would grind a partial bag at a time. Probably no more than a half hour's use since then but when I ground up some in advance last week, I'm guessing the motor overheated and seized up. It's in the trash now. I'd recommend using this light-duty grinder for no more than a few ounces of beans at a time.

reviews.reviewTitle: OK, but loud and dust cakes to top of grind container
reviews.reviewText:
We've had this grinder for a couple years now and it works ok. My two complaints are:

1) Its very loud
2) "Dust" cakes at the top of the plastic container leaving a bit of grind inconsistency.

We got our DBM-8 5 years ago as a wedding present and it's worked great except, the BURRS ARE WORN OUT and I called Cuisinart about where to get new burrs (Mazzer, Racillo, Fiorenzata and almost any other company sells replacement burrs) but Cuisinart refuses to sell them and "trade secrets" and warranty voiding were the reasons given to me for why I couldn't buy them.

I explained to the guy that Bosch sells skill saws that last for 20 years, but they key is that you can get NEW BLADES FOR THEM... no one's using the same skill saw blade that came with the saw after 5 years of woodworking.

MORAL OF THE STORY: ONLY BUY THIS PRODUCT IF ARE OK WITH THROWING IT AWAY AFTER A FEW YEARS AND BUYING A NEW ONE ($35) BECAUSE THE $10 BURRS AREN'T "AVAILALBE TO THE PUBLIC"

Great grinder for the daily coffee drinker. Its not a $500 grinder and your not gonna make expresso but it does a great job. The settings are easy to use and vary from fine to coarse. The top has a setting for how many cups you want to grind and seem to be accurate. The grinder provides a taste of fresh coffee that you wont get from coffee in a bag. The grinder doesnt get to hot and wont burn your beans. Its not messy and well worth the money.

reviews.reviewTitle: We typically grind light to medium roast beans on a medium-coarse setting for a French Press and are happy with the results
reviews.reviewText: We've had ours for almost 9 years and have never had a problem. We typically grind light to medium roast beans on a medium-coarse setting for a French Press and are happy with the results. Although we haven't compared it to higher end burr grinders, this is definitely a step up from blade grinders.

I am one of the people that became frustrated with the mess created from static electricity. When opening the plastic receptacle, whatever coffee didn't stick to the inside would pop out all over the kitchen counter. Even in the summer it was a problem. Now that we are into the dry, 20 below Minnesota winter, I almost went back to buying ground coffee. I did, however, come up with a solution. I cut a half-inch strip of aluminum foil from the end of a roll and inserted about half of it into the plastic container. The remaining 6 inches was left to dangle out the front. I found that this totally resolved the static problem and the foil can be re-used forever.

It's unfortunate but this product does not last long, and Cuisinart does not stand behind their products. It lasted me approximately 10 months, with an average use of 1 time per day. Prior to dying, it would occasionally act up by either grinding too much or too little, but typically worked well, when it worked. My sister and brother also had this same product, and they too experienced the same thing, with their products ceasing to work after some time.

reviews.reviewTitle: Would buy for any coffee aficionado!
reviews.reviewText:
Great coffee grinder with some pretty specific control features beyond just the grind. The setting for the amount of cups it makes lets me fill the hopper without worry (it's also air tight) and grind what I need. It puts a little more than what I'm used to out, but that's great if you're looking for a darker cup of coffee.

Fiancee and mother love it!
China nuff said!

The DBM-8 coffee grinder (a gift) arrived with problems. Out of the box the start button worked erratically then died completely an hour later. I called Cuisinart customer service. They charged me $4 to ship a new unit and I was to return the defective one at my expense. The lowest price shipping I found was $16. Paying $20 to replace a defective $45 item seems excessive to me. The replacement grinder works. However, as many have reported, at the finest setting it doesn't grind finely enough to make espresso. In retrospect, I would have been smarter to apply that $20 to a grinder that can grind for espresso.

reviews.reviewTitle: Better than a blade grinder, by a bit
reviews.reviewText:
For the price, it's better than a blade grinder, and it will do an adequate job for drip coffee. The french press is not consistent and has a lot of dust which gets through the filter. It isn't fine enough for espresso.

I recommend spending the extra for a conical burr grinder, even the Cuisinart one, because the quality goes up a lot.

(Helpful? Not? Please vote, so I know someone's reading these ;-) :: This grinder has a good name, seems sturdy enough, and gets the job done down to espresso grind, but no further.
1: Finest grind setting sufficient for pressurized portafilter espresso machines.
2: Turkish coffee is not going to be possible w/o modifying the machine.
3: Plastic hopper prone to static cling. Let grounds sit a couple minutes.
4: Noise level is tolerable, even low compared to other grinders
5: "Dosing" feature OK, but it's in "cups", so not like the fancy ones.
6: Finesse adjustments to grind are easy, sturdy, and work as advertised.
7: Model is compact, attractive, and reasonably priced.
8: No good for commercial-style espresso machines. Option up if that's you.
9: Does not supply the quality or consistency of grind like $300 models.
10: Beats trying to make espresso grinds with a blade grinder, hands down.

Remember, this is a $50 grinder, not a $350 Rocky conical-burr. If you want the best, you must buy the best. For my money, this was a good compromise. For others, with very sophisticated palates, it is unlikely to satisfy. That is the low-down on the equipment. Next ... know thyself. ;-)

I've owned this coffee grind mill for over a year now and use it almost on a daily basis. This is the first I've owned but I gave it a 5/5, however I do not have anything else to compare it to.

The grind is always consistent, it's quick and it's clean. Easy to use. Has a sturdy build.

Sorry if my review lacks substance but - I am very pleased with this and I've had no problems with it whatsoever. I highly recommend to anyone.

reviews.reviewTitle: Seems like it could've lasted another three
reviews.reviewText: I had mine seven years and it croaked. Seems like it could've lasted another three, for what I paid. Safety features started kicking in at the wrong times. I disassembled and cleaned, and could not revive reliable operation. I think it's a faulty start button.

reviews.reviewTitle: A waste of money ! Does not last!
reviews.reviewText: Performance is adequate until it quits on you. We have not had this very long, maybe a year to eighteen months, and it just stopped, as others have noted. Sorry, Cuisinart, we expect performance and durability from you. I will try to clean it out, but as this is a consistent problem, Cuisinart needs to fix it before the consumer does.

reviews.reviewTitle: Major design defect in Cuisinart DBM-8 Coffee Grinder
reviews.reviewText: Unlike the Baratza coffee grinder line, this Cuisinart has a "single fail" fuse that blows as it senses the motor overheating. Unfortunately beans such as Starbucks French Roast will clog the grinder within a short time, and if you are not impeccable with cleaning it, your unit's fuse will blow rendering it useless. The Baratza line has a multi-use fusing circuit, that once your grinder cools down, it resets and you can continue using your grinder. The Cuisinart has many nice features, otherwise but this "cost focused" design is a major limit. For a self-liquidating price Cusinart will ship you a replacement unit during the warranty period. Recommend the Baratza line as much better alternative, until you find Cusinart listing "overload reset protection." Cannot recommend this unit.

That's how long it has taken to burn this bad boy out. 9 years 1 month of multiple grind daily use. What more can you ask for? I'll be definitely making a repeat purchase. My only suggestion (which I didn't follow) would be to clean it each time you empty the hopper. If I had done that I am certain it could have worked for another 10 years. Great product.

reviews.reviewTitle: No need for coffee. This will wake everyone up.
reviews.reviewText: Geez this thing is loud. It will wake the dead. I would recommend never run the thing in the morning, cuz you'll wake the house, maybe the neighborhood.

reviews.reviewTitle: Too much dust for French Press
reviews.reviewText: I have recently gotten into coffee and received this product as a gift. Before using it I knew that it was a mid to low end burr grinder and that a high quality grinder costs twice as much. I tried it anyways and found that it produced way too much dust / "fines" to make a quality French Press coffee. I used it for 2 days then sent it back for a refund. If you want a burr grinder for under $50 or $100 you will have to get a hand grinder. From what I have red the Hario Mini Mill is a top choice.Hario MSS-1B Mini Mill Slim Coffee Grinder I'm going to check that out instead of this.
Does the job, but VERY loud.. like ear-piercingly loud. Always feel guilty for partner/neighbors when I fire it up in the morning.
it worked great, altho very noisy, but sure didn't last long! no way to return it via amazon, and complex and difficult instructions to return to manufacturer

I took this product back the first day I bought it for the simple fact that it did not have a fine enough grind for espresso. It seemed to produce a decent drip or press grind, but would also create a clump of dust in the top corner of the bin (annoying). For the engergy conscience, it also stays warm when plugged in, maybe because of internal circuitry such as a transformer. I bought a Baratza, much more expensive, and was impressed with the quality of the grind. I recommend the Baratza.

At less than six months old, the automatic function ceased; next time it stopped and began to smoke. Then I could not locate the receipt to return it where I purchased it (Costco) so it will probably get dumped. Will buy another brand. Yes, I had read earlier reviews of the Cuinsinart appliance and I should have heeded the warnings.

reviews.reviewTitle: Second unit motor burnt out each less than on year.
reviews.reviewText: Bought one, motor stopped working, unit replaced under warranty and after less than one year the motor stopped working again. Unit used once a day fo one pot of coffee..

After 10 months of light use our grinder stopped working. The cause was the bottom of the hopper broke off in the grinder. Cuisinart was great, giving the choice of exchanging it at any store that sold the same product, or mailing us a new one (some special California agreement).
We use it mainly for our 10 cup drip coffee maker. It works great and makes grinding very quick and convent. With a smoother taste compared with the blade grinder. For the price it is hard to beat.
Very loud, i had to return it. It ground well, but the plastic container that the ground coffee goes into always seems to scatter ground coffee on the counter. Could be static from the plastic.

This Cuisinart Supreme Grind is only slightly better than a blade grinder.
The burrs are metal plates with blunt, not sharp, teeth for grinding. I am skeptical that the burrs are even steel. Another downside is that as it grinds a fine powder builds up in the corner of the container while larger grounds fall to the bottom; static is a problem, but ultimately it is easy to keep a tidy counter with this grinder.

One positive feature is that one of the burrs is removable and therefore, I can have it modified and sharpened.

Conclusion: spend $20-30 less and get a blade grinder or spend $30-40 more and get a good burr grinder.

Grinder worked OK for about a year and I agree with most of the reviews while it was running. Noisy and messy but you just have to put up with that. But suddenly one day it just died and I am unable to repair it. For the price I was happy with its performance until it died.
I've had this for less than a year and it already died. I didn't even use it on a regular basis either. Definitely disappointed in the performance of this grinder.
Besides being loud and messy (static electricity), the motor just failed after three months. I'd say that's deserving of a low rating.
Great gift. Ordered for my dad as he’s recently gotten into starbucks coffee. He loves it.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great for drip, not for espresso
reviews.reviewText:
The box says it will do an 'ultra-fine' grind, but I would say that it doesn't even get to 'fine'. The regular grind is very consistent, so it should be great for drip coffee. I returned it, since 95% of my coffee is espresso.

If you're a drip drinker, go for it. It seems very sturdy.

It is loud, with a piercing whine.
I'm sorry Cuisinart, but this is not a Burr grinder. Buyers, do your research before you fall for this. Burr grinders don't have plastic discs with blades attached to them.

reviews.reviewTitle: I wanted to like it... But...
reviews.reviewText:
I purchased this exact burr mill today at a well known brick and mortar store, mainly based upon the reviews from here.

I gotta say, I was pretty excited to get it home and grind the first batch of beans for my french press.

Unfortunately, I was pretty disappointed with the results

Pros: It's a very nice looking machine that I would've been proud to display in my kitchen

Cons: I like my coffee, and pretty doesn't cut it

The very first thing I noticed was that the plastic catch bin catches a LOT of dust. So much so, that on the first batch of beans, it had already caked up on the opposite side of the hole where the grinds come out. I can live with a little dust in my house, but, I don't want dust in my coffee... yes, I know the dust in my house is different, but, that's besides the point I'm trying to make. The point is, if the mill is making THAT much fine dust on the coarsest setting, then it'll be a LOT of sludge in my coffee.

The second thing I didn't like so much, was when I was taking it apart to clean it so I can take it back, my thumb brushed over top burr, and got a smatter of grease on my thumb. I don't know off of which part it separated itself from, but, eventually, it would've ended up in my coffee... I want grease in my burgers, not in my coffee.

I wish I had the same luck as the majority of everyone on here did with it, but, I certainly didn't. I'll be returning it, and going with a conical burr grinder, and spend a little more money on it like I should've already done.

reviews.reviewTitle: I have been using this machine for years. It ...
reviews.reviewText: I have been using this machine for years. It does an amiable job of grinding coffee for just about any purpose. My only complaint is it is incredibly noisy! There is no insulation on it and the noise is stifling. Surely someone makes a quieter grinder!!

This was the fourth grinder I have purchased from this rip-off company. The new one I just purchased one month ago and ground one pound of coffee stopped working. I was not over used or over heated. It is piece of s***t. Save your self a lot of headaches and time by buying some other brand as this one sucks!

Great coffee mill until the motor gives out, support is very nice but they have your money for the defective product and are in no rush to replace the broken unit. This one was purchased in February 2014 and the motor just gave out on Aug.8, may just have been a lemon as it was working very well up to that point. If it were not for the un- urgency to keep a happy customer i would recommend the unit to new buyers. They will take the entire 10 business days before sending out the replacement..

Bought the first one and it stopped grinding after two weeks. The replacement lasted three months! Looked it up on the internet and found multiple complaints over the same problem. Stay away from this product and do your research.

This grinder was fine at first. We used it maybe once a week, and followed all the care instructions. It stopped working after 18 months. We filled out the warranty information, and it's been almost a full-time job trying to jump through all the hoops they require to get it replaced under warranty! I don't find it acceptable that it only lasted 18 months.

Yes, this grinder conveniently stores beans in the hopper, has a huge number of grind settings, and makes great coffee. But even if you get over how loud it is, the plastic grind bin is the worst product design I've ever seen. The plastic gets a static charge which make grounds (I grind "medium") cling to it. I defy you to dump the grounds into a coffee pot without making a colossal mess. I've had 5 different people try it (to make sure it wasn't just me) but there are grounds on the counter, the floor, and all over the coffee pot itself. How could this have gotten thru product testing?!

. I bought this in 1/2013, used it off an on, about once a week. A month or two ago,I could hear the motor laboring, and about a week ago it just stopped running. I'm a big Cuisinart fan, with a food processor, hand mixer, toaster, and most of my cookware is Cuisinart, and they're all excellent products. I am disappointed in this product, however.

This coffee grinder was disappointing in the short run (didn't grind fine enough for espresso--we had to haul out our old La Pavoni, which is only good for fine grind), and maddening in the long run (after about a year of use, it now completely quits every few weeks, we believe because whole beans tend to get stuck in the chute). I had a Braun blade grinder for 10 years that we only retired because the plastic top finally got eaten away, but for a regular pot (filter or press), it made perfectly good coffee. It didn't do espresso, but then, neither does this.

This burr grinder is not worth the money. It is very noisy and the quality of the grind is not good. I came with a sticker on the part that captures the ground coffee that stated an even grind for better coffee. When you do the grind there is a pile of coffee in the bottom of the container but there is all kinds of fine coffee powder that sticks on the side of the container. I know this is not very explanatory but trust me, you don't want to buy this thing.

Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill

This does not deserve even one star. My second one just died. I had figured out how to take it apart to clean when it stopped grinding. But then the motor burned. out. I had both for less than one year - but forgot to save the sales slip since I assumed these would last

I will NOT buy another!
I’ve had two of these, and both motors wore out after a few months’ use. Cuisinart replaced the first one under warranty. This time, I think I’ll just get a different grinder.

we are coffee freaks...meaning we love to have really good quality coffee all the time. when we're not spending too much money at coffee shops for great microfoam lattes, we're trying to make a good cup of french press with our burr grinder. we had this thing for 3 months and could never get in to it. honestly, it was worse than our hand blade grinder. i would not recommend this product; it is messy beyond belief - meaning crazy static mess all over my counter... we returned it for the bodum burr grinder. great design, but honestly, don't waste your money.

We liked it, operative word is liked. It stopped working 6 months after we got it. I took it a part and was able to get it go work, but it has stopped working again. Going to look for a different one.
After less than ten uses, the unit ceased working. No response to button or slider - completely dead. Basically a paper weight now. Received as a gift so no recourse.

I recently purchased the Cuisinart DBM-8 grinder after my Krups grinder failed after 1 year. So far the Cuisinart is holding up quite well to twice daily use but there are a couple of minor details that could use a bit of improvement.
First, Cusinart touts the fact that the bin will hold up to a half pound of beans. Unfortunately, I prefer to alternate the varieties of coffee I use so there is absolutely no advantage in pouring a half pound in at a time. This fact also made it a bit tricky to correctly estimate the amount of beans needed for a single pot. ( Perhaps adding some sort of measurement indicators on the bin would help?)
Second, the bin holding the ground beans is extremely difficult to slide back in, a flaw the Krups had as well.

I've owned several of these but i had to stop buying them because I got tired of returning them! I think it is the safety interlock that causes the problems. It is a shame too because there are a lot of things to like the large capacity, being able to preset the amount of beans to grind etc. I'm not that fussy about uniformity of grind and I don't expresso so I'm good with that.
its a shame they don't fix the interlock, I'd buy one again.

I don't mind spending money on a quality product. I do mind spending money on a product that purports to be quality. If I would've known this would have crapped out so soon, I would have bought 2 or 3 cheap grinders and probably still be using one of them. Now to research manual grinders.
works great

You're better off buying pre-ground.
I upgraded to a proper grinder and my coffee is so much better and more consistent.
Go to wirecutter and read their reviews for a proper grinder.

First DBM-8 worked fine for 3 years, daily and sometime nightly use. Motor just died. Three year period of use, good, not great.
Purchased another one and motor died in 6 months. Have not called Customer service due to other post which reference difficulty with them and I don't have time to waste on hold. Have Cuisinart coffee maker, Cuisinart K-cup machine, Cuisinart food processor. Done with Cuisinart products.
Love the multiple grinding sizes! Love the multiple options for amount of coffee to grind! Noise level is ok but wished it would be a bit lower.

I've had this burr grinder for years and like it much better than my previous grinder.

Cons:
It is difficult to clean. I've spent hours digging old grinds out of the mechanisms. It cannot be taken apart to clean the burr.
It is loud.
The 'timer' is not accurate for coffee measure.
The high speed of the grinder can heat the oils in the beans and leave a burnt or bitter taste.

My next grinder will be a high quality (ceramic) manual grinder.

reviews.reviewTitle: Getting the most out of the coffee bean
reviews.reviewText:
Like you do, to get the aroma and taste out of herbs and spices, the same applies to getting more flavor out of your coffee. With this grinder, one can grind the fineness or coarseness for the brewing process and the amount for the number of cups. I have two cups per morning, so I have a fresh grind for two cups and get the best flavor out of my beans and no stale coffee taste.

I would like the grinder motor to run at a slower turn to mimic the real old coffee grinders. The burr mill style performs better than the chopper blades that are offered, but a slower motor speed would improve the grind.

reviews.reviewTitle: Uneven grind. Needs a 2 and 3 cup setting.
reviews.reviewText:
Grind is uneven. So much for "burr mill" claims.
Does not provide a 2 or 3 cup setting. Starts at 4.
Game over.

reviews.reviewTitle: Avoid it if you can afford to
reviews.reviewText: I've been searching for a good grinder for home and I know I don't want this one. We've been using this one at work. It's messy and the throat clogs with beans regularly. The burr does not come out to clean, either, so it's difficult to maintain. If you can afford a better one, I would recommend you pass this one over.

reviews.reviewTitle: Functionality hinges on a tiny SAN plastic tab that breaks easily
reviews.reviewText:
Does it grind well? Yes. That is, when it works.

The construction of the chamber that holds the grinds is made of SAN (a clear, but highly fragile plastic). There's a tab on the bottom of this container that clicks into place on the floor of the grinder and allows the grinder to operate (it's the safety switch). If the tab doesn't click into place, the grinder won't grind.

My question is why any engineer would place the entire functionality of a product on the durability of a SAN container. The container fell out of the drying rack and --pop-- off came the tab. Grinder no longer works.

It would have cost the manufacturer ~$1 more to make this container out of polycarbonate, which wouldn't break even if you stepped on it. It's cheap and idiotic on their part. Or brilliant, since replacement canisters cost $20 on their site.

Unit works OK, but is very loud and difficult to clean. Grounds jam exit port and cause heat. Output hopper is plagued by static electricity which causes grounds to cling inside. Internal mill screws will keep falling out and jam mill or end up in your coffee (you can really hear the screws when they fall into the milling section -- turn it off when this happens). Unit will wear completely out within the first year. Overall, if you like cheap Chinese imports, not bad for the money.

I have had this grinder for over a year, using it daily, and it has held up alright. It rarely gets clogged, and it has been durable. The grind is inconsistent, even in the same batch of grinding, which complicates espresso making. However, it is a reasonably priced burr grinder (which is always going to be better than a non-burr type) and it's still running.

The Cuisinart DBM-8 has all the bells and whistles, and it will grind exactly as much coffee as you want, exactly the way you want it...However, after three weeks of use and trying 21 different ways to get the ground coffee out of the incredibly static plagued plastic hopper without getting ground coffee all over the kitchen (and yes that includes slowly and carefully using a brush), it has resisted every effort to do so. As a matter of fact, I have yet to figure out how to get the lid off the hopper without spilling the ground coffee that sticks to it, and have to do so in the sink so clean-up is minimal.
Does not work! Gets jammed up and won’t grind beans, even after cleaning. Very disappointed. Need to buy something else. Waste of money.

I have owned 3 in the last 3 years, all stopped working. The first one I threw away about 1 year old, I did not keep the receipt. The second 1 lasted 3 months, they replaced for under warranty. The 3rd one just broke and they told me it is not under warranty. I usede about twice per month ( 24 oz of beans)
I will not buy another one.
On the plus side, its worked well, holds 12 oz of beans grinds well, easy to use.

Terrible grinder. Temperamental from the beginning, would just randomly not turn on at times. After about 2 months it just outright stopped working. Which is just as well because its also the messiest kitchen appliance Ive ever owned.

Dont waste your money.

reviews.reviewTitle: Do not buy. This product is garbage.
reviews.reviewText: This product is garbage. It last 6 months and the grinding engine died. Do not waste your money on this obviously CHEAPLY built product.
Worked great but burned out quickly. I just threw it away as it went grind at all.

I thought I was purchasing a top quality product, but was very disappointed. First, for its size, the grinder is loud. Second, the slider switch for the amount of grounds is flimsy, and the off/on switch is too easy to press when you don't want to activate the grinder. Finally, after one month, regardless of the setting, the unit would only run for a couple of seconds with an activation. I returned the unit and received a replacement, which I haven't used yet.

reviews.reviewTitle: It grinds very inconsistent and puts out a lot of fine powder.
reviews.reviewText: Very loud and it grinds poorly. It grinds very inconsistent and puts out a lot of fine powder.
One year and then dead as a door nail.
I've had this coffee grinder for about two years, used it maybe twenty times before it stopped working.

reviews.reviewTitle: It's a shame because I have other Cuisinart products in my kitchen that I love. Let's hope the motor doesn't suddenly die in ...
reviews.reviewText: This worked well enough for a little over three years. Static is a problem. It's loud. But I got used to those things. Then the motor died all of a sudden, and I will not be replacing it with another Cuisinart grinder. It's a shame because I have other Cuisinart products in my kitchen that I love. Let's hope the motor doesn't suddenly die in those too.
Works as well as the 100 dollar grinder it replaced!

reviews.reviewTitle: Less than 6 months old and It just Died
reviews.reviewText:
This product worked great, while it worked.
One day I pushed the grind button and it did not work.
Waste of money and would not buy again.

reviews.reviewTitle: Works well foe about 6 months. I have had ...
reviews.reviewText: Works well foe about 6 months. I have had 2. The switch and safety lockout seem to get filled with coffee dust then start working sporadicly. Very frustrating when trying to get your fresh grind in the morning,

While cuisinart arguably makes products that look good, their quality is not good. We bought this model to use each morning to grind beans for a 6 cup pot of coffee. Less than one year after purchase, it has failed.

You will spend your money better, elsewhere.

reviews.reviewTitle: Amazing quality at an amazing price
reviews.reviewText: Cuisinart rocks. Never disappoints. Great performance, great price and it's a really elegant design

reviews.reviewTitle: only if you have time to kill in the morning.
reviews.reviewText: world great for about three months. Now I have to squeeze the contrainer and hold it in the grinder while it is grinding. Once you move your hand it stops working.

reviews.reviewTitle: Grinds every bean to dust...no matter what
reviews.reviewText: This grinder grinds all beans to the same consistency no matter what setting you use. I was hugely disappointed.

Really disappointing. Worked great for a month, then would not turn on anymore. Tried multiple outlets and cleaned it to no success. Read multiple reviews for troubleshooting, but, again, nothing worked. Do not recommend.

reviews.reviewTitle: Good product but came with old coffee beans in it already
reviews.reviewText: I live to product but I had to clean it out as soon as I got it because it had old coffee beans in it and also was very dirty.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great overall but not coarse enough for French Press
reviews.reviewText:
Overall this works well. It's simple to use, fairly quite, fully automatic and grinds exceedingly well for everything from uber-fine espresso to fairly coarse drip machines. Unfortunately even at the most coarse setting, many of the grounds still sneak through the French Press screen. I use French Press only occasionally, but I'm thinking of returning this for something that handles a fine grind. I really don't need 18 settings...just two, and one of those two really doesn't quite cut it.

Still you will like this machine if you mainly do espresso or drip.

reviews.reviewTitle: Great until it broke after 11 months
reviews.reviewText: This was my first burr grinder purchase. I was happy with it until eleven months after purchase, the plastic spout which screws into the grinding area cracked, leaving large peices of plastic and a couple screws grinding along with my coffee. I won't be purchasing another Cuisinart product because I haven't had one of them last for more than a year (2 toasters in 2 years as well).

I'm on my 3rd and last one. The problems vary from the threads on the screws of the burr becoming stripped, to the beans not falling down from the hopper, to the exit hole into the coffee container constantly clogging. Today I threw in the towel and bought a Capresso 560 on Amazon.

I bought this item two weeks ago and have used it to grind a total of two pound of coffee. Although it looked like a good idea to get a burr grinder (I thought it would be quicker and quieter) it turns out my standard mill grinder does the job just fine. I do like the fact you can set the grind for fine to coarse but eliminating this the less expensive and quieter and quicker mill grinders suit my needs just fine. The machine states it grinds a half pound at a time but in reality the hopper holds about this much and it takes three or four cycles to empty the hopper. We are returning ours and going with the older mill grinder. Think twice before you buy.

reviews.reviewTitle: I've finally given up and getting another machine
reviews.reviewText: Like many have reported, this machine is loud and produces a lot of dust. My major frustration is that the beans don't go into the machine consistently and it won't grind the correct amount. I've resorted to picking up the machine and shaking it so the beans will go into the mill. While I appreciate the 6am workout (sometimes), I'm going to repurpose this machine into something it may be designed to do like particle reduction for items going into the compose pile. Or maybe I'll just give it away to some unsuspecting soul. My goal is a decent mill for under $100.

I was so excited when I received my first Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Automatic Burr Mill grinder in the mail. It worked for about 2 months and then just stopped working out of the blue. We got in touch with Cuisinart and they sent us a replacement. However, the second one only lasted for about 1 month and we would really only use it once a day. I have given up on getting yet another replacement and instead bought one of the Breville grinders. Hopefully we will have better luck with this one!

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked good for a while, but not long enough
reviews.reviewText: It worked great while it worked. The first time it broke down --after about a year, I was able to take it apart and blow it out with my air compressor. Now I am pretty sure the motor is gone. Really disappointing that it didn't last. Something like this should last for many years.

I have had 3 of these and they all have broken. I will stick with my old Braun grinder I have had for 15 years. The last one of these I bought only lasted about 3 months and then the motor burned out. Don't waste your time or money on this one.

As a another reviewer has pointed out, this is for coffee and not espresso, don't leave a bad review because of your own lack of knowledge.

This grinder is perfect for a normal cup of coffee. It grinds the bean with consistency but does leave a little bit of powder (which I actually like). I have even used this grinder for my french press and it worked just fine.

The grinder itself is well put together and seems like it will last a long time.

Really a good buy for a low priced coffee grinder. I would recommend it to anyone who wants to go to drinking fresh ground coffee.
It works fairly well, always leaves a few beans underground, but overall I'm satisfied. Works well and is inexpensive.
Worked once out of box. Dead to the world after that. Extensive troubleshooting all components using Cuisinart website. Would not turn on at all,

reviews.reviewTitle: Another customer suckered into buying this for espresso
reviews.reviewText: I wanted to buy a burr grinder just for making espresso, but didn't want to pay the $200+ I saw machines selling for from Gaggia and other high-end espresso machine makers. Since I like my Cuisinart food processor so much I thought I'd give this machine a try. What a waste of money! It doesn't come anywhere close to grinding coffee beans fine enough for a good high-pressure espresso machine. DON'T BUY THIS MACHINE FOR MAKING ESPRESSO! Trying to save $200, I wasted $50.

We bought this burr grinder about a year ago as a Christmas present for my dad. It worked great for about 4 months and then it broke. Support wasn't helpful at all, and we couldn't figure out a way to get it fixed. Honestly we were just really disappointed with Cuisinart on this one. Go with a different brand like we did, you won't regret it!

This is a very nice grinder for the price. It does a really good job of getting the coffee superfine for my espresso machine. Only thing which would make it better is is the container the coffee goes into was glass to avoid the static issue.

I bought this from Bed Bath & Beyond and it was incapable of producing a powder-fine grind like I was getting with my old Krups blade grinder. I wished I'd taken pictures, but it's too late - it's all boxed up and ready to go back to BB&B

reviews.reviewTitle: BEWARE - NOT GOOD FOR ESPRESSO MACHINES!
reviews.reviewText:
I really wish that I could say I love this machine because there are a few aspects I really do love. I love how it looks, I love the grind it makes for Drip coffee & French Press, but it is horrible for producing a good espresso shot because the grind is not "ultra fine" as described on the package. it is fine, but not fine enough. It produces very thin shots because the grind is not fine enough and therefore the crema is almost nothing. It looks and tasted more like coffee than espresso! BUMMER!

I called Cuisinart Customer Service to see if there is anything I could do to refine the setting so it was finer and she told me that that the machine should produce the correct grind. I explained I have seen many other reviews (now that I have bought it) that say it does not! She said sorry there is nothing wrong with the machine so you can't return it. I asked to talk to a manager and they were all in a "business meeting" ARGH!

So I will update this review when I hear back from them, hopefully with better news than I am out of luck and $50.00 into a grinder that does not grind as good as my $5.00 for Espresso Machines!

I bought this grinder for my wife for Christmas in 2010 from Cotsco. We used it almost every day. For our taste, we put it on 6 to make 8 cups of coffee. It would be nice if there were a little more control, but it is a pretty mechanical process. It has a solid construction and fits a whole pound Of beans. The ground coffee container is fairly easy to clean; a couple taps upside down in the sink and a dry paper towel will suffice. Well she moved out last month and I really miss the grinder...

I have owned different brands, Krups, Braun, Cappresso, Cuisinart, and Mr Coffee burr grinders. The Cuisinart did a good job of grinding, and was no more or less messy/hard to clean than others. But, it was the loudest and then broke at about 6 months. It's back to the Braun KMM 30 for us.

reviews.reviewTitle: You get what you pay for....
reviews.reviewText:
After more than 5 years of service, our old Krups burr grinder finally bit the dust, and I was disappointed that it had been obsoleted and no longer available.
So I purchased a Cuisinart DBM-8, an impulse purchase at Costco, and what a mistake that was. The finest setting is too coarse for decent espresso, and the high static levels spewed gfine coffee dust every time you removed the box holding the coffee. We used it anyway as a "drip" coffee machine, and after about 6 months of use the unit died and would not grind any more.
Moving on to something else. Any recommendations?

This grinder worked fine initially. But after about 9 months, the motor just died. Completely Kaput. Totally unacceptable for an appliance this expensive. Is nothing made to last anymore?!? Don't waste your money on this piece of junk
It worked great for maybe 4 - 5 grinds (literally) and then poof - it just stopped working and I have no idea how to fix it. So disappointing :(
The coffee tastes great, this makes making the morning coffee easy.
I used this 3 times and it stopped working. Up to that point I really liked it.

I bought this after doing a bit of research and concluded it was my best choice for the price, but I regret buying it now because it's cheaply made and messy. It does do the job, however, so if you aren't looking to spend a ton of money on a grinder and don't mind the bothersome process or cheap plastic then give it a shot.

reviews.reviewTitle: Used 3 times, now in the garbage
reviews.reviewText:
I bought this at Costco to replace my old coffee grinder which was several years old. The grind is far from consistent ranging from dust to course on the fine setting. The plastic hopper to collect the ground coffee also collects static. The results are coffee grounds falling off creating a mess when the hopper is removed. The sound is terrible. My german shepard presses himself into the floor and shakes when this is running. The food processor, and old coffee maker never bothered him.
Garbage.
burnt out after 4 months of use. every morning i used it, burnt out after 4 months.. no good
Not a consistent grind. Broken down and cleaned 2 times in 9 months to improve but just stopped working. I do not recommend.

Marginally better than a blade grinder. The cuisinart burr grinder produces an enormous number of fines aka coffee dust. This leads to a bitter tasting cup of coffee. You're much better off investing a bit more into a Baratza Encore.

reviews.reviewTitle: Figured out a work around for the static issue
reviews.reviewText:
For the price I'm very happy with my purchase. I think the grind could be a little finer for my new espresso machine I bought but I paid enough for the machine and not willing to pay hundreds for the grinder just yet.

The main reason for writing this review was sharing my work around for the static issue. I grind the beans, with the lid still on the top I remove the container holding the grinds, tap the top so the grinds fall to the bottom and without removing the lid I pour the grinds from the hole in the back into the paper container that my beans came in. You can obviously use any container to pour the grinds in but that got rid of the mess. Hope that makes sense.

Happy Holidays!

It never did grind coarse enough for my French press, but I liked that it came apart easily for cleaning. Problem was very very low quality plastic on the inside that came off a piece at a time until it just simply disintegrated. Lasted less than a year.

reviews.reviewTitle: Quit working. Keep your receipt or no warranty
reviews.reviewText: Worked great for about a year. Then just slowed down and quit. I did not have receipt so cuisineart would not honor the warranty. I gave them the model and serial number which they should of been able to use for proof of purchase but to no available. Otherwise I would of gave it five stars.

It does a poor, no very poor job at grinding any where close to 'fine'
do not purchase for anything other then drip coffee makers.
It can be modified by filing the 'stop' off so bean holder can turn to a finer grind. But that leads to another problem, they put a micro switch that recognizes if the bean holder is on or off so cutting the 'stop' tells the machine to stop so you must open the machine ( which voids the warrenty) and bypass the micro switch. There easy right? I did it and it work well. I suggest just spending a little more and get a better one . Good luck!

This burr grinder does not deliver the consistent grind that you should expect. Whenever I did a coarse grind, there was also a fine clumpy powder that would stick to the lid. Which would make a nice coffee slushy but not a proper cup of joe. This grinder was a gift to me, so I thought I would stick with it but after three years the internal mechanism stripped the threads on the plastic hopper making it completely unusable.

My advice spend another $40 and get a better made grinder. The cuisinart was bad from beginning to end.

reviews.reviewTitle: Super loud, if you have sleeping kids I would use this outside in you car...
reviews.reviewText: Purchased! Its just ok, we have to keep it in the garage because it sound like a freight train coming through the kitchen. Outside of that it works,

The advantage of burr grinders is that they (supposedly) provide a consistent grind. The Cuisinart? Not so much. Even the courser grind settings deliver a fair quantity of powdery overground coffee. I just got it a couple of weeks ago, so I can't comment on how long it will last, but it's a poor performer out of the box.

reviews.reviewTitle: Cuisinart Automatic Burr Mill never dies
reviews.reviewText: I have the Cuisinart Automatic Burr Mill I don't think the model is the same but it looks just like this one. I have had it now 6 years and it is going strong never a problem. I do after a few refills of beans turn it upside down and tap the sides to any little bits of coffee grind and any little bits of coffee beans out. I am very happy with this it has grinded alot of coffee beans.

This grinder was given to me as a gift to accompany an espresso machine, but unfortunately I will be returning it. I've found that even on the finest grind setting, the results are much too coarse and uneven to brew proper espresso. Furthermore, this grinder is LOUD; the first time I ran it I thought the steel burrs were grinding themselves together.
Other problems: The minimum setting is for 4 cups of coffee, which is far too much for a shot (or even a double shot) of espresso. And a good deal of grounds (about 2 cups worth) ends up stuck inside the machine, so to get freshly ground coffee you really first have to grind 2 cups and empty the bin, then grind what you need. This is a waste of coffee. And if you forget to put the plastic lid on the hopper when you slide it into place, grinds will fly everywhere, and there's no way to stop the grinding or put the lid into place short of unplugging the machine from the wall!! This is a serious design flaw.
Anyhow, for making large amounts of drip coffee this grinder might decently serve the purpose, but otherwise I'd look elsewhere.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not a burr grinder, just a blade grinder that ...
reviews.reviewText: Not a burr grinder, just a blade grinder that you don't control. Also clogs all the time. Also makes about one third coffee dust out of all the beans. I thout cuisine art at least means functional but this thing misses every mark.

reviews.reviewTitle: Both that I've had have stopped working after about a month
reviews.reviewText: Works for about a month, then poops out. I've had 2 since I got the first as a gift and it might have been mishandled or something. But both stopped working after maybe a month (they just won't start anymore)

This unit works great ...before it burns out.
I purchased this unit at Bed bath and Beyond.
The first one lasted 2 months. I returned it and they replaced it with no fuss.
This one has also burned out after 7 months, smoke pouring from the bean outlet (into base)
I only grind Starbucks coffee once every other week on setting DOT 4
Plan on buying one each year (if your lucky)
Most of all, stay near it at all times. (while its working)
Already had one, it died after many years, good product replaced it with same

I bought this unit because I was under the impression that it could grind the beans in a variety from coarse to fine- not the case. You need a nice fine grind in order to make good expreso, and this unit doesn't seem to be capable of doing that.

reviews.reviewTitle: Love this Grinder---but, I've Killed two of them now
reviews.reviewText:
I really like this grinder...I used it to make drip coffee from my local bean roaster. I grind exactly what I need each day on a level 5 setting and the coffee is substantially better than getting my beans pre-ground.

However, I have killed two of these in two years. Cuisinart replaced the first one no questions asked. The second one just died and I think it's time to move on. I'm looking to get a heartier burr mill this time around.

reviews.reviewTitle: Not bad until it stopped working
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to use with an auto-drip. It was my first coffee grinder. I generally enjoyed it and the flavor of my coffee until it stopped working after less than 6 months. That is simply an unacceptable lifespan for a relatively simple appliance. Otherwise I agree with other comments that it is noisy, messy, and creates a good amount of powder. I could have lived with those minor complaints and given this 3 or 4 stars if it was reliable. But it isn't - on to another brand...
Absurdly loud. Like, plug-your-ears-or-leave-the-room-until-it's-done loud. Motor died in less than a year. Don't waste your money.
very loud
Love it fresh coffee every morning!!!!

This is a waste of your money! Threads broke off bean chamber sent 2 replacement neither fit. Say I'm now out of warranty. I bought this in January if your product sits on the shelf for a while your s.o.l. Supervisors and customer service are rude and demeaning. I will not buy any more products from them if this is what I will have to deal with. This is not okay cuisinart. They even make you pay for shipping on machine and replacement parts if they feel like it.

reviews.reviewTitle: While this grinder looks nice and doesn't seem cheaply made
reviews.reviewText: While this grinder looks nice and doesn't seem cheaply made, the grinder was purchased to grind espresso beans finely and it does not do that. I hope I saved the box, because it is unusable for the use of grinding the beans finely enough to make my own latte.
This grinder doesn't last. We replaced one on warranty and have had the second one fail, all within a few years. What's the point of a brand name like Cuisineart if the warranty is only 18 months?

reviews.reviewTitle: Finally a burr grinder I can LOVE!!!
reviews.reviewText:
I'm a self proclaimed whole bean coffee snob. I've owned several grinders over the years and have become addicted to grinding my own beans when I'm ready for brewing my trusty cup o' joe. Since I have an espresso machine, drip coffee maker, and a variety of french presses I can't just use the one-grind-fits-all approach. But why have 2 or 3 grinders taking up cupboard or counter space when I can now just use this?

The traditional whirling blade grinders take a lot of practice to get the timing just right depending on what level of grind you are looking for. More often than not I ended up settling for something a little too fine or a little too course. Enter the first burr grinder of my amateur barista world: I loved the consistency of it but couldn't get a fine grind for espresso. So for the last year or so I've had to use both...

No longer! This Cuisinart grinder has been a blessing from coffee brewing heaven! The variability of grind options is amazing with this machine! I can grind up my beans to a powdered perfection for espresso or chunky enough to make cowboy coffee worthy of Jack Palance's Curly from City Slickers.

As far as the quality concerns another reviewer mentioned it must have been a bad unit. I've used this one daily for over a month and not even a hiccup! This grinder is well worth the price!

reviews.reviewTitle: Only buy this if you're willing to throw it out after 6 months
reviews.reviewText: My wife bought me this grinder for Father's Day 2009. The motor burned out by December. Only used it on weekends to grind our breakfast coffee which was coarse ground. So relatively light duty. I've sent an email to Cuisinart customer service via their website...total radio silence. Next stop for me...a Baratza Maestro. Don't waste your time or money on a Cuisinart grinder.

I grind a large amount of beans every few days and keep it in the refrigerator. This grinder does a very good job.

I have a Briel Espresso machine and this grind is perfect. To check the grind, I bought some beans and had it ground at the coffee store. My grind with this machine was just as good, correct texture

reviews.reviewTitle: Ordered the same model since it grinds perfect
reviews.reviewText: My daughter took mine when she moved out. Ordered the same model since it grinds perfect coffee

First of all I'd like to say that the price of this item in the UK is about 60 pounds sterling - a lot more expensive than in the US but still a lot cheaper than the Kitchen Aid machine that retails at about 130 pounds. That said, I am pleased with the machine. I use it to grind beans for a Gaggia Classic expresso machine and I find that I do not need to use the finest setting to produce a good shot that takes about 20 seconds.

The machine is quite loud but no more so than other burr grinders I have heard. As to how long it will last I will wait to see but here in the UK we get a 5 year warranty!
Works well

reviews.reviewTitle: I would not recommend this product/appliance
reviews.reviewText: It's MESSY!!!!!!! VERY MESSY! It's going back. Coffee grounds everywhere. In addition, it uses a lot of coffee beans. I have been buying Peets preground coffee in the 12 oz bag for years, this 12 oz bag last me 7 to 8 days, the 12 oz bag of Peets beans lasted me 5.5 days. I would not recommend this product/appliance.

Cuisinart DBM-8 Supreme Grind Automatic Burr Mill

This grinder has got to be the "war horse" of inexpensive burr grinders. I purchased this model over a year ago for twice this price at a big box store and I haven't had a bit of trouble with it. I make at least 2 pots of coffee per day using the finest grind and it gives a consistant texture every time. It's easy to clean and the receptacle has a lid so coffee doesn't spray all over the place (try it without the lid and you'll see what I mean). This is a terrific buy for the money.
Broke two months after purchase. Junk product.
I loved this grinder while it lasted. All that we have had broke. Two broke within just a few months and the third lasted for 2 years. I will purchase a different brand going forward.

I bought the Cuisinart DBM-8 after an unpleasant experience with another coffee mill costing three times as much. I was amazed at the quality. This is a rock-solid product that does a great job. I especially like the ability to select the number of cups of coffee I want and then simply press an activation bar. The mill automatically grinds the proper amount of coffee. This is a great buy!

Noisy, imprecise fineness, does not grind as fine as needed for some brewing, quality control problems (top part broke once, then died after 3 years).

However, inexpensive, easy to load and empty.

reviews.reviewTitle: Does not grind for expresso and stopped working within a year
reviews.reviewText: My grinder just ground to a halt this morning, about a year after I purchased it in a local store. I wasn't happy with it from the start because it does not grind fine enough for expresso! Just well enough for drip...this is the second Cuisinart product that's died on me within a year of purchase...the other was a juicer. I thought that Cuisinart was a solid brand...or it used to be!

Mine stopped working after a year or so, though the motor was ok. I had heard that grinding white, uncooked rice would clean one and mine ground the rice fine but beans would not go through. Unscrewed the hopper and found pasty residue around the feed tube keeping beans from going through but smaller rice was no problem. Cleaned the hopper tube with wet paper towel and back in business. Only objection now is high noise level.

"Fool me once, fool me twice, fool me three times?"

Yes, we bought our THIRD Cuisinart coffee burr mill after the first two failed because it was the only burr mill available at our local Bed Bath and Beyond. That was November 4, and here it is December 29 and it has failed. It simply won't start.

There is only one word to describe this product: "Junk"
Died within 3 uses. Made a terrible mess when it did work.

It's not dead!. Turns out grinds blocked/clogged the safety switch.
I cancelled my order but rest assured when the current grinder dies - if it ever does - I'll buy the same one.

I bought this machine as a newly released product and was very excited to try it. At first it worked great, and I loved the fact that it was so easy to use...just put the beans in, set the desired grind, slide the cup amount selector, and press start. There was no measuring like you have to do with the coffee grinders as well as no messy counter. However, it was not too long before our coffee started to taste really weak, and I knew something was wrong. When I took the machine apart, the entire burr grinder was jammed with ground coffee and the spot where the ground coffee exits into the holder was so clogged that only a small amount of coffee was actually able to make it out of the machine. The supplied cleaning brush was next to useless so I used a thin wooden skewer to scape the jammed coffee away from the sides of the interior. Doing this every couple of times gets tired real fast, and I am at the point of taking it back to the store. If only they could have designed it so the coffee does not get jammed! We use French Roast, or Blue Mountain which tends to be greasier than other types, so perhaps the problem does not occur so quickly with other roasts. But! I am absolutely certain that no matter what beans you use, your machine will get clogged.If there was no clogging, this machine would get 5 stars!

Got this grinder because I think I needed a new one. Granted it was company refurbished but I thought it would of been tuned up. I think the grinder stinks. I have a 30 year old Waring grinder that is better than this fancy-dandy one. It stops grinding even if there are beans in canister and set at 12 cups

My motor just went out with a puff of smoke. Seemed OK before that. Coffee bin is a little messy. The plastic housing radiates a lot of noise.

I'm looking for a different brand grinder now.
Died after 6 months of light duty use. No more Cuisinart stuff for us.

Too many fines on coarse settings - not ideal for french press. Not fine enough for espresso unless you tamp REALLY hard - not ideal for espresso. It's a good entry level grinder, but if you want to step your coffee game up to the upper echelon you need to look elsewhere. Pony up another Benji or two if you are serious about coffee.
Only lasted 4 months than motor burn out!!

The dbm-8 has decent reviews for grinding for drip coffee, but I was unable to get a usable espresso grind out of it and so had to return it. As much as you may want to get away with buying an espresso grinder for cheap (ie, less than a couple hundred bucks), it really isn't possible.

My second unit broke after 6 months of use -- once per day. I currently have 3 of these machines (one broke today); 2 at one house because my wife and I like different blends, and one at my vacation home. Fortunately, I bought them from Costco, so they are all going back. Cuisinart customer service is worthless. Looking at the reviews here, looks like I'm not alone.

reviews.reviewTitle: It’s a very good Coffee Mill. I’ve had this for years.
reviews.reviewText: After milling put on mat for cleaning and putting it in an empty jar.

reviews.reviewTitle: Excellent value. Satisfies my daily grind.
reviews.reviewText: Have been using this almost daily for 5 years. Other than being noisy, it's performed as expected. Being one of the least expensive burr grinders on the market, it's a great value. If I paid 2x the price ($30 range, 5 years ago), I'd give it 4 stars. it does create some dust, and static, but I believe all plastic housings and entry level burr grinders would do the same.

reviews.reviewTitle: Awkward to start and broke after one year
reviews.reviewText: I bought this in 2004 so I don't remember a lot of details except I found it awkward to use - sometimes it was hard to get it to start. it wouldn't start at all after one year. its primary attraction is it is inexpensive for a Burr grinder. I am stepping up to a Capresso Jura Infinity 560.01 Conical Burr Coffee Grinder - Black.
works ok until you do a large load of beans at which time it appears to burn out. I suppose that if you do a pot at a time it may work for you but it is supposed to grind larger loads then that.

reviews.reviewTitle: Worked for a bit. Grind was kind of inconsistent ...
reviews.reviewText: Worked for a bit. Grind was kind of inconsistent. Motor died after 3 months. It's kind of a "you get what you pay for" device.

Original quit. Cuisinart replaced it. Replacement quit. Appeared to be same problem. Service couldn't find my original registration card however they could tell me the serial number of the original unit. How can that be? Would not honor their 18 month warranty because they calculated, from the serial number, the date of manufacturer instead of Date of Purchase. Could not give me any technical support or any quality answers or referals. Buyer beware.
Only complaint is that it is on the louder side. No big deal to us though. Works really well!!! Would purchase again.
This this is crazy loud. Be prepared.

I have owned two of these machines in the last two weeks. I read with astonishment that for some consumers, the grinder lasted 2 years!

In both instances, our machines burned out after about an hour. We followed the instructions meticulously, but alas...

I have owned my last Cuisinart product.

reviews.reviewTitle: Clean it internally to extend life
